HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE STRATEGY; 
Leaders Face Challenges Far Different From Those of Last Conflict

BYLINE:  By TODD PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 

 BODY:
The last time leaders named Bush, Cheney and Powell faced foreign aggression, their challenge was to marshal a skeptical public, a divided Congress and a reluctant alliance to fight the Persian Gulf war against a known foe on clear turf. Now a new President Bush -- and a Dick Cheney and a Colin L. Powell indelibly shaped by that experience a decade ago -- confront almost the opposite task.
 They face an aroused public, a unified Congress and an international alliance that is eager to help -- at least on the surface. But they must find ways to buy enough time and patience to conduct a new kind of long, 21st-century twilight struggle against a shadowy enemy -- or many enemies -- in unknown corners around the world. 
 "Let me tell you, the only way we can do this and keep the support of NATO is to clearly identify the tentacles, and then the octopus, and then the ink-squirter itself, and then gather it all together and say, 'Here they are, and are you ready for what will really be a total military assault,' " said former Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming. "At that point, we have to be so sure." 
Or as a former national security official from the Clinton years put it: "The hardest part of this is going to be to convince people to shut up and be patient."
Early polls suggest that Americans believe the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington will result in war, and that sizable majorities would support retaliation, even if innocent people were killed. The realities and complexities of any actual response seem all but certain to affect that support, whether the public winds up confronting American casualties in Afghanistan or civilian deaths elsewhere.
Vice President Cheney, a former secretary of defense, and Secretary of State Powell, a former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, are patient and methodical men. They know the uses of military force, but, more important, its limitations. They are engaged in planning a global military campaign, not a quick strike or a brief battle. They are thinking in terms of years, not weeks.
And while they balked at marching on Baghdad or toppling Saddam Hussein at the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991, they are now talking about "ending states who sponsor terrorism." Having witnessed the fall of the Soviet Union, they are fully aware of how cataclysmic such a change could be.
"This operation isn't going to be quick, or pretty, or certain," said Anthony H. Cordesman, a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. "To do anything at all is to invite an element of ambiguity. There's going to be casualties and collateral damage. That's why we call it war."
All week, senior administration officials have made it clear that they would not settle for largely symbolic strikes against suspected terrorist training camps or against a target identified as a military factory, the way the Clinton administration did after attacks on United States embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.
"I was raised a soldier," Secretary Powell said at his briefing today. "And you're trained there is the enemy occupying a piece of ground. We can define it in time, space and other dimensions, and you can assemble forces and go after it.
"This is different. The enemy is in many places. The enemy is not looking to be found. The enemy is hidden. The enemy is, very often, right here within our own country. And so you have to design a campaign plan that goes after that kind of enemy, and it isn't always blunt-force military, although that is certainly an option. It may well be that the diplomatic efforts, political efforts, legal, financial, other efforts, may be just as effective against that kind of an enemy as would military force be."
The deputy secretary of defense, Paul D. Wolfowitz, made a similar point on Thursday when he said, "I think everyone understands that we have, unfortunately, entered a new era," as he outlined the administration's commitment to "removing the sanctuaries, removing the support systems, ending states who sponsor terrorism." It was Mr. Wolfowitz, as a top Pentagon official under Mr. Cheney, who devised the elder Bush administration's plan to solicit contributions from an alliance to help finance the Persian Gulf war.
In his homily at a prayer service at the Washington National Cathedral this morning, President Bush described the mission in even grander terms, saying: "Just three days removed from these events, Americans do not yet have the distance of history, but our responsibility to history is already clear: To answer these attacks and rid the world of evil."
That makes Woodrow Wilson's pledge to make the "world safe for democracy" sound simple by comparison.
Former President George Bush said Thursday: "It is far more difficult to fight an enemy who refuses to show his face."
The former senior national security official who asked not to be identified said there would be nothing easy about the task ahead. "There'll be the amount of resources we put into domestic surveillance, balancing that with civil liberties," the official said. "And then abroad, if we are talking about bin Laden, we're talking about a network that operates in different places. The United States, with our allies, has taken down a lot of these cells in the last two years, many more than people know. Finally, if there is a military component, we will have to define the objective in an achievable way."
If, as the weeks wear on, Saddam Hussein is shown to have had any hand in fostering the attacks, or exploits them for the instability they create in the Middle East, questions will doubtless resurface about why the first Bush administration, led by so many of the same people now in positions of power, did not press on to invade Iraq.
Besides Mr. Cheney, Mr. Powell and Mr. Wolfowitz, other veterans of the gulf war have roles in this administration, including Condoleezza Rice, then a Soviet expert on the National Security Council staff and now its head, and Richard N. Haass, then the Middle East expert at the N.S.C. and now director of the policy planning staff at the State Department.
The current President Bush, whose recent preoccupations have been the budget and taxes and fears of a faltering national economy, must also be all too aware, given his father's own example, how much those problems could still affect his fortunes, whatever his foreign policy successes or failures. Indeed, some of the biggest challenges may turn out to be at home.
"The challenge is to take all the pollsters and all the consultants and put that all aside," said former Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, who now heads the New School University in New York. "This is the wealthiest nation on earth, and please don't tell me that you can't put enough money out there to make certain that men with hand knives and box cutters can't hijack four American planes within an hour. Now we know that every airplane that takes off in America is a bomb, fully loaded. So deal with it. Don't let the lockbox or ideology or anything else get in the way of that."
Mr. Kerrey, a combat veteran of Vietnam, also pointed out the psychological challenge for leaders and a public that have been quick to denounce the attacks as the work of cowards or madmen.
"I condemn it morally, and I do think it was cowardly," Mr. Kerrey said. "But physically, it was the opposite of cowardly, and if you don't understand that, then you don't understand the intensity of the cause and then you're papering over one of the most important things. There is hatred out there against the United States, and yes, we have to deal with terrorism in a zero-tolerance fashion. But there is anger, too, and they ought to have a place for a hearing on that anger, in the International Court or wherever we give them a hearing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former President George Bush reached out to President Bush yesterday at a prayer service in Washington. (J. Scott Applewhite/Associated Press)

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: IN PAKISTAN; 
U.S. Demands Air and Land Access to Pakistan

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 14 

 BODY:
In intensive talks here and in Washington over the last 72 hours, American officials have demanded that Pakistan agree if necessary to allow American ground troops and special forces units to operate from this country, senior officials said.
 Pakistan's ruling generals have also been told that they must allow Pakistan's airspace and its military airfields, as well as its powerful military intelligence apparatus, to be used for attacks against targets in Afghanistan that appear to be under review in Washington. 
 Beyond this, the officials said, the United States has demanded that Pakistan place the Taliban rulers of Afghanistan under what would amount to immediate siege, cutting off fuel (the Taliban's sole supply), denying use of Pakistani banks (crucial to what is left of the Afghan economy) and halting all other forms of support. Some of these demands were reported today in The Washington Post. 
All other countries that border landlocked Afghanistan, and particularly Iran, are hostile to the Taliban and support the Northern Alliance, which is fighting a rear-guard action to hang on to isolated pockets of territory that amount to about 10 percent of the country.
Without Pakistan, the Taliban, who play host to the terrorism suspect Osama bin Laden, would never have swept across Afghanistan and succeeded in imposing their purified and regressive form of Islam.
Confronted by the American demands, President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan and a group of fellow generals met today in a tense, seven-hour conference at army headquarters, then delayed for at least another day any public response to President Bush's demand that they commit Pakistan to an all-out effort to capture or eliminate Mr. bin Laden and his network in Afghanistan.
The length of today's meeting itself suggests that even the military is divided on the issue.
A statement issued after the meeting, in Rawalpindi, 20 miles from Islamabad, said the generals had agreed on "recommendations" to put before the cabinet and National Security Council on Saturday.
The delay seemed to be a formality, or a bid to gain time on an issue that has thrown Pakistan into perhaps its most severe political crisis.
All the signs are that General Musharraf will agree to steps that will align Pakistan, at least formally, with the international coalition that the Bush administration wants behind it as it prepares military steps to smash the bin Laden network.
But the uncomfortable truth is that the attacks on New York and the Pentagon have heightened the quandary that Pakistan has confronted since it emerged as a nation in 1947: whether to continue to straddle the divide between pro-Western, secularist elements and deeply conservative Muslim groups, some with extremist agendas, or to cast the country's lot decisively with the West. 
Behind the wall of secrecy that surrounded today's discussions, it was a fair guess that one issue that caused dissension was the American demand for access to everything that Pakistan's shadowy military intelligence agency, the Interservices Intelligence directorate, or ISI, knows about the bin Laden network.
American officials want to know about his hideouts and his bases, how he supplies his mainly Arab force of several thousand men, and how he operates a supporting network that runs deep into Pakistan.
All or much of this is certainly known to the ISI, which has operated as a fief ever since it was designated as the key agency handling weapons flows, training and other support for the Muslim guerrillas fighting Soviet forces in Afghanistan in the 1980's -- aid that was mainly American. 
The ties with the Afghans carried into the post-Soviet period in Afghanistan, with top ISI officers adopting pro-Islamic and anti-American views, and continuing to support some of the most militant guerrilla commanders when they formed the military backbone of the Taliban.
At crucial moments in the Taliban's rise, Pakistani officers in Afghan disguise and units of Pakistani troops reportedly provided the decisive edge in Taliban military operations. So it was no surprise today that one influential voice raised against accepting Mr. Bush's demands for cooperation was that of Hamid Gul, a retired general with links to pro-Taliban Islamic groups in Pakistan who was ISI chief in the closing years of the anti-Soviet struggle.
"Afghans defeated one superpower, and by the grace of God they will defeat another if the United States decides to attack Afghanistan," he said. 
On Islamabad's streets today, many Pakistanis offered sympathy for the United States. 
"Not good," said a 40-year-old minivan driver, Ejaz Hussain, when asked about the attacks. "Not good for New York, not good for America, not good for Pakistan." American reporters were greeted with handshakes in malls and hotels.
But in the mosques and in every village and town, Muslim clerics are powerful figures, and many have backed militant political groups that have links to the Taliban. 
"The destruction in America was God's warning in response to its anti-Muslim policies," Qari Hussain Ahmed Madani, a cleric in Peshawar, on the Afghan frontier, told worshipers. "A couple of attacks has turned America from a superpower to a zero power."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: REAL ESTATE; 
As Hard Hats Volunteer in Rubble, City's Building Boom Falls Into Doubt

BYLINE:  By RALPH BLUMENTHAL and CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
Construction in Midtown Manhattan has been stalled and some premier New York projects on the drawing board have been thrown into doubt because of the devastation wreaked downtown by the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, officials and construction executives said yesterday. 
 The biggest question mark, arts executives said, is the $1.5 billion reconstruction of Lincoln Center, an estimated 10-year effort that was to have been one of the largest cultural works projects in American history. The city alone had pledged $240 million. Most of the rest of the money was to be raised from corporate and private benefactors. 
 Work slowed or halted on many Midtown skyscrapers on Tuesday, after the 110-story twin towers at the World Trade Center were rammed by hijacked jetliners and collapsed, killing thousands of people and damaging surrounding office buildings.
To help in the rescue effort, ironworkers, steamfitters, crane operators, carpenters and laborers left work on the Westin Hotel at Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street, the AOL Time Warner headquarters under construction at Columbus Circle, and a half-dozen other projects. 
"No one was really on the job," said Stephen M. Ross, chairman of Related Companies, which is developing the 52-story AOL Time Warner Center. "All the construction jobs in the city were pretty much closed down because the skilled workers went downtown."
Developers hope that the workers will return to their jobs at the Midtown construction projects on Monday, as demolition workers take over at the World Trade Center. 
But developers and others are worrying that the long-term strains of clearing the downtown site and replacing an estimated 20 million square feet of space there will worsen the shortage of skilled workers in the city. And that, they say, could affect projects that have yet to begin, as well as some Midtown projects already under way.
Among those that may be threatened by the demands of new construction at the trade center site are the Guggenheim Museum project planned for the East River, the East River Plaza in Harlem, and the billion-dollar stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets. 
Not only do many of these projects require a huge commitment of skilled workers, but they also were to be heavily financed with city and state subsidies that now might be diverted to pay for the massive rebuilding.
The Lincoln Center renewal project is perhaps the most prominent one jeopardized. Marshall Rose, chairman of the Lincoln Center constituent group in charge of the project, said yesterday that he would meet over the next few weeks with members "who will collectively decide on the next steps, but as of now the project is going ahead as planned."
Yet in a letter to members sent on Thursday, two days after the attacks, he noted that many members had called for more time to review the plan, and that a "four-month feasibility review period is a suggestion."
Privately, top cultural officials said that the immense scope of the project made it likely that it would be put off if not altogether scrapped.
Speaking in general, and not specifically of Lincoln Center, Joseph Volpe, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, said of the attack: "This has major, major implications for the whole city. One would have to rethink every new and proposed project in the city based on recent events."
The construction plan calls for rebuilding Avery Fisher Hall, making major additions to many buildings and possibly creating a new home for the New York City Opera. The project has already provoked disputes, with the Met briefly withdrawing earlier this year over what it called a lack of consultation. It rejoined the project under modified rules. 
Some arts officials said that in view of the huge financial losses suffered by many corporations and business titans in the bombing, they might no longer be counted on to underwrite the redevelopment. The city's commitment could also be uncertain. It was unclear, too, whether the daunting effort downtown would stretch the availability of construction workers. 
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki have both vowed to rebuild at the trade center site, and the federal government has promised to provide about $20 billion for the whole area. But executives said they feared huge problems.
Two electrical substations were knocked out by the collapse of the twin towers. And a shortage of electricians, sheet metal workers and other skilled labor has only grown with the pace of construction since the late 1990's.
Edward J. Malloy, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council, a union alliance, said that it was just beginning to assess the need for thousands of additional construction workers.
Mr. Malloy said that he expected to augment the work force with young people looking for a new career and workers from parts of the country where the economy is weak. "It's a daunting challenge to our industry," he said, "to rebuild what was taken away from us."
The huge undertaking of rescue and cleanup downtown siphoned vast armies of workers from most projects in Midtown, leaving them at a near standstill.
The work force at Tishman Speyer's office building at 222 East 41st Street dropped to 70 from 180. Earlier this week, there were only 75 workers, down from 400, at the Morgan Stanley tower under construction at Seventh Avenue and 50th Street. And no one was working on the excavation at Madison Avenue and 42nd Street where Brookfield Financial Properties is building a new headquarters for the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce. Union workers went downtown in response to city appeals for help, as well as a spontaneous desire to contribute to the rescue effort.
As heroic as the effort was, some construction executives rued the loss of their work force. The primary need downtown, they said, was for ironworkers, but nearly every trade responded in force.
"It was the biggest mistake we could have made," said Peter J. Davoren, senior vice president of Turner Construction, whose company is managing all three projects. "It was really upsetting. It left a void in the construction of our current Midtown projects. They are so important because that real estate needs to be on line immediately to free up other space for the dispossessed."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rescue workers and volunteers passing buckets of debris up the line early yesterday. Work slowed at Midtown projects this week as construction workers volunteered downtown. (Edward Keating/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 1 Angry Man 

BYLINE:  By Barry Gewen; Barry Gewen is an editor at the Book Review.

 BODY:
 A TRIAL BY JURY
By D. Graham Burnett.
183 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $21.
 In February 2000, D. Graham Burnett served as foreman on one of the most contentious juries this side of "12 Angry Men," and once the four days of deliberations were concluded he set out to do what so many former jurors dream about doing but never get around to: he wrote a book about his experience. Burnett brings several strengths to the task. He is a graceful, economical writer, with a sharp eye for detail and a nuanced feel for character. He never loses his sense of the ridiculous. By turns humorous and dramatic, "A Trial by Jury" speeds along; it can be devoured in a single sitting. Any reader who has gone through a tour of jury duty is likely to respond to this engaging book with a glow of recognition. (And anyone who hasn't can indulge in the pleasure of schadenfreude.)
The People of New York v. Monte Virginia Milcray was a tawdry case. On Aug. 1, 1998, Milcray killed Randolph Cuffee, stabbing him more than 20 times. Milcray claimed that he had acted in self-defense. He said that Cuffee, who ran a gay escort service, had lured him to his apartment and, dressed as a woman, had tried to rape him. Milcray's story was not particularly credible, but then neither was anything that anyone else said. The state's case was built on a collection of characters out of Manhattan's multisexual demimonde -- drag queens, crack addicts, male prostitutes. The star prosecution witness was a flamboyant, self-possessed cross-dresser named Nahteesha Breen, "her diction and intonation smoldering like a young Lauren Bacall's." Not to be outdone by this parade of Village people was the (unnamed) judge in the case, a sadistic martinet, as portrayed here, who seemed to enjoy humiliating everyone around him except the transvestites. Burnett calls him "a dry and disagreeable man . . . a sour bone, a humbug autocrat." Another juror termed him "the rudest person she had ever met." He would turn out to have a surprising role in helping the jury to arrive at a unanimous verdict.
Any expectation the 12 jurors might have had that life would imitate art, that they would be presented with a crisp, clear set of facts from which to render an informed and impartial judgment, probably went out the window by the time the first witness finished testifying. In this courtroom the gods of incompetence and confusion presided. The police had neglected to gather crucial evidence from the murder scene. On the stand they contradicted one another. The defense counsel violated the first rule of the trial lawyer's handbook: he failed to anticipate the answers to his questions, with the result that witnesses were able to make a fool of him. Trying to besmirch the victim, he insinuatingly asked Nahteesha about the dildos and whips that were found in Cuffee's apartment. "Honey," she replied, "we all have whips." The prosecution was no better. When the soft-spoken defendant took the stand, the only strategy the assistant district attorney could think of was to bully him, swinging the murder weapon wildly in an exaggerated re-enactment of the crime. Burnett writes, "So egregious did I find the whole performance that . . . I felt a deep desire to see the prosecutor lose the case."
If the jurors weren't sufficiently flummoxed by this procession of bunglers, the judge made sure to complete the job. His charge to the jury was so complicated, in Burnett's words so "Thomistic," that it took them much of the first two days of deliberations just to work their way through the instructions (which the judge refused to write down for them). They had no ground rules, no procedures to follow, no agreement on the facts. "The thing I felt most strongly," Burnett says, "was that the case defied judgment on the evidence we had available." They were 12 proverbial blind people poking around at the elephant -- and one of indeterminate sex at that.
Much of the book's humor derives from the author's own personality. Burnett reveals himself to be an aloof, donnish historian of science, something of a stiff ("I had worn a tie practically every day since grammar school") and so fastidious about food that he filled a duffel bag with fruit, nuts and vegetables so that he wouldn't have to eat at the restaurants the jurors were taken to during sequestration. Deeply orderly, proudly rational, this Mr. Chips had to cope with the chaos of 11 fellow jurors racing off in every direction.
No sooner had they received the case than an impasse threatened to end all discussion. Burnett wanted to start, logically he thought, with a vote to see how many believed Milcray was guilty of something before considering the various charges of murder and manslaughter. Others, less eager to win the Logician of the Year award, insisted on determining what Milcray was guilty of before deciding if he was guilty of anything. A frustrated Burnett suggested they vote on how to proceed, but one of his colleagues argued that any such vote had to be unanimous. Should they now vote on whether their vote had to be unanimous? An infinite regress beckoned. "So this is where constitutions come from," Burnett thought to himself. One juror persistently demanded to have almost all the testimony read back to them, an exercise that would have taken several days. Another felt they should ignore the law and consider nullification. A third suggested that "we need a more sensual approach." There was shouting, there was cursing, there were tears. Someone got sick, someone else tried to sneak away.
Yet through it all, progress was made, and the comedy turned serious once they began to reflect on the difference between the demands of justice and the demands of law. Apparently no one believed that Milcray had clean hands, and though most felt that the prosecution had failed to prove him guilty beyond a reasonable doubt, they were uncomfortable about letting him go scot-free. A few began searching for a compromise in a manslaughter conviction, even if the facts of the case didn't warrant it. Finally, a domestic missionary in Spanish Harlem, a former methadone addict and cowboy, made a speech that turned things around. "I believe Monte Milcray did something very, very wrong," the man said. "But I also believe that nobody has asked me to play God. I've been asked to apply the law. Justice belongs to God; men only have the law. Justice is perfect, but the law can only be careful."
Burnett reinforced the point. The prosecution's burden of proof had to be very high, he declared, because the state's power was so strong. They had all learned something about that power in recent days, he observed. "We discovered that a man in a chair and a robe could tell us we couldn't go home, that we couldn't talk to our families, that we couldn't even talk to a lawyer. He could send us to jail. . . . We discovered that, in the end, there seemed to be no limit to the power of the state over us, once we fell into its hands." Thinking about the tyrannical behavior of the judge over the course of the trial, the last doubter caved. Milcray walked away a free man, but none of the jurors cheered.
Burnett went home tearful, exhausted, to resume a life that now seemed surprisingly banal and insignificant. Those who have ever sat on an important case will understand his reaction. Locked in a room with 11 often discordant strangers, struggling to reach a decision on matters of genuine consequence, one focuses with a degree of attention and concern rarely achieved in the everyday world. Burnett calls his experience "the most intense 66 hours of my life"; others have said that they have never learned so much about themselves. Existentialist philosophers might describe jury duty as a path to authenticity. No wonder so many people find their time as jurors so rewarding -- even if it seems painful while they are going through it -- and bore their friends and family for weeks afterward as they pick over every detail of their story. Burnett has made much more worthwhile use of his days in the courtroom. He has given us this irresistible book.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Peter Blegvad)

HEADLINE: My Ordeal In A Chinese Cell 

BYLINE:  By Gao Zhan as told to Alix Spiegel; Gao Zhan is a faculty fellow at American University. Alix Spiegel is a contributing editor of "This American Life" on Public Radio International.

 BODY:
This is a story I'm not supposed to tell, a story you're not supposed to hear.
It begins on Feb. 11, the final day of a three-week vacation to visit family in China. My husband, my son and I were staying in a hotel near Tiananmen Square, and we got up early for our 9 a.m. flight. As Donghua dressed Andrew, I went to the front desk to pay the bill. When I got downstairs, there were a number of people standing in the lobby, maybe 15 or 20, and I noticed that many of them were looking at me. It is common for the Chinese to stare at anyone who looks somewhat Western, and after living in America for the last 12 years, I knew I did, so I didn't think much of it. I just paid up and climbed into a taxi with my family. Later, I was told that the men in the lobby were secret police. Evidently, there are about 200 secret agents working in that hotel every day. On that morning, about 20 of them were watching us. Twenty agents for myself, my husband and our son. Twenty agents for a scholar, a computer geek and a 5-year-old child. 
 At the time, of course, I knew nothing of this. I didn't have a clue. I had no sense of being surrounded or watched, even after we were stopped at airport security. All our luggage was opened -- even my son's Rugrats suitcase. Every piece of clothing, every book, every CD, was examined. They went through my address book and diary, turned on my husband's computer. It took about 40 minutes, and by the time they let us go, I was so angry that I threatened to bring it to the attention of the authorities. 
 As we started toward the Northwest ticket counter, I was still furious, still complaining, and I remember that my son said to me, "Mom, ignore them." It's funny to think about now, but my last words to Andrew -- the very last thing I said to my son for six months -- could not have been more innocent: "Yes, ignore them."
At that moment, at that moment exactly, we were stopped by a man dressed in street clothes. He stood in front of my family and said very firmly, "Ms. Gao, Mr. Xue." When a total stranger in a Chinese airport identifies you by name, you know that you're in trouble. I realized immediately that somehow we had been watched. Several of my friends had been detained, just questioned for a few hours and then released, and like everyone I had heard stories of known dissidents being held by the secret police for long periods of time. But I am not a dissident; I'm a scholar. In 1989, I came to the United States to study sociology at Syracuse University. Since 2000, I've been a researcher at American University in Washington. My area of study involves women, family, marriage and immigration, so it never occurred to me that my work could be considered sensitive. Which is why, when the man told us to follow him, I was more irritated than frightened. I asked the man who he was, and he told me he worked for the Beijing State Security Bureau. I remember I cast a quick glimpse at the ticket counter; it was only 20 feet away. I thought about running to it and asking for help. I considered yelling and making a scene, but I didn't. I suppose I thought they would just question us for a couple of hours, then let us go.
He took us downstairs to a large public space where another 20 or 30 agents were waiting for us. Then the casually dressed man turned to my husband and said, "Mr. Xue, will you come with us?" He gestured to a door. My husband told the man that our family would not be separated. Then the man said this: "We will be polite first, and use force second." In Chinese the phrase is only four characters: polite first, force second. Simple enough for my son to understand. Again my husband refused and again the man repeated the phrase: polite first, force second. 
My husband turned to me, and for a solid minute, maybe longer, we just stood there, looking at each other. I guess my husband was trying to ask me what to do, silently. But I didn't say a word. I didn't tell him to go ahead; I didn't tell him to stay behind. I didn't utter a sound. I just stood there, dozens of thoughts flashing through my mind, and looked in his eyes. The huge hall seemed still, all these agents standing around looking at us, as if we were all frozen in the moment. 
Then an agent came over and grabbed my husband's arm, said, "Let's go!" and pulled Donghua through a nearby door out of the airport. Donghua kept looking back at me and Andrew until he disappeared into a car. I felt like crying or screaming but didn't, or couldn't. I remember thinking, This is a mistake. 
Next, the same man turned to me and said, "Ms. Gao, follow me." So Andrew and I followed him to the same door. When we got outside the man said flatly: "You have to give us your son. We will put him somewhere else." 
Even after they took my husband, I couldn't imagine that they would separate me from my son. I didn't think anyone would do such a thing. I looked at the man and shook my head. I told him in an angry but calm voice that it was impossible. Then the man said the same thing to me that he had said to my husband: polite first, force second. 
Andrew said nothing. He stood next to me and I held his hand tightly in mine. I didn't have a chance to look at him; I was too busy staring, staring blankly I think, staring in shock at this man. Without breaking my gaze I said again, "I will not let you take my son away." 
For a couple of minutes we stood like that, me staring at him, him at me. Then, two female agents walked up to us and ripped Andrew's hand from mine. Still Andrew said nothing. He didn't even cry. I didn't cry either. As they were walking him away from me, I couldn't even look in his direction. All I could do was stare at this man. There was no thought, only a feeling of pure physical pain in my chest and a numbness in my arms and legs. Finally I was able to turn my head, and I watched as Andrew was put into a car. He was looking at me as if he didn't understand what was going on. Why was his mother letting these strangers take him? 
Then the man said, "Let's go!" And this time they didn't wait -- they pushed me into another car and drove away.
Two female agents in the back seat of the car took my glasses and covered my eyes with a blindfold. When I asked where they were taking me, I was ignored. When I asked about my husband and child, I was ignored. We drove for 40 minutes, maybe an hour, in silence. Eventually, someone turned on the radio -- there was some news about the Olympics, the Beijing application. 
Finally we arrived somewhere. They removed my blindfold, and I was taken inside a three-story Western-style house. I was taken to a small room with two long tables and three chairs. One of the chairs was facing the other two across the table. I was told to sit in it. Across from me was a pale-looking man sitting near a large, glaring light. I asked how long they would detain me. He said he had a warrant for 24 hours and this made me feel better; I thought I could stand 24 hours. My interrogation started immediately. He asked about my whole biography, my education from elementary school through university. He wanted to know everything. Then he asked about my family. My father's occupation, my mother's birthdate, my brother's favorite activities. The look on his face was frightening -- half stern, half condescending. 
After several hours, I asked to use the bathroom. A female guard followed me in. I asked her to leave but she refused. I stood staring at her, my humiliation and fury growing. After a couple of minutes, I told her that I had lived in a civilized country for 12 years and that I was not accustomed to being watched while using the toilet. Finally she agreed to step outside, but she insisted on keeping the door ajar. 
I was questioned until 2:30 a.m. Then I was taken to another small room next to the interrogation room to sleep. But sleep was impossible. Over and over again, I thought about the scene at the airport. Why hadn't I spoken to my husband, told him not to worry? Why hadn't I explained what was going on to my son, hugged him, comforted him, told him that I loved him? Why didn't I scream, kick, bite, cry -- anything? How could I have allowed my son to be taken without a word? How could any mother fail in such a way? 
Two female guards sat on a sofa next to my bed. They weren't allowed to sleep during the night. I pulled my blanket over my head. I didn't want them to see me cry. I was afraid they would report it to the interrogator, and I didn't want him to think I was weak. Under the blanket I cried for my son, for Donghua, for myself. I was very careful and made no noise, just let the tears stream down my face silently.
The first 24 hours came and went, and still I was held. I kept asking myself: Why am I here? Why, why, why? What have I done? Toward the end of the first session, my interrogator had begun to question me about my academic work on Taiwan. I had written two papers comparing the political participation of Taiwanese women with their counterparts on the mainland. But I couldn't imagine that this sociological work could truly preoccupy the Chinese government. I was not an activist, not particularly political. There were many people who fit my profile: academics from the mainland who were living in the States. Why had they chosen me? And what was happening to Donghua and Andrew? My husband and I were permanent U.S. residents but not U.S. citizens. Andrew, however, was. Would that protect him in any way? 
Every day for the next five weeks was the same. I passed from my bedroom to the interrogation room and back again. I was not allowed downstairs, not allowed outside. I didn't put on my shoes -- there was no need. Each morning I'd be brought into the interrogation room, and my interrogator would stick the light in my face and say: "Gao Zhan, today is a new day! Yesterday, your attitude was not very good, perhaps, you'll have a good attitude today! I will remind you again: our party's policy has always been leniency for those who confess, severe punishment for those who resist." 
Then for 10 hours I would be asked all kinds of questions. What did you do on your first trip to Taiwan? Whom did you see? What did you say? What did you eat? When was your second trip to China? How long did you stay? What articles did you read? Where did you go? Sometimes he would ask questions that had no answers: Do you remember what you wore in the summer of 1991? It was infuriating and absurd. I remember thinking he was trying to drive me crazy. 
Mostly though, my interrogator was interested in my affiliation with an academic group in America called Chinese Scholars of Political Science -- I was treasurer. In particular, he was deeply suspicious of my relationship with Li Shaomin, a fellow scholar who was teaching in Hong Kong and had been arrested for spying at around the time I was detained. Li's father had been jailed in 1989 for supporting the Tiananmen Square protests, and the younger Li was not allowed into China for a time. In 1993, while I was still working on my Ph.D., I gave Li photocopies of books and articles that I had gathered on a trip to the mainland. They were all so insignificant that I can't even recall what they were. This lack of memory greatly upset my interrogator. He wanted to know what the books and articles were about, how long they were and what Li said when I gave them to him.
He also questioned me relentlessly about materials I collected for my and my colleagues' research. Most of these were documents that could be found in books and articles you could buy in any bookstore or newsstand in China, but there were also a small number of documents that I was given from a quasi-government office. These included regulations for Taiwanese journalists working on the mainland -- rules that the journalists were supposed to know -- and statistics about marriage between Taiwanese men and Chinese women for a paper I wrote on Taiwanese-Chinese relationships. I never considered these materials sensitive, but they were designated "internal." Of course, most information in China is labeled "internal," including some that's available in bookstores, and it's common practice for scholars to use and pass on "internal" documents as a basis for academic work. It's so routine that I never gave it a second thought. My interrogator, of course, didn't share this view. 
From the beginning I hated my interrogator, and every day I hated him more. I could sense that he was trying to break me, and our sessions were a constant mental battle. Sometimes he'd pound his fists on the table, tell me that he knew what I had done. I should confess! I would suffer the consequences! My husband and my son would suffer the consequences! Other times, we would be talking quietly and I would think that at last he understood that I had done nothing. That I would be released and that everything would be O.K. But then, out of the blue, he would begin to scream again. It would continue that way -- smiling, screaming, smiling, shouting, smiling, scolding -- all day long. His face could change in an instant, and I never had time to prepare emotionally for the shift. I tried to stay strong. I never begged. I never shed tears while he was shouting at me. When he played mind games, I would play them right back. I would answer his questions with questions. I would answer his screams with silence. 
I broke down only once. It was about 10:30 p.m. in the interrogation room. Every day I asked him about Donghua and Andrew, and every day he told me that I should worry only about myself. This night he began the session by shouting that he would keep my husband and son in China until I confessed. He told me that I had ruined my husband's and son's lives, and I guess, inside, I believed he was right. I had nothing real to confess, but without a confession my husband and Andrew would not be allowed to return to their lives. I felt trapped. My head turned hot and then cold, and I started to feel dizzy. I had a deep pain in my chest. And then I started to cry. I asked for a break. "I thought you were strong," my interrogator said, smiling wryly.
One day, after about five weeks, the interrogations simply stopped. I was hopeful that they were finished with me, that they would let me go. To pass the time, I chatted with the female detention guards. They were curious about life in America. They asked about the schools, the shopping, the best way to apply to American universities. They wanted to know about the flowers, the landscape, my marriage. They were all extremely young, just out of college, and I thought they seemed very innocent. They knew almost nothing about the facts of my case, only what they overheard through the walls of the interrogation room, and they didn't seem particularly interested. Their hearts weren't in it. I remember that one day I said to them: "If you have any possible way of getting away from your current job, you should do it. It's too harsh for young girls." They seemed to agree. Many of them wanted to come to America. 
On April 2, almost two months after arriving, I was unexpectedly called into the interrogation room. There were two video cameras and two new faces. My interrogator's voice was soft, almost sympathetic. His tone made my heart sink. He told me I was formally under arrest for spying; they were sending me somewhere else.
I was blindfolded for the drive to the detention center. As I sat in the back, I heard on the radio that a U.S. spy plane had collided with a Chinese military fighter jet over China. There were words of condemnation from Chinese officials and ordinary citizens, and I worried about the implications for my case.
That night at the center, I was strip-searched and handcuffed. It was the first time in my life I had seen cuffs up close, and they were on my own wrists. For the second time since my abduction, I broke down. 
The detention center was completely different from the temporary detention house. My cell was small, with an open toilet and a large wooden board for sleeping. Food and water were free, but I had to pay for soap, toilet paper, clothing and toothpaste. Fortunately, I had some money on me when I was arrested at the airport
The center was organized so that no one ever saw another prisoner unless she was sharing a cell. I learned that most of the cells had five occupants and that by Chinese standards this number was a great luxury. Later I found out that this facility was one of the best in China -- a place for suspects with international backgrounds and former high-ranking government officials. I had only one cellmate, a 21-year-old woman who was sentenced to a year in prison for stealing 1,300 yuan, about $150. She had been transferred from another prison, and she said that there they lived 20 or more to a room. 
I spent many hours listening to my cellmate talk about her life. She was a peasant from northern China with little schooling. Her mother left when she was 6 years old, and her father beat her constantly. She told me about growing up in her family, her experiences committing petty crimes, but I kept my own history hidden. I didn't want to tell her about my Ph.D. or that I lived in America. I was afraid my education and background would create a gulf between us. I was very lonely, and I desperately needed a companion. To win her trust I paid her expenses and tried to shield her from the prison guards. 
My life in detention passed very slowly. I would sit in our cell and count each hour. Every morning a loudspeaker in the cell -- which also concealed an eavesdropping device -- would wake us at 6:30. We would listen to a half-hour of government propaganda. This was followed by board sitting -- we were required to sit very straight on the beds in our cells and reflect on our crimes -- and finally, a recitation of the rules. 
The rules. It was against the rules to sing or speak loudly. Against the rules to exchange information with your cellmate, speak of government officials in a derogatory way or walk too slowly to the door when your number was called. No one was to speak of his or her crime. No one was to reveal anything about his or her identity at all. We were not permitted to lie down in our cells during the day, or cover our eyes to shield them from the lights. The lights were on at all times.
In the afternoon there was more board sitting -- more contemplation of our crimes and failings. Of course, I spent most of these hours thinking about Donghua and Andrew; I thought about them all the time. The morning was always the most painful for me. I would wake up from dreams, just dreams of daily life -- taking Andrew to Toys "R" Us or buying Donghua a shirt at J.C. Penney -- and suddenly find myself back in my cell. I would feel a desperate sadness, and there was nothing around to distract me. I prayed for a coma. I wished to sleep my life in prison away. 
One evening, my cellmate and I were sitting together while I was telling her a story from the Bible. Earlier in the day, one of the prison guards was cruel to her -- mocking her for having no money -- and I came to her defense. That night, as we were talking, she leaned over very close to my ear and whispered -- so that the eavesdropping monitors couldn't pick it up -- that she had been sent to my cell to watch me. She told me she would be rewarded with reduced jail time if she reported something of value. She said that she thought I treated her very well, and she didn't want to do it. I don't think she ever did. 
As time went on I became more and more depressed. I would remain silent for most of the day. I even stopped talking to my cellmate. I still couldn't figure out why I was being held, but I developed a couple of theories. Last January, a book called "The Tiananmen Papers" was published in America. It contained information -- said to be genuine state secrets, including specific information about how the decision was made to crack down on the prodemocracy protesters -- that was embarrassing to the government. I had heard that top Chinese officials were enraged by the leaks. During the months after publication, six scholars, including myself, were arrested for "spying." I imagined that these arrests were a kind of retaliation, a general warning to Chinese academics everywhere. The second theory was that the government simply wanted to use me as a source of information. As treasurer of the Chinese Scholars of Political Science I had many contacts in both the Asian and American academic communities. I got the impression that my interrogator didn't actually believe I was a spy but thought that he could use me to learn more about China's potential enemies. 
Then one day, on July 10, two lawyers came to see me. It was the first time I had any solid information about Donghua and Andrew. It turned out that the government had detained and interrogated Donghua for several weeks. They had asked him about my research, my trips to Taiwan and my contacts in the States and in Taiwan. Despite Donghua's request that Andrew stay with relatives during that time, the government kept him in a state-run children's facility. After 26 days, both were released and immediately flew home. Upon returning, Donghua hired an American lawyer, Jerome Cohen, who sent two Chinese lawyers to the detention center to meet with me about my defense. The lawyers were under pressure to make our meeting short and not convey much information. They quickly read a list of things from sheets of paper that Donghua and Cohen had given them. I remember the first thing on the list: "Andrew is fine, he is going to be a first-grader in September."
When I heard Andrew's name, my body began to shake. I was crying and laughing at the same time. I could barely concentrate on anything else. The rest flew by in a dizzying jumble: Donghua had spoken with senators, congressmen, the international press. Resolutions were being passed on my behalf. President Bush and Secretary of State Colin Powell were concerned with the case. I was astonished, almost disoriented. I never imagined that the American public -- the American government -- would be interested in my case. 
A few days after meeting my lawyers, I was indicted. It was July 13, the day the 2008 Olympics were awarded to China. Eleven days later, my case was brought to trial. It was lightly raining, and a huge crowd had assembled outside the courthouse gate. As the car I was in pulled into the driveway, I looked through the tinted window and saw my father-in-law and mother-in-law standing in the rain, looking anxiously at the passing cars. Looking for me. My mother was also there, but I didn't see her. I felt deeply ashamed. I had always been the most successful child, the glory of my family. My parents were very proud of me. When we visited in February, my father took me around the neighborhood, showing me off and telling all his friends that his youngest daughter had come home for the Chinese New Year. 
In the courtroom, the prosecutors presented their case -- primarily a list of articles I was accused of taking out of China -- to three judges while my lawyers tried to defend me. The whole process lasted less than three hours, then I was led downstairs to the waiting room. 
While I waited, I thought about the possible verdicts. Since I had done no more than collect academic articles and documents, might they simply let me go? And if they convicted me? I imagined that they might sentence me to the six months served as a way to show that I really was some sort of threat. After 40 minutes, I was led back up. The court secretary said, "All rise." "All" meant 11 people: the secretary, 3 judges, 2 prosecutors, 2 defense lawyers, 2 court police officers and me. There were no jurors, no relatives, no U.S. Embassy officials. The presiding judge stood to read the decision. She said that she found the evidence true and the charges justified. She sentenced me to a 10-year term. Ten years. Ten years. I really can't remember that moment. I know I didn't cry. Ten years is beyond tears.
That night, as I lay in my cell, I thought about my life until that moment. I thought about Donghua, our time together for the last 14 years, the first day we met, our wedding. At about 3 a.m. I made a decision. I decided to divorce him. It seemed like the right thing to do. It seemed like the only thing to do. I didn't want my son to live without a mother; I didn't want my husband to live without a wife. With tears streaming down my cheeks and the pain in my chest intensifying, I wrote a letter to my husband in my mind. It began with this sentence: "Donghua, I will love you every day for the rest of my life."
The next day I could barely speak. i started to think that the outcry from the States had backfired. The Chinese government had been forced to justify my initial arrest with a 10-year sentence. Perhaps my husband's efforts to bring me home quickly had produced the very result that we most feared. 
Around noontime I was called out of my cell and told I would meet with my lawyer. When I walked into the room, to my amazement, he was smiling. "I have some good news for you," he said. The whole world opened up. 
I was released the next day. I had been granted medical parole because of a heart problem I have had for years. It was a political move, no doubt. After I was convicted and sentenced, Secretary of State Powell expressed concern over my case, along with the cases of other scholars who were U.S. citizens or permanent residents. And Powell was scheduled to arrive in Beijing to meet with China's president, Jiang Zemin. No doubt the Chinese government didn't think it was worth upsetting the delicate relationship with the United States over this issue. Granting medical parole was a way to alleviate America's concern while saving face.
Before I left, the interrogators from the detention house and the detention center came to me with several documents, including an agreement stating that as a condition of my parole, I must not talk about my time in detention. The detention-center interrogator said: "You are Chinese, with black hair and yellow skin; you know what to do. You know what is best for your country and family." He repeated this several times.
Even though I signed the agreement, I suppose I knew that I would speak out. In my heart I knew. I have suffered a great injustice, and I'm dedicated to clearing my name. Still, I have grave concern for my family -- and my husband's -- most of whom remain in China. When we moved to America 12 years ago, I never expected to stay. I wanted to return to the mainland and do a talk show, something on family and marriage, along the lines of Oprah or Dr. Laura. There are so many divorces in China today, so many families breaking up, I wanted to use my academic specialty to help. I also wanted to live near my family, to serve my parents after being away so long. 
But now this is impossible -- any life in China is impossible. After my detention, after going public with my story, I will not be permitted back in the country. This pains me greatly because it means I will never see my father again. He is old now, 76, and has a serious heart ailment; he cannot travel. He and my mother have suffered enormously over the past months -- both of my parents were hospitalized several times during my detention -- and I'm afraid they will continue to suffer. The government has made many harsh and distorted statements against me, and most people think I'm a spy. This is especially difficult for my father, who was a government worker all his life and tends to believe whatever the government says. My mother told me that during my detention, my father stopped listening to the radio, even stopped watching TV. He wouldn't go out; he was afraid to be seen by his friends. 
I have always been my father's favorite daughter, the family success. Now all that has changed. After I was released and returned to my home in the United States, I called my parents. I spoke to my father, and I could hear the tightness in his voice. It got to the point where I had to say: "Father, I didn't do what I was accused of doing. Please, trust me." He told me that he had always thought his life would end happily, peacefully, but because of my incident, he believes that this is impossible. "Don't say anything about your experience, just let it go, like nothing happened to you," he said to me. This made me cry. Once again I feel trapped. But this time I'm caught between my family and my need to tell the truth about China. Beneath the rapid economic growth, beneath the smiles of Chinese officials and the handshakes with international leaders, China's political and ideological system remains unchanged. China is still a dangerous place, not just for dissidents, but for anyone interested in pursuing the free exchange of ideas. 
When I was finally freed from detention, I was taken back to the Beijing airport to pick up a flight back to the States. As I was walking to the ticket counter, I saw him. It was the casually dressed man, the agent who had stopped us six months before. He was standing with the same agents. Presumably he was waiting for someone.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
Packages Put Europe on Sale

BYLINE:  By MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON; MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON is a freelance writer living in San Diego.

 BODY:
FIVE nights in Paris, including air fare, for $439? A round trip to Ireland, plus a week's rental car and lodging, for $449? These are the kinds of prices travelers will see on packages to Europe this winter.
 Air fares historically fall in the autumn, but the slowed economy and an unusually soft market for business travel made for discounted summer fares this year. Revenue by the standard industry measure, the cost of flying one seat one mile -- called the available seat mile -- fell 12.3 percent in July compared with the previous year, according to the Air Transport Association. And the European Travel Commission expects the peak season, May through September, to be flat this year, after eight record seasons in a row, according to Neil Martin, a spokesman. 
 Airlines are responding by cutting fares even more, and tour operators have jumped in, adding hotel stays and sometimes car rentals to create some notable bargain packages to Europe. Although least expensive during the off-off-season before and after the year-end holidays, prices promise to stay low into spring.
"People have less money to spend, and maybe now they don't want to take more than a week away from work," said Bram Majtlis, president of IMTC/Pegasus, an Atlanta-based travel company offering a range of European packages. "We created these packages as an answer for these people." 
Packages offer savings individuals can match only with luck, research skills and good timing in booking the components individually. Sometimes this does happen. My husband, Jinx, and a friend recently bought round-trip tickets from San Diego to Amsterdam for only $385 each, through a US Airways online promotion, for mid-September. If they were to find a budget hotel room at, say, $100 a night including breakfast and tax, they would spend $535 apiece for a three-night stay. That would beat most of the aggressively priced package deals.

Multiple Cities
By comparison, IMTC/Pegasus has a package to Amsterdam, Brussels or Paris for $599 that includes three nights' stay in a two- or three-star hotel and round-trip air fare from New York, Boston, Washington, Atlanta, Chicago or Dallas ($79 more from Los Angeles or San Francisco.) Available from Nov. 1 to March 31, it offers the option of flying into one city and out of another. For more information, call (800) 790-4682, or see www.imtc-travel.com.
A similar package for Barcelona, Madrid and Lisbon is $659, but the three nights are in first-class hotels. To compare this package with a trip booked independently, I found round-trip air from Boston to Madrid for travel beginning Nov. 1 at $350 a person at the US Airways Web site. Hotellocators.com listed three nights at the Hotel Arosa, the central hotel used by IMTC, at $420.91, so the total, booking independently, came out to $560.46 each, nearly $100 less than the package. The discounted air fare was available only from Boston, however, and required booking in a narrow time frame (by Sept. 5) 
An advantage of packages is that tour companies can offer advice about hotels and connections, and in some cases, provide assistance after arrival. Those that offer two-city deals, with arrival in one city and departure in another, can be impossible to match independently.
Obviously, the better the agent, the fewer potential problems. As an extra precaution, always pay by credit card, and consider buying trip-cancellation insurance. 
The packages that follow include economy air fare and tourist-class hotels with private bath for either five or six nights (prices are per person, double occupancy); upgrades in air and hotel arrangements are usually available. Many packages provide reduced fares for domestic flights to and from departure points, and most include daily breakfast (ask what kind), hotel service charges, city and sales taxes, but exclude airport taxes and departure fees (usually about $65).

London Remains Popular

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
Finding a Niche in Housing for Older Residents

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THE new apartment at Stone Hill in Washingtonville, about 10 miles from Newburgh in Orange County, is everything Robert and Joy Ann Dixon dreamed about for their retirement: two light and airy bedrooms, a dramatic view from the living room window of trees and Woodcock Mountain, an all-new kitchen with wood cabinets and modern appliances, central air-conditioning and a private clubhouse for residents only.
 It may sound as though Mr. and Mrs. Dixon, both 61, have moved to a luxury complex for seniors, but that is hardly the case. Their monthly income is limited to Mr. Dixon's Social Security check and the disability insurance he receives since injuring his back several years ago. 
 In December, the couple moved out of the three-bedroom, two-bath home they could no longer afford in Florida, N.Y. -- leaving behind a $1,000 a month mortgage, $7,000 a year in property taxes and the upkeep that goes along with a single-family home. 
They are now paying $545 a month for their apartment at Stone Hill. It is one of a growing number of below-market-rate senior housing communities in the New York area built by Wilder Balter Partners of Elmsford, Westchester County.
The residential housing developer, a partnership between Robert H. Wilder Jr., 55, and William G. Balter, 38, builds everything from luxury to below-market-rate housing, with the company averaging close to $50 million a year in new housing construction. They currently have about 15 active projects -- from luxury single-family homes to multifamily and senior housing, which they own and manage in Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess, Orange, Suffolk and Fairfield Counties.
Over the decade they have been in business together, the partners have become known for both kinds of housing, with Mr. Balter handling most matters related to the luxury residences and Mr. Wilder overseeing financing and construction of the below-market-rate projects. As Mr. Wilder recently said, "We haven't put all our eggs in one residential basket."
Their luxury projects include Arrowcrest at Ardsley and Westwind at Stony Street in Yorktown.
Stone Hill in Washingtonville, their newest below-market-rate project, offers 104 apartments for those who are 55 and older and have an annual income of not more than 50 percent of Orange County's median income, which is $55,800 for a family of four. The income guidelines vary from project to project, depending upon the county in which the housing is located. 
Under the terms of the government financing used for Stone Hill and other similar projects, the rents may be increased only after a rise in the county's median income, which is calcuated annually. The projects -- which are managed by the builders or a nonprofit agency -- must remain within the government classification as affordable for a 30-year period.
Wilder Balter recently broke ground for Hughson Commons, 94 units of below-market-rate one- and two-bedroom rentals in Carmel in Putnam County. In Dutchess, it has built 82 units of below-market-rate rentals for seniors at Heritage Park in Hyde Park.
In Suffolk, the developers have completed 265 such units at Woodcrest Estates in Port Jefferson, and because of the success of the first units, they are planning a second phase. Also on Long Island, Wilder Balter recently broke ground for 208-unit project at Brookview Gardens in Babylon. 
Such complexes are helping to fill a growing demand for low-cost senior housing. In Westchester, for example -- where Wilder Balter is applying for public financing for a similar project in Mount Kisco -- there is a a larger percentage of older residents than in the rest of the country over all. One in every five Westchester residents was 60 or older in 2000; the country as a whole is not expected to have that rate of older people until the year 2050. Meanwhile, the first of 76 million baby boomers nationwide have turned 55.
The numbers have prodded policy makers, service providers and builders like Wilder Balter to develop policies, services and programs responsive to the needs of seniors. Toward that end, Wilder Balter locates its senior complexes near shopping areas, doctors, hospitals, parks or other recreation sites and nonprofit social service agencies that handle the needs of the aging. 
"My husband has a heart condition," Mrs. Dixon said, "so it was very important for us to be close to medical services. He's already had one heart attack, and I worry about him."
The Dixons own a car and also enjoy walking to nearby shopping and recreation. For the most part, they are independent and able to manage their lives without special services. Those services, however, are available if needed -- as they are for residents in all of the developers' senior complexes.
In Port Jefferson at Woodcrest, for example, the complex's project manager, Diane Foster, not only oversees maintenance of the property but also coordinates residents' activities with nonprofit agencies that provide assistance with housing and heating costs, home health aides, meals and elder day care, among other things.
Also enabling seniors to "age in place" -- in the words of planners, social workers and builders -- are amenities like elevators in buildings so residents do not have to move out when they can no longer negotiate flights of stairs. Units in all complexes have been built in such a way that grab bars and other aids for the handicapped can be easily added. Mr. Balter said the apartment complexes were designed to enable residents to continue living in them as long as possible -- often until they move on to assisted living housing.
Attesting to the need for below-market-rate housing for seniors are the long waiting lists at many of the complexes.
In Tarrytown, Rose Noonan, the executive director of the regional Housing Action Council, a nonprofit housing organization that has worked with Wilder Balter on several projects, said, "In some places we're seeing a two- and three-year waiting list."
At Woodcrest, there are 500 on the waiting list for apartments, Ms. Foster reported.
"Demand always exceeds supply," Mr. Wilder said.
While multifamily developments sometimes face opposition because of concern about added traffic and other planning issues , the complexes for older residents are often welcomed by the municipalities in which they are located, Mr. Wilder said. "There is a huge desire on the part of elected officials and their constituents, as well as the seniors themselves and the children of the seniors, to find ways to enable those over 55 to stay in the community and not be forced by economics to move elsewhere," he said.
For the most part seniors are considered good neighbors to have -- especially since they place fewer demands on a municipality than growing families, he added.
The developers finance their senior rental projects through a variety of sources. As an example, the $12 million Stone Hill complex raised $8.3 million from the Federal Housing Tax Credit program, which encourages private investment in below-market rate rental housing. The federal money was distributed by the state through its Division of Housing and Community Renewal. It also received a $1.2 million New York state Housing Trust Fund Loan, a low-interest loan issued by the state, and a $778,000 Federal Home Loan Bank loan, also at a low interest rate. In addition, Stone Hill received a $200,000 loan from Orange County. Most of the remaining cost was covered by a $1.7 million conventional mortgage loan.
The developer takes up to 15 percent of the total cost as his fee. "The real art," Mr. Wilder said, "is applying for and receiving funding in sufficient amounts to cover all of the project's costs, including the developer's fee."
Ms. Noonan at the Housing Action Council -- which often helps in guiding proposals for senior projects through the local approval process as well as sometimes taking a partnership stake with a developer -- suggested that prospective renters ask the following questions before signing a lease: Is the lease renewable? What social services are provided through the complex? What is the reputation of the developer, and what other projects has he completed?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert H. Wilder Jr., a developer of Stone Hill, a senior housing community in Washingtonville, N.Y. (Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times)
