HEADLINE: THEATER: A Symbolic Nation Aspires to the International; 
A Symbolic Nation Aspires to the International

BYLINE:  By JACQUES GODBOUT; Jacques Godbout has published essays in Montreal and novels in Paris. He has made more than 30 films, including 4 features, all produced by the National Film Board of Canada. This article was translated from the French by Robert Gray, Kinograph.

DATELINE: MONTREAL 

 BODY:
WOULD the idea of holding a Quebec arts festival in New York have occurred to anyone 20 years ago? Probably not. We Quebecers were then still searching for an identity, unsure of our relationship to the Americas, embroiled in a literary and theatrical adventure in a French language that wavered among standardized forms, archaisms and original expressions invented to communicate our lives in our seasons. Our cinema aspired to documentary values.
 What gave Quebecois culture its strength 20 years ago resulted from a profound questioning of traditional values and the identification of the larger artistic community with a national project. Today, in all the arts, under the influence of globalization, Quebec artists have become autonomous individuals. The project for political sovereignty, it seems, has succeeded only on the personal level. Our national culture aspires to be international, and Quebec, which is still only a symbolic country, regularly showcases its arts abroad, as it is doing in the festival Quebec/ New York 2001, which was to begin on Thursday and runs until Oct. 7. 
 Quebec culture is influenced by intellectual life in Paris (we share the same language) and by the creative energy of New York (we are almost neighbors). This is felt in the rhythm of our television shows, in our comedians, in the ambition to make Montreal a world center for contemporary dance. 
If we issue from both Hollywood and St.-Germain-des-Pres, if our heads are often in Europe but our hearts in the Americas, this is not because of any split personality; it is simply our way of existing. Relations between Quebecers and Americans (we prefer to call them "United-Statesians," since we, too, inhabit the Americas) are friendly, ancient and deep. In our national history, for example, our French ancestors were the first to cross the New World from east to west, to explore the Mississippi Delta and to settle Detroit and St. Louis. So you will understand our concern about the image Quebec projects in the world, and especially in the United States.
The situation is delicate. Not since the Major League Baseball Players Association strike of 1994 have the Montreal Expos led the National League standings; the Montreal Canadiens are a pale shadow of the kings of the ice that they once were. Worse still: Mordecai Richler, taking advantage of his fame as a novelist, began a malicious campaign in The New Yorker a decade ago, which he followed up with a book, "Oh Canada! Oh Quebec!," in which he denounced, more or less honestly, the project for a sovereign and French Quebec. How far did his mudslinging carry?
Richler was, though he would disdain the term, Quebec's greatest writer. He died too soon, for his wife, his children, his friends and, of course, his readers; but also too soon to celebrate this "Quebec Fall," which follows the "Quebec Spring" presented in France two years ago. This man who never tired of denouncing the desire of Quebecers to exist in French could nonetheless have kicked off the New York festivities with a blast and could perhaps even have finally apologized, with his timid half-smile, for having described his French-speaking compatriots as raving fanatics.
Quebec numbers six million Francophones (French speakers) and one million Anglophones. Richler, an Anglophone who left Montreal for London in 1954, at 23, not to return until 1972, in his 40's, never really understood what had happened to his country during his absence.
Richler's Quebec dated back to his childhood, and to mine. It was a rural-minded province, dominated by soutane-clad bigots and peopled by workers exploited by Anglo-American big business. It was led by the autocratic head of a nationalist party, and its citizens were instructed to devote their energies to preparing for the next world rather than trying to improve their lot in this one.
Yet while Richler was in England, laying the foundations of his career as a writer, our country, with its siege mentality, was undergoing a cultural mutation of unimaginable breadth. Within a decade or so after he left, a silent people began to speak, its artists and businessmen to embark on new projects, and visitors to discover, on the occasion of Expo '67, a Quebec in a state of social and political ferment, in stride with other cultural movements around the globe.
This was the Quiet Revolution, taking place without bloody confrontations or massive demonstrations in the streets. Long in the making, the transformation was no doubt a belated response to World War II. The war had brought new wealth to Canada, stimulated industry and opened up offices and factories to women; the soldiers who returned from the European front were no longer the trembling youths who had left the banks of the St. Lawrence River in 1940.
But the Roman Catholic Church, still maintaining its stranglehold on Quebec society, controlled social life from birth to death, ran schools and hospitals, censored the press and kept a tight lid on the intellectual and artistic pot. One example from many: in 1959, cinephiles who wanted to see the complete version of one of the films of the French New Wave had to drive from Montreal to New York, eight hours on the road, to outwit the censors.
Like Richler and dozens of other young people of my generation, I left a conservative Quebec in 1954 to study in Europe, where we discovered a multiplicity of cultures, a profusion of languages and intellectual freedom. Born at the right time, we hadn't suffered from the war -- just the opposite -- and we were able to study in an age riveted by ideologies, secular and Marxist, stimulated by intellectual debate and ready to overturn the established order.
I returned home in 1960, and by then our generation no longer recognized itself in a dominating English Canada and a consenting Quebec. Our poets were the first to come together, inventing a liberated Quebec with literature. This poetry proved a seismograph, and its quality was acknowledged immediately in France. Modern and demanding texts -- by Anne Hebert, Gaston Miron and a hundred other poets -- inaugurated a new era.
Our generation was scarcely 30; more than half of Quebec was in its 20's. And so we entered the modern age pushed from behind by impatient youths but wielding an extraordinary tool of communication, television. The church never saw its cathodic rival coming.
Unlike the United States, where radio and television belonged to the private sector from the start, Canada (less populous than the state of California alone) had always favored a mixed economy, and television was viewed at first as a public service. In the same way, Canadian cinema was forged at the National Film Board, a state-run agency whose only rivals were to be found in Communist countries like Poland and Czechoslovakia. The federal government thus entrusted French-language television to young people from the theater or fresh out of universities.
Growing up is a strange experience; it is even stranger to watch oneself grow up before the cameras of Radio Canada. The cultural construction set in motion by the poets gave rise to poet-songwriters like Felix Leclerc, Gilles Vigneault, Claude Leveillee and Jean-Pierre Ferland, who appeared on variety shows and won over a young generation eager to hear its life reflected in ballads and pop tunes. Robert Charlebois taught the French that rock 'n' roll could be sung in their language, our language.
The more the political and religious elites tried to smother these early manifestations of freedom, the more French-Canadian society responded with pyrotechnical displays, which made the TV news. This was the time of the Algerian war and of African independence movements, and in Paris, Jean-Paul Sartre, Frantz Fanon and Albert Memmi were developing theories that reverberated in our intellectual magazines.
The program of the Quiet Revolution, certainly not as straightforward at the time as it appears to us today, had as its primary ambition the decolonization of Quebec on three fronts. Three capitals imposed their laws on us: Paris, whose cultural model was primordial; Rome, whose clerical influence extended as far as our universities; and Ottawashington, capital of the Anglo-American establishment in business and industry.
Poets, novelists and playwrights insolently tossed off the cultural yoke of France. The abundance and quality of Quebecois works, and the unshakable support of public radio and of the Canada Council, the federal arts financing agency, gave birth to an original literary life that has asserted itself ever since. Quebec's French-language writing, from Hubert Aquin to Gaetan Soucy, boasts among its ranks numerous authors of the highest order.
The church, in turn, was forced to bow to the sexual revolution of the 60's, the ministry of education and the democratization of teaching having quickly secularized the members of religious orders. Secular discourse replaced Sunday sermons, church pews emptied, and Rome's dictates began to look dated. Pope John XXIII summoned a council to modernize the rites. In Quebec it was already too late.
The process of political decolonization was arduous and, it can be said, is still going on, since even today the Parti Quebecois includes nationalist sovereignty on its plank. For more than 40 years, Quebec politicians have searched for the magic formula to allow them to counterbalance federal powers.
It is easy to understand that Richler, returning from London in 1972, no longer recognized the Quebec of Duddy Kravitz. The lower ranks and NCO's (that is, the French-Canadians) now gave the orders; socialist and sovereignist speeches packed political meeting halls; in Quebec the federalist Liberal Party had floated aimlessly after the kidnapping and murder of one of its ministers.
With ever greater insistence, Francophone society demanded government measures to affirm and protect the French language, its status having been weakened by the arrival of immigrants, who invariably sent their children to school in English, and by French Canadians themselves, who seemed on the verge of assimilating, as their grandparents had done 50 years earlier in New England.
Thus, in 1976, the new Quebec government, led by the journalist Rene Levesque, passed a language law that provoked the ire of the author of "Joshua Then and Now." Judging this act "fascist," Richler began to denounce what he deemed "the language police," who were responsible for ensuring that all public signs were in French. The novelist, like many other Anglophone Quebecers, embarked on a crusade.
In Quebec, the linguistic question is fundamental. We like to believe that Francophones have the right to a territory of their own in the Americas. In Quebec, the English-language community has access to public educational, legal and health services in its own language. French is not a disease, and it threatens no one. "We don't need to speak French," wrote the author Andre Belleau, "we need French to speak."
The real problem is again one of demographics. We have built, patiently, from generation to generation, across various movements of solidarity and resistance, a distinct society. If at times we appeared to be more community-oriented than individualistic, it was because we had to organize the structures and establishments that would one day allow the personal fulfillment of our citizens.
Numbers, as we know, are fundamental. Richler could count on his readers in the United States, England and Canada. We could rely only on a nation of six million inhabitants, hence the necessity of protecting our rear before setting out to conquer the universe. But the time for confidence is upon us.
Some authors, like the novelist Marie Laberge, reach hundreds of thousands of readers in Quebec alone, and others, like Michel Tremblay, have, after enormous local success, seen their plays translated and staged around the world. Without government support the filmmakers Denys Arcand ("The Decline of the American Empire"), Francois Girard ("The Red Violin") and Denis Villeneuve ("Maelstrom") would not have been able to practice their art.
It is this highly original approach that allowed the Cirque du Soleil to set up its tents and provided support for the brilliant work of the actor, author and film and stage director Robert Lepage, who lives in Quebec City and has works in progress in every major artistic capital. His "Zulu Time" opens on Friday at the Roseland Ballroom in mid-Manhattan.
In the 1950's, painters of the automatist movement, Jean-Paul Riopelle being the most famous, had no choice but to go into exile to continue their careers. Since then, painters, conceptual artists and sculptors like Serge Lemoyne and Armand Vaillancourt have earned places at the pinnacle of their professions and in the collections of savvy buyers.
When the rock operas of Luc Plamondon and his outstanding casts occupy the largest stages of Paris, we must be grateful to the musical and vocal traditions bequeathed to us by the church. Choirs led to bel canto; convent piano lessons educated a demanding audience that throngs to concerts by piano virtuosos like Marc-Andre Hamelin or Louis Lortie, prestigious guests of the Montreal Symphony Orchestra and its Swiss conductor Charles Dutoit.
Today Las Vegas, Toronto and New York welcome works by Quebec creators, many of whom, like the stage director and playwright Washdi Mouawad and the novelists Dany Laferriere and Sergio Kokis, are not native-born. Quebec has become a proving ground for Francophones from the Caribbean and the Americas.
Quebec (whose official motto is "I Remember"), remains one of Canada's 10 provinces and may continue to do so for a long time to come, from one referendum to the next. No matter. If boredom grows out of uniformity, our French presence on this continent is a factor for diversity.
Today Montreal is a cosmopolitan city with 2.5 million inhabitants. In Rimouski, Chicoutimi, Quebec City and Sherbrooke, the majority of people are of French origin, and they still bear the names passed down from Louis XIV's soldiers: La tulippe, Laforce, Latendresse, La rose. Or even Johnson, Ryan and MacDonald, for Scottish and Irish troops married Quebecois women after the English victory of 1760. And the blood of many Quebecers has long been mixed with that of Native Americans, which has not kept those Native Americans from demanding in turn the right to their own territory.
In Quebec, as everywhere else, high culture rubs elbows with street culture. The great tragic novelist Marie-Claire Blais, who has been publishing for more than 40 years, represents us just as much as the pop star Celine Dion, singing in Tokyo or Berlin. The author of "Barney's Version" knew how to question our identity, which is essential to the well-being of a country where the Catholic temptation of universal consensus still lurks. Richler is no longer with us. Let us hope that this "Quebec Fall" will allow us to bury, as we did his ashes in Montreal last summer, the prejudices that he kept alive.

From Quebec, a Fete Worthy of a Roi

QUEBEC/ NEW YORK 2001
 This festival of dance, theater, music, visual arts and film by 30 arts organizations from Quebec, which was to begin on Sept. 13, will continue through Oct. 7 at sites across New York. Below are some selected events. A series of free concerts and exhibitions had been scheduled for the World Financial Center in downtown Manhattan; these and others may been canceled or postponed in the aftermath of the attacks on the World Trade Center. Readers are advised to call (212) 843-0969 for information or consult the festival's Web site (www.quebecnewyork.com).

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 9-16-01: Salient Facts: Alternative Energy; 
The Dregs

BYLINE:  By Robb Mandelbaum 

 BODY:
 The crisis in California's grid seems to have abated for now, but in its wake, it has left renewed interest in alternative energy technologies. By 2006, the state hopes that 17 percent of its power will come from renewable energy, and it is now allocating $135 million a year to meet that goal. But California has its work cut out: last year, only 12 percent of its energy came from alternative sources. Here's what is in the pipeline.

FOOD IS FUEL
Recently, Los Angeles World Airports, which manages LAX, began hauling small amounts of food waste from an airline catering company to a treatment plant nearby. After the food is ground (pictured above) and "digested" in a tank, the methane that results powers a steam turbine that generates electricity. The airport eventually hopes to recycle all 8,000 tons of leftover food produced each year by airline caterers. The plant already operates with electricity derived from sewage it processes, a fuel that costs about 2 cents per kilowatt-hour; Jerry Hernandez, a sanitary engineer for the city of Los Angeles, says that food may even be a cheaper fuel. Can mystery meat and sewage compete with natural gas and coal? Depends on how you look at it. Electricity from natural gas and coal might come cheaper, but some economists say that renewable energies deserve a handicap that takes into account their environmental benefits, like clearing the atmosphere of potent greenhouse gases like methane.

TREASURE FROM TRASH
Landfill gas is too weak to power most generators, but new microturbines, made by a company named Capstone, can burn gas that has a third of the fuel of natural gas. In August, the L.A. Department of Water and Power installed 50 microturbines at the Lopez Canyon landfill. (They now power 1,500 homes.) Next, Edan Prabhu, founder of a company called FlexEnergy, plans to develop seven prototype turbines, which could run on even weaker gas: "If it comes out of a bakery or a printing plant, I'd be able to suck that into our machine." Robb Mandelbaum

HEADLINE: Your Home; 
Weighing No-Cost Refinancings

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
FOR most people who have a mortgage on their home, the decision to refinance is typically based on a rather straightforward calculation: are the savings that will be realized by refinancing to a lower interest rate enough to justify the expenses of refinancing?
 In recent months, however, some lenders have been advertising "no-cost refinances" -- in which the lender picks up the expenses that would normally be paid by the borrower and the borrower gets the benefit of a brand new mortgage with a lower interest rate. 
 Does that mean, then, that it might be worthwhile for a borrower to refinance an existing mortgage no matter how small the reduction in interest rate might be?
Well, mortgage experts say, perhaps. Then again, perhaps not. 
"I think that a no-cost refinance can make a lot of sense for a lot of people," said Tim Malburg, president of the Capstone Mortgage Company, a mortgage broker in Wilton, Conn. 
Mr. Malburg explained that with a typical no-cost refinance, the lender charges the borrower zero points -- one point is equal to 1 percent of the amount being borrowed -- and also picks up the tab for things like appraisal fees, credit report costs, application fees, bank charges, title insurance fees and even the fee frequently charged to the borrower by the lender's lawyer.
"When I tell a client he is getting a no-points, no-closing-cost refinance, I'm talking about a mortgage that requires no out-of-pocket payments from the borrower," Mr. Malburg said, explaining that, as with any mortgage, the borrower generally does have to come up with the money required to finance escrow accounts for homeowners insurance and real estate taxes. 
In other words, Mr. Malburg said, since with a no-cost refinance the lender picks up all of the costs associated with obtaining the mortgage, it is possible -- theoretically, at least -- for a borrower to benefit from an interest rate drop of as little as one-eighth of 1 percent. Why, then, wouldn't everyone take advantage of a no-cost refinance whenever a rate drop made a refinance appropriate?
"Because there's no such thing as a completely free lunch," Mr. Malburg said.
He explained that with a typical no-cost refinance, if the lender pays the closing costs, the borrower agrees to pay a slightly higher interest rate than he or she might otherwise pay. 
For example, Mr. Malburg said, if the very best interest rate the lender can offer a borrower who is willing to pay his or her own refinancing costs is, say, 6.75 percent, the lender may charge that same borrower an interest rate of 7 percent for a no-cost refinance. So, he said, to determine whether it is wise to take out a no-cost refinance, the borrower must first determine whether a refinance makes sense in the first place, and then determine whether it makes more sense to pay one's own closing costs -- and thereby obtain a lower interest rate. 
For example, Mr. Malburg said, if a borrower's existing $200,000 mortgage was at 7.5 percent, and the interest rate for a traditional refinance was 6.75 percent, the borrower would save about $1,212 a year. (The payment on a 30-year $200,000 mortgage at 7.5 percent is $1,399 a month; the payment on the same loan at 6.75 percent is $1,298 a month, a savings of $101 a month.
While the principal balance of the mortgage is also being slightly reduced with each payment, that is not being taken into consideration for purposes of this example.) This means that it would take about 20 months for the borrower to "break even" after paying $2,000 in refinancing costs. 
In other words, the borrower would start saving the $101 a month only after he or she had spent 20 months recouping the closing costs. Nevertheless, the borrower would continue to save $101 a month for as long thereafter as he or she kept the loan.
The calculations work differently, however, for a no-cost refinance.
If that same borrower chose to take out a no-cost refinance, Mr. Malburg explained, he would not have to pay the $2,000 in closing costs, but he would have to pay 7 percent -- one quarter of a point more -- in interest. So instead of paying $1,298 a month, the borrower would instead be required to make a payment of $1,331 a month. And while that is still less than the $1,399 the borrower had been paying on the 7.5 percent mortgage, it is $396 a year more than he or she would have paid on the 6.75 percent loan. 
"What all this basically means is that after five years, the $2,000 savings in closing costs is eaten up by the additional interest being paid," Mr. Malburg said. 
As a result, he said, no-closing-cost refinances make more sense for borrowers who plan on selling their home -- or refinancing again -- within a relatively short period of time and are typically less appropriate for those who plan on keeping their house, and their mortgage, for the long haul.
But those who want to sell their home or refinance within a short time need to be careful they don't find themselves facing what is known as a "prepayment penalty."
Kenneth Polin, president of Banner Mortgage Group, a mortgage broker in Scarsdale, said a prepayment penalty is a provision in a mortgage that requires the borrower to pay the lender a certain amount of money if the borrower pays off the loan "prematurely" within a certain period of time. 
"There are soft prepayment penalties and hard prepayment penalties," Mr. Polin said, explaining that with a soft prepayment penalty, the penalty is imposed if the borrower pays off the loan by refinancing, but not if the borrower pays off the loan because the property has been sold. 
"The more common are the hard penalties," he said, explaining that with such a prepayment penalty, the penalty is imposed if the loan is paid off within a specific period of time, regardless of the reason. 
In most cases, Mr. Polin said, the prepayment penalty can be charged if the loan is paid off within 12 to 36 months -- depending on the specific terms of the mortgage -- and can amount to as much as 3 percent of the outstanding balance of the mortgage.
In fact, he said, anyone who is contemplating refinancing should check with both the current mortgage lender and the new lender to determine whether a prepayment penalty will be imposed if the mortgage is paid off early. And in every case, Mr. Polin said, borrowers should crunch the numbers to make sure that a refinance makes sense.
"In my opinion, the best strategy is to get the best rate you can possibly get," he said. "And that usually isn't possible with no-cost loans."

HEADLINE: The Early Education of a Wine Taster 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

 BODY:
SINCE boyhood, the memory of fiveoclocksupper -- thought of as one word, like Presidentroosevelt -- has regulated my instincts. Even though dinner now ranges from 7 to 9 p.m., hunger automatically glances at my watch at 5.
 In Newark's poor Central Ward in the 1940's, we didn't eat dinner on weekdays. We ate supper, usually at 5 o'clock, 5:30 at the latest, on weekdays. The same recipe, when served on Saturday at 6 or Sunday at 4, when company came, was called dinner. 
 In a federal housing project, where I was raised for six years, if the dishes weren't washed and put away by 7 o'clock, something was suspiciously wrong. One couple who ate late and owned rooms full of books were thought to be Communists. 
Fiveoclocksupper implied an All-American evening ritual: fathers, workingmen all (mine was a shoe salesman), would drag home, wash up, eat at 5, put on slippers, read the sports and war news in The Newark Evening News, listen to the ball game and go to sleep.
From Monday to Friday, wine was as beyond my ken as the gossip columnists' beloved madcap heiresses who swigged cocktails in the Stork Club. Newark was famously a brewery town, and Dad favored Krueger's. Although ads implied that if the home front drank enough Coke the Nazis would lose, the rest of the family thrived on grape soda, sarsaparilla, birch beer and root beer. 
If supper, on oilcloth, was routine, dinner was ceremonial. A table was opened in the parlor and given an embroidered cloth. Dishes materialized from high kitchen shelves. Silverware emerged from a felt-lined box. Stemmed goblets appeared, to be filled with an all-purpose (fish, chicken, meat) kosher wine, Mogen David, a sweet Concord red, especially on holidays.
It was this wine and the tart Concord grape, which tastes like its wine (not all grapes do), that started my informal wine education. A Concord arbor behind my paternal grandparents' house in Long Branch, N.J., an old seaside resort, smelled swooningly delicious in high September.
Although the arbor dated to Prohibition, which put Grandpa's liquor store out of business, he, unlike Italian neighbors, didn't make wine: Grandma disapproved of any pleasure. Like clockwork, we all sat down to supper at 5 o'clock. Afterward, as they schmoozed on front-porch rockers, with Grandpa's connivance I stole grapes from fat clusters that soon became jelly kept cool in a dirt basement. Sometimes the juice started fermenting on the vine.
In Newark, on holidays and sometimes on the Sabbath we drank semidry raisin wine that my maternal grandmother, who lived with us, made in autumn. The fermentation aroma filled the house and made a lasting impression, as did the wine's piquancy and golden color. 
The only other really impressive wine I ever encountered in Newark was sweet plum stuff in an upstairs Chinese restaurant whose full dinners ran from 75 cents to $1.25, and, once, something French in a famous, ritzy restaurant beyond our means called the Tavern, where at lunch we celebrated my graduation from grammar school. 
My formal wine education began when the word aperitif, so rich in connotations of the Good Life, penetrated my awareness as a Rutgers freshman. 
The idea that wine tasted dry (who ever heard of a thing?) and could, after 5 p.m., actually stimulate rather than retard an appetite was a bombshell. My first glass of dry sherry, a nutty fino, at a fraternity brother's Park Avenue South apartment in Manhattan, was a divine revelation; thereafter, a glass of sweet Gallo muscatel at the Corner Tavern, a hangout in New Brunswick, held no interest.
The occasional students from France were so nonchalant about a glass of Pommard that their urbanity seemed unfathomable. (National habits never die: A student from the London School of Economics was overbearing about claret.) Aside from learning how to affect world weariness while holding a Pall Mall at a 45-degree angle, for me an enduring freshman lesson was that a swell red like Pommard needn't always be a big deal. 
College life brought countless thirsts and sea changes. Although I ascended to Chianti by graduation, beer had triumphed. Wine went underground until, 18 years later, I rediscovered it, in German rieslings. Since then, almost daily a wish for a dry kabinett or dry spatlese has arisen, invariably signaling the arrival of, no surprise, 5 o'clock.

HEADLINE: Dinner Is Served. But Just Who Cooked? 

BYLINE:  By PAULA GANZI LICATA 

 BODY:
WHAT'S handier in kitchens across Long Island: the grocery list or the takeout menus? At dinnertime, the words Greek, Chinese and Italian are understood to mean cuisines, not languages. Although we may be eating at the dining room table, in the kitchen pots and pans are nowhere to be seen and the aroma of garlic is coming from the car, not the oven. 
 Years ago home-cooked dinners were the norm Monday through Friday, while dining out was reserved for weekends. Nowadays, the weekday grind ends with eating out and ordering in. Cooking dinner from scratch has become a weekend recreation. 
 Despite the popularity of the Food Network, the cornucopia of cooking shows or the proliferation of Calphalon, Cusinart and KitchenAid, cooking has become a hobby, perhaps even a passion, but often it's not part of the nightly routine. 
"The funny thing is we like cooking," said Christopher Barry of Glen Cove. "We just don't have the time."
Mr. Barry is a teacher at Glen Cove High School; his wife, Diane Dobler, is the director of design services at Rainbow Media Holdings Inc. in Bethpage. They have a 2 1/2-year-old daughter, Samantha. The family dines out and orders in during much of the workweek.
Carl Bachmann, the owner of the 10 Ruby Tuesday restaurants on Long Island, believes that the prevalence of two-income families is part of the reason for the increase in eating out. "It's a lot of hard work to cook and clean after getting home from work," he said.
This all comes as no surprise to Tim Zagat, a co-chairman of the Zagat Surveys, a popular series of dining guides that includes a book devoted to Long Island.
"In the New York metropolitan area, 60 percent of all meals are eaten out in restaurants or prepared outside the home or office, and those statistics are the same for Long Island," he said.
Meryl Souci of Massapequa, who has four daughters, said: "We eat out so often I could probably pay my mortgage with what we spend. Friday night is always pizza night in Massapequa, better known as MassaPizza. It's amazing how many pizzerias there are -- two on any given block. You have to call way ahead on a Friday night from the train, and still your pick-up number can be 999."
Mrs. Souci, a sales manager at a children's clothing manufacturer in Manhattan, said she cooks only two nights out of seven. "Sunday I make a full balanced meal, with enough for seconds," she said. "And Thursday it's breakfast for dinner. Since everyone is dodging out the door in the mornings, this gives us a chance to eat breakfast together."
The menu? Pancakes, omelets or waffles. 
It's actually cost-efficient to eat out. Or so the restaurant industry would have you believe. So the industry has responded to the dinner dilemma with what are known as BATH restaurants, an acronym that stands for "better alternative to home."
"These are the little places that never get written about, the pasta places, neighborhood joints, ethnic places," Mr. Zagat said. They have three characteristics: prices are low, the setting is casual and the food is hearty.
"They're so inexpensive," Mr. Zagat said, "that they are more efficient than you would be if you did the shopping and cooking."
"The fact is that even though we love the romantic nostalgia that our mothers were shopping, cooking and cleaning -- that was romantic to us, but not necessarily to them," he said. "Today the majority of women, even women with young children, are working. There's nobody at home who has the time to do that shopping, cooking and cleaning. Both parents are lucky to get home by 7, and at that point there's very little time and energy for those things."
But many parents don't feel absolved by this explanation.
"Tonight I have to go home and throw out all the leftover takeout food because my mother is coming tomorrow," said Ms. Dobler, the design director.
Joseph Varsalona is a producer at Cablevision and the vice chairman of the Bellport Film Society. During a summer visit at Mr. Varsalona's home in East Patchogue, his grandmother expressed surprised at how often her grandson didn't come home for dinner.
"One night I called to tell her that I was eating out with Michael, a longtime family friend," Mr. Varsalona said. "Coincidentally, Michael's grandmother happened to be visiting with Nana." Mr. Varsalona overheard his grandmother say to her visitor, "Mr. Trump and Mr. Rockefeller will be dining out this evening."
Whatever relatives' reaction to dinners out may be, many Long Islanders say they refuse to play the blame game.
"I don't feel guilty about not cooking more," said Janet Fisher of Oceanside, because her son, Andrew, seems to prefer pizza and sushi. "Andrew doesn't seem to care," his mother said. 
What may help assuage parents' guilt is the fact that families aren't the only demographic group throwing in the dishtowel at dinnertime. 
"Being single, I never feel like cooking when I get home from work," said Joan Marasco, a widow who lives in Baldwin. Mrs. Marasco, an assistant vice president at Citibank in Manhattan, chooses from a number of local restaurants: Raay-Nor's Cabin, Kam's Kitchen and the I'm in a Hurry Pizzeria.
Laurie Bloom, the marketing director at Rivkin Radler, the largest law firm on Long Island, doesn't feel guilty, either.
"When you work the long hours we do, the goal is simply to eat before 10," she said. 
Ms. Bloom and Leonard Thon, a television producer for Hofstra University, own a historic Tudor in Brightwaters with a nice kitchen. But since they both work in Uniondale, a 30-minute commute, they eat out, often at Caffe Spasso in Carle Place.
"I like the friendly bistro atmosphere, and the food is terrific," Ms. Bloom said.
Eating out also satisfies social yearnings. "I'd rather be dining at a table with friends than alone at my kitchen counter," Mr. Varsalona said. "Sometimes you can't devote a weekend to friends, but planned dinners after work keep you in the loop."
The social scene is evident at all levels.
"Samantha started playing with another girl while at Ruby Tuesday," Ms. Dobler said. "I said to the other mother, 'Do you want to meet here next Wednesday?' "
Will people continue to eat out five nights a week if the economy continues to stall? "I would suspect a down economy puts pressure on people to work longer hours or second jobs, so they have even less time to shop and cook," Mr. Zagat said.
Mr. Bachmann, the Ruby Tuesday owner, contends that his restaurants are something of a bargain.
"When the economy dips, people might not spend $5 at Starbucks, but they can get a lot of value at Ruby Tuesday," he said. "On Long Island, the average cost for an adult dinner is $12, $5 for kids."
And there seems to be a curious contradiction at work. "People love to brag, 'I don't cook,' " said Carol Gross of East Northport, 'yet we all have these $80,000 kitchens with Sub-Zero freezers."
Mrs. Gross, a co-director of Fly Without Fear, a desensitization program for people who are afraid of flying, likens the situation to another fantasy: "People love to look at travelogues," she said, "but they don't go to Africa."

HEADLINE: Finally, a Doctor Is in the House 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE DIGRAZIA 

 BODY:
RESIDENTS of Beacon Falls, a rural town of about 5,300 on the banks of the Naugatuck River, say they are accustomed to always having to go somewhere else. A Big Mac attack or a Dunkin Donuts Coolatta craving means driving to next-door Naugatuck or Seymour. Shopping at Wal-Mart or renting a video from Blockbuster also requires mini-excursions to other communities.
"We always went to high school out of town and to the movies," said Beverly Krenesky, a Beacon Falls native and president of its Historical Society. "I guess we just got so used to going out of town for everything."
 That has included going to the doctor. The town has not had a full-time doctor for about 50 years. Even the town historian can't remember when the full-time doctor left, and it was so long ago that he can't remember who it was. He said a couple of doctors once had part-time offices, but they were closed in the 1960's. 
 "The only doctor we've had here in town all the time was up on South Circle," said Mike Krenesky, the town historian and Beverly's husband. "Patients came to see him in that house. This was right after World War II and I can remember because I hurt my finger playing ball and went to see him. But I can't remember his name."
While the town's quaintness draws people who like living in a rustic setting, it's not a draw for doctors. Economically, they can do much better in larger communities, and in this area they have gravitated to nearby areas with hospitals, like Derby, New Haven and Waterbury. Beacon Falls has a local nurse on its payroll, but she is available only on a limited basis and mostly conducts blood-pressure and diabetes screenings.
So, it's no surprise that Beacon Falls recently celebrated like the Fourth of July when Dr. Sudipta Dey, a 38-year-old internist from India, opened a primary-care center there. The town threw a "Welcome Dr. Dey Day" in April, a big open-house-type party complete with an office ribbon cutting, a proclamation, clowns, music, balloons and refreshments. The Kreneskys later presented Dr. Dey with a series of historic town photographs to hang on the wall of his new waiting room. "He's not only our first doctor, he's our first town museum, too," Mrs. Krenesky said.
Dr. Dey said he still can't believe the fanfare his arrival has caused. "I never heard of a community welcoming a doctor like this," Dr. Dey said. "I sent my mother in India some photos of the party. It was beyond my wildest dreams."
Town leaders and local medical officials said the same of the serendipitous chain of events that brought Dr. Dey to Beacon Falls. First Selectwoman Susan Cable said she and officials of Griffin Hospital in Derby worked for more than two years to find a doctor willing to open an office in town. At least three doctors didn't work out. The process began, Mrs. Cable said, when she attended a hospital presentation two years ago.
"I was somewhat taken aback that the hospital was basically writing off Beacon Falls because not a lot of people were using Griffin," Mrs. Cable said. "I spoke up and said in all my years as a selectwoman, they never spoke to us about our health needs."
A federal study conducted in the 1970's and still widely quoted calls for one physician per 3,500 people, and "our population warranted having a doctor," Mrs. Cable said. At the same time, she said, the town was building a new regional high school and courting businesses for its new industrial park -- the town's biggest employer, Uni royal, a rubber manufacturer, shut down in 1980. And, she said, in recent years, more people were moving to Beacon Falls from New York and Fairfield County to take advantage of lower housing prices.
"We were thinking that having a doctor in town could only improve the quality of life here," she said.
In the meantime, Dr. Dey, unaware of all the high-level discussions and doctor searches, was a full-time teaching faculty member at Griffin Hospital, but was growing disenchanted with the transient nature of treating only hospital patients.
"At a hospital, you see patients who are very sick people," he said. "You treat them and send them off. But it takes time to build a relationship with patients. Once you do that, then you can treat the patient as a whole." Dr. Dey said his holistic philosophy was a result of seeing how his late father, a physician in Demow, a small town in India where Dr. Dey grew up, treated his patients.
"I come from a small community like Beacon Falls," he said. "People used to drop by my father's office and say hello. I liked that idea and I liked my father's style. He spent 45 years in the same town."
But the realization that he yearned to pattern his career after his father's didn't hit him right away.
"In the beginning, I wanted to be a cardiologist and joined a big hospital in Calcutta that specialized in cardiac care," he said. "But I found it very localized; you're looking at one organ system all that time and that's it."
After Calcutta, Dr. Dey spent three years in England with his wife, Bindu, also a physician who practices in Shelton, pursuing cardiology opportunities. He landed at Griffin Hospital in 1995, a result of a recruitment program. Last year, Dr. Dey mentioned to Patrick Charmel, the hospital president, that he was interested in opening a community practice, "and within a couple of weeks, he came back and said he thought he had something for me," Dr. Dey said. "It was very good timing."
Dr. Dey's first exposure to Beacon Falls was when a women's group invited him to a potluck supper at a local church earlier this year. "I liked the community feeling," Dr. Dey said. "At the end of the supper they gave me a banana bread to give to my wife." This bribery aside, Dr. Dey said: "I had the same feeling I had with my dad. It was a golden opportunity and I had to grab it."
Hospital and town officials found a building in Beacon Falls in which the landlord was storing antique cars and persuaded him to let them renovate the space into a doctor's office.
"By contractual agreement, Griffin Hospital did his start-up and is responsible for the building renovations," said Bill Powanda, vice president of Griffin Hospital. "As his practice builds, he will become his own business." Dr. Dey will draw a salary from the hospital until his practice becomes profitable, Mr. Powanda said. 
Dr. Dey's move to open a small-community practice while remaining affiliated with a hospital reflects a growing trend in the medical community, said Bob Brunell, director of scientific affairs for the Connecticut Medical Society, which represents 7,000 doctors. "Trends are dictated by the economics of health care," Mr. Brunell said. "In an HMO environment, physicians are expected to see more and more patients in the same amount of time, or less. It becomes more and more difficult for a physician to develop a close relationship with patients."
But at the same time, he said, more doctors with smaller practices are joining larger groups or hospitals. "Physicians who don't have affiliations will be out in the cold," Mr. Brunell said. Dr. Dey's situation is the best of both worlds. "I would guess he's really gotten off with a bang," Mr. Brunell said. 
Indeed, Dr. Dey may own the practice sooner than anyone expected. He opened the Pines Bridge Primary Care Center in April with three patients and already has more than 100. Word of Dr. Dey's personal attention to his patients and early-morning and late-evening office hours has traveled fast. Mrs. Cable said her son has switched to Dr. Dey, as has her sister and her mother. "They tease me because I havent switched yet," she said.
In fact, many patients related similar experiences of new, family-wide allegiances to Dr. Dey based on his "old-fashioned" doctoring.
"He reminds me of those cowboy pictures where the doctors went to the house and delivered a baby, like 'Dr. Quinn, Medicine Woman,' " said David Murphy, 59, of Beacon Falls, referring to the television show. "The guy actually talks to you. I feel safe with him."
Mr. Murphy, who is a diabetic with a history of heart problems, talked about a recent gesture by Dr. Dey that had cemented Mr. Murphy's devotion. He said that the doctor called him the day after an announcement that the cholesterol-reducing drug Baycol was linked to 52 deaths worldwide to make sure he wasn't taking the medication. "Isn't that something?" Mr. Murphy said.
Peter Sokolowski, a 54-year-old aircraft electrician who lives in Beacon Falls, said that he was looking for a new doctor closer to home when he heard Dr. Dey was coming to town.
"He has special hours," Mr. Sokolowski said. "One day he's open from 1 p.m. to 8 p.m., which is great because you can go after work. The guy's been like gold. My wife is switching to him now."
For Dr. Dey, the feeling is mutual. He said he was enjoying the relationships he was building with his new patients, but was struck by one in particular. It's the one that came to mind when he is asked what he has liked most about being a small-town doctor.
"I have one old patient, who was one of my first," he said. "Initially when he came in he was very depressed. I found some ailments and treated them, and he got better. He came in a few days ago and his wife said to me, 'You saved his life.' That made me feel very good."

HEADLINE: Taking a Chance At Hartford Stage 

BYLINE:  By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
IT must be impolite, if not uncivil, to say a disparaging word about a new play by the venerable Horton Foote, the theater's last authentic articulator of a bygone time.
 Perhaps best known for two Oscar-winning screenplays, "To Kill a Mockingbird" and "Tender Mercies," Mr. Foote, at 85, goes on writing for the stage. 
 No matter that he presaged the decline of Broadway back in the mid-1950's. That was when he turned to or helped create other stages: off-Broadway and regional theater. And then there was television drama, of the early golden age when plays were performed live, unedited, immediate and unstoppable, to paraphrase Mr. Foote's recollections in "Beginnings," his second memoir, out in November. 
"Of the ever-declining theater, I have written 60 plays by now," Mr. Foote says. And he's still talking of the one to come, while "The Carpetbagger's Children," runs at Hartford Stage.
Chronicling intricate family ties and family wars, the new play belongs to Mr. Foote's increasing series of life and death in Harrison, Tex., his reinvention of Wharton, where he grew up and still resides.
Three elderly sisters are sitting -- truly, they sit, they stare, they sew, they do not get up . An homage to Chekhov is strictly intentional and nowhere comprehensible. Once, actually, there were four, but Beth, the favored one, died young, and mysteriously. Beth is an ever-present ghost; Brother, the unseen fool. 
The surviving sisters talk to the audience, hardly ever to each other. Traversing time, they recollect, in opposing, overlapping versions, the saga of their father, who paid no mind to ethics in his accumulation of 20,000 acres.
As Grace Anne (Jean Stapleton) the eldest sister, tells it, Papa got himself appointed County Treasurer and Tax Collector. Then, when the plantations were breaking up and people couldn't pay their taxes, he grabbed land left and right and held onto it. That's the townspeople's side of the story. 
It's also the side of the rebel, resigned Grace Anne, too. When she ran off with an unworthy man, Papa disinherited her. But but then every man was unworthy. Papa didn't want any of his daughters to marry, the better to keep the estate intact. 
In Mr. Foote's most complete works, details are invariably colorful, sometimes charting a genealogical journey, including cousins once removed. And the story is irrevocably bound to universal truths.
Here, the details are details -- the cotton gin, the neat yards, the lovely flowers, the filling stations that have replaced the big old houses. The truths are a stretch, demanding a search; the motivations, blurred. 
One needn't relate to old-time provincial mores to be touched by lost souls, screaming on the inside, locked into tranquility and repose. Mr. Foote's perennial themes of sisterly rivalry, brotherly mismanagement, divided families squabbling over inequitably divided estates and the catalogue of resentments that come with the territory of blood relationships, always lurk underneath. 
In "The Carpetbagger's Children," the disconnection between dialogue and subtext is traceable to the words. With Michael Wilson, more as spiritual disciple than director, the three actors are quite beyond merely reverential, being so precisely tuned into Mr. Foote's elusive style, as to form a chamber trio. They are masterly storytellers, but their stories are not very involving, interesting or theatrically rooted.
Unlike Ms. Stapleton and, in particular, Hallie Foote, the playwright's daughter, who instinctively draw upon an established Foote repertory, Roberta Maxwell appears to have no such credits on her otherwise considerable resume. You couldn't tell. Ms. Maxwell is possessed of the elegance and cool that define Cornelia, the daughter with the business savvy. Casually controlling, she matter-of-factly calls Grace Anne "jealous-hearted," convincing us she is the story's driving force; that is, until the swelling of emotion overtakes her final moments. If only the hold of "The Carpetbagger's Children" were as steady as the nuanced skills of its interpreters.
Memory plays are a theater staple. But "The Carpetbagger's Children" is all memory, no play; all exposition, no event. Centered on an unseen Confederate con man, and his dotty, delusional wife, it becomes a rarefied study of ruthless people, demanding effort, patience and endurance. In the end, an appreciation of acting style is the evening's reward.
As for tiresomely evoking Chekhov, so handy, so misunderstood, how many playwrights do not not owe a chunk of their art to the Russian master? Mr. Foote has been, not aptly, called "the Chekhov of the small town" often enough as it is.
Mr. Foote's stage work, like the art house or independent film, is for a specialized, some would say an acquired, taste. Even at its finest, the cadences and deceptive simplicity of language, the subtleties and hidden aspects of character are not easy to grasp. 
In its first New York staging, his Pulitzer Prize play, "The Young Man from Atlanta" was not fully realized. A stunning Broadway production followed, starring Rip Torn and Shirley Knight. Armed with star power and Pulitzer prestige, the play did not have box-office appeal.
Perhaps with such economic practicality in mind, even though two other major regional theaters, the Alley in Houston and the Guthrie in Minneapolis, are sharing production costs, Hartford Stage chose "The Carpetbagger's Children" to open an experimental makeshift second stage series. 
The theater, coyly called Stage Too, is reconfigured to hold 340 seats, instead of the customary 489. For this production, folding chairs on platforms against the rear wall of the stage create an in-the-round effect. In the rear, divider units seal off a few rows. Yet the play gains little in closeness; we're talking less than 150 seats in a space that is hardly cavernous in the first place. 
But "The Carpetbagger's Children," strangely structured as it is, suggested a form new even for the unorthodox Mr. Foote. It seemed a longshot for mass appeal. But ticket sales have been lively and the run, which was to have ended Thursday, has been extended until next Sunday. 
It remains for two more Stage Too plays, the next to be designed for 252 seats and a thrust stage, to test intimate exchanges in a simulated theater-within-a-theater. The six-play mainstage season is to go on as ever, Oct. 4 through June 30.
By taking a chance on an unknown new work by a playwright who may be renowned, but isn't easy, Hartford theatergoers are playing an important part in determining the viability of the theater's new venture. 
A test case has been approved. So has a case example of how a lesser play can be perfectly played. One is reminded of Beckett, whose work, even more than Chekhov's, informs Foote's spare style. When told he had failed, Beckett replied: "Next time Ill fail better." 
Hartford Stage, 50 Church Street. Box office: (860) 527-5151.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Roberta Maxwell as Cornelia in Horton Foote's "The Carpetbagger's Children" at Hartford Stage. (T. Charles Erickson)

HEADLINE: Agency Offers a Backup Plan 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE DIGRAZIA 

 BODY:
SUSANNE MURPHY recalls that not too long ago there were not enough substitute teachers to fill in for absent teachers at Ansonia High School.
 "We had days when there were three classes of students in the media center because there were three teachers out that day and no subs to cover for them," said Ms. Murphy, the Ansonia assistant school superintendent. "The biggest problem was that the room had to be closed to other students. It took the library and media center offline. No one could use it for research, which is so vital for learning." 
 These days, Ansonia school officials say they no longer fret over whether they will be able to round up enough substitutes each morning.
Since the 2000-1 school year, the school system has contracted with a temporary employment agency, Kelly Educational Staffing, an off-shoot of Kelly Services, which provides as many substitute teachers as needed on any given day.
"The whole relationship is just perfect," Ms. Murphy said. "We're very, very happy."
Ansonia, like all school systems in Connecticut and the nation, faces the daily difficulty of finding qualified substitute teachers.
According to a survey released in March 2000 by the Substitute Teaching Institute at Utah State University, 96 percent of the nation's school districts face substitute teacher shortages, with the average school district having a daily absentee teacher rate between an 8 and 10 percent.
With Connecticut having one of the nation's lowest numbers of unemployed workers -- the usual pool for substitute teachers -- this all spells trouble when it comes to replacing any of the state's 45,000 teachers, Tom Murphy, the spokesman for the state Department of Education, said. 
"We don't collect statistics, but we're finding more school systems are availing themselves of these temporary services because it's a really efficient way to find the necessary people they need day in and day out," Mr. Murphy said. "When this happens, school districts free up the resources they use in finding those people every morning."
The National Education Association recently surveyed the substitute teacher situation in all 50 states and said Connecticut had "no exemplary substitute teaching programs."
Ms. Murphy can attest to that. She said that Ansonia school officials were dissatisfied with recruitment efforts that produced few, if any, qualified substitute teachers.
"Most of it was word-of-mouth recruitment," she said. "Or teacher candidates we did not hire would get 'sorry' letters that ended by saying, 'If you'd like to substitute teach, let us know.' "
When Kelly Educational Staffing approached the school system in 1999 with details of a program that was already in place in other parts of the country, Ansonia officials were all ears, Ms. Murphy said. Their school system became the first in Connecticut to use Kelly substitutes.
Dr. Ed Favolise, Ansonia's superintendent of schools, said that about 70 Kelly substitute teachers are used each week throughout the school system, totaling about 2,520 a year.
Kelly pays its substitutes the going rate in each municipality, usually ranging from $50 to $100 a day, and charges an administrative fee that varies with each school system.
Jeffrey Whone, the Ansonia schools business manager, said the school system pays Kelly Services $74.25 per substitute teacher. Of that amount, the substitute receives $60. He said Ansonia's budget for substitute teachers for the 2001-2 school year was $100,000. 
Ten school districts in Connecticut, including Meriden, Branford, East Haven and Woodbridge, use Kelly Educational Staffing, and three contracts are pending, said JoAnn Ryan, the district manager of Kelly Services in Waterbury.
"At the height of this year in my district, which includes Litchfield, Middlesex and New Haven counties, we'll place between 150 and 200 substitutes a day," Ms. Ryan said.
Ms. Ryan said that Kelly's substitutes meet local certification requirements, which include holding a bachelor's degree, and must submit to fingerprinting and background checks if requested by the school system.
"We also relieve the school system of the hiring, recruiting, advertising, training, orientation, scheduling, payroll and retention issues," Ms. Ryan said.
She said that Kelly's substitute-teacher pool in Connecticut was filled with retirees, people who want to change careers, and stay-at-home mothers looking to get back to work.
While Kelly apparently has answered the needs of the Ansonia school system, there are still some people who scoff at the idea of using "temps" to fill in for teachers.
Shirley Kirsten, president of the National Substitute Teachers Association in Washington, said that the responsibility of recruiting, referral and placement of substitute teachers belonged with the school district, not Kelly Educational Staffing. 
"Kelly is a for-profit agency whose goal is to maximize profit," Ms. Kirsten said. "Whereas the school district rests on a very different foundation or premise: that of educating students. Some school districts that have contracted with Kelly to place substitutes have paid up to $30 in fees per subs that are not passed down to the subs."
She said, for example, that in Chicopee, Mass., the school district pays Kelly $95.90 for a substitute, who then receives only $70.
Ms. Murphy said that there had been no concerns raised by the Ansonia teachers' union.
But Luba Soldra, president of Ansonia's teachers' union, said the union was "not thrilled" with the arrangement with Kelly Services.
"The reality is, we had no choice," Ms. Soldra said. "The Board of Education believed it was a financial decision, but we don't buy that because a clause in the teachers' contract ties substitute pay to teachers' severance pay. So, whenever we talked about raising the pay for subs, it always came back to the severance pay issue. If they can keep the sub pay down, they don't have to increase severance pay. Rather than change that, they hired Kelly Services."
Ms. Ryan of Kelly Services said: "We try to talk to the unions to stress that this is a service we are not only providing to school systems, but to teachers and subs as well. We're helping by offering the substitutes resources, training and orientation."
Out of 1,600 Kelly substitutes across the nation, Kelly chose Jane Barth of Ansonia as the National Substitute Teacher of the Year for the 2000-1 school year, an award that brought Ms. Barth a $250 gift certificate.
Ms. Barth, who was a stay-at-home mother with a bachelor's degree in psychology before she became a substitute teacher in Ansonia schools, said not too much had changed since Kelly took over.
"The pay is the same," she said. "I just get called by a Kelly person every morning instead of someone in the school system."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jane Barth, selected the National Substitute Teacher of the Year, teaching at a school in Ansonia. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: One Man's Vision: The Tappan Tunnel 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON 

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN 

 BODY:
ABOUT a year ago, Alexander Saunders began showing up at community meetings with his outlandish proposal to replace the aging Tappan Zee Bridge with a seven-mile tunnel, from the Palisades Mall to Elmsford.
The bridge project is a sensitive one here, and at first Mr. Saunders's Tappan Tunnel idea served mostly as comic relief.
 But that is changing. 
 Mr. Saunders, 62, a big, wild-eyed man with disheveled hair, a tireless tongue and not an ounce of tunnel construction experience, has been neglecting his foundry supply business to preach his tunnel theory. 
He has discussed it over lunch with John R. Platt, executive director of the New York State Thruway Authority, and over yard work with Gov. George E. Pataki, who is his neighbor in Garrison. He has persuaded major tunnel-boring companies to send representatives to local public forums.
And, to hear state officials tell it, he has succeeded in getting the state to at least consider replacing the Tappan Zee Bridge with a tunnel.
"It's gone from a suggestion out of the blue to becoming something other people believe in strongly," said Mr. Saunders, whom everyone calls Sandy.
Terry O'Brien, a spokesman for the Thruway Authority, said the proposal for a Tappan Tunnel "is on equal footing" with those for bridges.
"The slate's clean and everything is on the table at this point," Mr. O'Brien added. "A tunnel is just as much an option as a bridge. Now we have to see if it makes sense from an engineering, economic and environmental standpoint."
The agency recently selected four consulting firms, three of which are engineering and design consultants with experience building tunnels and bridges worldwide. (The fourth is a public relations company to handle publicity for the process.)
The firms will examine the technology, cost, and environmental impact and benefits of constructing a tunnel, Mr. O'Brien said. "The evaluation process is only in the embryonic stages," he said. "We're going to get as much public input as possible and judge every option on its merits."
The Tappan Zee Bridge is 45 years old and suffering from corrosion, cracks and other structural problems requiring costly daily maintenance. Last year, a state task force recommended replacing the bridge with a new, wider one. The Thruway Authority, which is responsible for the bridge, is conducting a three-year study to determine whether to replace or rehabilitate it.
According to the agency's preliminary estimates, it would cost $1.1 billion to rehabilitate the current bridge, and about the same to replace it. A new bridge, with one added lane and room for a commuter rail line, would cost about $1.5 billion. (A rehabilitated bridge could not accommodate a rail line at all.)
A much larger project, which would include building an extensive passenger rail line linking Stewart Airport to Metro-North, would cost an estimated $4.5 billion. The state says that no decision will be made until 2004, and no project will be completed until at least 2010.
Mr. Saunders insists that with modern tunnel-boring machines, the kind used in Europe to build the Chunnel and other major tunnels, a Tappan Tunnel could be built faster and at lower cost than a replacement bridge. And, he says, it would require far less maintenance and would last longer.
Basically, he envisions two parallel tubes starting at the Palisades Mall exit of the Thruway and passing through Nyack a bit south of the Thruway. They would cross the Hudson about 500 feet south of the present bridge, and surface at Exit 8 on Interstate 287, in Elmsford.
Each tube would have three or four lanes of roadway on an upper level and a track on a lower one, for passengers and freight. Mr. Saunders favors a train line connecting Metro-North to the CSX West Shore Line in Rockland County, a freight line currently being considered for conversion to a commuter rail.
Tunnel depth would vary: from some 50 feet below sea level when crossing the river banks, to 140 feet deep at its lowest point, beneath the main channel of the river. Mr. Saunders, basing his estimates on the prices for many European tunnel projects, speculates that his seven-mile tunnel would cost about $1.4 billion.
Modern tunnels are safe, he said, cost less than roadways and bridges to maintain, and last 50 years longer than the typical bridge and road projects. He said his idea is only far-fetched in that the state has never seriously considered a tunnel option before.
Actually, Mr. Saunders's crusade goes beyond a Hudson crossing. Replacing the bridge alone, he insists, would hardly solve the congestion that extends for miles in either direction from the bridge, including I-287, the Cross Westchester Expressway.
"Replacing the Tappan Zee Bridge with a tunnel is a no-brainer," he said. "I realize people think a tunnel across Westchester is far-fetched, but the more they learn about it, the less far-fetched it is."
He envisions a tunnel that would extend the roughly 10 miles across Westchester, to run beneath and replace I-287. 
His ultimate vision is a 45-mile passage, crossing from Rockland to Westchester and under Long Island Sound to the North Shore of Long Island. This Grand Ring, as he calls it, from Suffern to Syosset, would cost around $10 billion, Mr. Saunders said.
"A Tappan Tunnel would be a great first step, but traffic in New Jersey, Westchester and Long Island is going to be a continuing mess, and we need a larger solution," he said. The land now occupied by I-287 -- "millions and millions of dollars in expensive real estate" -- could be restored to local communities for parks or development, he said.
Mr. Saunders has discussed his proposals in public meetings and at news conferences. Though his Tappan Tunnel idea draws serious interest, his Grand Ring idea is pretty much relegated to the realm of novelty, appealing mostly to frustrated commuters and science fiction fans.
The Tappan Tunnel proposal, however, has caused quite a buzz around the village of Tarrytown in recent months, its mayor, Paul Janos, said, adding, "People here really think it's worth looking into, for the environment, for traffic reasons and for the Hudson."
Mr. Saunders has presented his ideas to Governments United in Action for Responsible Development, a coalition of elected officials from 25 local municipalities along I-287. The group, known as Guard, wants the bridge repaired, said Sherwood B. Chorost, a founder and a Tarrytown trustee. But if this is not feasible, he added, the group would like to see a tunnel built because "it just makes sense."
"A tunnel shows real promise," he said. "It's not on the average person's radar screen, but there are many positives. It would help the air quality and the noise problem. It seems to win on all counts.
"Just picture what that river would look like if you erased that steel monster," he said.
Overall, tunnel experts say that a Tappan Tunnel would be rather straightforward to build. But they also agreed on the obstacles: financial, political and one of public acceptance.
"This is no futuristic Buck Rogers idea," said Albert Appleton, a senior fellow for the Regional Plan Association in Manhattan. "In Europe, a tunnel like this would be considered as a matter of course. To the extent that it is seen as off-the-wall, all that goes away once the first one is built here."
Mr. Appleton directed the association's successful four-year campaign to get the state to consider building a four-mile tunnel to replace the Gowanus Expressway, from the Verrazano Bridge to the Battery Tunnel.
At first, he said the proposal "had to pass the laugh test." But public forums, constant contact with state legislators, and the creation of detailed tunnel reports all helped raise consciousness enough to get the state's consideration. The Gowanus Tunnel would consist of at least two tubes, holding eight lanes of traffic. According to preliminary estimates, rebuilding the highway would cost $1.5 billion, and a tunnel would cost $3.5 billion.
Mr. Saunders said he came up with his tunnel ideas while traveling in Europe, where large tunnels are common. In the past year or so, he has swamped state officials with tunnel information. He said that although Governor Pataki's office has never officially responded to his letters, the governor is well-acquainted with the tunnel plan. Mr. Pataki was hiking by Mr. Saunders's farm recently and stopped by to chat, Mr. Saunders said.
"I said, 'Governor, I'm keeping your staff well acquainted with my ideas for the Tappan Zee Bridge study.' He looked up and said, 'No, Sandy, you mean the Tappan Tunnel study.' "
State and county transportation officials have attended local meetings organized by Mr. Saunders. At one such meeting in Tarrytown in May, Mr. Saunders introduced a panel of tunnel consultants and representatives from tunnel-boring machine companies.
One such company was Herrenknecht, a German manufacturer of tunnel-boring machines. 
The Herrenknecht official suggested using a machine with a 50-foot diameter, weighing about 1,300 tons and costing more than $50 million to build, deliver and assemble. It simultaneously digs and builds a tunnel at the rate of about 40 to 50 feet per day in gravel-sand soil, which is found under the Hudson.
Propelled by hydraulics, the huge rotary cutter excavates material and passes it to rail cars and out of the tunnel. It then immediately cases the tunnel in concrete. The excavated gravel could be used to make the concrete for the tubes, and sold to defray costs, Mr. Saunders said.
A handful of residents attended the meeting, and at first, many were bewildered and skeptical. But halfway into the meeting, the skepticism gave way to curious questions to the panelists about various tunnel-boring techniques. ("What do you do with all the dirt?" and "What are the machine's blades made out of?")
Experts say that tunnel-boring technology has come of age, with the use of computer-operated tunnel cutters, but America is far behind Europe and the Far East in terms of using it.
The 31-mile Channel Tunnel, or Chunnel, connecting England to France was completed in 1995 and cost about $15 billion. (It is a rail tunnel only, and narrower than what Mr. Saunders proposes.) The St. Gotthard Tunnel is a 9.3-mile-long railway tunnel with two tubes, running through the Swiss Alps. It cost $10 billion.
The Westerschelde is a 3.7-mile tunnel connecting Holland to Antwerp Harbor in Belgium. It has two tubes, each 36 feet wide with three traffic lanes, and it runs more than 200 feet below sea level. It cost $750 million and took about three years to build.
In a phone interview, Martin Herrenknecht, who owns the Herrenknecht company, estimated that a tunnel like the one Mr. Saunders envisions would take three years to build.
One obstacle would be selecting a company with enough experience in large tunnel projects, he said.
"It would be no problem building it," he said, "but for an American company to take on something of this size, they'd need a joint venture with an experienced European firm. The U.S. is at least 10 years behind Europe and Japan in building tunnels."
Mr. Saunders dropped out of a graduate engineering program at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to work for his family business. For all his futuristic visions, he freely admits that he is hardly technology-oriented. He is still struggling to set up his cell phone voice mail, and his wife sorts through scraps of paper to find phone numbers.
"I'm a handwriting person," said Mr. Saunders, who is friendly with Pete Seeger and was the first president of the Clearwater Organization, a Hudson Valley environmental group, and with his father helped found another environmental group, Scenic Hudson. His other causes include a crusade to erect a monument to the buffalo out West.
The tunnel idea, he insists, is his latest conservation effort. He speaks of highways as "barbaric desecrations" of the land, arguing that a Tappan Tunnel would eliminate the intrusion that a bridge and roadways have made on the environment. Also, the tunnel would have a system to cleanse car exhaust of pollutants. 
Long a champion of the public process, Mr. Saunders now wonders if Nimby-ism might work against his project, one he calls the "boldest and most imaginative and sweeping project in this region in several decades."
"Things have changed," he said. "Never has there been so much public negativity about anything. Public review policies have empowered the public to just arbitrarily say 'no' and feel they're right. There's so much discussion that nothing can get done.
"You used to have a level of positive excitement and a willingness to spend money on bold, grand projects -- going to the moon, the World's Fair -- a level of excitement where people get enthusiastic about seeing something happen, but now people say 'no' because it's easier to say.
"It makes you wonder if even something like Yankee Stadium could get built today," he continued. "Could we have built the Interstate highway system in our time? Or the Central Railroad? I'm not sure Robert Moses could have done it today. You have to devote too much to politics to making it happen."
Nowhere in this region, or even this country, is there a tunnel of the magnitude of the one Mr. Saunders proposes. The question remains: is it practical?
"Is this feasible? It is certainly is," said Randall J. Essex, a vice president of Hatch Mott MacDonald, a tunnel engineering firm that worked on the Chunnel. "This kind of project has been done elsewhere for years. The question is: is it cost-effective? Tunnels are generally more expensive to build than bridges, but there are benefits for quality of life of people around it."
Mr. Saunders's crusade is well known in the close-knit tunnel-building industry, Mr. Essex said, adding, "These kind of projects start with passionate advocates." 
To get a large tunnel project built, he said, it is crucial to make it a priority in the region and to win support from state government officials, no mean feat. "You can't expect state D.O.T.'s in this country to know anything about tunneling," he said.
"Then to obtain federal funding, you've got to have someone championing this project in Congress or the Senate," he said.
Other ambitious tunnel proposals have been kicking around the region for years, including the Gowanus Expressway proposal. There is also the decades-old plan for a freight tunnel under New York Harbor from New Jersey to Brooklyn. Boston is currently in the middle of its so-called "Big Dig," a large underground highway (about half of the 7.8-mile corridor is underneath the city) scheduled to be completed by 2004. The project was originally budgeted at $3 billion, but was expanded and increased in scope to $14.4 billion.
While some speak of mammoth tunnels as a thing of the future, they are really a thing of the past, at least in this area. No major ones have been built here in the last half-century.
The Holland, Lincoln and Battery Tunnels were all built before World War II.
In fact, the Tappan Tunnel idea actually predates the Tappan Zee Bridge. In the 1930's, a decade before the bridge was even on the drawing board, a tunnel was proposed by a Rockland assemblyman, Frederick R. Horn. In 1933, he began holding public meetings. 
Engineers from the Reliance Construction Company prepared a preliminary proposal to build a two-lane tunnel to be built in 300-foot sections on land and then floated out, connected and sunk down to the river bed.
"Now is the opportune time for the construction of this tunnel," the proposal said.
But even today, many transportation experts are skeptical that the state would agree to build a Tappan Tunnel. As feasible as it is to build, it would be difficult to even get considered, much less approved.
Jeffrey M. Zupan, a senior fellow for transportation at the Regional Plan Association in Manhattan, said it would be difficult to get the state to approve a tunnel project, even if it were the best overall proposal.
"Governments tend to be conservative," he said, adding that factors like economic downturns, as well as tax and toll increases, would be discouraging.
Thomas J. Abinanti, a county legislator, also favors examining the tunnel proposal, but agrees that it could well be undone by the political process.
"It makes too much sense, so it probably won't happen," said Mr. Abinanti, a Democrat who represents the area around the Westchester side of the bridge and has been outspoken in calling for ways to solve congestion. "I think we ought to study it very seriously."
In terms of financing, a Tappan Tunnel project would certainly take a back seat to other transportation construction projects with much more support in the metropolitan area: a Long Island Rail Road link to Grand Central Terminal, a Second Avenue subway in Manhattan, the Brooklyn rail freight tunnel and an expanded commuter rail line to New Jersey and Rockland County.
And one factor that might discourage the state from even considering Mr. Saunders's tunnel proposal is that the Thruway Authority is in the middle of a $187 million project to reconfigure I-287 near the Tappan Zee Bridge. It is the authority's largest reconstruction plan ever.
Nevertheless, Mr. Saunders insists that increased awareness among the public and politicians will help bring the idea to the table.

His tenacity has led the New York State Thruway Authority to put his Tappan Tunnel proposal on the table along with those for bridges.
