HEADLINE: The Early Education Of a Wine Taster 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

 BODY:
SINCE boyhood, the memory of fiveoclocksupper -- thought of as one word, like Presidentroosevelt -- has regulated my instincts. Even though dinner now ranges from 7 to 9 p.m., hunger automatically glances at my watch at 5.
 In Newark's poor Central Ward in the 1940's, we didn't eat dinner on weekdays. We ate supper, usually at 5 o'clock, 5:30 at the latest, on weekdays. The same recipe, when served on Saturday at 6 or Sunday at 4, when company came, was called dinner. 
 In a federal housing project, where I was raised for six years, if the dishes weren't washed and put away by 7 o'clock, something was suspiciously wrong. One couple who ate late and owned rooms full of books were thought to be Communists. 
Fiveoclocksupper implied an All-American evening ritual: fathers, workingmen all (mine was a shoe salesman), would drag home, wash up, eat at 5, put on slippers, read the sports and war news in The Newark Evening News, listen to the ball game and go to sleep.
From Monday to Friday, wine was as beyond my ken as the gossip columnists' beloved madcap heiresses who swigged cocktails in the Stork Club. Newark was famously a brewery town, and Dad favored Krueger's. Although ads implied that if the home front drank enough Coke the Nazis would lose, the rest of the family thrived on grape soda, sarsaparilla, birch beer and root beer. 
If supper, on oilcloth, was routine, dinner was ceremonial. A table was opened in the parlor and given an embroidered cloth. Dishes materialized from high kitchen shelves. Silverware emerged from a felt-lined box. Stemmed goblets appeared, to be filled with an all-purpose (fish, chicken, meat) kosher wine, Mogen David, a sweet Concord red, especially on holidays.
It was this wine and the tart Concord grape, which tastes like its wine (not all grapes do), that started my informal wine education. A Concord arbor behind my paternal grandparents' house in Long Branch, N.J., an old seaside resort, smelled swooningly delicious in high September.
Although the arbor dated to Prohibition, which put Grandpa's liquor store out of business, he, unlike Italian neighbors, didn't make wine: Grandma disapproved of any pleasure. Like clockwork, we all sat down to supper at 5 o'clock. Afterward, as they schmoozed on front-porch rockers, with Grandpa's connivance I stole grapes from fat clusters that soon became jelly kept cool in a dirt basement. Sometimes the juice started fermenting on the vine.
In Newark, on holidays and sometimes on the Sabbath we drank semidry raisin wine that my maternal grandmother, who lived with us, made in autumn. The fermentation aroma filled the house and made a lasting impression, as did the wine's piquancy and golden color. 
The only other really impressive wine I ever encountered in Newark was sweet plum stuff in an upstairs Chinese restaurant whose full dinners ran from 75 cents to $1.25, and, once, something French in a famous, ritzy restaurant beyond our means called the Tavern, where at lunch we celebrated my graduation from grammar school. 
My formal wine education began when the word aperitif, so rich in connotations of the Good Life, penetrated my awareness as a Rutgers freshman. 
The idea that wine tasted dry (who ever heard of a thing?) and could, after 5 p.m., actually stimulate rather than retard an appetite was a bombshell. My first glass of dry sherry, a nutty fino, at a fraternity brother's Park Avenue South apartment in Manhattan, was a divine revelation; thereafter, a glass of sweet Gallo muscatel at the Corner Tavern, a hangout in New Brunswick, held no interest.
The occasional students from France were so nonchalant about a glass of Pommard that their urbanity seemed unfathomable. (National habits never die: A student from the London School of Economics was overbearing about claret.) Aside from learning how to affect world weariness while holding a Pall Mall at a 45-degree angle, for me an enduring freshman lesson was that a swell red like Pommard needn't always be a big deal. 
College life brought countless thirsts and sea changes. Although I ascended to Chianti by graduation, beer had triumphed. Wine went underground until, 18 years later, I rediscovered it, in German rieslings. Since then, almost daily a wish for a dry kabinett or dry spatlese has arisen, invariably signaling the arrival of, no surprise, 5 o'clock.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
New Strains, But Nothing The System Can't Handle

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
INVESTORS, rendered speechless by terrorists last week, will get their voice back at 9:30 a.m. tomorrow, when trading resumes for the first time since last Monday. Almost certainly, they will not be in a sunny mood. But how bleak they feel will be a matter of intense interest and conjecture.
 James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, assessed the market impact even as he righted himself from the tragedy last week: stranded in Denver for two days, Mr. Paulsen spoke from a rental car somewhere in Nebraska as he headed home. Following are excerpts from the conversation. 

Q.Some have argued that the world became a fundamentally different place last Tuesday. Do you agree?

A. I don't see this as a systemic event that is going to create long-term fundamental economic problems. We will have short-term problems as a consequence of what happened, but if nothing else happens there will not be warlike distortions that have no determining end.
Certain industries will be impacted for quite some time. But fairly quickly the undertone of the economy in general will move to the front burner again.

Q. Which industries will be hurt?

A. The insurance industry will be impacted. Insurance claims stemming from the attacks are estimated at $25 billion to $30 billion. To put that in perspective, the tax rebate this year amounts to $38 billion. So those claims are going to have a significant impact on insurance stocks. The airline industry will be significantly impacted, even after they get planes in the air. The energy industry will feel this, because a big component of fuel usage is jet fuel, and that will go down. For the short term, earnings of the financial industry will be impacted, primarily the asset management and brokerage communities.

Q. Will shaken consumer confidence be a drag on the economy?

A. The attacks will impact consumers over the next couple of months. But the biggest challenge is not this as much as it is the loss of jobs. The unemployment rate might be headed to 5.5 percent.

Q. Is there any good news coming out of what happened last week?

A. Even without the crisis, the economy was heading into recession. The good thing about this situation is that it is bringing a lot of monetary and fiscal stimulus to the forefront right now. Without the attacks, it would have taken a much longer period of time to get this kind of stimulus.

Q. The Federal Reserve pumped a lot of liquidity into the banking system last week, but it did not cut short-term interest rates. Do you expect that to happen soon?

A. I still expect the Fed will cut rates in the next couple of days. They may want to wait until the New York Stock Exchange opens on Monday before they go.
The bond market is certainly expecting a cut. On Thursday, three-month Treasury bill rates were trading at 2.75 percent, which is three-quarters of a percentage point under the overnight federal funds rate. So the markets are looking for a cut of at least one-quarter of a point, and maybe half a point.

Q. Could interest rates go even lower?

A. Fear and arguments about recession are going to be with us for the year. It will take mortgage rates at 6 percent to promote a full-fledged refinancing cash-flow cycle, something that creates much more stimulus than any tax cut. A 6 percent mortgage implies a 4 percent, 10-year Treasury note, which in turn implies a federal funds rate of 2 percent to 2.5 percent. It is possible we will get to that point sometime next year.

Q. What do you advise?

A. There are ways what happened last week could escalate, but at this point I am optimistic this is not going to be an ongoing event that will disrupt the economy. But if you want to dream up the worst-case scenario, there is probably no better place than cash in your mattress or gold.
More realistically, it depends what investors were doing in the period leading up to this tragedy. If you were overweight equities, it might be time to buy some bonds. If you were way overweighted in consumer cyclical stocks and in retailers, reduce your allocation there. But if you were already defensive, I wouldn't do much. And if the stock market moves much lower, I would be moving back into stocks. And in times of economic crisis, larger-company stocks tend to do better than small-company stocks.

Q. What areas interest you?

A. We have been very focused on noneconomic sensitive sectors like consumer staples and health care. They look very exciting if retailing and capital goods are suffering without any leverage from the economy. And we are looking at interest-sensitive areas that pay dividends, like utilities, high-quality financial service stocks and integrated oil companies.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volkswagen Lupo; 
A Thrifty Spin in a 99 M.P.G. Car

 BODY:
IN Italian, lupo means wolf, but for much of Europe it also denotes the smallest car in Volkswagen's litter. The Lupo 3 Liter TDI is also VW's most efficient. "Three liter" stands not for engine displacement or size, but for fuel efficiency: three liters per 100 kilometers in European measure, or 99 miles a gallon.
 That figure was the four-minute mile of fuel efficiency. With the Lupo 3 Liter, Volkswagen beat Opel, Renault, Fiat and other automakers to seize the bragging rights for selling the first, and so far only, production vehicle to reach this miserly pinnacle. 
 Last year, a fleet of Lupo 3 Liters drove around the world in 80 days, averaging better than 99 m.p.g. But their passage across the United States was barely noted. Today, however, with fuel prices moving higher (although American gasoline remains laughably low to Europeans), the Lupo might get more attention. 
Could a car like this -- with its sophisticated turbocharged direct-injection diesel engine and astonishing fuel numbers -- be practical for the American lifestyle? President Bush's advisers have declared 80 m.p.g. an unrealistic goal, perhaps because the target was set by the Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles set up by the Clinton administration.
VW has no plans to sell the Lupo -- which comes in several guises in Europe, including a hot GTI -- in the United States. Volkswagen does sell a 90-horsepower, four-cylinder version of the TDI engine in North America in Golfs, Jettas and New Beetles, and the manual-transmission Beetle gets 49 m.p.g. on the highway.
As so-called Tier 1 vehicles under California's complex clean-air regulations, TDI's are limited to 3,000 units of each model per model year. Similar restrictions apply in New York, part of a Northeast consortium of states that follow the California rules. VW sold its 2001 consignment of 11,000 by June; the 2002's are now arriving.
The engine in the Lupo 3 Liter, however, is nearly twice as clean as the larger TDI.
The Lupo is slightly shorter than the Suzuki Swift but feels roomier inside. It is smaller than the VW Polo sold outside North America, which is tinier still than the Golf, the smallest VW sold in the United States. 
To get 99 m.p.g., VW made the Lupo light. In the 3 Liter, VW engineers used aluminum and magnesium wherever possible, including in the hood. They reduced the power drawn by accessories. There is no power steering. The windows must be cranked, and the mirrors must be adjusted by hand. The Lupo does, however, offer air-conditioning, and unlike the power-robbing units on small cars like the old Chevy Metro, once the star of Florida rental fleets, the Lupo's system does not offer a stark choice between acceleration and refrigeration.
VW also honed the aerodynamics of the round-face vehicle. But the Lupo hit the three-liter mark primarily by using a diesel -- and not a rugged, old-fashioned, sooty diesel, but a newer turbocharged direct-injection diesel with a computer chip to regulate its breathing.
The Lupo 3 Liter is available across Europe, where a third of all new cars -- and well over half all luxury cars -- are diesels. The owner's manual offers service addresses from Manchester to Minsk.
Hitting the three-liter average while meeting emissions standards depends on using low-sulfur diesel. The test car came already filled, with warnings not to add American diesel, which has a higher sulfur content -- up to 300 parts per million, compared with European standards that range as low as 10 parts per million -- and therefore produces higher sulfur dioxide emissions. VW would like to see all the sulfur removed from diesel -- Sweden sells fuel as low as 10 parts per million -- but it tunes the TDI's sold in the United States to the fuel here.
Diesels, you may recall from middle-school science class, are the oldest form of internal combustion engine and ignite from simple fuel compression, no spark needed. They are simpler and have fewer parts than do gasoline engines and therefore are more durable.
The Lupo raises these questions: Is diesel a potentially comparatively quick solution for reducing fuel consumption? Is it at least a short-term measure before hydrogen or fuel cells or other technologies mature and their supporting infrastructure is put in place?
Passenger-car diesel has a mixed record in the United States. Its image suffers from association with 18-wheel tractor-trailers whose smokestacks gush clouds of soot and memories of the erratic diesels General Motors offered in the late 1970's. Even VW's American-built diesel Rabbits of the early 1980's were only partly successful.
Diesels inspire memories of slow winter starts, sluggish performance and shuddering at idle. But the TDI is a different animal. In the Golf or Jetta, it runs so smoothly -- without any "dieseling" vibration -- and accelerates so avidly as to be almost indistinguishable from a gasoline motor. 
The turbo direct-injection engine, a 1.2-liter three-cylinder, makes about 61 horses. It comes equipped with a version of the Tiptronic transmission, developed by Porsche, which runs in either an automatic or clutchless manual. But it idles less smoothly than does the larger TDI available in the New Beetle, Golf or Jetta. It does not offer the low-end response one might like on the 100-foot merge ramps onto some of the New York area's main arteries. 
Additional fuel economy is provided by the start-stop function. After three seconds at a stop light, the engine switches off, as it does in hybrid gasoline-electrics like the Toyota Prius. (The engine automatically and seamlessly starts back up when the accelerator is pressed.) 
To activate this feature the driver pushes the "eco" button, cleverly hidden among the climate controls. The feature is disconcerting at first but the driver's manual reports, "You will be happy to realize that one can very quickly get used to this driving style." What one cannot become used to is the Lupo's kinky power curve, with its lurching gaps between gears that see the engine drop from 2,800 revolutions per minute, to 2,000, for instance, as the unit shifts from first to second.
The interior wears the familiar Braun-Krups black Bauhaus look of other VW's, with cobalt and ruby-lighted instruments. Rear-seat room was not bad, according to a pair of customarily critical teenagers. The Lupo can fit into urban parking places that larger cars have to pass by, though maneuvering the car to within the customary Manhattan millimeter of a neighbor's bumper was more difficult without power steering. 
An m.p.g. needle gauge, similar to one that is standard in BMW's, is supplied, and in addition, the test car was run with a fuel computer that measured m.p.g. -- immediate and average -- and other variables. At cruise, the needle showed us above the three-liter mark and even with much idle time on the helix to the Lincoln Tunnel and other sluggish traffic funnels, the Lupo averaged around 62 m.p.g. over several days of driving -- a better real-world figure than even the Honda or Toyota hybrids.
In the New York area, the price of a gallon of diesel fuel is generally about 15 cents higher than that of regular gasoline. At one service station in suburban New Jersey, for example, a gallon of regular gas cost $1.56; diesel was $1.70. The price in the New York area is usually greater than that in regions like the Midwest, which have large farm economies and are laced with long-haul truck routes.
With its German plate number beginning WOB, for Wolfsburg, the test Lupo caught the eyes of many passers-by. Just so no one missed the fact it was a green car, the tester came in a hue charitably described as early spring grass and familiar to fans of certain Dodge muscle cars of the late 1960's.
"Is it Mopar?" asked one curious man, a Corvette owner. "A good commuter car for someone, I guess," he added doubtfully. On an adjacent lane of Route 46 in New Jersey, a man in a new Passat honked appreciatively and offered a thumbs up. A woman in Manhattan's West Village asked about the Lupo, then reminisced about her old Beetles. Another man was led to recall fondly his trusty VW diesel Dasher.
Several people swore they would buy one if it were offered for sale. Many used the word "cute." 
When VW introduced the TDI in 1995, the response was underwhelming. Now, it looks smart. VW plans a new, cleaner generation of the engine for the 2004 model year. The new engines will have four valves, instead of two, per cylinder and finer injection spray, for cleaner, more efficient combustion. Volkswagen is also planning a large diesel for its forthcoming D-1 luxury model, with 10 cylinders arranged like a W. Other makers are returning to diesel; the most powerful engine on BMW's new 7 series will be a diesel; it will be available only in Europe.
VW engineers say that relatively little work on the catalytic converter and particulate filter can improve diesel emissions significantly, and Federal regulations for 2006 will reduce the amount of sulfur in American diesel fuel. Wolfsburg's wolf may one day mature into a larger beast.

INSIDE TRACK: It's not so amazing that it was done well, but that it was done at all.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 23, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An automobile review of the Volkswagen Lupo 3 Liter TDI last Sunday misstated the American equivalent of its European mileage rating. Three liters per 100 kilometers, an overall figure for combined city and highway driving, is the equivalent of 78 miles per gallon, although VW says the car has achieved 99 miles per gallon in highway driving under ideal conditions. The reviewer's byline was also omitted. He was Phil Patton.

SECTION: Section 14; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 1298 words

HEADLINE: THE FRAGILE CITY; 
'These Fantasies Have Been Horribly Realized'

BYLINE:  By MIKE WALLACE; Mike Wallace is distinguished professor of history at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, director of the Gotham Center for New York City History, and author, with Edwin G. Burrows, of "Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898."

 BODY:
THE hijacked planes that zeroed in on New York and Washington with such murderous accuracy obviously chose their targets for a reason. They didn't attack Los Angeles and Miami, after all. Why not? It's reasonable to assume that they chose cities and buildings that they believed had great symbolic and actual potency: the respective headquarters of the military and financial institutions whose decisions have tremendous impact throughout the globe.
 As we've seen from the outpouring of support from around the world, millions of people love and admire the United States and its pre-eminent urban centers. But others hate us passionately. Not, despite President Bush, because we are the land of the free and good, but because the nation has embraced policies from which they feel they've suffered. Driven by calculated strategy and suicidal fanaticism, they've dealt a terrific blow to proud towers and command centers alike. 
 New Yorkers are rolling with the blow magnificently, despite the added shock of having it come both figuratively and literally out of the clear blue sky, shattering our sense of invulnerability. But that sense always rested on a truncated reading of history. While the particular form of the attack was fiendishly novel, New York, over nearly four centuries, has repeatedly been the object of murderous intentions. Through a combination of luck and power, we have escaped many of the intended blows, but not all of them, and our forebears often feared that worse might yet befall them. 
The Colonial town was utterly vulnerable to attack by sea. Its citizenry worried about being bombarded by warships of the contending European empires seeking to seize its harbor and hinterland. Had not the English captured the Dutch village in 1664 simply by pointing ships' cannons at the wooden houses? 
In 1776, when the city and country rebelled, the English invaded New York in history's largest amphibious landing to that point. That led to the destruction of a large part of the town, the flight of almost all its inhabitants and its further devastation by occupying British troops.
The postwar city rebounded miraculously. But the memory lived on to spur a mammoth outpouring of citizen volunteers to strengthen the city's defenses against the British during the 1812 war, though in the end it was Washington that was attacked and sacked. 
During the 19th century there were few external threats of consequence. Confederate sappers did infiltrate the city in 1864 from Canada. They planted bombs in the big hotels and theaters, hoping to incinerate the entire town, but the fires were contained and the worst averted. Far greater damage was wrought during the 1800's by our own violent internal divisions, most horrifically the great draft riots of 1863. 
There were, however, ill wishers aplenty outside the city. As New York had developed into the nation's financial capital, many in the South and West came to deeply resent what they depicted as their colonial subordination to Wall Street. Others detested the immigrants piling into Gotham's slums. 
The Charleston Courier roared that the headquarters of "merchants and Mammon-worshippers" should "be blotted from the list of cities." And in 1860 a Southerner wrote a fantasy novel that imagined Gotham destroyed after an urban Armageddon that pitted working-class Irish against the city's business classes (an eerie prefiguring of the draft riots to come).
In the late 19th century, Western and Southern populist opponents of the "Money Power" in New York drew on its tradition of violent internal clashes to pen apocalyptic fantasies describing a city consumed by orgies of violence. One envisioned war between an "Oligarchy" of capitalists and a proletarian "Brotherhood of Destruction," culminating in a quarter-million corpses being stacked in Union Square. 
Inside the city, there were fears that anarchists, a handful of whom had made windy pronouncements about dynamiting the city's elite, might yet blow the place up. There were virtually no such incidents until a hellish explosion ripped Wall Street in 1920 (with the House of Morgan and the Stock Exchange the likely targets, though no perpetrators were identified).
 WITH World War I, there were again real foreign foes to contend with, and old anxieties about vulnerability to assault from the sea (and now the air) returned with a vengeance. Again, New York -- a financial and industrial powerhouse -- seemed the chief target. Propagandists concocted lurid posters, one of which depicted the city under air attack, with Lower Manhattan in flames, while a U-boat lurked near the ruins of the Statue of Liberty, its severed head half submerged.
But apart from a spectacular blowup of a munitions dump on a New Jersey wharf that shook skyscrapers and shattered glass in Times Square, defenses proved more than adequate. Similarly in World War II, a reported (but false) sighting of enemy bombers two days after Pearl Harbor engendered panic, and German submarines prowling the coastline kept tensions high (the enemy, said F.D.R. in 1942, could "come in and shell New York tomorrow night, under certain conditions"). The city again seemed a logical target, as it played a crucial role in convoying soldiers and supplies to Europe. In the end, however, coordinated air and sea patrols kep the city inviolate.
The Cold War and the arrival of nuclear weapons touched off a new round of fears, as 1940's writers and artists repeatedly hypothesized an atomic bomb being dropped on Manhattan. In 1945 Reader's Digest noted it was "now in the power of the atom-smashers to blot out New York with a single bomb. Such a bomb can burn up in an instant every creature, can fuse the steel buildings and smash the concrete into flying shrapnel." 
By 1947 the magazine contemplated the added devastation of radioactive fallout. Its article "Mist of Death Over New York" imagined a nuclear explosion in the harbor that, within six weeks, would leave 389,101 New Yorkers dead or missing. Again, the presumption was that the Russians would attack New York on both symbolic and strategic grounds.
In recent decades, some opponents of the expanding global cultural and economic order of which New York and Washington were seen as headquarters, turned to terror. The resulting mayhem seldom touched New York's shores -- the first World Trade Center attack was a notable exception -- but fantasies about urban destruction exploded in popular culture. The popularity of cinematic depictions of overseas (or alien) predators wreaking havoc on New York and Washington, with the World Trade Center and Statue of Liberty as attendant casualties, was perhaps also fueled by antagonism to Big Government and Big Corporations.
Now these fantasies have been horribly realized -- one reason that we've repeatedly heard stunned witnesses exclaiming the devastation seemed "unreal" or "just like a movie." This is not to say that terrorists are copycats and that Hollywood's to blame, but rather that cultural producers, like almost everyone else, tend to assume that New York and Washington are the likeliest targets. One consequence of reality having caught up to fiction might be a new reluctance to spin such fantasies -- a reissue of "Independence Day" was just postponed -- though it's equally likely that someone is already hard at work on a mini-series. 
More hopefully, our shattered sense of invulnerability will be replaced by a sober appreciation of the fact that, even as we mourn our casualties, take prudent precautions to prevent similar attacks, help track down and punish those responsible, and reconstruct our city, our generation of New Yorkers, like those that preceded ours, has witnessed and survived a cataclysm even worse than our imaginations had been able to conceive.

HEADLINE: THE FRAGILE CITY; 
'Close-Up Death Ought to Change a City'

BYLINE:  By BARBARA GARSON; Barbara Garson is the author, most recently, of "Money Makes the World Go Around: One Investor Tracks Her Cash Through the Global Economy From Brooklyn to Bangkok and Back."

 BODY:
MY husband phoned to say that an airplane had flown into the World Trade Center. He called a while later about a second plane. "All right, I'll go look," I said. 
 From my back door on the West Side Highway, you'd normally see the two towers clearly. I've always hated them. 
 In fact, as soon as Governor Rockefeller erected them, I announced a plan to unfurl an 80-story banner down each tower labeling them "David and Nelson: Two Big Phalli." (That's not exactly the word I used.) But I never did anything about it, and the two arrogant towers remained standing. 
There was only one, however, by the time I got outside on Tuesday morning. The neighbors were passing around binoculars and helping one another distinguish the black hole from the black smoke.
Then the second tower disappeared. For a moment, someone thought she could smell something acrid. But nothing was blowing as far north as Bethune Street. From where we stood, there was a luminous white cloud where the tower had been. It was beautiful. 
My neighbor Vera gasped, remembering the surrounding buildings. "My grandson goes to Stuyvesant." That was my first visceral sense of real people in those buildings. 
By then people from the World Financial Center were walking up West Street. They'd been evacuated immediately, they told us, and so had everyone at Stuyvesant High School. 
Reassured about her grandson, Vera, a lifelong pacifist, could refocus her anxiety from her grandchild to mankind.
"We're hopeless," she said. "The pacifists will explain that Israel should have done this or that in 1947; England should have done that or this in 1917; yeah, and if they all acted correctly at the Garden of Eden. But if we got to do the whole of history over, we'd make other mistakes. The killing will go on."
My husband called back about dangerous black smoke.
"It's gorgeous out," I said. "Turn off the television."
The next time he was worried about asbestos. It was obvious that I wasn't going to get anything done that day. Besides, I didn't want to miss out on history. So I decided to bike up from the Village to join him on the Upper West Side. 
Traffic in the West Village and Chelsea was just about normal, except that there were more ambulances and, for once, the cars pulled over for them. Midtown traffic was very light. Clumps of people waited patiently outside Penn Station to hear when train service would resume. Office workers stranded outside the subway at Columbus Circle didn't complain. They seemed ready to trade their day-to-day anxieties for a good collective disaster if someone would only give them an assignment. 
As I biked up Eighth Avenue in the autumn sunshine, it annoyed me to think that the world would be watching smoke, rubble and ambulances on CNN. I wish those terrorists could be out here with me to see how beautiful and calm my city is. Twenty blocks from the Trade Center, it's as if you guys didn't exist. 
But that was Tuesday morning before the casualty count started. At that point, the dead seemed to have vanished as magically as the twin towers and as bloodlessly as people in Iraq.
I suppose there will be retaliations, leaving equally unreal people dead in other cities. If I thought that would lead to fewer corpses overall, I guess I'd reluctantly buy it. But I doubt that it will. 
Unfortunately, I can't suggest a more effective or immediately satisfying response. But let's not give completely free rein to machismo. The politicians will go on television saying that America is now stronger, safer, taller and prouder than ever. They'll want a symbol to show our unswerving resolve. 
But so much close-up death ought to change a city somewhat. At least let's not rebuild those same arrogant towers.

HEADLINE: The Economics of Diesel Meets the Politics Fuel 

BYLINE:  By PHIL PATTON 

 BODY:
FOR years, the appeal of diesel-powered cars, primarily their efficiency and durability, was offset by emissions that were generally above those of gasoline autos.
 While low in carbon dioxide and carbon monoxide, diesels produce more nitrous oxide and particulates -- the sooty stuff -- than similar-size gasoline engines. The soot is largely caused by sulfur in the fuel. 
 European law limits the amount of sulfur in diesel. Engines like the Lupo's TDI are built to take advantage of that. Indeed, a modern engine like the Lupo's requires low-sulfur fuel to prevent the fuel injectors from becoming clogged.
A new set of stricter diesel standards, known as Euro 4, goes into effect in Europe in 2005, but Volkswagen's TDI already meets them. VW is working on an even cleaner and more efficient diesel, as well as a particle filter that, unlike current ones, does not have to be regularly changed. Mercedes, BMW and other European manufacturers are also improving diesels, and some industry experts predict diesel cars may account for half Europe's sales by 2010.
In February, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Christine Todd Whitman, endorsed a regulation put in place in the waning days of the Clinton administration that would limit sulfur to 10 parts per million, a tenfold reduction, in most diesel fuel by 2006. Under the existing timetable, 80 percent of all fuel sold will be required to meet the standard by 2006, and the rest by 2010.
The petroleum industry is not happy with the rules, and car makers are split. Some welcome cleaner fuel that would enable them to sell more diesel engines, while others resist installing the new equipment necessary to meet the higher standards.
This includes filters for particulates and catalytic converters to remove nitrous oxide. The National Petrochemical and Refiners Association challenged the rule in court, arguing that it would burden consumers with large price increases and create shortages.
The American Petroleum Institute and the American Trucking Association have both sought delays or revisions. On Aug. 9, the E.P.A. decided to create a panel of industry experts to consider delaying the planned changes. PHIL PATTON

HEADLINE: VIEW; 
An Insignificant Spectator

BYLINE:  By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
HUNDREDS of people stood in front of my Greenwich Village apartment house on Tuesday morning, staring downtown as about a mile away the World Trade Center towers burned and disappeared. The view down the avenue was clear; it has always been a pleasant feature of the neighborhood. And the weather was glorious, if you recall.
 There was something about being this precise distance from the awfulness -- close enough to hear the explosion of the second plane but far enough away not to feel the heat or dodge falling debris -- that felt taunting. In retrospect I summoned an image: an enormous, frightening silhouette of a man, blocking out the sun. "Watch this," it stage whispers. 
 And we did.
The reaction on our street could fairly be described as perplexity, which was, as I look back, the seed of the punishing irrelevance that has been plaguing me since then. No one knew what to do or which way to move. There was something both compelling and repellent about the incredible event taking place in front of our eyes. I mean that literally; it drew you toward it, it pushed you away. You wanted to race downtown at top speed to bear witness; you wanted to turn your back, to flee.
Many people were simply held in their tracks, the understanding kicking in that just going to work as usual, just going to the store for the breakfast milk, would be deeply inappropriate. Throughout the morning I kept going upstairs and coming back down, as if to verify in real air and space the pictures I was seeing on television -- and vice versa.
I've thought a lot about my fellow gawkers on Mercer Street since then, wondered for how many of them the grotesqueries of the week got closer, more personal, and how many have merely shared my experience of bystanderhood. I heard one network newscaster say that "just about everyone I know has some connection to someone who was involved in this attack," but the reality is
that most of us don't. We have been moved to suffer in sympathy. Which, as it turns out, holds a distinct agony of its own. Just about everyone I know felt worse as the week went on.
One of the obvious lessons of terrorism is that it renders people helpless. Americans have understood this, even though up to now we have largely been spared the emotional erosion of living in constant insecurity. Our immunity on that score is up.
But the persistent and deepening throb of pain, I think, is caused by something beyond helplessness. I'll speak solely for myself here, but I've never felt smaller or more insignificant than I have this week and partly this is a terrible irony because I'm among the lucky. As far as I know, I've lost no one close to me. I've lost no property. Whatever images there are to haunt me from the tragedy are the ones that haunt millions who watch television and read the newspaper. Even my personal experience of the calamity is one I shared with a crowd of neighbors.
I have, in other words, no private terror or individuated anguish, the emotional currency of the moment. And though this will sound selfish or chilly or less than magnanimous, I resent having no purchase on sympathy. But I understand. There's only so much sympathy to go around; we're all doing triage with our available feelings.
At the same time, unless you are in certain professions, it turns out there is almost nothing to be done to lend a hand, aside from donating blood (not so easy to do in the chaotic aftermath or, stunningly, so necessary) or money. The business of reassuring out-of-town friends and loved ones of one's own safety doesn't take much time or energy. Compulsively watching television does.
The inability to do much more than keep oneself informed is a terrible frustration. And it is cruelly isolating, at least to me, because of the extraordinary urge I have to be counted among my communities -- of New Yorkers, of Americans, and of my fellow men and women. But who knows how to do this right now? The way I'm generally satisfied to announce my presence in the world is through what I do every day.
Whether this is healthy or admirable is another argument, but I won't deny that my profession commands an enormous role in my idea of myself, and as a theater critic I didn't feel any more necessary after curtains went up in New York on Thursday than I did while theaters were dark. How could I find meaning in such frivolousness? I'm thankful to the firefighters, police officers, rescue workers, doctors and others, including my fellow journalists, for responding with such ardor to this catastrophe, but I'm envious of them as well.
I know I'm not alone in this. The fruitlessness of pursuing one's daily life was shared by a spectrum of people who renounced their chosen practices. Professional athletes were among those who publicly expressed disdain for doing what they do, and the shopkeepers in my neighborhood expressed the same thing by closing their shops. Indeed, commerce has rarely seemed so crass; the young man who took advantage of the occasion to peddle American flag bandannas on lower Fifth Avenue on Thursday drew far more glares of disdain than customers, at least while I was watching.
I commend Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's declaration that New Yorkers should return to their normal lives, go to restaurants and stores, resume their jobs, in order to keep the economy and the spirit of the city afloat and to send a message of our enduring hardiness to those who would destroy us.
But part of me wants to respond, respectfully: That's easy for you to say. You have a pertinent life to lead.
What about those of us who feel as if we've been robbed of ourselves, who've had no choice but to wait until this all subsides and the world returns to a semblance of something we recognize, something that allows us to go on with our lives without dismissing them? 
It seems to me that what terrorists stole from even the most fortunate of New Yorkers on Tuesday may not have been our lives but fragments of them -- whole unrecoverable days, an unspecified number of them in which we simply believe we don't matter. 
What can we do in the meantime to pretend otherwise? Frankly, writing this essay was all I could think of.

PERSON: Charles A. James 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
In Antitrust, Stress on Restraint

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
SITTING on the coffee table in his spacious office at the Justice Department, next to a stack of newspapers, are "The Art of War" and "Who Moved My Cheese?" -- two books that Charles A. James says provide vital insights for his job as the nation's top antitrust enforcer.
 "The lesson of 'The Art of War' is that a dispassionate solution and all tactical decisions flow from a realistic assessment of where you are, and if you don't do that initial assessment right, you'll make mistakes," Mr. James said last Monday, referring to the book by the ancient military strategist Sun Tzu. "And the lesson of 'Who Moved My Cheese?' is that you have to be open to change in all of your planning because life is constantly changing." 
 They are lessons of significance for Mr. James, particularly as he tries to resolve the most important antitrust case of a generation, the government's legal assault on the monopolistic practices of Microsoft.
Before the disasters in New York and Washington last week, the business world had turned its eyes to Mr. James. On Sept. 6, he had dropped the government's effort to break up Microsoft and abandoned a central antitrust claim -- that the company had violated the Sherman Act by integrating its Internet Explorer browser with its Windows operating system.
After prosecutors and the company's lawyers were unable to meet last week because of the moratorium on air travel, the judge gave them a brief extension and ordered them to file a report by Tuesday outlining how to proceed with the remaining aspects of the case. A hearing is set for Friday.
Though some senior aides to President Bush have never liked the breakup order, or the idea of keeping those products from being linked, the prevailing view among lawyers following the case was that the decision was a blend of ideology and pragmatism -- an assessment, in light of the appeals court opinion, that it was not unreasonable to take steps to expedite proceedings.
"In some senses it may not really matter why the government is doing this," said John Shepard Wiley Jr., a law professor at the University of California at Los Angeles who uses the lawsuit as a case study in his antitrust classes. "The case will certainly be more streamlined" without those two issues, he added.
Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission in the Clinton administration, said the decision to drop the breakup request did not particularly trouble him.
"Conduct remedies, properly enforced, can be quite tough," he said, although he added that he might have gone a different route on the "tying claim" -- that Microsoft had improperly integrated its browser with the operating system.
"Dropping the tying claim may make it difficult to settle this case with a first-rate order," he said. "The threat is removed. Sure, the Court of Appeals made it tougher to make the tying case. But it was not impossible."
As soon it was made, Mr. James's move prompted some executives to consider large corporate deals that in a different regulatory climate would be unthinkable, like a possible bid by AOL Time Warner for AT&T's cable operations, which became public last Monday.
According to an aide, Mr. James, a soft-spoken 47-year-old lawyer, cringes at news articles framing the legal battle that began in the Clinton administration as a struggle between himself and Bill Gates. Even as Mr. James prepares for the next round of litigation, it is clear from the tone of his remarks, and those of his aides, that he would prefer settlement to battle.
Barely three months in office as the assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division, Mr. James, by virtue of the issues before him, has risen quickly to become a significant figure at the Justice Department. In the Microsoft case, a federal appeals court issued what now stands as the central opinion in the lawsuit a mere two weeks after his confirmation by the Senate. 
A few weeks after that, Mr. James's counterparts in Europe broke sharply with him and blocked the proposed $45 billion acquisition of Honeywell International by General Electric. The Justice Department, which had already approved the deal, reacted angrily to the move. But it was characteristic of Mr. James to issue a statement that, while disagreeing with the Europeans, was significantly more measured than those of other administration officials.
"For years, U.S. and E.U. competition authorities have enjoyed close and cooperative relations," he said. "In fact, there were extensive consultations in this matter throughout the entire process. This matter points to the continuing need for consultation to move toward greater policy convergence."
Other signs have emerged that Mr. James wants to ratchet down the often contentious relationship between prosecutors and their counterparts in the private sector. In a speech before the American Bar Association last month, Mr. James proposed streamlining the procedures for reviewing corporate mergers, giving more authority to line prosecutors, and reducing the often inevitable friction between the government and corporations.
Mr. James said it would be wrong to conclude that the new process of identifying legal issues sooner suggests that the government will ease its scrutiny of mergers. "This is not a burden-reduction effort for parties proposing mergers, but done properly it will reduce the burden," he said last week. "It is not an effort to reduce time for the sake of reducing time, but done properly it will reduce the time."
Mr. James, a native of Newark, said his decision to embark on an antitrust career was largely fortuitous. As a law student at George Washington University, he got a job at a small law firm that represented plaintiffs in antitrust cases. That ultimately led him to work as a junior lawyer at the F.T.C., where he befriended a colleague, Timothy J. Muris, now the agency's chairman. The two men share a concern that the previous administration may have been too aggressive in pursuing some kinds of monopoly investigations and cases challenging "vertical" mergers, like that of a producer and a distributor.
"My conservative view of economic issues leads me to have faith in market forces and to be circumspect about the extent to which government interacts with market forces," he said. 
Although his approach to antitrust is low-key, Mr. James is not wanting in the discipline department. When he found himself significantly overweight a few years ago, he embarked on a rigorous body-building regimen, losing 125 pounds. He still keeps a rigorous schedule, getting up by 4:45 a.m. so he can go to a gym.
"It's a passion," he said. "To show you the yin and yang of it, I should mention that I also love to cook. I am hopeful when I hang up my antitrust spurs I will open a restaurant."

HEADLINE: Business; 
Sudden Sense of Insecurity at Many Companies

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON; Additional reporting for this story was done by Julian E. Barnes, Claudia H. Deutsch, Chris Gaither, Danny Hakim, Constance L. Hays, Richard A. Oppel Jr., Andrew Pollack and Matt Richtel.

 BODY:
AT Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif., inspectors have begun checking backpacks for weapons, a procedure instituted only once before, during the Persian Gulf war. At the headquarters of Intel in Santa Clara last week, the front gates to the company's 12-building campus were locked, accessible only by employees with badges. And at Janus Capital in Denver, a mutual fund company that manages $200 billion in investments, executives are discussing new air-travel policies. 
 When hijackers toppled the World Trade Center towers on Tuesday they reshaped New York's financial landscape. But the impact is being felt much farther than that as companies around the country rush to bolster their security systems in the wake of the terrorist attacks. Thousands of executives accustomed to freewheeling travel, loose record-keeping and open access to workspaces are finding their work lives changing. 
 Employee identification badges are being scrutinized with new zeal. At the parking garage at Xerox, which has offices in Rochester's tallest building, at 29 stories, employees are grilled by security guards. At the TransAmerica pyramid in the heart of downtown San Francisco, itself a landmark as recognizable as the twin towers, there is only one entrance in use, and workers have to show ID to enter. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., has also reined in the travel schedules of its employees. 
But many industry analysts say this is only the beginning of a renewed focus on security as companies grapple with their own vulnerability. Paul Saffo, a veteran Silicon Valley technology analyst who works with numerous local companies there, said he expected to see more changes in security measures as businesses realize that they are now targets of terrorism.
"If this is a war, it's businesses that are on the front line," Mr. Saffo said, describing the attack on the World Trade Center as a wake-up call. "It's dawning on businesses that they have to take prudent steps."
Kenneth Katzman, a scholar and senior analyst in Middle Eastern affairs at the Congressional Research Service in Washington, agreed. 
"Terrorists are going after things where the U.S. is dominant," he said. "I've long told audiences I've spoken to that companies like Microsoft are a target. Terrorists are looking for something that is distinctive and will get a lot of press." 
Why so much attention on security now? In the 1970's, corporate executives were concerned about a spate of high-profile kidnappings and hijackings, Mr. Katzman said. But as the cold war ended, workers prospered and the United States economy expanded. Corporations then perceived competing businesses to be their enemies, not terrorists or Communists. Now, the focus is abruptly shifting. 
The most immediate concern on employers' minds, it seems, is whether and when they will allow employees to travel by air. And with good reason. On Thursday, two days after the World Trade Center attack, a man who tried to use a false pilot's identification to get past security checkpoints was arrested at Kennedy International Airport. The New York City area's three airports were then closed and other men were detained.
Almost every major corporation suspended corporate travel last week or made it discretionary. Nova Chemicals, a Canadian company whose United States headquarters are in Pittsburgh, instituted a two-day moratorium on flying. 
On Tuesday, Hewlett-Packard asked its workers in San Francisco and Los Angeles, where two of the hijacked planes were destined, to stay home. And in a memo distributed to employees, Carleton S. Fiorina, Hewlett-Packard's chairwoman and chief executive, instructed her workers to restrict business travel in all regions of the world to "customer-critical situations," such as when Hewlett-Packard's services are needed to keep a customer's computer systems running.
For many in the financial world, including investment bankers, mutual fund managers and analysts, flights to visit other companies are as routine as an Upper West Side commuter hopping on the subway to get downtown. Janus Capital, a unit of Stilwell Financial of Kansas City, Mo., takes pride in having its team of money managers and analysts visit every company Janus considers investing in both here and abroad.
But on Tuesday, Janus scrambled to account for its employees, who were spread all over the world, said Jane Ingalls, a Janus spokeswoman. Janus executives are now discussing what the company's travel policy should be in the future. They agree that it will be more risky and more cumbersome.
"We all have a sense that airline security is going to change tremendously," Ms. Ingalls said. "Gone are the days when you went up to the counter and got those two questions you already knew."
Some companies may wind up increasing their use of private jets. Gary Rieschel, an executive at Softbank Venture Capital, a unit of the Japanese company Softbank that is based in Mountain View, Calif., said that many of the investment executives he knows in Silicon Valley who travel often are not talking about investing in new security systems, but whether to buy a share in a corporate jet.
One reason is that new airport security measures may make commercial flights too time-consuming. But safety is an even greater concern. Mr. Rieschel says he often gets phone calls from family members worried about his safety when he travels. "I'm used to that," he said, but his family is not so sanguine.
So far, corporate America's approach to security is as varied as the companies themselves. For example, railroad operators have increased security in part because transportation is a national concern. 
"We've added more security officers and beefed up the scope of what they do," said Richard Russack, a vice president at Burlington Northern Santa Fe, in Fort Worth, which has 33,500 miles of track in 28 states and two Canadian provinces. "We're asking people to be very sensitive to trespassers," he said.
Boeing, the second-largest contractor for the Defense Department, has operated under a heightened level of security since the terrorist attacks. Bob Jorgensen, a spokesman for the company's crisis management team, said that Boeing's security forces erected barricades on every road leading to administrative buildings, which, unlike Boeing factories, are not surrounded by perimeter fences and alarms. 
Mr. Jorgensen also said Boeing, which opened its new headquarters in Chicago this month, was reminding workers of existing company policies, such as never wearing clothing or carrying luggage identifying themselves as Boeing employees when traveling on international flights.
The Principal Financial Group, one of the nation's leading 401(k) management companies with $113 billion under management, increased security around its corporate headquarters in Des Moines on Tuesday. The company banned curbside parking around its offices, limited access to building loading docks, posted extra security inside the building and conducted extra patrols around its buildings.
"I wouldn't say its permanent, but I can't tell you when it will end," Rhonda Clark-Leyda, a spokeswoman, said.
But at Cisco Systems, the largest maker of computer networking equipment, people who visited its facilities last week said it did not appear that any special measures were being taken. Steve Langdon, a spokesman for the company that is based in San Jose, Calif., declined to discuss the issue, stating that "information about our security is not something we share publicly."
And on Sand Hill Road in Menlo Park, Silicon Valley's equivalent of Wall Street, where many of the most prominent venture capital firms that fueled the technology boom reside, few precautions have been taken. Security guards are practically nonexistent. 
Even at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's offices there, visitors said they have seen no increased security, even though that firm had its brokerage offices in 2 World Trade Center. 
"No one has really had a chance to talk about it," said Vinod Khosla, a partner at Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. "The other thing is you don't want terrorists to disrupt your life."
Along with personal safety issues, corporations have to worry about protecting the integrity of their operations. But many companies already addressed that issue in their preparations for the millennium, when many feared that power failures and computer malfunctions would bring business to a standstill, ground airlines and freeze automated teller machines. 
BANKS, mutual fund companies and investment firms have already invested billions of dollars in new technology and backup systems in the event of any natural disaster.
The Vanguard Group, the nation's second-largest manager of mutual funds, has backup in three states for its records and telephone operators. The company, based in Malvern, Pa., near Philadelphia, also has a site in another part of the Philadelphia area that functions as a backup for account processing and shareholder record-keeping. 
"We're ready to go in an unfortunate situation," said John Demming, a Vanguard spokesman.
Fiduciary Trust, a subsidiary of Franklin Resources, which manages money for wealthy clients, had its headquarters at 2 World Trade Center, and executives there say they remain deeply concerned about the employees who are still missing. But Anne M. Tatlock, Fiduciary's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that the company had extensive backup systems in place and was confident it would be up and running when the stock market reopens. Franklin Resources is based in San Mateo, Calif.
"Senior members of our management team were at our disaster-recovery site in New Jersey within an hour of the tragedy and efforts were immediately taken to restore our business capability," Ms. Tatlock said. "We have recovered our complete portfolio accounting system and we successfully backed up all of our data through the close of trading on Monday night. We will be fully operational when U.S. equity markets reopen on Monday."
Other companies have taken steps to make sure their products can get to customers in the event of a major disaster. 
Amgen Inc., the nation's largest biotechnology company, began shipping its drugs by truck last week, following a plan developed in 1999 as part of its millennium strategy. "We can get to most of our customers in 24 hours without getting into the air," said Jeff Richardson, a spokesman for Amgen, which sells, among other things, a drug to treat anemia. 
IF anyone understands the security decisions American companies are facing, it is Alan Boeckmann, president of Fluor in Aliso Viejo, Calif. Fluor, one of the country's largest engineering and construction companies, employs 47,000 workers in 35 offices worldwide.
"We deal with a lot of far-flung places with shaky politics," Mr. Boeckmann said. "We react quickly to issues so we can keep control of the situation." In 1999, for instance, he said, Fluor employees working on an $800 million project in Indonesia were forced to leave the country three times because of civil unrest.
Mr. Boeckmann warned that companies could create security risks if they drew too much attention to themselves. 
"Sometimes you can be too high-profile," he said. After Fluor had a bomb scare in one of its foreign offices, the company decided to remove its name from the building.
"In our case and the case of others, the concern will be visibility," Mr. Boeckmann said, a lesson companies are already learning. Bain & Company, a consulting firm based in Boston, closed its offices in New York City and Washington on Tuesday, and also closed operations in any building considered a national landmark, including the Sears Tower in Chicago.
Many corporations are loath to discuss any security measures they have put in place. "For security purposes, we can't talk about security," said Lisa Gallegos, a spokeswoman at Franklin Resources, which manages $266 billion in assets. 
"Even if I knew I would not tell you," said Ray O'Rourke, a spokesman for Morgan Stanley, one of the largest tenants at the World Trade Center, when asked if the company had instituted tighter security at its offices around the world. 
In fact, there is a good chance that companies are doing a great deal more about increasing security than they are willing to let on. Corporate security chiefs at Eastman Kodak, the photography giant in Rochester, are not pretending that it is business as usual in the aftermath of the events of Tuesday. But they have little intention of publicizing the precautions they are taking.
"Our security people are totally disinclined to provide any detail on what we are doing here," Gerard Meuchner, a Kodak spokesman, said. "The way they see it, if you want to keep a safe locked, you don't give out the combination."

HEADLINE: Business; 
Airlines' Bad Year Is Suddenly Looking Much, Much Worse

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

 BODY:
EVEN before the mass death and destruction caused by the multiple hijackings last week, the American commercial airline industry had been struggling through an extraordinarily rough year. But those financial travails may look mild compared with what comes after the worst terrorist attack in the nation's history.
 The government's unprecedented two-day grounding of all commercial flights, draconian new security rules and the hesitance of a frightened public could add billions of dollars in losses to what was shaping up as the worst year for United States airlines since the downturn after the Persian Gulf war of 1991. That could result in curtailed schedules, smaller fleets and widespread layoffs. On Friday, Congress was considering a $15 billion bailout of the industry. 
 The pressure on airlines became clear one day after the attack -- they were not bringing in any revenue but were spending money to maintain grounded planes, pay flight crews and accommodate stranded passengers. Midway Airlines, one of the weakest carriers, announced that it was going out of business. Speculation increased that US Airways would not survive. And Standard & Poor's, the debt rating agency, said it might lower the credit ratings of all airlines in the United States, which could raise borrowing costs for them. 
The attack on Tuesday by suicide terrorists who slammed commandeered jetliners from American Airlines and United Airlines into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon "will turn a bad year into a very, very bad year," said Raymond E. Neidl, the airline analyst at ABN Amro Securities.
Before the attack, analysts who follow the industry had been expecting major United States airlines to lose $2.5 billion to $3.5 billion for 2001 because of the rapidly slowing economy, fewer passengers and higher labor costs. Earlier this month American's parent, AMR, which lost $507 million in the second quarter, said it expected significant losses in the third and fourth quarters.
Now there are fears that losses by the industry will approach or even exceed the $4.8 billion it lost in 1992, when it suffered from a recession and terrorism fears because of the gulf war.
"This will be the worst year we've ever had," said Darryl Jenkins, director of the Aviation Institute at George Washington University in Washington.
Mr. Jenkins and Mr. Neidl, who was stranded last week in Chile after his flight home was canceled, said it was too early to precisely forecast the losses. "Nobody really knows what will happen with the industry, how far off we are going to be because of this unprecedented situation," Mr. Neidl said. 
Of course, the other shoe has not yet dropped. If the United States retaliates with a military strike abroad, as is widely expected, there could be a collapse in international air travel, which had been a growth area in the airline industry.
Kevin C. Murphy, who follows the industry for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said each airline's current supply of cash would be crucial in coming weeks and months, as the industry spends more than it receives just to induce people to fly with fare discounts and expensive new security procedures.
"At times like these, you sort of forget about the income statement," Mr. Murphy said.
The major airline companies -- AMR; Delta Air Lines; UAL, the parent of United; Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines -- have about $1 billion each in cash and marketable securities, Mr. Murphy said, which can tide them over for awhile. 
But smaller carriers have less on hand. And some airline executives and analysts are predicting that the federal government will have to give the airline industry an emergency infusion of cash. Gordon M. Bethune, chief executive of Continental, warned Friday that without such aid, "we are all going to be bankrupt before the end of the year."
John Heimlich, director of economic research for the Air Transport Association, a trade group based in Washington that represents the domestic industry, estimated that United States airlines had only about $10 billion in cash on hand before the terrorist attacks, and the industry has been incurring costs of about $350 million a day. "Something's going to have to be done," he said. "Obviously, we're going to need a package."
It is the unexpected that can hurt the industry the most. The closure of the nation's air lanes after the terrorist attacks, curtailing flights around the world, caused immediate and unplanned declines in revenue. 
The International Air Transport Association, a trade group based in Geneva, said the world's airlines incurred expenses and lost sales last week that could reach $10 billion.
The domestic airline industry is also facing a new and unexpected expense: drastically strengthened security. Under Federal Aviation Administration regulations announced last week, airlines and airports will have to search passengers far more aggressively to confiscate cutting instruments of any size -- even plastic knives.
How much of that expense can be passed along to passengers remains unclear, especially if the airlines find that they must also lower fares to revive their business.
Under the new federal rules, the airlines are prohibited, at least temporarily, from carrying cargo or mail. Freight has been a small but not insignificant business for major passenger airlines. Michael V. Iswalt, an associate economist at Economy.com, a research group in West Chester, Pa., said it represented 7 percent of revenue at Northwest, 4.5 percent at UAL, 4 percent at AMR and 3 percent at Delta.
Airlines, of course, have long learned to cope with some unanticipated events that temporarily reduce revenue, as when severe weather shuts airports or when there is skittishness among customers after a crash. Kevin Mitchell, chairman of the Business Travel Coalition, a research group based in Radnor, Pa., said it was normal for an airline's business to fall significantly for 10 to 14 days after an accident. 
This time, he said, "I think it's going to be a couple of months" before many passengers feel comfortable again.
Lingering horror is an important reason. In most cases, the public never sees a plane crash, only the shattered remains. But vivid color video and photographs of jetliners striking the World Trade Center have been viewed by people worldwide -- again and again.
AIRLINE officials say they know they have a difficult task. To assure passengers, "we must be at the top of our game," said Ed Stewart, a spokesman for Southwest Airlines, based in Dallas.
"Right now, the focus is on getting back to a sense of normalcy, to showing that we are stronger than this," he said, referring to the terrorist attack.
Mr. Stewart said Southwest, among the few American airlines that analysts expect to be profitable for 2001, is prepared for the burden of added security.
"We live in a world that is not Disneyland," he said.
One of the biggest unknowns is how many business travelers, the airline industry's most profitable customers, will soon be flying again. Having already reduced their travel because of the weak economy, they are widely expected to cut back further because of terrorism fears.
In a survey of 63 major corporations released in June, 86 percent told the Business Travel Coalition that they had sought to reduce the cost of business travel this year. Now airlines could also have trouble luring executives back to their jets because corporations do not want to gamble on even the slightest security problem, said William Curtis, chief executive of CurtCo Robb Media, publisher of The Robb Report, a magazine aimed at an upscale leisure audience.
"The risk factor has certainly changed," Mr. Curtis said, "not just the risk but the reality."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Strengthened security measures at airports could further hurt the airlines' bottom lines. At Minneapolis-St. Paul, an officer used a hand-held metal detector. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section 3; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1
