HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report; 
The Internet passes its first test as a source of communications in the aftermath of a disaster.

BYLINE:  By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
NEARLY 40 years after it was conceived as a method of maintaining communications in the event of an attack on the United States, the Internet -- long since broadened past that purpose -- last week had the first real test of its original goal.
 To judge by the availability of media sites, many of which were inaccessible in the hours just after the first plane hit the World Trade Center on Tuesday morning, one might assume the Internet had failed the test. But in fact, according to firms that analyze Web site traffic and performance, while some sites slowed, the overall flow of data across the Internet was not degraded by either damage to critical fiber optic lines or the clogging of those lines by Web users. 
 Keynote Systems, which tracks the performance of 40 highly visited business sites, including major news and search sites, said it took about 13 seconds for the average home page to load on Tuesday morning at 10:15 Eastern time, or from three to four times the normal daily average. Over the next several hours, that average returned to normal. 
The improvement reflected the sometimes drastic steps taken by media companies in particular to slash all but the most vital information from their home pages, so users could log on. Take CNN.com, which, like The New York Times on the Web and others, had been unavailable to many users immediately after the attacks. The site cut photos, graphics, text and ads from the first page users reach, leaving just one story, a few bullet points and a headline. The New York Times on the Web took a similar approach, according to Meredith Artley, associate editor. Ms. Artley said the Web page was stripped of all nonessential items, like ads and images, which made the page easier to load. She added that user registration, normally necessary to view certain articles, was suspended.
Viewed another way, CNN.com's home page before the events held more than 255 kilobytes of information; the slimmed-down version was about 20 kilobytes, according to Keynote.
CNN.com's executive producer, Mitch Gelman, said his site also tripled the number of servers -- the technology engines of the Web site -- by using servers that had been dedicated to CNNfn.com and CNNsi.com, which deliver financial and sports news, respectively. Mr. Gelman said the site also received additional servers from, among others, AOL Time Warner, which hosts CNN.com's advertising servers.
Some companies that help Web sites stay up and running reported nothing out of the ordinary on Tuesday. Melissa Neumann, a spokeswoman for Exodus Communications, which operates servers on behalf of more than 4,500 Web sites, said, "our network performed quite well." Any problems with specific sites, she said, were attributable to those sites' not having secured enough servers.
Ms. Neumann said Exodus has four facilities in New York City, including one data center in an undisclosed site in Manhattan, but that none of them was affected by the disaster.
If the overall performance of the Internet was not diminished on Tuesday, one reason is that commerce sites generally saw a marked decrease in the number of users. Not surprisingly, sites like Amazon, IBM.com, and eBay all had fewer visitors than their average.
But in the case of eBay, for one, the drop was slight. According to Kevin Pursglove, an eBay spokesman, people were still trading items as the day progressed, although he did not know specifics about the site's overall sales for the day.
Some of the items put up for auction included items purportedly from in or around the World Trade Center, including stop signs and other debris. EBay quickly halted trading on all items related to the World Trade Center or the Pentagon, a policy that will remain in effect until the end of the month.
While travel sites, too, saw a decrease in the number of visitors, they also experienced a more complicated day than usual. In Chicago, the headquarters of Orbitz, the online travel agency owned by several major airlines, was evacuated Tuesday morning, along with other offices in the vicinity of the Sears Tower.
Employees gathered in nearby apartments and other locations and communicated via instant messaging and conference calls, said Carol Jouzaitis, an Orbitz spokeswoman, to plan the site's response to customer travel inquiries. The company's customer service centers outside Chicago operated smoothly, she added -- a situation that was perhaps aided by the fact that many people could not complete telephone calls on land lines because of volume.
Notably, the site did book flights. "It was significantly less than on a normal day, but it wasn't negligible, either," Ms. Jouzaitis said.
Meanwhile, a supporting player in Internet commerce, advertising, was all but invisible throughout the middle part of the week, as many informational and transactional Web sites distanced themselves from product pitching.
Terrell B. Jones, the chief executive of Travelocity, said he pulled ads on his site on Tuesday "simply because it was inappropriate," and also canceled Travelocity television and radio advertisements that were scheduled for the week.
Other commerce sites placed much more emphasis on Tuesday's events than they did on their merchandise. Amazon, for example, removed all the merchandise from its front page on Tuesday evening and replaced it with a solicitation for donations to the American Red Cross. The site had raised $5.7 million as of Saturday night.
Patty Smith, an Amazon spokeswoman, said she was unsure how long the notice would remain on the front page. "We're more focused on the news" than sales, she said. "And people can still find the stores we have." (Similar efforts were underway on the sites of the Target Corporation, Yahoo and Eddie Bauer, among others.)
Just as the travel industry was disproportionately affected by Tuesday's events, so, too, was the financial industry. According to John Metaxas, a spokesman for E*Trade, the company stopped taking orders for trades on Tuesday, and spent the day testing the systems of trading partners to ensure things would go smoothly once the markets reopened. By Tuesday night, the company began taking orders again for future trades.
For Web sites catering to the corporate community, Tuesday was largely a day off. There were some exceptions, of course. According to David Leip, corporate Webmaster for IBM.com, most of Tuesday was spent accounting for employees in the core of his technology team, which is based on Broad Street, a short walk from the World Trade Center. Mr. Leip said the staff was indeed safe.
I.B.M. technologists were, meanwhile, hard at work, helping a number of large corporate customers in the area get their sites operating normally. A company spokesman declined to name the customers, but Mr. Leip said there were "quite a number of tenants in the World Trade Center who are customers of ours, and there were some major networking hubs" in 7 World Trade Center, which collapsed Tuesday night.
The number of visitors to the IBM.com site was, of course, down significantly, Mr. Leip said. "The last thing people were worried about was doing that I.T. upgrade next quarter."
Still, not all business-to-business Internet companies were able to focus squarely on the day's events. Boston-based Akamai Technologies, which works with corporate and consumer Web sites to route information and graphics more efficiently around the globe, helped a number of media companies, including CNN.com, improve their accessibility as the day wore on.
For Akamai, the additional work was particularly troubling for other reasons. Daniel C. Lewin, the company's co-founder and chief technology officer, was on American Airlines Flight 11, the first plane to hit the World Trade Center. Felicia Spagnoli, an Akamai spokeswoman, said the company was "devastated," but she said Mr. Lewin's death did not paralyze the company's technology team.
"If anything, it inspired people that much more to get it done, and fulfill his vision to support the Internet and allow it to become a vital communications resource," Ms. Spagnoli said. "This week is a testament to the fact that his idea works, and will continue to do so."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE MARKETS; 
Uncertainly, Market Reopens Today

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
In a triumph of determination and intense effort, America's stock markets plan to reopen this morning for trading, less than a week after the worst terrorist attack in history devastated Lower Manhattan.
 But after trading resumes on both the Nasdaq stock market and the New York Stock Exchange, investors and securities firms will face considerable uncertainty about how the markets will perform, physically and financially. No one really knows how well the damaged communications and power systems of downtown Manhattan will be able to handle what Wall Street expects will be a very busy day of trading. The psychological toll on employees who must return to an area that was consumed by fire and fear just six days ago may also be heavy. 
 Nor can anyone be certain whether stocks will rise or fall, or whether appeals to patriotism and resolve will overcome the fears that Tuesday's attacks dealt a heavy short-term blow to an already slowing American economy.
Any technical problems with trading may add to the nervousness of investors. Yesterday, the communications systems at the Big Board and securities firms were tested for a second day, with no problems reported. Richard A. Grasso, the Big Board's chairman, has pledged that trading will resume today, with no contingency plans needed. "I have absolute confidence," he said.
Wall Street wants to go back to work. Capitalism has been very good to many people in the securities industry, and more than one trader views opening the markets as a patriotic duty, a sign that terrorists cannot cow the United States. Firefighters, police officers and the mayor and governor of New York plan to be on hand when the opening bell rings at the New York Exchange.
Opening stock markets is important not just as a symbolic gesture but for practical reasons. Many Americans have most or all of their savings in the stock market. Some, especially people who have recently been laid off, may need to sell shares to pay mortgages or other bills.
The slowing economy, meanwhile, may cause some companies -- even ones that have been profitable -- to lose money for the next few months. Those companies need to sell bonds and stocks to raise money so they can continue to pay their employees and suppliers. Other companies may use the money they raise to expand. While most companies are issuing bonds to raise money, the bond and stock markets are inextricably linked, and the bond market would eventually come to a halt if stocks could not be traded.
"You will see very high volume tomorrow. You will see companies needing to raise capital and investors needing to buy and sell securities," John Thain, the president of Goldman Sachs, said yesterday. He did not, however, expect to see panic selling when the markets reopen. Mr. Thain said that Goldman, whose headquarters are only a few hundred feet from the New York Stock Exchange, planned to have nearly all of its employees at work.
One trader for a major investment firm said that those companies that were displaced, including Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers, would probably handle a smaller share of the day's trading than usual. To place trades with those firms, customers will have to dial unfamiliar numbers in New Jersey rather than punching keys on their computers.
The New York Mercantile Exchange, which trades commodities like gold and crude oil, will also resume trading this morning in its headquarters in the World Financial Center.
When the stock markets reopen, the Big Board will be at far greater risk of having unexpected problems than will the Nasdaq. On the Nasdaq, firms like Goldman and Merrill Lynch compete directly with each other to buy and sell shares from investors of all sizes. The Nasdaq's computers serve as a central clearinghouse where the firms, called market-makers, can post their bids to buy and offers to sell, and confirm trades when they are made.
But the Nasdaq has no physical center. It exists only on computers. Nasdaq's computers are not in New York City, and the data lines that connect the Nasdaq to its market-makers do not primarily run through downtown Manhattan. Firms in buildings that were damaged or destroyed, like Merrill Lynch, have moved to backup sites that have undamaged connections to Nasdaq.
The New York Exchange has a very different model. Many small buy and sell orders on the exchange are matched electronically. But larger orders are usually routed from the securities firms that receive them to the exchange's trading floor, where a human specialist helps match buyers and sellers.
As a result, the exchange depends on Lower Manhattan's communications systems to operate, and it cannot easily move to a backup site. The exchange is tightening its security. The section of Broad Street in front of the exchange will be permanently closed to traffic.
But the stakes for the exchange are high. To keep the securities industry united during a time of national crisis, Nasdaq agreed not to reopen until the exchange was ready. But the president of Nasdaq, Richard Ketchum, said Saturday that the Nasdaq would probably not close again once it reopened, even if the Big Board cannot operate.
"We are looking for both of us to be up on Monday," Mr. Ketchum said. "Once we're up, we expect to continue to trade."
The situation is even more complicated because securities firms can already trade the Big Board's stocks on the Nasdaq's system, bypassing the exchange entirely. The trading of Big Board stocks away from the exchange floor has always been relatively minor, because securities firms and investors think they will get the best prices, either as buyers or sellers, at the exchange. But if the Big Board has problems today, securities firms may begin routing their trades of New York Stock Exchange stocks onto Nasdaq's system, a blow from which the exchange would have a difficult time recovering.
The New York Stock Exchange has made enormous efforts to ensure that its systems will be ready for trading. Now, in just one of the many questions that Wall Street will face today, the Big Board must hope that work has been effective.

Nymex to Close Early
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, the trading day will be shortened, opening at 11 a.m. and closing at 2 p.m. Normally, the first contract starts trading at 5 a.m., with other openings staggered until 9:50 a.m. The closes are also staggered, concluding at 3:10 p.m.
Today, all contracts will open at once. The trading will be done in the exchange's pits, using the traditional open outcry method.
The exchange had a two-hour session on Friday, conducted over the Internet with a system usually used for after-hours trading. Gold rose almost 7 percent then, to $290.90 an ounce, while a barrel of crude oil climbed $1.89, to $29.74.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Wall Street prepares to return to business even as security stays tight in Lower Manhattan. Clockwise from top, a checkpoint on Broad Street; an officer takes precautions; and Big Board workers go through a dry run yesterday. (Reuters) Chart: "Reopening for Business"The biggest obstacles to getting the stock exchanges running involve ensuring that brokers who take and place orders can communicate with the exchanges that execute them. For the many brokers who have had to relocate, and there are many, there are added problems related to getting back to work. HOW THE SYSTEM WORKS Brokers receive orders to buy or sell stocks, electronically or over the phone. THE PROBLEMS TO BE OVERCOME Brokers have to make sure that telephone and Internet systems, many of which were damaged, are working well enough for customers to place orders. Brokers transmit the orders to the exchanges through direct computer links. The networks connecting many brokers to the exchanges have to be repaired or backup networks have to be put into operation and tested. The exchanges receive the orders, match them up and execute them. On Nasdaq, this is entirely done electronically. On the New York Stock Exchange, orders are processed by specialists, who receive most orders by computer. For larger orders, representatives of major brokers, which have booths on the trading floor, walk over and speak to the specialists. After trades are executed, confirmations are sent electronically to the brokers. In cases where firms have to move, software that lets the brokers communicate with the exchanges also has to be tested. At the end of each day, the brokers send lists of executed trades to a clearinghouse, which has three days to match them up and make sure that money and stock change hands. Trades executed last Monday were settled after the attack occurred, but it remains to be seen if the systems connecting the brokers to the clearinghouses are working fully. (pg. C12)

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE POLL; 
Public Voices Overwhelming Support for the Use of Force Against Terrorism

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE and JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
As they move from shock to fury, Americans are bracing for the United States to go to war, and they overwhelmingly say the nation should take military action against those responsible for the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
 That sentiment declines at the prospect that thousands of innocent civilians abroad could be killed. Still, a majority of Americans support engagement by the military even under those circumstances. 
 The crisis has spurred the public to put aside its past reservations about the leadership of President Bush and instead to rally wholeheartedly behind the relatively new president and express confidence in his ability to guide the nation. His job approval rating has soared to 84 percent, compared with 50 percent just over a month ago. 
Americans say they are ready to alter the way they live, and even sacrifice some of their own liberties, for safety considerations. They say they would be willing to arrive three hours early for domestic airline flights to pass through heightened security and would withstand long lines at public events and in public buildings to pass through metal detectors and inspections by guards.
The public also supports changing the law to allow for the assassination of people in foreign countries who commit terrorist attacks.
Although more than half the respondents said they did not think Arab-Americans were any more sympathetic toward terrorists than other Americans, the public is expecting a backlash against Arab-Americans, Muslims and immigrants from the Middle East.
The telephone poll of 959 adults nationwide was conducted on Thursday and Friday, as Americans were only beginning to digest the implications of the terrorist attacks and to ponder how the nation should respond. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
As the initial shock begins to dissipate, Americans are now turning toward thoughts of punishing the perpetrators. The poll did not ask who people think is the enemy or what specific action they envision. But in follow-up interviews many respondents in the Times/CBS poll said they backed military action, even if that meant American casualties.
"I don't like the idea of American lives being lost in a war," said Virginia Harrison, 56, a homemaker in Tallahassee, Fla., "but we can't just sit here and let them continue to do it because they will probably do it again."
Describing herself as "angry and outraged," Joy Hess, 58, a library clerk in Medford, Ore., said: "I'm not talking about revenge, but justice. I have a son in the military and I know loss of life is a risk. But there is no other way to get across that we mean business. We wouldn't be where we are now in history if we hadn't fought for our freedom. Freedom means losses sometimes."
It is not a huge surprise that Mr. Bush faces the most critical chapter of his presidency with a surge in his popularity. His 11 predecessors enjoyed sharp increases in support during crises. After the bombing of Pearl Harbor in 1941, President Franklin D. Roosevelt's ratings skyrocketed. He was the earliest president about whom such surveys were taken. John F. Kennedy won great public support during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962, as did Jimmy Carter when hostages were seized in Iran in 1979 and Mr. Bush's father, George Bush, in the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
Seven in 10 Americans now say President Bush is a strong leader, including 55 percent of Democrats. That is his highest rating since he became president, up from 54 percent in June.
In the follow-up interviews, several people said they were heartened that Mr. Bush had been turning to seasoned advisers.
"Even though I'm a Democrat, I approve of him," Mrs. Harrison said. "He's doing the best he can, and I'm sure he has a lot of advisers."
But there are no assurances that Mr. Bush's popularity will persist. His father's peak job approval of nearly 90 percent in March 1991 after the early success in the gulf war eroded as economic anxieties rose and the immediacy of war faded. His job approval tumbled to 37 percent just before the 1992 presidential election.
The most long-lived increases in public favor were the 30 weeks for President Roosevelt after Pearl Harbor, the 31 weeks for President Kennedy after the missile crisis and the 30 weeks for President Carter after the hostages were seized.
Underscoring the degree of commitment, 68 percent of Americans said they believed the United States would go to war.
Eighty-five percent said the United States should take military action against whoever is responsible for the attacks. Seventy-five percent of those people said the action should be mounted even if innocent people were killed. Almost all of them said they would favor going to war with a nation that was harboring those responsible for the attacks.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE HIDDEN VICTIMS; 
Those at Towers' Margin Elude List of Missing

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE and MIREYA NAVARRO 

 BODY:
Most of the people listed as missing in the twin towers disaster were part of the World Trade Center's life as an elite corporate community. Determining who was missing among them after the terrorist attack, however painful, would not be that hard. And the most prominent would be mourned with much eloquence.
 But in the self-contained city that the trade center truly was, there were also many people -- undocumented immigrant deliverymen and Albanian window washers, Polish maintenance workers and single men and women without close family -- who may not appear on formal personnel records or whose absence might simply not register with enough people that someone would come forward to search. And the mourning for the immigrants with families, but without glamorous jobs, would be done in near anonymity. 
 And so the excruciating effort to fully document the dead that has gone on since last Tuesday, so far only modestly successful, will be all the more difficult when it comes to the universe of people who worked at the trade center's margins or inhabited its huge informal economy.
Part of the culture of the trade center, for example, depended on Mexicans and other immigrants -- many of them men supporting families back home -- who hustled breakfast orders to corporate offices, carried flowers to secretaries and washed dishes in the concourse restaurants. Estimates of the number of these workers who were in the towers last Tuesday morning range from a few dozen to as many as 10 or 15 times that number, according to a group that has been formed to search and interview survivors.
Some of the lost seem barely to have been known.
Carlos Bravo, a 26-year-old Mexican immigrant, was making pizzas at Akbar's Greenhouse Cafe, on the street level beneath the trade towers when disaster struck, and he escaped. Only a few minutes before, however, he said he saw two food delivery workers with orders for the office workers on the higher floors. Both were immigrants, Mr. Bravo said -- one of them here illegally. 
All Mr. Bravo knew about them was their first names and a few sparse facts: Humberto was married with a daughter and lived in Queens; Patricio, an Ecuadorean whose girlfriend was pregnant. "I never saw them again," Mr. Bravo said.
Various efforts are under way to document the undocumented -- to attach names, faces and perhaps stories to the invisible uncounted. The Polish Consulate in New York, for example, has been trying to find seven people -- all Polish citizens -- who were working at the trade center doing maintenance work. A spokesman for the consulate said that information from survivors suggests that all seven made it out, but no direct word has been received.
A group called the Tepeyac Association of New York -- an umbrella group of 40 Mexican immigrant organizations -- has put together a list of 29 Mexicans who are missing. But the group's executive director, Brother Joel Magallan, said he feared the number could be much higher based on survivor's reports. But he admits the numbers are pure speculation -- most Mexicans in New York, he said, are undocumented, and many work in the city's cash economy where paperwork is kept to the minimum.
But there are many other immigrants who were caught in the terror of the trade center disaster whose stories have remained mostly untold -- people who came to America to escape poverty, repression and war, and who made lives in mostly humble jobs. 
The service employees union local that represents about 1,000 maintenance workers at the twin towers has done an intensive phone canvas and found that 28 of its members are missing.
Jan Demczur, an immigrant from Poland who washed windows at the trade center, said his friend, Roko Camaj, adored his job, working on the roof of the north tower to maneuver the machinery that washed the building's 46,300 windows. Mr. Camaj, a 60-year-old ethnic Albanian who immigrated from Yugoslavia, loved working so high up, often telling his children that he felt he could touch the sky. 
"I can't imagine Roko's gone," Mr. Demczur said. "He was so happy that he had this job. He said, 'Nobody is going to take my job from me. I'm doing to die here.' And he died there."
Many immigrants coveted maintenance jobs at the trade center because the pay was considered excellent for unskilled workers -- at least $32,000 a year before overtime. 
Raysa Rodriguez, the sister of Esmerlin Salcedo, a 36-year-old security guard from the Dominican Republic, said one of his co-workers told her that Mr. Salcedo went back inside the towers after helping her escape. Mr. Salcedo, who had applied to become a police officer and was taking computer courses, left behind a wife, a 5-year-old daughter, a 4-year-old daughter and a 1-year-old son. "Like every other immigrant, he came for a better life," his sister said. "He achieved a better life."
Alexa Ortiz said her mother, Sonia, who immigrated from Colombia in 1971, was delighted to land a job as a trade center janitor two years later. 
"It paid good," she said. "Her English wasn't good and it was a job where she didn't have to talk much."
Eventually she was promoted to run the freight elevator at Windows on the World, the restaurant near the top of 1 World Trade. "She was so excited working in such a tall building near the sky," said Sonia's son, Victor, a building painter. "She had so much pride that King Kong was made there. She said she met Michael Jackson one day."
Through hard work and frugality, Sonia Ortiz, 58, bought a handsome, brick home in Flushing, where she lived with Alexa. In the dining room, Sonia had Lladro sculptures of fairy tale characters and place mats with angels, and in the living room, she had a gilded mirror and a coffee table made of petrified wood.
Alexa, who works as an assistant in a medical office, said her mother came to New York to escape poverty, after having worked as a seamstress as a child in Colombia. "She loved it here," said Alexa. After the 1993 trade center bombing, Sonia, known for her optimism, dismissed the idea of renewed terrorism, her children said. Colombia, they all agreed, was far more dangerous.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE AIRLINES; 
In Early Economic Fallout, Major Carriers Cut Back

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK and LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Kevin J. Carlson has worn a lot of hats at Continental Airlines. He has taken passenger reservations, handled baggage, worked the gates, and he recently became a flight attendant, a job he loves. 
 But now he is worried he may become one of thousands of airline employees who lose jobs in the wake of last week's terrorist attacks. 
 "I won't kid you, it's a tough nut to swallow," Mr. Carlson said yesterday at Intercontinental Airport in Houston. "I didn't sleep last night." 
In an early sign of the economic fallout from the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, Continental on Saturday became the first major airline to announce sweeping layoffs. Some 12,000 people will immediately lose their jobs, more than 20 percent of the carrier's work force.
Gordon M. Bethune, the chief executive of Continental, predicted 100,000 layoffs industrywide, noting the sharp decline in passenger reservations since the airlines gingerly returned to the skies on Thursday. Northwest, American and United have indicated that they plan to reduce their flight schedules by 20 percent, and US Airways is expected to announce a 25 percent cutback today. Airlines were operating at about two-thirds of their normal flight schedules yesterday.
The major airlines were working feverishly to come up with a new strategy to receive financial relief from Congress after a bill authorizing $12.5 billion in loan guarantees and $2.5 billion in grants failed in the House early Saturday.
In a conference call last night, the chief executives of the major carriers agreed to ask the government to suspend or to reduce ticket taxes and passenger service charges that airlines pay. They will also seek an immediate infusion of cash to cover losses suffered since planes were grounded on Tuesday.
One executive said the industry would not seek a specific amount of aid; another said it would seek the same $15 billion package that the House rejected over the weekend.
Several chief executives, including Mr. Bethune and Leo F. Mullin of Delta Air Lines, say that the industry may face widespread bankruptcies if the government does not intervene. Industry leaders said they planned to supply lawmakers with financial data to back up the claim.
In an interview broadcast on the CBS News television program "60 Minutes" last night, John F. Welch, the recently retired chairman of General Electric -- which makes and services jet engines and finances plane purchases -- said the government would need to help the carriers "in some way."
But on the same program, the investor Warren E. Buffett noted: "There have been a lot of airlines that have gone bankrupt without having the sort of events you've had in the last week. So we have to be very careful about any mass subsidization."
Several airline chief executives are expected to meet tomorrow with Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta and White House officials. Congress is not scheduled to reconvene until Thursday. "We hope there will be a bill produced quickly next week," an airline executive said.
Employees of the big carriers are hoping that their bosses are successful, given the latest shock to the industry, which rode a booming economy to new heights only to stumble into multibillion-dollar losses with this year's slowdown. 
"I think it's going to get a lot worse for the airlines," a pilot based at the Continental hub in Newark said. "If the U.S. government starts striking terrorists and the terrorists keep striking back," he said, "no one will be flying. People will be even more scared than they are now, even though right now is probably the safest time ever to fly. And if nobody's flying, there won't be any jobs."
Employees facing layoffs are grim about their prospects. "A lot of people are really, really scared," said Ami Doneff, who was working a triple shift at the Continental ticket counter at Newark airport yesterday. "There's a lot of single mothers with children. They'd lose benefits."
Jessica Santello, 27, was a supervisor of gate agents in Raleigh, N.C., for Midway Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy protection before last week's terrorist attacks and afterward shut down for good. "Everybody has just been in shock," she said. "Part-timers are trying to get full-time work at their other jobs, and most of us, though, just don't know what to do. I'm sitting here looking at the classifieds right now."
On Wednesday, the industry faced a 2 p.m. deadline for making quarterly payments of hundreds of millions of dollars in ticket taxes to the government. Eager to hold on to as much of their cash as possible after the grounding of flights, the airlines petitioned the Internal Revenue Service for relief; they received a letter at 1:50 p.m. stating that they would not be subject to a penalty if they deferred the payments.
They did.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE CHAIRMAN; 
Wall Street's Driven Steward Presses for Business as Usual

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

 BODY:
The man who will try today to tug American finance back to its feet decided to place grief counselors on the trading floor of the stock market when it reopens this morning. Asked if he had sought any psychological help since his world collapsed on Tuesday, Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, seemed startled. 
 "No, I don't need it," he replied sharply. He paused, and added, "My counseling is this: that Monday morning 9:30 bell." 
 As with many other disaster victims, Mr. Grasso repressed emotions to help focus on the task ahead. And his is more demanding than most: having pledged to reopen the stock market today even as rescue workers continue to search the rubble nearby for thousands of missing and dead, Mr. Grasso, 55, has overnight become the steward of Wall Street's attempt to return to business as usual. 
Since Tuesday, in countless phone conversations with colleagues, government and city officials and telecommunications experts, Mr. Grasso has raced to get the market's technology ready. In interviews and television appearances, Mr. Grasso has tried to improve the market's mood. 
The effort to coax investors to stay calm is spread out among numerous government officials and mandarins of finance, but Mr. Grasso's seems to reflect a personal and sometimes poignant lifelong mission. A little like Stevens, the devoted butler in Kazuo Ishiguro's novel "The Remains of the Day," Mr. Grasso appears unwilling to allow the possibility that his world may have been altered for good. 
In an interview on Saturday, Mr. Grasso suppressed his memories of the day Wall Street shattered, and instead recalled a small lapse of trading floor etiquette. 
"I had invited the directors of Bergen Brunswig to celebrate a merger by ringing the bell," Mr. Grasso recalled with a pained smile. "Very rudely, I never got to say hello to them." 
Visitors did not ring the bell at 9:30 a.m. to signal the start of tradingthat day because terrorist pilots plunged two hijacked airplanes into the World Trade Center not far from the stock exchange, a strike against Western capitalism that instantly and perhaps irrevocably changed Wall Street's way of life. 
Addressing financial reporters on Saturday who had gathered to watch him direct system tests of the trading floor, a vast space still infused with the acrid scent of wreckage, Mr. Grasso likened the crisis to the stock market crash of 1987. "Is this not just another one of those moments when America has been challenged, and will rise again?" 
Perhaps. There is no question that at this vulnerable moment, many New Yorkers are clinging to his composure and optimism, reassurances delivered in the clipped, confident accent of his native Queens. 
Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary who was once a top Goldman Sachs executive and now is co-chairman of Citigroup, has worked with Mr. Grasso, a career employee of the exchange, for more than 25 years, and said that his selection as chairman six years ago was unusual at the time, but now, fortuitous. 
"It's funny," Mr. Rubin said, "I was thinking about the fact that until Dick, the board always used to pick an industry statesman, but Dick is exactly what they need now, someone who knows the innards of how the floor operates. When I was at Goldman Sachs, whenever we had a problem, I said, 'Call Dick Grasso.' He is ideally suited to this."
Actually, the crisis has also cast Mr. Grasso as a statesman. 
A huge American flag covers almost the entire front of the New York Stock Exchange, distracting the eye from dust, bulldozers and broken glass.
Patriotism laces his every appeal for investors not to "bet against America." A red, white and blue ribbon was pinned to Mr. Grasso's lapel yesterday.
This weekend he gave a telephone interview to an NBC affiliate, asserting that the American economy "is as strong as it ever was in terms of resolve." (He shrugged off a recent "softening of the metrics.") Afterward, an anchorwoman at WNBC, Felicia Taylor, turned to her co-host on the air and praised his words as "so powerful and fortifying for everyone here." 
Brokers this weekend seemed hungry for his reassuring touch as he patted their backs and hugged old friends on the trading floor, crisp and dapper as always in a yellow cashmere pullover, pink and white striped shirt and Gucci moccasins.
"If the marketplace were to fold or blunder, we would be giving the terrorists who did this their third target," Joseph N. Cangemi, a trader who owns a seat on the exchange, said in a tone of angry desperation that the chairman does not permit himself. "Dick is the leader of the free market," he said of the chairman. 
"It's Dick's responsibility to be strong, but somewhere deep inside I think he feels the same worry and hurt as everyone else." 
Mr. Grasso, who grew up in lower-middle-class Elmhurst, bought his first share of stock at the age of 13 and began his career at the bottom rungs of the stock exchange in 1968 -- after two years in the United States Army. He worked his way up to executive positions that were then still the preserve of the WASP establishment. Appointed chairman in 1995, the first staff member ever to rise to the top of the New York Stock Stock Exchange, Mr. Grasso was once described by The Economist as "the public face of the American bull market." He relished the attention, bringing fashion models and, once, a cow to the opening-bell ceremony. 
Two summers ago, he traveled to Colombia to lecture leftist guerrillas about the merits of free-market capitalism. 
Until now, his greatest challenge as chairman was to modernize and protect the New York Stock Exchange, which still relies on floor traders and which is described by some critics as a quaint but archaic system tailored to preserve the privileges of its members. 
Mr. Grasso succeeded in defending incursions by computer trading systems like the archrival Nasdaq, but in the aftermath of Tuesday's attack, experts are once again questioning the viability of a system that keeps thousands of jobs in Lower Manhattan, but also requires brokers and specialists to assemble on a trading floor even though technology allows customers and brokers to buy and sell from remote sites.
Mr. Grasso defends his system just as staunchly as ever, focusing on clients' desire for human service as well as computer efficiency. 
"We want the software to do baggage handling and schedules," he explained, "but we want a real pilot to fly and land the plane." 
He then winced as the implications of his metaphor sunk in.
On Tuesday morning, Mr. Grasso got early word of the disaster, before it showed up on television screens, the kind of insider tip that comes with the job. He said that one of his vice presidents was in the exchange's office in the north tower of the World Trade Center and called him a few seconds after the first explosion. They instantly decided to evacuate their 133 employees from the trade center. By day's end, he said, all of his employees had found safety and been accounted for, but other colleagues, clients and friends still have not.
He recalled that his first outside call after the first plane struck was to the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Harvey L. Pitt, and so was the last one before calling it a day, after midnight. Mr. Grasso spent the day overseeing the chaos from a vantage point on the trading floor, a kind of elevated command center with telephones and televisions, and he fell asleep on a couch in his sixth-floor office that night. 
"I couldn't turn off my big TV," he admitted sheepishly, either because he was too tired or too stunned to maneuver the off button. "I fell asleep under this eerie light under the television." 
Asked whether, after Tuesday, he had gone outside to examine the smoldering ruins of the World Trade Center, Mr. Grasso looked alarmed by the question, replying sharply, "No." Asked why not, he seemed momentarily nonplused. 
"I have a lot to do here," he replied.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE FLAG; 
U.S. Binds Wounds in Red, White and Blue

BYLINE:  By RICK BRAGG 

 BODY:
The signs of the pain inflicted by the terrorists span New York, from the dust cloud over the southern tip of Manhattan to the faces of the missing tacked onto walls in Greenwich Village to the thousands who watch heartbreaking images of the World Trade Center hulk on giant television screens in Times Square.
 But covering all that hurt, not only in New York but across the nation, are countless bandages in red, white and blue. In this city that is so often slow to show its feelings, the American flag bloomed in Manhattan and the boroughs, waved and worn by countless New Yorkers who wanted to do something, anything, to vent their anger and sorrow. 
 Tiny American flags fluttered from the radio antennas of taxis driven by men from Pakistan, Africa and Latin America. On the West Side Highway, a wall of people waved flags and cheered as rescue workers passed by. A bicyclist from Belgium, a florist from Korea, a Vietnam veteran from Puerto Rico, all flew the flag in Greenwich Village. Vendors hawked flags from Midtown sidewalks, patriotism at four bucks a pop. 
"Just as the terrorists know that we are watching them, we know that they are watching us," said Moses Davila, an unemployed teacher from Puerto Rico. "When they see us in the streets, wearing the flag, they know that we are not afraid of them, and that we will defeat them."
That sense of patriotism, and defiance, blanketed America.
In Miami, where the protests of the government's handling of the custody battle over Elian Gonzalez had included flag desecration (a tow-truck driver dragged the flag through the streets behind his truck), American flags blossomed from porches in Little Havana.
In California and the South, hardware and department stores sold out of flags. In the heartland, tiny flags fluttered like wildflowers in highway medians.
Mohammed Jaje, a cab driver from Pakistan who lives in Brooklyn, had one on his cab until someone took it on Friday night.
"I am not mad," Mr. Jaje said. "Maybe someone needed it. God bless America."
In Hammond, La., 60 miles northeast of New Orleans, Melissa Webb wore a T-shirt decorated with the flag on a shopping trip to the mall.
"We can't do anything to help them because we're down here," said Ms. Webb, 36, who works in a sporting goods store. At least, she said, she can fly the flag to show that her heart is with the rescue crews in New York.
Flag sightings were countless in the nation's capital, one of the biggest billowing from a staff lugged about the city by Joseph Doria, 82, a Filipino-American veteran of World War II.
"For years, I wave this flag in the streets and my neighbors think I'm crazy or a Communist," said Mr. Doria, who seemed in danger of toppling as he grasped a flag twice his size. "We divided and scattered after the war. But now, my friend, history repeats," he said of the terror attacks. "And we are learning America's heritage again."
Mr. Doria strutted off along the Mall, passing the Museum of American History where a woman pushing a stroller festooned with the Stars and Stripes entered an exhibit on the American presidency. A big banner proclaimed Harry S. Truman's observation: "Being president is like riding a tiger."
In Greenville, S.C., stores sold out of flags by the weekend. Home Depot and Wal-Mart did not have any left.
Around the city, thousands flapped in the wind, outside houses, on mailboxes, everywhere. It seemed that at least one in every three cars in Greenville had a flag on it, sometimes two.
Some did not have to shop for a flag. Bob Krause, a former marine, had flags that have been in the family for generations, flags that flew over old wars. Brock Sanders hung a 48-star American flag inherited from his grandfather who had flown it after Pearl Harbor was bombed.
On Peachtree Road in Atlanta, signs of patriotism marked almost every block -- flags flying at half-staff in Buckhead in front of Lenox Square and Phipps Plaza malls, at the Marta commuter train station. Expensive homes with neatly trimmed lawns have flags draped across the front door.
A red Cadillac with four large flags in each corner, its radio blaring "Stop, hey, what's that sound, everybody look what's going down," pulled out of Rocky's Italian Restaurant on Peachtree where a band was playing a "U.S.A. Jam" to raise money for the Red Cross. A woman walked out of a church on Peachtree wearing an antebellum-style Southern bonnet with red, white and blue ribbons.
Some telephone poles had homemade cardboard flags attached to them. Underneath one sign another one read "What's Next" in crude red lettering. Flags flew from high-rise buildings, apartments and construction sites. A sport utility vehicle was decorated with a homemade flag that looked as if it had been drawn by a child.
In one suburb, a house sported a freshly painted red, white and blue picket fence.
On a football weekend in the Deep South, cars that would normally have flown college flags now flew one, the same one.
In the heartland, the flag waved from the antennas of hot rods. In Brookville, Ohio, gasoline stations and the Holiday Inn pushed flags on two-foot sticks into their grounds. Hastily made paper flags appeared in windows of trailers and the homes of the wealthy. Flags appeared on the tops of buildings that had never before worn one. In Rockford, Rochelle and Le Roy, Ill., the flag hung at half-staff and from poles in front of courthouse squares, schools, town halls and police stations.
"There is hope in that familiar sight," wrote Carin Chappelow, in a column for The Journal Review, a daily newspaper with a circulation of 10,000 in Crawfordsville, Ind. The Wal-Mart there ran out of flags on Wednesday.
At the start of a prayer service in front of the courthouse in Crawfordsville, Glen Long, a member of the local Veterans of Foreign Wars, clutched three small flags. "Five minutes ago I had 48," Mr. Long said.
Near Washington, in the well-to-do, normally sedate Chevy Chase Village, on the northwest edge of the capital, six flags appeared on one block of Grafton Street. John Klein, a retired federal worker, usually puts one up on holidays. Mr. Klein's flag was there again. But there was another on the home of Laurence Alvarado, an executive of an accounting firm, and another at the home of Peter Yeo, a Senate aide, and at the home of Anne Urban, a consultant. Another waved across the street, from the stoop of Emilie Downs and Clark Evans Downs, a partner in a law firm in Washington. "Because of what happened," said Julia Downs, one of the couple's two college-age daughters.

HEADLINE: THE ATTACKS: THE ASIAN MARKETS; 
Tokyo Index Dives and Japan Buys Dollars to Stem Yen Rise

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
Japanese stocks plunged in afternoon trading today and the yen strengthened against the dollar as Japan nervously awaited the resumption of trading in New York.
 The benchmark Nikkei 225 was down 4.02 percent and sank to an 18-year low of 9,453 at one point. The broader Topix index was down 3.08 percent. Both recovered somewhat in the afternoon from sharper drops in early trading. 
 The dollar lost almost 1 percent of its value, trading at about 117 yen in early trading. At midday the Bank of Japan intervened, buying United States currency and strenghtening the dollar to as high as 117.91. 
On Sunday, Masajuro Shiokawa, Japan's finance minister, suggested that the Finance Ministry would step into currency markets to sell yen to prop up the dollar. He also said that he would urge the Bank of Japan at its monthly meeting on Tuesday to further relax monetary policy to maintain liquidity.
Adding to jitters today, the Kyodo news agency reported less than two hours before markets opened here that the Japanese government was searching for a dozen foreign Islamic extremists who came to Japan in early September. Acting on information supplied by "a foreign intelligence agency," Kyodo reported that the National Police Agency was searching airports, railroad stations and hotels for the extremists, who apparently flew to the country from Pakistan before Sept. 10. On Sept. 7, the United States Embassy in Tokyo warned that United States military installations in Japan and South Korea might become targets.
On Friday, Japan's securities watchdog said it was investigating trading about the time of Tuesday's terrorist attack on the United States to determine whether any transactions were linked to Osama bin Laden, the main suspect identified by the American government in the attacks. The Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission said it was studying trading on the Tokyo and Osaka exchanges. The investigations come as Japan is struggling with the effect of the disruption of trans-Pacific flights. Even though flights to the United States resumed over the weekend, thousands of Japanese vacationers have canceled their plans, pushing down airline and travel company stocks. With half of Japan's imports from the United States arriving by air, prices have jumped for a range of food, including tuna and strawberries. Japan imports 60 percent of its food. With one-third of Japan's exports to the United States going by air, Japan's trade surplus is expected to continue its decline in September.
Last week, the Nikkei reacted to the attacks on New York and Washington by falling 6.6 percent on Wednesday, largely within the range of the drops in major European markets. But Japan carried the psychological freight of dropping below the 10,000 level for the first time since December 1983.
Trading on Thursday did not move the index appreciably. But on Friday, the index rebounded 4 percent, closing at 10,008. This rebound was largely attributed to the news that the Mycal Corporation, one of Japan's largest supermarket chains, was filing for bankruptcy after its lead lender, Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, decided to pull the plug on bad loans, which totaled $13.2 billion. Traders read the bankruptcy -- the second-largest nonfinancial collapse in Japanese corporate history -- as evidence that Japanese banks were starting to move to dispose of their huge bad loan portfolio.
With Japanese telecommunications stocks off in recent weeks, the Vodafone Group P.L.C., Europe's largest cell phone company, reportedly plans to announce today that it is starting a bid for majority control of Japan Telecom, the nation's third-largest cell phone company. Earlier this year, Vodafone raised its stake in Japan Telecom to 45 percent. Vodafone would reportedly spend about $1.7 billion to raise its stake to 67 percent. Shares of Japan Telecom were up 2.7 percent in early trading.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE MEDIA; 
Media Trying, With Dignity, to Stem Huge Losses in Advertising

BYLINE:  By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
Images of death, destruction and mourning make an unseemly backdrop for pitching new cars, beer brands or fancy vacations, and that awkwardness is creating a costly predicament for the media industry in the aftermath of last week's terrorist attacks.
 Industry analysts estimate that the broadcast and cable television networks and stations have lost from $40 million to $100 million a day from Tuesday, when they began uninterrupted coverage of the attacks and rescue efforts, to Saturday morning, when the first network began gingerly interspersing a few commercials amid its news. Until recently, the television industry expected to sell about $53 billion in advertising this year. 
 In the magazine industry, Time, Newsweek and U.S. News & World Report all devoted costly special issues, free of advertising, to the attacks.
Many magazines and newspapers have lost other revenue as companies pulled or postponed their planned advertisements. And film studios and book publishers hoping to plug their latest releases have been squeezed out of the airwaves and public attention. 
Some say the gloom may lift as people return to their daily routines or seek relief through entertainment. Although theater attendance was low on Friday night, crowds flocked to the escape of the movies on Saturday. 
The weekend's box office returns -- $49.9 million for the top 10 movies -- was 13 percent below the previous weekend's total, 44 percent above the corresponding weekend last year. 
On Saturday morning, the television networks began testing viewers' reactions to the return of commercials. Some networks began broadcasting a few childrens' programs with ads before returning to the news. That same day, on "Today" and "The Nightly News," NBC, part of the General Electric Company, began inserting commercials into news coverage of the attacks.
No one knows how long the depressing effects of the attack on advertising and consumer enthusiasm might linger. The situation is unprecedented in the annals of the mass media. Unlike other national crises like the remote, short-lived and triumphant Persian Gulf war, the current situation is as disturbingly close to home as the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and as potentially open-ended as the Vietnam War.
During the gulf war, the extended periods of wall-to-wall, commercial-free news coverage were broken by returns to normal programming. Even so, there were often fewer commercials as advertisers cut back on spending or pulled potentially inappropriate images of war or even Arabs. Network programmers also felt sensitivity required less onerous commercial loads. That year, 1991, advertising spending fell 1.2 percent from 1990, the last fall in advertising.
The loss in revenue is all the more painful because this year the media industry is already suffering from one of the steepest drops in decades. Advertising is projected to fall more than 6 percent from last year after the end of the Internet boom. And the sudden squeamishness about commercial activity also bodes ill for consumers' inclinations toward indulgent diversions like shopping during the coming holiday season.
"We know consumer confidence levels are bad," said Lauren Rich Fine, an analyst at Merrill Lynch who follows newspaper publishers. "They were bad before this happened. It's really bad now." 
"I don't know if advertisers think they can spend and get consumers to come in. They don't know if there's going to be prolonged military action."
Some executives say they now see a patriotic purpose in returning to the airwaves, to demonstrate that terrorists cannot scare the country into altering its way of life.
"The president wants us to show we'll be getting back to business," said Anne Doyle, a spokeswoman for Ford in Dearborn, Mich.
In a survey conducted on Thursday by Eisner Communications, a Baltimore ad agency, 70 percent said they did not think it was appropriate for ads to be discontinued or reduced in light of the attacks.
Also, 79 percent of respondents said the government should encourage citizens to return to normal life and business as usual as quickly as possible, and 82 percent said they wished to do so.
But any selling is complicated now, said Peter Seeley, adjunct professor of marketing at the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley because, while advertising is a customary part of doing business, "on the other hand, you cannot seem callous."
" 'We love to make you smile' and 'Life tastes good' -- you clearly can't do that," he added, referring to the respective campaigns for McDonald's and Coca-Cola.
The television networks incurred the biggest financial losses by suspending their commercials in their all-news coverage for the last week, at a particularly sensitive time. "We are in the worst ad market in history," said Jack Myers, chief economist for the newsletter publisher Myers Reports. "And you are at the point in time when the networks were beginning to increase their their advertising rates because they were moving into the fall season."
The major networks have each delayed the start of the season, which Mr. Myers said were likely to result in lower ratings and further revenue losses. 
But luring back advertisers will not be easy. "The airlines and the financial services guys don't really want to go on the air, and the people with the happy-life commercials don't want to be there," said Jon Nesvig, president for sales at Fox Broadcasting. "People are trying to make sure their commercials are as appropriate as can be. We will probably see more patriotic, responsive commercials in the near future."
Mr. Myers said advertisers of all kinds will be reluctant to spend money on fall schedules almost certain to be pre-empted regularly by news coverage, much of it likely to be horrific and heartbreaking.
"As we look forward to the next weeks and months of war, there will be continued disruption of the schedules,"' he said, "which makes advertisers reluctant to launch campaigns knowing at any time you could have networks going over to 24-hour, advertiser-free coverage."
On Friday, Paul Rittenberg, senior vice president for ad sales at the Fox News Channel in New York, said he had commitments from only 30 of the network's 200 regular advertisers for the week ahead.
"You can't just pretend you're going back to selling Wheaties," he said. "It's hard to do a feel-good campaign when so many people are hurting."
Mr. Rittenberg said some of the largest advertisers, however, were returning to the fold, like Procter & Gamble and FedEx.
"You know, with a normal crisis, if there is such a thing, with something containable, you can say here's what we've lost, here's what we can make good, here's our exposure," he said. "This is completely open ended. It's a substantial hit."
Of course, times of war and crisis are when journalistic reputations are made. Americans have rarely immersed themselves more thoroughly in news media than in the hours and days after the attack. "You can sell everything you can print," said W. Dean Singleton, the chief executive of the Media News Group, whose flagship newspaper is The Denver Post.
But the expanded readership does not make advertisers less squeamish. "There's been a tremendous amount of advertising canceled," Mr. Singleton said. "Who is going to buy a car this weekend? Anyone who even thought about hiring anyone and running a help-wanted ad isn't going to run it this weekend. Obviously airlines aren't buying ads because they aren't flying much. Almost every category is getting hammered."
Ed McCarrick, publisher of Time magazine, part of AOL Time Warner, said the magazine had canceled commitments from several planned advertisers for space they pulled out of its Monday issue, dedicated to attack news. "Even though there might be an expense to us we feel this is part and parcel of what we do to build advertisers' relationships with us," he said. "This is a time when clients are trying to figure out what their message should be. You are sort of in uncharted water right now."
Most executives at the major media companies said it was too soon to tell the lasting effects.
But Michael D. Eisner, chairman of Walt Disney, which owns ABC, said he remained sanguine. "I am not sure this is a sky-is-falling scenario," he said. "There is no country whose economy is as strong as the United States, and there is no business as strong as the entertainment business in the United States." 
In an encouraging sign, Mr. Eisner said, a Disney cruise ship departed from Florida late last week with a full load of 2,200 passengers, even though many had to travel from as far away as Chicago and California and their flights had been canceled. 
"We expected nobody would be on the ship," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Advertisers have searched for the right tones to take since last week. (pg. C8)

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE MAGAZINES; 
Editors Rush to Revise Long-Made Plans

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
Whether at newsweeklies or women's magazines, editors scrambled last week to make their next issues relevant: to give voice to the terrors of the World Trade Center disaster and to provide context for articles that might otherwise seem callous or irrelevant.
 The task was hardest for the monthlies, like Good Housekeeping, which usually send their magazines to the printers weeks before they hit the newsstands. 
 Ellen Levine, the editor in chief of Good Housekeeping, consulted the archives to see what had been published after Pearl Harbor and subsequently during World War II to review how the magazine, owned by the Hearst Corporation, had covered that period. "It was the only thing I could think to do," she said. 
She did not find many solutions for the November issue, which was already at the printer and will arrive in 3.5 million subscriber's mailboxes in early October. But she and her team finally decided to bind a memorial card into the front of each copy, a note from the editors saying in part, "We share the sorrow so many Americans are feeling."
The next challenge for Ms. Levine is the magazine's Christmas issue, now in the works. With a military response to the terrorist attacks possible, trying to anticipate the mood of this country two months from now is difficult, Ms. Levine said. "The Christmas edition is usually uplifting," she said, "and yet how can you go into Christmas like that now?"
Her solution was to call back some pages that had already been produced and change the lineup of features. "We yanked random stories about what to wear to parties and assigned stories that reflect the tragedy."
In Good Housekeeping's October issue, already on the newsstands before the attacks, there is a profile of Mike Zeller, a 36-year-old New York City policeman who saved his wife's life. In the wake of the trade center disaster, "we have gotten more than a dozen calls from readers wanting to see if he is all right," she said (he is). "People are just reaching out."
Meanwhile at Vogue, the premiere fashion monthly owned by Conde Nast, the editor in chief, Anna Wintour, intends to show strong support for the American fashion industry and is planning to have references to it on the cover of the November issue, which may mean revising what is currently scheduled. "We want to be extremely positive, since the American collections were so hurt by the disaster," she said, referring to the cancellation of the annual Fashion Week, which was to have been held around Manhattan. And she said this issue would have an article on Berry Berenson Perkins, who was a passenger aboard the first jetliner to hit the World Trade Center last week. Ms. Perkins was a photographer for Vogue and other publications in the 1970's.
Magazines with twice-a-month frequency also examined their options. Forbes grappled with the problem of putting out a magazine that some might consider in poor taste in the current context: the annual Forbes 400 compilation of the nation's wealthiest people.
Although the editors discussed revising the issue -- typically among Forbes's best known and most profitable of the year -- the magazine, published by the family-owned Forbes Inc., was already at the printer last Tuesday. Minor changes were possible, but pulling the issue altogether was not, said the editor in chief, Steve Forbes, who said he wrote about the attacks in his editorial and "shoehorned" in other references.
"Our next regular issue will have prospective and thoughtful analysis about what this means for the American and global economy," Mr. Forbes added.
In fact, Mr. Forbes scrambled to find a way to make the issue relevant. 
"The 400 list really celebrates the values of creativity and freedom, mobility and opportunity," he said. "It is the essence of democratic capitalism and the opposite of their agenda," he said, referring to the terrorists.
The weeklies have, of course, the most flexibility, and they took full advantage of it. The three major American newsweeklies -- Time, Newsweek and U.S. News & World Report -- rushed to put out special issues last week that carried no advertising. And all three planned to devote the bulk of the next regularly scheduled issues to the crisis.
"I have been at this for 20 years, and there are none of us working here that can honestly say this is not the biggest story we have ever seen," said Richard Folkers, a spokesman for U.S. News, which is owned by the real estate developer Mortimer B. Zuckerman.
As for putting out a special issue, "The question is not can we do this, but how can we not?" Mr. Folkers added. "Our editor, Brian Duffy, said: 'It doesn't matter what beat you are on. We just need people to work the phones, do reports and get involved.' "
Sports Illustrated said that its next issue, which reaches newsstands on Wednesday, will have an emphasis on the attacks' effect on sports and sports figures. Among the articles under consideration is one on Garnet Bailey and Mark Bavis, hockey scouts for the Los Angeles Kings, who were on the second plane that crashed into the World Trade Center. Sports Illustrated, like Time, is a part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner. Newsweek is part of the Washington Post Company.
At The New Yorker, the editor, David Remnick, had four days after last Tuesday to completely revise his story list. As a result, almost the entire issue will be devoted the World Trade Center attack.
"Almost all of the front of the book will be devoted to this, with pieces by Toni Morrison and John Updike," Mr. Remnick said. For space reasons, the magazine, owned by Conde Nast, is postponing some fiction.
And for one of the few times in The New Yorker's history, "there will be no cartoons," Mr. Remnick said. The back page will contain a poem by the Polish poet Adam Zagajewski: "Try to Praise the Mutilated World."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Some magazines had time to focus their issues on the attack, in ways subdued or startling. But others were at the printers, and had time only to insert memorial cards.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE INVESTORS; 
Bracing for Reaction When Trades Resume

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
For a nation that became enamored of the stock market over the last decade, investing seemed a trivial, even forgotten pursuit, over the last week. Yet as the market prepared to reopen after a strike to the heart of Wall Street, investors faced an unavoidable question: What should I do now?
 Precedents are of limited value. Bullish advice may be dusted with patriotism, bearishness exaggerated by fear. So many professional investors and money managers are retreating to the most basic kind of guidance: Hold tight. 
 On his brokerage company's Web site, Charles Schwab has maintained the same message since Tuesday: "invest for the long-term" and "keep your cool during the rough times"; callers heard him reading the same message while they were on hold. 
Similarly, John J. Brennan, chief executive of the Vanguard Group, the nation's second-largest mutual fund company, wrote on his firm's Web site, "Regardless of how the financial markets respond to the news of the day, investors rarely are well served by hasty decisions."
Some experts sought to divine the immediate prospects for stocks by examining investors' responses to past crises. 
A study by Ned Davis Research of the market's reaction to 28 crises from 1940 to 1998 -- events like Pearl Harbor, the assassination of John F. Kennedy and the start of the gulf war -- found that the Dow Jones Industrial Average, on average, initially fell about 5 percent. But after about four months, the Dow rose 5.1 percent.
Citing the study, Keith Banks, chief investment officer for Fleet Asset Management, said, "I'd be surprised if we didn't see the markets open down 5 to 8 percent out of the box. That'll be a knee jerk," he added. "At some point, people will step in and begin a buying process."
Many investors, of course, had already started shifting from stocks to bonds and other conservative investments this year as the stock market continued its protracted retreat. When bond trading resumed Thursday, investors renewed that flight with a new vigor, sending the yield on two-year Treasury notes to their lowest level in decades.
But there have been few signs of panic. Activity at Fidelity Investments, Schwab and Vanguard has been exceedingly light, the firms said, with most customers seemingly preoccupied with the news. 
There are forces at work that could increase the chances of a rebound. Vice President Dick Cheney, on television on Sunday, urged Americans to "stick their thumb in the eye of the terrorists" by maintaining "their normal level of economic activity." The Securities and Exchange Commission said last week that it would temporarily ease restrictions that limit companies and executives from buying shares of their own stock. And many analysts expect that the Federal Reserve will quickly cut interest rates again. 
Meanwhile, in e-mail chain letters and on message boards, a grass-roots campaign, echoed by Washington, is under way, best summed up by one of the electronic messages: "Fight back. Buy Stock."
Many of Wall Street's most prominent forecasters -- the likes of Abby Joseph Cohen of Goldman, Sachs and Thomas Galvin of Credit Suisse First Boston -- were silent last week, in the immediate wake of the attacks. 
Among those who did speak out, there was obvious concern -- partly because the world's major economies were already weak, partly for fear that Sept. 11 was only the beginning of a period of volatility.
"A global recession had, hitherto, been averted by the resilience of the U.S. consumer," said Edward Kerschner, chief market strategist of UBS Warburg, in a note to clients on Wednesday. "But sadly, such resilience will be severely tested over the coming months."
For certain sectors of the stock market -- airline stocks, for example -- the concerns are obvious. 
American Airlines, United Airlines, Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines all have said they would eliminate 20 percent of their flights. Continental's chief executive, who on Saturday said that he would furlough 12,000 workers, warned that several major carriers could go bankrupt by year's end without a bailout from Washington.
"Airline revenues are going to be hit, and their costs are going to be higher," said Douglas D. Ramos, who manages four mutual funds for the Dreyfus Corporation. "They're going to get a double hit, because there's going to be a huge curtailing of people wanting to travel."
Other industries are expected to suffer, too. 
For example, property and casualty insurers, along with the reinsurance companies that back them, face claims that could run as high as $30 billion to $40 billion. And not all the victims are obvious: General Electric warned that its third-quarter earnings would come in below estimates because of World Trade Center-related claims of possibly $600 million facing its Employers Reinsurance Corporation subsidiary.
Some industries can expect to benefit from the turmoil. The shares of defense contractors like Northrop Grumman and Lockheed Martin often rise when war is in the air. Oil companies like ExxonMobil and Chevron could go up, too; though OPEC countries have promised to keep oil flowing, events could lead to volatility in supplies, which usually adds to oil company profits. 
Predictions about the market's behavior, though, may run smack into individual investors who choose to ignore traditional market logic. 
Gloria Dittus, who runs a Washington public relations firm, started one of the chain e-mails urging Americans to buy stock. "I'll buy 100 shares of American Airlines, because my brother is a pilot," Ms. Dittus said. "I don't care if I lose money. It's a statement."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Yes, New York Will Prosper Again, but It Needs More Than Moral Support

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
THE mayor says New York City will be better than ever. And some day it surely will be, because New York never stays down for the count -- never. But before the city and the region recover from last week's terrorist assault, they are destined to go through a tough time.
 Terrorism not only seeds pain and chaos, it spreads fear, paralyzes ordinary life and business. Though New York's leaders, intent on building confidence, don't want to talk about it in detail yet, the city's economy is shaky after a period of prosperity so long that young people never knew tough times, cannot imagine a city that is fearful, that is not forever shining like the lights of Times Square. 
 "My daughter is a little metaphor," Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday. "She's been going to this beautiful school, Stuyvesant. Everything's been great." But the high school, not far from the site of the suicide attacks, is now part of the rescue effort, and its students have to commute to Brooklyn Technical High School. "She's not sure where her records are, she's not sure of where anything is right now," Mr. Schumer said.
Neither is New York City. Although it is planning the remarkable reopening of the stock market today, it cannot confidently predict its income and does not know how much adrenaline it will get from the $20 billion in federal money for New York that Mr. Schumer and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton got from President Bush (and another $20 billion for security nationwide) .
Officials are fighting to keep businesses from fleeing the city or to lure them back. And that, too, will cost money. The city cannot possibly raise taxes, or predict the psychological impact of the attacks. "The city is not perceived as safe," said one elected official who would not speak for attribution because he feared sounding "like a doomsayer."
Public officials and economists are quietly saying that no matter how spectacularly Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani rallies New York -- and the mayor has earned the respect of even his harshest critics -- the city is in for a period as bad as the shaky years after the stock market's downturn in 1987, when offices went begging for tenants and there were more taxis than passengers. 
The country is supportive, but moral support will not make people want to rebuild or set up shop in New York or help a small business without the resources of a multinational company to find new offices. Nor will it make up for lost revenues, costly needs or understandable fears -- especially since Mr. Giuliani, his staff and most of the rest of city government leave in three months because of term limits. 
The timing even fueled a buzz about having the State Legislature find a way to extend Mr. Giuliani's term, but since that would give terrorists the power to upset a democratic election, the idea has seemed to fade. That leaves two mayors -- this one and the next -- to help New Yorkers come back from unspeakable heartache, and to rebuild more than the physical city.
THE numbers are daunting.
There were at least 50,000 jobs in the World Trade Center complex alone, and as many as 50,000 additional jobs in surrounding buildings. Workers in related businesses are affected, too, for now -- accountants and lawyers who worked for the financial companies in the trade center complex, restaurant workers, taxi drivers.
Revenues from personal income taxes, real estate and other business taxes will inevitably drop. So will the economic benefits of jobs lost throughout the region as the airlines industry cuts back -- and income lost from fewer tourists.
Alair A. Townsend, a former city budget director, is concerned. "I think there will be an enormous economic jolt," said Ms. Townsend, now publisher of Crain's New York Business.
"The mayor, I suspect, will have to look for cuts everywhere," she said, but on reflection predicted that the cuts would be concentrated because the city cannot possibly touch police, fire and sanitation services now. Some city officials predict a budget deficit growing to as much as $5 billion over the next few months.
There are optimistic developments, too. Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, pointed out yesterday that a few businesses forced to relocate had found space and are buying new equipment and furniture. "And if there is a ray of sunshine, the city is not the enemy of the rest of the country any more," he said.
That might help, that and the long view. Enzo Panebianco, a hansom cabby since the late 1970's, is not worried. "There are good times and there are bad in New York." he said yesterday in Central Park. "It will be O.K. People want to forget."
