HEADLINE: Attacks May Drain Income, Dow Jones Says 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, already hurt by a drop in advertising, said yesterday that the attacks last week had increased the risk that its third-quarter earnings would fall short of forecasts.
 Dow Jones, which was forced to evacuate its offices across the street from the World Trade Center, said the decline in advertising at The Journal was steeper than expected, a trend some foresee across the newspaper industry. 
 "Most advertisers pull their ads in response to crisis," said Peter Appert of Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. He noted that while circulation rises to meet the rising interest in the news, higher newsprint and labor costs offset any gains. "How deep the estimate reductions go," Mr. Appert said, "depends on political and economic developments over the next couple of months." 
The shares of Dow Jones fell $3.75 yesterday, to $49.
Analysts said Dow Jones was especially vulnerable because a lot of its revenue comes from financial and technology companies. "People are still trying to figure out how to do business and put their companies back together," said Edward Atorino of Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein.
The Journal's ad linage in July and August fell 35.4 percent; the paper had forecast a 25 to 30 percent decline. September shows no signs of improvement, Dow Jones said. 
Nevertheless, Dow Jones said it still hoped to reach the lower end of its earlier third-quarter forecast of 20 cents to 30 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected earnings of 29 cents a share, with estimates ranging from 25 cents to 32 cents.
On Friday, another big newspaper publisher, Gannett, said that ad revenue fell in August and that last week's events were likely to hurt revenue this month.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SMALL BUSINESSES; 
In the Shadow of Wall Street, Merchants Look for Assistance

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON and JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
They may work in the shadow of Wall Street's office towers, but most of the 375,000 or so people who commute every morning to the financial district are not high-paid stockbrokers. They are florists and jewelers, card-shop owners and newsstand workers, clothing-store clerks and shoe-repair men.
 Yesterday, they were cleaning up. They were grieving. And they were trying to get solid information and financial help that, despite major governmental efforts, are in short supply so far. 
 One such person was Mary Wilson, who was trying to find out when the police would let her drive in from her home in Astoria to retrieve her hot dog wagon from a garage on Ann Street east of the trade center.
There was also the problem of where she would go, with soot still falling. "You really can't go to another person's territory, they get mad," she said. "The thing is, how's anyone around here going to want to eat, if it smells so bad?"
For Ashak Patel of Queens who runs a small newsstand on Fulton Street, the biggest loss is the receipts from the lottery. "We have no power for the machine, but everyone still wants to play," he said, adding that about a third of the $4,000 of business he lost last week would have come from the state lottery.
Some people were seeking financial assistance yesterday -- and a few have at least the promise of it. The Federal Small Business Administration has already agreed to make 10 disaster loans, totaling $448,900, said Barbara Manning, a spokeswoman for the agency. The Empire State Development Corporation said that since Thursday, 500 people have visited its business assistance center and 4,100 calls have come in on its hot line.
One person looking for a loan was Henry Mishenie, whose store, Coast to Coast Communications on Nassau Street, specializes in cellphones. That is in the area that opened up yesterday, but Mr. Mishenie said he had no phone service, and thus, no business. "I can't check people's credit," he said.
At a city assistance center on Pine Street, Mr. Mishenie said he did not know how much he might need. "We don't have income and don't know how long this will be," he said. "And I owe people money."
Another person at the center, Peter Kotsoris, said he was there to apply for a loan and to learn what damage might have been done to the Park Place building that houses his nightclub, B-52. But he did not sound optimistic about the future for his business, which drew half its customers from the trade center. "Even if we reopen," he said, "nobody will go out down there because their friends were in the World Trade Center."
Lucja Andruczyk is out of a job, missing a paycheck and unsure about her future. Ms. Andruczyk had worked as a housekeeper at the World Trade Center since 1994, a year after her family arrived here from Poland. Her paycheck was in a building that collapsed, she said, and her employer will not reissue it right away.
She has worked only one day in the past week, and has been told that most of the people who cleaned the twin towers will have to apply for unemployment insurance. But she will not know for sure until a union meeting on Thursday. Until then, "I am not thinking clearly," she said. "I cannot put it behind me."
Some people have problems that are more than monetary. On William Street, Iyskyie Yusupoe tried to explain to three police officers what had happened to the shattered door of his shop, Best Shoe Repair and Shine.
Was anything taken? Mr. Yusupoe said he did not know, but perhaps he would not say. Where is he from? Russia, he said, after a long pause, looking at a woman in a head scarf and embroidered top who was watching television news. Will he reopen? Yes, he said, "I like this area."
Kasim Ghonoja said he had no problem reopening Ray's Jewelry on Hanover Square. Things were not even too dusty, and the store will reopen on Friday after closing for the Jewish holidays. No problem, he repeated -- "except I miss my brother."
His 23-year-old brother-in-law, Eli Chalouh, was in the trade center when it collapsed; Mr. Ghonoja said he had been searching the hospitals for four days, to no avail.
Most were far luckier. Cleaning was the major order of the day at many places yesterday. At Rochester Big & Tall on Wall Street at Pearl, Robert Butler had his tie-wearing salesmen spritzing the doors and wiping them with paper towels.
At the American Greeting store on Nassau Street, Rich Kromer and his staff were dusting the hordes of porcelain angels and snowman figurines and big-eyed moppet statuettes. A door lock wasn't working, Mr. Kromer said, but the store's only losses were some knickknacks in the windows that were smashed after the explosions nearby.
Michael Karp's employees at Ranch 1 Chicken were using Lysol and hoses to swab down the sandwich store on Pearl Street, in hopes of opening by 12:30. "We will not open if I see this," he warned, running a finger along a molding and displaying the dust. 
While many merchants fretted that business would be slow, plenty of people came into Dick's Hardware store on Pearl Street when it reopened yesterday, in search of brooms, flashlights or other cleanup aids. The trouble was that Dick's had none to sell; the police commandeered anything useful last Tuesday.
"Ropes, batteries, power tools, snow shovels -- you name it, they took it," said Michael Ullman, whose family has been running the business since 1956. "Of course, none of us were thinking about money at that point, but now I'm hoping we'll get paid soon so we can stay in business."

HEADLINE: The Economy, Too, Will Recover 

BYLINE:  By Stephen S. Roach; Stephen S. Roach is chief economist and director of global economics for Morgan Stanley.

DATELINE: ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands 

 BODY:
The United States economy and the broader global economy were probably in a mild recession before the devastating terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. The shock that America now feels can only make matters worse for a while. Yesterday's wrenching drop in world financial markets suggests that investors have been quick to figure this out.
 Yet even in this despair, hope for recovery exists. The markets are responding to the extraordinary blow of the terrorist attacks, and the painful impact of that blow on American confidence and optimism will eventually dissipate. Just as the business cycle proved to be alive and well in the economic downturn this year, now it is only a matter of when and under what conditions an upswing will occur. 
 This global recession had been in the making for some time. During the latter half of the 1990's, booming American economic growth probably accounted for as much as 40 percent of the cumulative increase in world output. But that means that the world economy had become overly dependent on American growth, making it exceptionally vulnerable to changes in our economy.
Unfortunately, America's boom contained the seeds of the bust that emerged just about a year ago. The Nasdaq bubble infected the broader economy. Consumers mistakenly viewed the stock market as a new and permanent source of saving. They let personal saving rates plunge to nearly 70-year lows; they also went heavily into debt. Corporations made similar mistakes, overinvesting in information technologies.
Once the bubble popped, these excesses diminished. Asia, at the other end of global supply chains that connect American companies to offshore producers, was hit hard by the end of the technology-driven boom. America's Nafta partners, Canada and Mexico, also felt impacts, since their exports to the United States account for more than 25 percent of their gross domestic products.
Asian weakness then took a toll on Europe and Japan, resulting in an unusually swift and sharp deceleration in the flow of global trade. The three largest economies of the world -- the United States, Japan and Germany -- collectively contracted in the second quarter of 2001.
Just days before Sept. 11, there were additional signs of rapid deterioration in the economy. The unemployment rate rose by four-tenths of a percentage point to 4.9 percent in August -- an unusually sharp increase by any standards. Layoffs rose further in early September. And then came the toughest news of all -- a sharp decline in consumer confidence reported by the University of Michigan right before the terrorist attacks.
In that context, the attacks on America are likely to inflict a devastating economic blow, given the effect on the fragile state of consumer confidence. In the face of fears about national security, consumers will almost certainly defer all but the most essential purchases, putting cars, furniture, appliances and vacations on hold. And barring a swift and decisive victory over terrorism, consumer confidence is likely to be subdued for some time.
This could well be the transforming event of the American and global business cycle. For the past year, the downturn has been driven mainly by weakness in business spending on information technologies. Now that downturn will be made worse by weakness in consumer demand -- which until now has been the most resilient factor in the economy.
This has important implications for the broader global economy, as well. Asian markets were hoping to weather the worst of America's technology-led downturn. Countries like China, which sold the United States more consumer goods than technology products, could fend off a deep economic slide if American consumer confidence and purchasing stayed high. Now even that is gone. The result is likely to be a deeper and longer global recession than we had expected.
But the unique nature of this downturn -- sealed by a brutal act of terrorism -- also means that recovery may come as America begins the process of healing. 
Yesterday's half-a-percentage-point cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve was the eighth cut this year. There is now plenty of monetary stimulus. Washington has also swiftly decided to provide a $40 billion emergency spending package to cover some of the costs related to last week's attacks, and more expenditures are likely as planning begins for more internal security and military actions. 
The sharp decline in world stock markets yesterday shows it is too early for investors to start banking on the recovery that will eventually follow. In large part, that is because financial markets had previously been hoping that an upturn was just around the corner. Those hopes have been broken. But painful dislocations in financial markets are unavoidable in every recession after every boom. The stock market drop shows that investors have become more realistic in assessing a worsening outlook. That suggests that financial markets now have a better chance to stabilize and then respond to any new shifts in the economic climate. It is out of such capitulation that the seeds of recovery are often sown. That remains the hope for a world now in recession.

HEADLINE: Securing the Skies 

 BODY:
All airports but Washington's Reagan National have reopened in the aftermath of last week's attack, but commercial aviation in the United States has been forever altered. The premium is now on security instead of convenience and speed. That is the only sensible course after hijackers seized control of four passenger planes and turned three of them into weapons of mass destruction. 
 Few freedoms are as vital to the nation's character, and essential to its economy, as the freedom to travel. But to ensure that it is preserved, the rules and expectations of flying have to change. The freedom to wake up in New York and get to San Francisco in time for lunch is going to have to give way to the freedom to get to San Francisco safely, even if it takes all day. 
 Americans should accept more stringent security not as a short-term inconvenience but as a permanent redefinition of the flying experience. No longer can passengers expect to arrive at the airport 30 minutes before departure or check in at an automated kiosk that handles security questions the way A.T.M.'s ask if you want a receipt. 
The Federal Aviation Administration has banned curbside check-in and will allow only ticketed passengers to go to the gate. It has called for more uniformed law enforcement agents, individual searches and luggage-matching to ensure that everyone who checks a bag boards the flight. Passengers will no longer be able to carry small knives or other cutting devices aboard. 
It is a reassuring start, but only that. A more fundamental long-term overhaul is needed to properly police the stream of two million passengers each day onto 40,000 flights. In light of last week's attacks, vigilance at airports must be deemed a matter of national security. It can no longer be delegated to airlines and their undertrained and underpaid private guards. 
The glaring vulnerabilities in the present system have been extensively diagnosed in a series of presidential commissions and other reviews. Weapons are often not caught by screeners, unauthorized personnel can easily gain access to aircraft, and workers who are authorized to get near the planes have not had their backgrounds checked. Airlines have been slow to deploy the most sophisticated bomb-scanning devices. Passenger lists are not screened for potential terrorists. Shockingly, two of the hijackers last week were able to buy tickets under their own names and board their flights despite being on the F.B.I.'s terrorism watch list. 
For years, pilot training and airline procedures have reflected the prevailing wisdom that it is best to cooperate with hijackers until a plane has landed safely. But security measures must now be updated to account for the possibility of more airliners being turned into weapons. Transportation Secretary Norman Mineta has rightly called for a revival of the "sky marshal" program, whereby armed undercover agents are placed on flights. He has also appointed separate advisory commissions to recommend, within two weeks, additional airport security measures and to look at ways of fortifying cockpit doors. The government must also consider creating a specialized airport security force.
As airlines cut back on service to accommodate the new security procedures, consumers will have to live with fewer choices. The men and women who perished last week would gladly have accepted a slower, less convenient air travel system if they knew it meant the difference between life and death.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
The Big Terrible

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan 

 BODY:
By quirk of fate I have been in Jordan for much of the World Trade Center crisis. Sitting here, I've been struck by the number of e-mails that have reached me from friends around the Arab-Muslim world -- from Kuwait and Cairo, from Lebanon and Turkey -- all just wanting to say how upset they were with what happened and checking if the family was O.K. In their own way, they each echoed what a secretary in Jordan tried to say to me in the most eloquent broken English -- that this terrorist attack was "the big terrible." 
 I relate this not to suggest that my friends around the Middle East reflect all public opinion out here. They do not. One need only visit some of the most popular Arabic Web sites and chat rooms to see that public opinion in the Arab world is split about 50-50 -- between those appalled by the bombing and those applauding it. The harshest e-mails, Arab techies tell me, come from Islamists in Saudi Arabia and the gulf, home to some of the hijackers. 
 No, I relate this simply to say that America still has many admirers in this part of the world. For all that Middle Easterners get enraged with America, many others value it, envy it and want their kids there. They envy the sense of ownership that Americans have over their own government, they envy its naive optimism, its celebration of individual freedom and its abiding faith that the past won't always bury the future. For a brief, terrifying moment last week people out here got a glimpse of what the world could be like without America, and many did not like it. America is not something external to them; people carry around pieces of it in ways often not articulated.
Why does all this matter? Because we need the help of the moderate Arab states to fight this war. And for now, most of these Arab leaders are ready to cooperate with us -- because enough of their publics are tilted our way. But the moderate Arab leaders are praying that the U.S. will proceed carefully and surgically, because they know that public opinion here, even after all the American deaths, is by no means solidly pro-American.
On Sunday I interviewed Jordan's King Abdullah, one of America's real friends. He had three wise messages: We can win if you Americans don't forget who you are, if you don't forget who your friends are and if we work together. "The terrorists are trying to break down the fabric of the U.S.," said the Jordanian monarch. "They want to break down what America stands for. The terrorists actually want to provoke attacks on Arabs or Muslims in the U.S., because if the American communities start going after each other, if we see America fragment, then you destroy that special thing that America stands for. That's what the terrorists want -- they want to be able to turn to your friends here and say, 'Look, this is all a myth.' 
"That is why you have to be very careful when you respond -- make sure you respond in a way that punishes the real perpetrators, that brings justice, not revenge, because otherwise you will be going against your own ideals, and that is what the terrorists want most." 
At the same time, U.S. strategy can't just be about punishing the bad guys. It also has to be about helping the good guys. Jordan is a country with a decent government and an economy that -- despite the Intifada -- grew 3.9 percent last year, thanks largely to a free-market approach, with an emphasis on software, technology and textile development that is drawing U.S. investors. That's a lot of jobs. (Jordan is also the first Arab country to sign a free trade agreement with the U.S., but ratification has been foolishly held up by the Senate.) In short, Jordan is becoming a good Arab model for how to do things right. We have a fundamental interest in this model succeeding, for all its neighbors to see. Terrorists thrive in failing, stagnant, weak states with illegitimate regimes -- not countries on the rise.
Which brings up the king's last point: "The bad guys work together, but we don't. The terrorist groups are a global organization. They know how to cooperate and stay focused on their military objectives. We have not. Some people didn't want to share intelligence. Some said, Islamic terrorism is not my problem, and looked the other way. We can defeat them, but only if we learn to cooperate globally as effectively as they do."

Ulster Catholic Leader Resigns from Party Post
John Hume, a leader of the Catholic civil rights movement in Northern Ireland for the last 40 years, announced in Belfast that he was stepping down as head of the province's Social Democratic and Labor Party. Mr. Hume, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1998, said the timing of his resignation was dictated by his deteriorating health. A3

Optimism After Korea Talks
North and South Korean negotiators broke through a six-month hiatus in negotiations with a sweeping agreement on a new round of family visits starting next month. The president of South Korea, Kim Dae Jung, who has made better relations with the North a priority of his administration, indicated his relief that the talks had taken place. A5

Experts Needed in East Timor
Constitutionalists offering their expertise to new or reforming nations will begin arriving soon in East Timor as they draw up the written foundations for statehood. Last month East Timor, newly independent from Indonesia, elected an 88-member council to draw up a constitution and gave it just 90 days to do so. At the moment, there is essentially no expertise here in constitution-making. Only three council members have studied law. A10

Third Year of Drought in Iran
The country's largest body of fresh water, the seventh largest in the world, is now desert. The worst drought in 30 years is strangling Sistan-Baluchistan Province. A4

Forces Approved in Macedonia
Bowing to European Union pressure, the Macedonian government approved the deployment of a modest NATO security force to shore up a precarious peace agreement with the rebellious Albanian minority. Macedonia's reluctant Parliament now looms as the last major hurdle in a process aimed at defusing the fifth ethnic conflict in the Balkans since 1991. A3

Peace Efforts in Middle East
The violence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip continued as Palestinian and Israeli leaders issued statements in response to urgent calls from the United States for truce talks. Since the attacks in the United States last week, Washington has called for greater efforts to end a year of Israeli-Palestinian violence as the Americans try to bring Arab and Islamic states into a coalition to repel terrorism. The European Union is also pursuing efforts to bring the two sides together for truce talks. A7

A Rift Over Rights For Rio Grande Water
Tensions are growing between South Texas farmers and Mexico over water rights to the Rio Grande after one of the driest summers on record along the border. Mexico has warned that not only will it fail to meet a Sept. 30 deadline to release millions of gallons of water it is required by treaty to provide farmers for irrigation but also that it needs to hold back even more water because of the prolonged drought. A14

Accusation Prompts Audit
Regulators have ordered an audit of Duke Power's financial statements to determine if the company underreported income to avoid cutting rates for two million customers in North Carolina and South Carolina. Internal company documents obtained by The State newspaper in Columbia, S.C., indicate that top Duke executives discussed underreporting income as early as December 1998, the newspaper said. The documents discussed how Duke Power could avoid exceeding its "allowed return." A16

Donald Schregardus, the Ohio environmental regulator nominated by President Bush to be the top law enforcement official of the Environmental Protection Agency, withdrew his name from consideration, saying that it was clear that his nomination "will not be considered in a timely manner." Several Democratic senators and environmental groups said Mr. Schregardus had been lax in enforcing pollution laws in Ohio. A16

Search After a Bridge Collapse
Recovery crews resumed searching the water for the bodies of people who may have been trapped in their cars after driving off a bridge that partly collapsed when it was hit by barges and a tugboat. The police said that at least five people had been confirmed dead and that an unknown number were missing in the Intracoastal Waterway after the collision on Saturday knocked out part of the bridge, the Queen Isabella Causeway, the only one linking Port Isabel and South Padre Island. Murderer Escapes From Jail
A convicted murderer escaped from a Mississippi jail on Sunday, a day before he was to stand trial for a 1995 stabbing death. The inmate, Kenneth Moody, 26, and his cellmate, Scotty Thomas, 33, somehow obtained a hacksaw blade, cut through an air-conditioning duct, and crawled through the duct to the roof, officials said. They jumped to the ground and vanished. The authorities began a manhunt and said that the two men should be considered extremely dangerous. (AP)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Stock Market Reopens, And Share Prices Fall
Six days after the worst terrorist attack on United States soil, the nation's stock market reopened and prices plummeted, reflecting investors' concerns about already fragile world economies pushed closer to the brink.
 Prices of stocks and bonds sank in spite of efforts by the Federal Reserve and other central banks to buoy the markets. Before stocks opened for trading, the Fed cut its benchmark rate by half of a percentage point. Page A1. 

Never before has a day in which the stock market tumbled so far seemed like a good day. But yesterday was a day unlike any other. The losses were smaller than many had expected, and they reflected a surge of buying by ordinary Americans, who were evidently convinced that it was patriotic to be bullish.
Floyd Norris: Market Place A1.

Trading Floor Moves to New Jersey
From where E. Stanley O'Neal, the president of Merrill Lynch, stood yesterday morning, the raucous trading floor behind him looked like a familiar Wall Street landscape. But instead of being at the World Financial Center in Manhattan, this trading floor was on the 10th floor of an office tower in Jersey City. C3.

Merchants Look for Assistance
Most of the 375,000 or so people who commute to the financial district are not high-paid stockbrokers. They are florists and jewelers, card-shop owners and newsstand guys. Yesterday, they were cleaning up. They were grieving. And they were trying to get information and financial help that, despite major governmental efforts, are in short supply so far. C9.

Buffett Backs Away From Offer
Warren E. Buffett backed away from a tender offer for Finova Group, saying that he was free to do so because the attack on the World Trade Center amounted to a war. C5.

Insurance Brokers Search for Help
Days after escaping from the 92nd floor of 2 World Trade Center, Brian Cohen, who works for the insurance broker Aon, was on the phone to a client, J. C. Penney. With his computer and files destroyed, there was not much he could do. But he was back at work. And one of his first instincts was to call customers. C8.

Evaluating the Effect on Advertising
As Madison Avenue continues to re-evaluate what business as usual may mean after last week, analysts are pondering the effects on advertising and the direction of the economy. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C9.

Oracle Says License Sales May Fall
Oracle, a maker of business software, said the threat of war could drive sales of its software licenses down 15 percent. C13.

2 Companies Warn on Earnings
Two financial services companies said last week's attacks would significantly reduce their earnings. American Express lowered its forecast for the third quarter, and Citigroup said its losses might reach $700 million because of insurance claims and lost revenue at its securities and banking units. C13.

Vodafone Plans Move in Japan
The Vodafone Group said it would buy an additional 21.7 percent of Japan Telecom, a purchase that would give it a controlling interest in the company. World Business, Section W.

G.M. Agrees to Buy Part of Daewoo
General Motors has reached an agreement to buy most of the Daewoo Motor Company for about $1 billion. World Business, Section W.

Inventories Decreased in July
Inventories of unsold goods at companies fell in July for a sixth consecutive month and sales increased before last week's attacks. C13.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VOICES; 
Stock Investors Shrug Off a Plunge and Wait

BYLINE:  By N. R. KLEINFIELD with DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
As the trading rituals of capitalism re-established themselves yesterday, individual investors watched the sobering saw-toothed lines of the indexes and the ever-tumbling prices, feeling the apprehension of badly shaken markets.
 Some bought, especially in the morning, and many others abruptly sold. But, to a large extent, they waited. 
 "It wasn't a day to trade," said Lorraine Trapp, who works in New York in the circulation department of a magazine. "It just wasn't." 
Friends had suggested that she buy, and told her to look at this stock, that stock. "I want to wait," she said. 
It was the first opportunity since the terrorist attack for Americans to wade into the stock market and buy, sell or do nothing at all. Throughout the last week, even as the subject of the idle markets increasingly crept into news reports trying to gauge the ramifications of the devastation, it seemed crass to think about money. What mattered was life itself.
But with the opening of the stock exchanges yesterday, after four days of suspended trading, there was no avoiding the subject. Individuals had to make decisions.
But even as the Dow Jones industrial average shrank by hundreds of points and the Nasdaq found itself rudely battered, many individuals remained remarkably calm and unflinching.
The tragic context in which the trading took place was so extraordinary that perhaps never before would an individual investor have spoken of the Dow as did Gordon Morlan, 65, a retired teacher in Grosse Pointe Park, Mich.: "We were concerned to see it dip 600 points. But, on the other hand, I consider that to be a reasonable adjustment." 
Certainly there were people who sold, some compelled by margin calls to put up more cash, after shares they had bought with borrowed money plunged in value, and others simply wishing to return money to safer refuges.
There were still others who bought, out of an expanded sense of patriotism or because they sniffed bargains. But interviews with investors around the country indicated that the prevalent sentiment in one of the market's riskiest days was to hold fast.
In Pocahontas, Ark., Henry McNabb, 42, was up and ready at 6 a.m. for the market opening at 8:30 Central time, giving him hours of time to worry. In the office of his funeral home -- outside, American flags were draped from the 12 light posts that lined the parking lot -- he clicked on the television and channel-surfed among CNBC, ABC, NBC and CBS, absorbing market intelligence as fast as it was broadcast. He switched on his computer and logged onto an Internet stock quote service.
He was ready for action. But as the markets commenced their relentless downward path, he was a study in inaction. He did not activate his Charles Schwab account. He did not send a sell order. "I'm a little bit encouraged," he said, even as the averages sank by 5 percent right at the start. "I'm just watching, hoping and praying we recover, hoping we don't go into a depression." 
Patrick O'Byrne, 33, and his wife, Geri, are saving to buy a house in Bergen County, N.J. They have money in three mutual funds, all of it earmarked for their down payment. On Sunday night, they compared thoughts about what to do when the markets reopened. They seriously thought about pulling out, but ultimately decided to do nothing.
"I think a lot of people are just scared and want to take their money and put it in a pillowcase," Mr. O'Byrne said. "I don't blame anyone for looking out for their own interests financially, their own concerns, but I am confident that we will recover."
Leong Joe Tsung, 40, a production worker at AOL Time Warner who lives in Princeton, N.J., has a substantial investment portfolio, 100 percent of it in stocks. He, too, took no action yesterday. "I don't want to take advantage of the situation," he said. "Today is not a day to be doing much with money."
Nikolaos Monoyios, a portfolio manager for OppenheimerFunds who escaped the World Trade Center last week and took up an office in central New Jersey, was asked by his 22-year-old daughter whether she should buy stocks to display her patriotism. Mr. Monoyios advised her against acting on her emotions. "Just do nothing," he said. 
There was so much information to digest and make sense of. There was the Federal Reserve slicing interest rates, the parade of companies promising to buy back their own shares, the repeated calls over the weekend to buy, or at least not sell, out of patriotic resolve. 
While many investors felt patriotism did not necessarily extend to stock market activity, others were moved by the messages. "We owe it to the memory of the people who were killed not to sell stock," said David Grossberg, an independent businessman from Albertson, N.Y. "I'm not selling at all. I find it offensive."
Or, as JoAnn Kelly, a retired banker who lives in Grosse Pointe Woods, Mich., said: "We are sitting tight. We basically feel that if people panic, then that hurts all of us."
Fidelity, the big investment house, said call volume was high but below what was expected, that buy orders exceeded sell orders, and that "people were very measured." Vanguard mobilized 300 members of its "Swiss Army," a contingent of former and current workers, including the company's chief executive, John J. Brennan, to assist taxed phone operators. The flow of calls was heavy in the morning, but then most of the Swiss Army was disbanded.
There were any number of individuals who could not cope with another day of worry. An investor in his mid-50's, who asked not to be identified because he had just learned that a friend had died in the World Trade Center collapse, was at the Schwab office in Rockefeller Center before the market opened because he wanted to move his portfolio of about $250,000 from a stock mutual fund into a money market fund. He had left the money planted in stocks during the gyrations of the past, but had reached his limit of tolerance.
"It's lower earnings but it's lower risk," said the investor, who is semiretired after having been laid off last year. "When you have worked for 30 years for your money, you don't want it to evaporate in a day."
Others plunged in and bought. Todd Shapiro, who owns a public relations firm in Hauppauge, N.Y., bought 100 shares of I.B.M. and 500 of AOL Time Warner when the market was down 600 points. "I think it's important now to support our economy in time of need," he said. "It was an unbelievable buying opportunity. Like our country, the market will be back stronger than ever." 
John Mannino, 47, who owns a restaurant marketing company in Broomall, Pa., also saw opportunity. "G.E. is trading in the low 30's; they're practically giving it away," he said. "I was waiting for a climate to give me a signal that it was time to expand my G.E. position, and now I can." 
In Milwaukee, Gregory Mews checked stock quotes on a cellphone as he worked. Mr. Mews, 48, is the assistant manager of a Walgreens and the treasurer of a small investment club. Before the attack, the club's account had dwindled to $525,000 from $750,000 at the start of last year. But at a meeting on Thursday, the members decided that terrorist strikes would not cause them to shrink from the stock market. They voted to buy additional shares of EMC, the big data storage company. 
Some other investors, hard as it may seem to believe, tuned out entirely.
Robert Croskery, a 68-year-old retired clergyman who lives in Cincinnati, has money in about 40 stocks, about half of them blue chips like Eli Lilly and Procter & Gamble. Fortunately, he did have a longstanding rule of never investing in airlines, which were particularly savaged in yesterday's trading.
Not only did he not buy or sell yesterday, he did not even turn on the television or the radio to check on the market's decimation. "I'm concerned," he said. "But I'm invested in what I believe are quality issues." 
He said he would wait until he got today's newspaper to see how the market did. In the meantime, he washed his car.

HEADLINE: The Fed's Statement About Rates 

 BODY:
Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates: 
 The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to lower its target for the federal funds rate by 50 basis points, to 3 percent. 
In a related action, the board of governors approved a 50-basis-point reduction in the discount rate to 2 1/2 percent. The Federal Reserve will continue to supply unusually large volumes of liquidity to the financial markets, as needed, until more normal market functioning is restored. As a consequence, the F.O.M.C. recognizes that the actual federal funds rate may be below its target on occasion in these unusual circumstances. 
 Even before the tragic events of last week, employment, production, and business spending remained weak, and last week's events have the potential to damp spending further. Nonetheless, the long-term prospects for productivity growth and the economy remain favorable and should become evident once the unusual forces restraining demand abate. For the foreseeable future, the committee continues to believe that against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness. 
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Richmond, Chicago, Minneapolis, Dallas and San Francisco.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE INVESTORS; 
There's Little Sign of Panic In Firm's Hot-Stove League

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
Like clockwork, Gene Morgan arrived at 10 a.m. today at the main branch of Charles Schwab to hash over the stock market with a group of fellow retirees. Mr. Morgan, 80, a retired lawyer, wore his characteristic pinstriped suit, and he said it was precisely days like these that reinforced the importance of dressing well, even when just hanging out with friends.
 "The more difficult the conditions, the better dressed you need to be," he said, adding with tongue planted sufficiently in cheek to elicit laughter from his friends, "You've got to go down with the flags flying." 
 They have gathered many mornings over the years, leaning against the railing across from the electronic ticker, their fingers tucked in the front of their pants, and discussing everything under the sun -- but mostly stocks. Today's topic was last week's terrorist attacks, and what they meant to the country. 
"Just hold in there," said Glen Brakefield, 77, a retired merchant seaman who served in World War II. A sturdy fellow, Mr. Brakefield told his compatriots there was no sense selling stocks in a panic, since the market would come back as it always had. "What's the hurry?"
Mr. Morgan took polite issue. "I must differ with my friend about hanging on," he said. Mr. Morgan acknowledged that his interest was academic, since he had little to invest these days. But based on years as a day trader, he did have firm advice: "Get out and stay out until the end of the year."
The debate was far from theoretical to investors who trickled in to use computer terminals to check their portfolios or to place trades. They assessed how much damage they had been dealt and whether to liquidate, or, as some economists and politicians have urged, hold tight in a show of patriotism.
One investor, Amy Thai, 35, a dental hygienist, stopped in to check on her family's investments. Last Friday, six members of her family met to discuss how to handle their investments. They decided to hold -- not wanting to sell in a panic and feeling that it would be unpatriotic to sell.
"I feel confident we have good companies," she said, adding, "If we sell stocks, we'll be showing that terrorists affected our economy."
From another terminal, a voice rose out. "Merck is up," said Herman Moss, 73, a retired programmer and member of the informal investing klatch. The report set off a small debate, and a fierce commentary from Alfred R. Karahadian, 84.
Mr. Karahadian said the terrorist attack was "taking its toll," but with important exceptions.
"It's not across the board," he said. "Drug stocks are up." He added that he was surprised the market had not fared much worse, but even if it had, he was standing firm.
"I learned hard lessons as a young buck," he said. "These corrections come and go, and I just ride them out."
Mr. Karahadian seemed to be the unofficial group's unofficial dean, and he got a great deal of attention because he flew B-24 bombers in World War II. When he entered Schwab around 10:45, a friend ribbed him that it appeared the Air Force was out of business last week when it did not intercept the hijacked planes.
"Just be patient," Mr. Karahadian said, a bit sternly. "They've got something in the works." 
Indeed, members of this group bring a perspective of having seen many high and low points in American history. But to a man, they said they had never seen anything like last week's attacks.
One man, a 55-year-old who apparently was the junior member, said he had protested American involvement in conflicts since he had returned from Vietnam. But the man, an advertising executive who insisted on anonymity, said his pacifist leanings were being tested now.
"This is the first time where I'm walking a fine line," he said. He said he did not mind seeing the guilty punished but did not want innocent people or civilians injured.
His elders, meanwhile, seemed to think that though this event was different from anything they had seen, it was in one crucial way no different. The stock market, the economy, and America in general have been rocked before, but they always bounce back, they said.
"It'll come back," Mr. Brakefield said of the market. "We always come back."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SCENE; 
Wall Street Returns to Work, Finding Good in Falling Prices

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY with DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Barricaded, its stone pillars bandaged in American flags, dust lapping its sidewalks, the New York Stock Exchange re-opened yesterday in a burst of patriotism and closed at a sharp low, its rallies and deeper dips mirroring its patrons' mixed mood of defiance and fear.
 "People felt they were doing what they should do, doing their duty," Richard A. Rosenblatt, a floor trader on the exchange and a veteran of financial crises going back to the 1970's, explained as the market closed. 
 "This was about getting the markets open and keeping them orderly and showing the world that we're not beaten, said Mr. Rosenblatt, who owns a trading company bearing his name.
"This wasn't about making good trades. It was about going on." Even before market jitters set in, there was a kind of physical anxiety, or perhaps just a dread of reliving Tuesday, all around the ghostly financial district, as brokers gingerly stepped out from downtown subway stops at 7:30, walked past police barriers, rows of masked rescue workers and breathed in the disaster. 
"The smell is everywhere, it stinks," an aghast trader in an elegant gray suit, decked with a red, white and blue lapel ribbon, whispered into his cellphone as he made his way to the stock exchange. He listened, then blurted out that which seemingly motivated thousands of others to return to work yesterday. "I guess I just wanted to be here." Another pause. "I love you." 
For him, like so many others, just getting back to work was the real profit of the day. Traders took subways instead of limousines, trudged on foot from the Staten Island Ferry, and began lining up at 7:30 outside the exchange to have their bags searched and ID tags checked. Jeffrey Atwood, 49, a staff manager for Syscore Solutions International, a technology company that serves finance companies, took his laptop, a large white pail and a mop on the subway to his dust-filled office building at 15 Maiden Lane. "I just want everything to be as normal as possible," he explained.
Business executives, investors, brokers, subway workers and hot-dog vendors all seemed to agree on at least one thing -- after four edgy days when the market stayed shut, business as usual, even if bad, was far better than not opening at all. 
And alongside hardheaded sell orders, there was also a marketwide mood to loosen the normal rules of engagement. Buyers and sellers of government bonds, for example, agreed to give each other more time to complete their trades. Both the New York Stock Exchange and the Philadelphia Stock Exchange made space available today on their floors for their rival, the American Stock Exchange, which lost communications throughout its building, situated behind Trinity Church south of the World Trade Center.
Across the river, in Jersey City, a shadow Wall Street filled with refugees from Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers began work shortly after dawn.
It was not the kind of day that matched anyone's memories.
"We've had dramatic markets in the past, but never anything that was so related to history before. So many of us have friends who are missing, there is that tremendous feeling of loss," said Jay Mahoney, a trader known as a specialist who is responsible for making an orderly market in several stocks. As he spoke, brokers, traders and clerks swarmed around him, squinting at electronic stock quote screens that all carried the words "God Bless America."
Before the opening bell at 9:30, everyone on the floor, a few traders with telephone headphones already nestled on their ears, bowed their heads for a two-minute silence to honor those who died in Tuesday's terrorist attack.
Mr. Mahoney noted that the sentiment that enveloped the floor before it opened as a United States marine sang "God Bless America," cleared as soon as the bell rang. As expected, stock prices began to sink. "When the market opens, it's instinct," Mr. Mahoney said. "People know what to do."
Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, led the opening ceremony surrounded by, among other local and national leaders, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill. The honor of ringing the opening bell went to a firefighter, police officers and an emergency services worker. 
"Today, America goes back to business," Mr. Grasso told waiting traders. "We do it as a signal to those criminals who inflicted this heinous crime on America and all Americans, they have lost."
Later, less than an hour before the market closed at 4 p.m., a weary Mr. Grasso said that the sell-off could have been worse. 
"Given the lack of trading over the past days, the enormous tragedy foisted on the community, and the president saying we are going to war, there is good liquidity in the market," he said."The message we are sending to the world is that you don't measure the market by one single day's performance." 
Businesses from far beyond Wall Street were relieved to see the markets reopen, said Jay Alix, president of Jay Alix & Associates in Southfield, Mich., which advises struggling companies or those already in bankruptcy. "The global economic heartbeat still happens in the financial district of New York," Mr. Alix said. "It gives people hope to see the capital markets functioning again."
Around noon, tourists and New Yorkers streamed toward Wall Street. On Williams Street, crowds paused to watch rescue workers. Others froze at the intersection of Williams and Liberty Streets to stare through dust at the listing skeleton of the World Trade Center. Some wept. A few crossed themselves.
Others whipped out cameras to take pictures, and a few narrated home videos.
Frank Murphy, 58, an employee of LaBranche & Company, a specialist firm, said, "You can see this on television, this scene, but when you come here and see that's what's left of these two towers, it's almost too much to bear." He said the resumption of trading "has nothing to do with profitability," adding, "it has to do with continuing." 
A few on the floor said they felt pumped up by the praise wafting their way. Bankers and stock market traders are not always cast as heros, so yesterday's mingling of star-spangled patriotism and profits came as a boost to many. "I came here with lots of adrenaline," Mr. Mahoney explained. "The mood is kind of set up by all the news programs. They focus on us more than they ever have -- at no other time has the whole world waited to see how we do." 
Some patriotic gestures had more muscle in the market than others. New York State Controller H. Carl McCall announced at midday that the pension fund for state employees had invested a fresh $250 million in the shares that make up the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. That index had fallen almost 5 percent by the time the market closed, but Mr. McCall was not deterred. 
The pension fund has doubled in eight years on the strength of the market, Mr. McCall said. "I know that American business will continue to be a strong and profitable investment for many years to come." Indeed, he said, the pension fund plans to invest an additional $750 million in stocks by the end of the week.
Among the money managers looking for bargains in yesterday's market was Martin J. Whitman, who at 77 has seen markets in turmoil. Mr. Whitman, who manages about $4 billion for public and private clients, was candid about his plans.
"Our investment management team will try to take advantage of securities market panics, if any, when the equity and debt markets reopen," he wrote.
Before the market opened, Mr. Whitman had huddled with his research analysts to produce a potential shopping list of 31 companies, most of them based in the United States, that could be bought if their prices fell to bargain levels.
More than two hours after the opening bell rang at the Big Board, the New York Mercantile Exchange, where oil and other commodities are traded, kicked to life. Situated on the edge of the Hudson River -- on the other side of the smoking rubble, relative to the stock exchange -- the Nymex building is the only one within the cordon of the disaster site that is open for business. 
In the bright morning before work began, dozens of brightly jacketed Nymex traders, smiling sadly, hugged each other in front of their building and then looked east. A curtain of smoke wafted in the breeze where the towers had stood. The day was this bright, many said, when they saw a jet plane bank at the Statue of Liberty and head for the World Trade Center. It was this clear, they continued, when they saw people falling out of the skyscrapers.
"I'm sick inside," said Joey Cardinale, who works on the Nymex floor. "I cried when the ferry pulled up. But we have to show them that we're going to go on. As much as I don't want to be here, we have to show those lowlifes who did this."

HEADLINE: World Briefing Middle East: Iraq: Kurds' Fuel Supplies Cut 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Iraq has cut supplies of diesel fuel to the Kurdish-held north of the country, stopping an illicit trade between Kurdish groups and truckers from neighboring Turkey. Iraq sometimes cuts the flow of fuel from government-run refineries near the Kirkuk oil fields at times of increased tension with either the United States or the United Nations. Turkey allows diesel from Iraq through its Habur border crossing, an illegal but lucrative trade that is a technical violation of a United Nations embargo but condoned by Turkey's Western allies who use an airbase in southern Turkey to patrol northern Iraq.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AIRLINES; 
A Spartan New Set of Standards For Airlines and Most Passengers

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN and LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
As airline stocks plunged and the airline industry worked feverishly behind the scenes yesterday to secure a financial rescue package from Washington, executives and industry consultants agreed that no matter what happened next, air travel had changed for at least the near term.
 The economic and psychological shock of last week's attacks, experts say, is likely to result in fewer airlines, fewer amenities for economy travelers, lighter schedules and more hours spent at airports because of tighter security measures or waiting for connecting flights. 
 But a dwindling number of passengers could also lead to dirt-cheap fares, more amenities for business- and first-class travelers, fewer air traffic delays and an elaborate courting of frequent fliers. 
"I don't think we will see any short-term recovery, or perhaps any recovery in ease of use in airline travel," said Peter Walsh, who runs the airline industry practice of Mercer Management Consulting. 
Much of the future shape of the industry will depend on when and how many passengers return to the skies. Wall Street analysts predicted yesterday that bookings might remain depressed for a year or more, but they acknowledged that they were just guessing -- there having been no precedent for last week's events. In any case, airlines are likely to be offering bargains to fill their seats. 
The share prices of airline companies plunged as much as 65 percent yesterday on the first day of trading since last Tuesday's hijackings. Continental Airlines dropped by almost half, down $19.59, to close at $20.05. The US Airways Group fell $5.57, to $6.05. America West plunged 65 percent, the shares closing at $3, down $5.60. Among the biggest carriers, AMR, parent of American Airlines, fell $11.70, to $18. United Airlines' parent, UAL, lost $13.32, to $17.50. 
For travelers, the most immediate change will be longer delays before flights as bags are searched with a new sense of urgency. Airlines are also advising travelers to refrain from packing sharp objects, including toiletry items like tweezers, scissors and nail clippers. And luggage that has been checked for a connecting flight on another carrier will have to be rechecked. 
Marie Magliano, owner of Uniglobe at Best Travel, which has a Manhattan office, said her agency was mailing hourly travel security updates to clients.
Fliers can still use electronic tickets, said Edward Adams, chief executive of Navigant International, one of the largest travel agencies. But to clear security checks, they must have either e-tickets specifically for that day or itineraries generated by a travel agent. If they have neither, they must go to a ticket counter.
Those restrictions are bound to affect online travel companies, which are big issuers of e-tickets. Indeed, Mr. Adams said that with air travelers wary, some might prefer having a ticket agent to talk to rather than booking flights online. 
Even before the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the airlines were having a bad year. The soft economy had reduced business travel, while fuel and labor costs rose.
Yesterday, saying the aviation system was "in jeopardy," US Airways said it was cutting its flights by 23 percent, joining other major carriers, which have announced 20 percent reductions. US Airways also said it would lay off 11,000 workers, or nearly a quarter of its staff. 
Over the weekend, Continental Airlines said it was laying off more than 20 percent of its work force, or 12,000 people. 
Yesterday, Continental announced that it would defer a $70 million payment due on debt securities used to finance aircraft purchases. It said the move did not constitute a default at this point. Delta said it had completed raising $1.25 billion through the sale of similar securities. 
America West said it would reduce its flight schedule by roughly 20 percent and eliminate about 2,000 jobs. Last week, it said it would discontinue food service on all flights.
In another sort of cost-cutting move, Jonathan Ornstein, chief executive of the Mesa Air Group, and Michael Lotz, its president, agreed to reduce their salaries by half. And pilots at AirTran Airways agreed to a temporary pay cut to avoid layoffs.
President Bush met with top economic advisers yesterday to discuss financial aid for the industry, his press secretary, Ari Fleischer, said. White House officials plan to talk with airline executives today about legislation that might be proposed to Congress later in the week. 
The Bush administration made one move yesterday to ease the industry's troubles, lifting a ban on airlines' carrying mail and cargo in the bellies of their passenger jets. The restriction, announced only last week, threatened to cost the industry $14 billion a year, experts said. 
Lawmakers from both parties met with airline lobbyists to try to determine the best form of help. An airline executive who refused to be identified predicted that the industry would need $24 billion in direct grants to sustain it over the next few months. Another said $2.5 billion in grants and $12.5 billion in loan guarantees would be enough for a start. 
No matter what happens, many analysts seemed convinced that the industry must consolidate around fewer airlines -- something they said had been necessary even before last Tuesday's attacks because profit margins were so thin. 
By winnowing their schedules, airlines will presumably reduce the number of flights each day between specific destinations. Frequent service had been seen as necessary to win the loyalty of business travelers, who were able to catch an earlier or a later flight home. With fewer flights each day, the airlines would find it less expensive to fly larger planes, which cost less to operate per seat. That, in turn, would reduce air traffic congestion. 
The added security measures, experts said, might prevent Southwest Airlines from maintaining its standard of turning around its planes at the gate in as little as 20 minutes. But Southwest said it operated 98 percent of its flights yesterday and nearly all were on time. At some airports, there were few travelers. Yesterday morning, just eight people waited at La Guardia Airport in New York for the US Airways shuttle to Boston. 
An airline executive said that carriers might be forced to adopt the kind of no-frills approach that Southwest had made successful, adding, "This is all about cash." 
Mr. Walsh, the consultant, said that it would require more than increased security to overcome the fear generated by the terrorist attacks and that the big airlines must woo back their best customers in personal ways. "Very few business passengers personalize their fear," he said. "This has come home to roost in a way that has never happened before. The days of 'Dear frequent flier, it is safe to fly' are over. It is going to have to be: 'Please contact Sophie. She will take care of your specific needs.' "
Mr. Walsh also said airlines might have to convince celebrities like John F. Welch Jr., the retired G.E. chairman, and Michael Jordan to fly on their planes to give others some comfort.

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Asia: Thailand: Steady Growth 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 The Thai economy was healthier than expected in the second quarter, government figures showed, but exports fell sharply and analysts warned that last week's terror attacks in the United States spelled further gloom ahead. Thailand's gross domestic product grew 1.9 percent from the year-earlier quarter, about even with the 1.8 percent year-over-year growth in the first quarter. The figure was higher than the 1.5 percent that analysts had expected.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
PIERSON, JOHN H.G.

 PIERSON-John H.G., 95, September 15 at home in Lenox, MA. He leaves his beloved wife, the former Harriet-Anne Duell. Born in New York City, son of Charles Wheeler and Elizabeth Groesbeck Pierson.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AFGHAN-AMERICANS; 
Group Struggling to Shed Association With Terrorism

BYLINE:  By EVELYN NIEVES and PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: FREMONT, Calif., Sept. 15 

 BODY:
Aziz Omar and his family began fleeing Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, when the Soviets invaded in 1979, eventually settling in this modest suburb about 45 miles southeast of San Francisco. They found themselves among other middle-class, politically moderate refugees who were re-establishing themselves in what has become the largest Afghan enclave in the United States.
 Fremont is home to about 10,000 of the Bay Area's 30,000 Afghan immigrants, said Rona Popal, executive director of the Afghan Coalition, a local community group. It boasts a stretch of Afghan mom-and-pop businesses on Fremont Boulevard known as Little Kabul, an Afghan newspaper and a growing number of Afghan social organizations. And while the community has remained largely invisible in the Bay area, Little Kabul notwithstanding, Mr. Omar says that is about to change. 
 Mr. Omar, who runs the De Afghanan Fine Kabob and Tandoori House, and his brother, Wais, a manager at a Silicon Valley electronics company, plan to distribute posters that show an X across the face of Osama bin Laden, who is the prime suspect in Tuesday's attacks. The posters also carry a strongly worded message: "The Afghan Community wants Mr. bin Laden out of their country and will not take the blame for Terrorism." 
The brothers want the world to know that Afghans here resent the Taliban, the fundamentalist Islamic group that controls 90 percent of Afghanistan, as much as they resented the communists before them. 
The reality is more complex. Afghans in Fremont say that the vast majority of their community despises Mr. bin Laden and the Taliban, and resent that their depressed, rundown country has become synonymous with both. There is wide agreement that Mr. bin Laden, who was born in Saudi Arabia, is a foreign invader foisted upon Afghanistan. 
But there are other Afghans, especially outside Fremont, who come from poorer, rural regions of Afghanistan and settle here in the poorer communities of Pittsburg, Concord and Hayward. They support the Taliban despite its harboring of Mr. bin Laden, said David Yaar, a professor of economics at California State University-Hayward. 
Support for the fundamentalist group is largely political, not financial, said Professor Yaar, who counts himself among the supporters and who escorted the Taliban's ambassador-at-large around the Bay area last year. He is the head of the Council of Cooperation of Afghan Immigrants, a political organization, based in Hayward, whose members have been largely pro-Taliban.
The support, Professor Yaar said, is based on the belief that the Taliban has restored order to a country from which five million people fled during the Soviet invasion and the subsequent civil war. 
When the country was in chaos, with no roads, no electricity and no economy, he said, "I and others thought they were a shimmer of hope to get the country pulled together." 
Dr. Yaar has a radio program on a station in Orange, Calif., where pro-Taliban views are expressed. But after the events of the past week many Taliban supporters, including Professor Yaar, are re-examining those views. "If it's proven that bin Laden is behind the events," Professor Yaar said, "I will review my position." 
In Fremont, women who wear traditional Islamic chadors are refusing to step outside and young people are peeling off bumper stickers that say "Allah." The lines for bread at the Maiwand Market, children crowding the streets on bicycles and scooters, and teenagers congregating on street corners were all absent over the weekend. Many stores were closed and those that stayed open made sure they displayed American flags, even if they were photocopies of flags printed in newspapers. 
Deana Haya, 25, a graduate of Wellesley College,was trembling after her mother asked that she remove a Muslim prayer sticker from her car's windshield. Ms. Haya was born in Afghanistan but has lived here since she was seven. She said she has traveled the world by herself but suddenly is afraid at home. "I've never felt as afraid in those cities as I feel right now in my own city in broad daylight." 
There are stories: of three young women who removed their Islamic head scarves; of a car defaced with keys; of a 13-year-old student who was called "camel jockey" and "terrorist" by schoolmates who hurled a rock at her in the schoolyard (and whose mother did not report the incident, fearing more trouble). 
Asia Miskeenyar worked with the group Doctors Without Borders in Kabul before arriving here last December with her four sons, ages 9 to 23. "When I came here I felt like I was alive," she said. "Now, the flashbacks and fear have come back." 
Last Friday night, about 300 people showed up at the Abubakr Sadiq Islamic Center in Hayward, the largest mosque in the area, to pray and to condemn terrorism. "In our culture, we fight our enemies directly, " said Arshad Ershad, 39, an Afghan-American who received a doctorate in comparative religion in Cairo. "We don't kill innocent people." 
The fear of attack is coupled with the fear that the United States will bomb Afghanistan, where more than a million residents are near starvation and many depend on relatives abroad for help. 
Among all their other worries, the anti-Taliban Afghans are mourning the assassination of the opposition leader, Ahmad Shah Masood, who was assassinated by a suicide bomber last week.
Mr. Omar said that he and others were planning a memorial service for Mr. Masood, after other memorials for the victims of the suicide attacks. "There is," he said, "much grief to go around."

HEADLINE: Catholic Leader in Northern Ireland Resigns Party Post 

BYLINE:  By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 17 

 BODY:
John Hume, a leader of the Catholic civil rights movement in Northern Ireland for the last 40 years and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, announced today in Belfast that he was stepping down as head of the province's Social Democratic and Labor Party.
 Mr. Hume, 64, said the timing of his resignation was dictated by his deteriorating health, which has resulted in several extended stays in the hospital. But he noted in his remarks that this week was one in which the fragile Northern Ireland peace process faced yet another deadline and also one in which the world had seen "the terrible effect" of terrorism. 
 "Could I say directly, given the current international atmosphere, could I say directly to Sinn Fein, please do all that you have to do now and all that you can actually do to insure the agreement is fully implemented by taking all necessary actions to insure that all weapons are put completely beyond use." 
Mr. Hume's reference was to the continuing refusal of the Irish Republican Army, which Sinn Fein represents politically, to begin disarming. The I.R.A. inaction has blocked progress on putting the peace agreement fully into effect and has presented the British government with an unwanted deadline of midnight Saturday for suspending the Northern Ireland government and putting the province back under direct rule from London.
Mr. Hume will stay in office until his party's annual conference in November, lessening the impact of the departure from active involvement in the struggle to bring lasting peace to Northern Ireland of the man thought of as the principal architect of the process that has brought the province this far. 
The 1998 agreement that set up the power-sharing Northern Ireland Assembly was a settlement between the pro-British Protestant majority and the pro-Irish Catholic minority to apportion authority among them and end more than three decades of sectarian violence that claimed more than 3,600 lives.
Mr. Hume is an admirer of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his principles of nonviolence and used to counsel people not to retaliate for killings and bombings with a comment he attributed to the American civil rights leader: "an eye for an eye leaves everyone blind."
He was credited with jump-starting the peace talks that led to the accord by easing the way for the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, to gain participation in the negotiations. At a time when I.R.A. terror tactics made Mr. Adams a pariah in Britain, Mr. Hume held secret talks with him that helped persuade the republican movement he headed that it could give up violence and successfully pursue its goal of union with Ireland through politics.
Rumpled, tousle-haired and witty, Mr. Hume was frequently the quiet and articulate spokesman for reason in a debate dominated by combative accusations and finger pointing. Standing outside the Stormont Castle Buildings one evening in 1998 after enduring weeks of exhausting negotiations, he said, "If you took the words 'no' and 'not' out of the English language, they'd have nothing to talk about in there." 
The I.R.A. and counterpart Protestant paramilitary groups have maintained cease-fires for more than four years while the province's Catholic and Protestant politicians have been negotiating the vexing final arrangements for disarmament, the reduction of British troops and military installations in Northern Ireland and the creation of a new police force to replace the predominantly Protestant Royal Ulster Constabulary.
In the parlance of Northern Ireland's politics, Mr. Hume and his party were known as nationalists -- people who sought the merger of North and South through constitutional means rather than through the violent means long espoused by republicans. Protestants are referred to as unionists, because of their desire to keep Ulster as part of the United Kingdom.
So successful has Sinn Fein become, however, that in the British election in June, it amassed more votes than Mr. Hume's party and became the largest nationalist party in Northern Ireland. Though Mr. Hume's likely successor is Seamus Mallon, 65, his deputy and the deputy leader of the Assembly, Mr. Hume's resignation may open the way for the eventual rise of younger members at a time when Sinn Fein is perceived to be the more vigorous representative of Irish nationalism.
Mr. Hume said he planned to keep his seats in the European Parliament and the British Parliament, where he represents the district of Foyle, which comprises the city of Londonderry. He also said he would continue to work to promote the economy of Northern Ireland, where he has had particular success in attracting American investment. 
He became leader of his party in 1979, the same year he entered the European Parliament. In 1983 he gained his seat in the British Parliament, and in 1998 was co-winner of the Nobel Peace Prize, along with David Trimble, leader of the province's largest Protestant party, the Ulster Unionists.
Mr. Hume is the second party leader to step down during the current stall in talks. Sean Neeson resigned his post as head of the cross-community Alliance Party two weeks ago.
In the absence of any move by the I.R.A. to disarm, Northern Ireland Secretary John Reid has until Sunday to either suspend the power-sharing government for a period of formal review or call new Assembly elections. Britain is reluctant to have a new vote because of the likelihood that the increasingly disenchanted Protestants will elect people opposed to power sharing who would bring the government down from within.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Hume in the Stormont Castle Buildings after announcing his resignation as leader of the Social Democratic Labor Party of Northern Ireland. He cited his worsening health as his reason for stepping down. (Agence France-Presse)
