HEADLINE: Arafat Orders a Cease-Fire and Israel Pulls Back 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
The Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat instructed his security forces today to hold their fire even in self-defense, and Israel then said it would refrain from any offensive action, pulling its tanks and troops out of Palestinian-controlled territory. The moves could set the stage for the first truce talks here since midsummer.
 Speaking in Gaza City, Mr. Arafat said that he wanted to volunteer for the antiterror effort and that he had informed the Americans that he was ready to "put all our capabilities at their disposal." 
 In Washington, President Bush called the developments "a glimmer of hope," linking them to the attacks last week on the United States. "I hope in my heart of hearts that out of this evil comes good," he said. As part of his effort to recruit Arab nations to his antiterror campaign, Mr. Bush has been seeking both Palestinian participation in the alliance and progress toward peace here. 
Each side in the conflict harshly questioned the other's commitment to a cease-fire, but, shaken by the violence in New York and Washington, each also seemed eager to demonstrate its own.
Under American and European pressure, Mr. Arafat has issued an escalating series of calls since Friday to halt the fighting. Today's statement was by far his strongest, and by late tonight, Israeli tanks were withdrawing from positions they had taken up in the last week around the West Bank towns of Jenin and Jericho.
In a speech on Sunday, Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, demanded that 48 hours of "absolute quiet" precede any peace talks. Ranaan Gissin, Mr. Sharon's spokesman, said tonight that Mr. Arafat should be judged only by results. "Arafat made a cease-fire with CNN," he said. "That's the easiest thing. CNN will not fire back." 
On the first day of Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, it was a day of relative but not absolute quiet. The Israeli Army reported that a hand grenade was thrown at troops in Hebron, and that firefights erupted there and on the Gaza Strip. No injuries were reported in those incidents.
For weeks now, Shimon Peres, the Israeli foreign minister, has been seeking to meet with Mr. Arafat. He had planned to do so last Sunday night, but Mr. Sharon blocked him, insisting that all violence cease first.
But also on Sunday, Israeli and Palestinian officials disclosed today, Mr. Sharon dispatched his son, Omri Sharon, and Avi Gil, the senior aide to Mr. Peres, to meet with Mr. Arafat. They worked out today's swap of statements and gestures and agreed that a meeting would follow promptly, Mr. Peres said on Israeli television tonight.
While today's developments may enhance the chances of a meeting, they do not guarantee a breakthrough if one takes place. Mr. Arafat and Mr. Peres met in June and July, without much effect on the yearlong conflict here.
Mr. Sharon has said any such meeting should be confined to measures intended to ease economic hardship for Palestinians while increasing Israel's security. But the Palestinians would like to negotiate a broad range of differences. 
Saeb Erekat, the Palestinians' chief negotiator, called on Washington to dispatch an envoy immediately to broker talks between the two sides. Between Israelis and Palestinians, he said in a telephone interview, "the confidence level is below zero." 
Terje Roed-Larsen, the United Nations special envoy to the Middle East, met for hours with Mr. Arafat in recent days, pressing him to make a strong statement against violence. In his statement today, Mr. Arafat reiterated previous assurances -- including recognizing Israel's right to exist within secure boundaries. But he had not previously urged his security forces to use "maximum self-restraint" even if attacked.
Mr. Roed-Larsen said tonight that the attack on the United States, and Mr. Bush's plans for a new coalition, have cracked the negotiating stalemate. "This has changed the whole equation in the Middle East," he said in an interview. "What Arafat is now seeing is that there is a new alliance here, and that he can be a part of it."
The last time a President Bush assembled an international coalition, Mr. Arafat backed the wrong horse, supporting Saddam Hussein of Iraq during the gulf war. Mr. Arafat's readiness to join this new alliance is also not without risk to him. Arab nations have reacted coolly to plans that might entail violence against Muslims. Also, Mr. Arafat could alienate the Palestinian extremist groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad. The Associated Press reported tonight that Muslim clergymen linked to Hamas had issued an edict branding as traitors those who side with America against Muslims.
It has been a week of intense violence, nasty words, and quiet backroom negotiation in the Middle East, as the antagonists in the conflict have tried to find their diplomatic footing after last week's upheaval. 
Mr. Arafat, who condemned the attacks on Washington and New York, has been working overtime to repair the damage done by images broadcast internationally of some Palestinians celebrating the violence. But even as those images set back his cause, he found new influence with the Americans intent on rallying Arab support.
For the Israelis, the results have also been mixed. In his speech on Sunday, Mr. Sharon also volunteered for duty in the coalition. But the United States has signaled Israel to keep a low profile, as it did during the gulf war.
In an interview on Monday with the Arabic language network al-Jazeera, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said he saw no role for Israel in any military response to last week's attack. At the same time, the United States is seeking the participation of Syria, which for years has been on the State Department list of nations which it considers foster terror and which Mr. Sharon said should not be a member of any antiterror coalition.
Mr. Erekat, the chief negotiator for the Palestinians, said, "This is the second time in the last 10 years when American interests were seriously threatened, and the second time in 10 years that Israel, the strategic ally of the United States, the country that gets more aid than any country on earth, is also being kept again on the sidelines. They can't be part of the alliance. Once again it's proving that the Arab countries are more needed in such an alliance."
But Israeli officials said they well understood the American interest in soft-pedaling any Israeli participation. "It's not the most important thing that we should be on the bandstand at the victory parade," said Zalman Shoval, a close adviser to Mr. Sharon. "We are not going to force ourselves upon anyone. And our practical role in helping the effort -- this is going to be there, with or without being official members of the coalition." 
Mr. Shoval said that Israel was "certainly not going to be in any way a hindrance to the efforts of the administration to set up the coalition. Not only that, but we see in this fight led by the United States and its ultimate victory, certainly a top interest of Israel, being victims of terrorism so many times." He said that Mr. Sharon's willingness to permit a meeting testified to his eagerness to help the Americans. 
Such a meeting, he said, would provide a clear test of whether Mr. Arafat had put violence behind him. "The onus will be on him," he said, "and the world will know exactly where he stands."

 BODY:
 Expanding Detention Powers
The Bush administration announced a major expansion of its power to detain immigrants suspected of crimes. The rules, prompted by the terror attacks last week, would allow legal immigrants to be detained indefinitely during a national emergency. The Justice Department said it would continue to hold 75 immigrants arrested in connection with the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. A1

Legal experts, noting that when the nation's security was threatened in the past the courts had effectively ceded vast powers to the government to limit freedoms, said that new measures to fight terrorism might not receive a rigorous court review. B7

Sikhs Put on the Defensive
Sikhs in the United States, alarmed by a wave of violence and harassment, are finding themselves pressed to explain that their turbans and beards do not signify that they are followers of the Taliban and that they are not responsible for the terror attacks. A1

Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld acknowledged that difficulty in identifying bombing targets in Afghanistan was leading the Pentagon toward a broader, more unconventional campaign -- leaving the door open to commando raids. A1

Conditions for Cooperation
The Bush administration experienced its first significant difficulties in building a broad international coalition to support the use of military power against the terrorists behind the attacks. China, in particular, urged other nations to press Washington on setting conditions. A1

No Decision in Afghanistan
The Taliban rulers of Afghanistan postponed a response to the American demand that they hand over Osama bin Laden and top lieutenants. B5

Tens of thousands of Afghans were on the move, fearing that a week of speculation would soon give way to actual events, with American bombs plunging from the skies. B6

The airline industry, warning that it might lay off 100,000 people because of the terror attacks, won assurances of billions of dollars in financial help from Congress and the Bush administration, though details and conditions remained to be set. A1

Attacks' Economic Shock Wave
New York's $25 billion tourism industry is reeling, with the effects being felt especially by hotels, restaurants and theaters. Some experts fear the slump will be prolonged. A1

State economies are beginning to experience adverse effects from the terror attacks as well. Some states, already struggling in a slowing national economy, are considering dipping further into rainy day funds or making deeper cuts in budgets already stripped to the bone. B1

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AIRLINES; 
U.S. WIDENS POLICY ON DETAINING SUSPECTS; TROUBLED AIRLINES GET FEDERAL AID PLEDGE

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
The airline industry, which has already indicated that it will lay off 44,000 people in the wake of last week's terrorist attacks, won assurances of billions of dollars in financial help today from Congress and the Bush administration. But lawmakers said they had not settled on details of the package and suggested that the aid would come with conditions.
 Executives from the major airlines shuttled from the Transportation Department to the White House to Capitol Hill to plead for help in coping with the economic impact of the attacks, saying they expected the layoffs to reach 100,000. And the Boeing Company, whose fortunes are tied to the industry, said tonight that it would lay off 20,000 to 30,000 workers by the end of 2002 because of fewer orders for aircraft. Page B2. 
 Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta said he hoped to have a package of assistance ready early next week. Congressional leaders also vowed to act quickly but said the industry would not get all it wanted. 
Industry executives started the day seeking up to $24 billion to get their companies through the next year. They said they were requesting outright grants -- including an immediate infusion of $5 billion -- plus tax breaks, loans, loan guarantees and protection against some claims stemming from the destruction caused by the hijacked airplanes.
The airlines are suffering a cash squeeze because their operations were suspended for days and because they are overhauling their security systems. 
The airlines told the government that some carriers could be forced into bankruptcy within days and that without help from Washington much of the industry would be financially crippled within months. 
United Airlines is expected to announce on Wednesday that it will lay off 20,000 workers. Continental Airlines and US Airways plan to lay off a total of 23,000 people, and Midway Airlines said last week that it was shutting down for good. Northwest and American Airlines said they would announce layoffs on Thursday. 
After their meeting with airline executives on Capitol Hill, lawmakers said the industry had pared its request, dropping its call for a repeal of the 4.3 cent-a-gallon federal tax on jet fuel and for airlines to be allowed to keep the proceeds from ticket taxes.
"They've given up on that," said Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, the assistant Senate minority leader. "That's now off the table." 
Help for the airlines -- a vital component of the transportation system and the economy -- has emerged as one of the most pressing issues arising from the attacks last Tuesday on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. 
The focus on airlines was one element of a broader debate emerging in Washington over what steps the government should take to keep the attacks from severely damaging the economy. 
Leaders from both parties in Congress plan to discuss the need for a stimulus package with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, on Wednesday.
Robert E. Rubin, who was Treasury secretary in the Clinton administration, and Lawrence B. Lindsey, President Bush's chief economic adviser, were also expected to attend the meeting.
Republicans in the House have been pressing for steps like a cut in the capital gains tax, and Democrats said they were open to a number of actions to bolster consumer and business confidence. 
The White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said Mr. Bush would be open-minded about the need for steps to stimulate the economy because "the president recognizes that this is not an era of normal economics."
In developing an aid package for the airlines, administration officials and members of Congress were grappling with how to separate the financial effect of the terrorist attacks from the economic woes the industry had before last week. 
They were also debating whether the government should be given a greater say over schedules and air fares in return for federal help, and the degree to which the industry should be shielded from liability claims stemming from the crashes of the hijacked jetliners.
Speaking to reporters outside the White House, Leo Mullin, the chairman of Delta Air Lines, said the package could be as much as the $24 billion the industry has requested, but depending on how the economy and air travel rebound in coming months, it could be "perhaps less, and we all hope it will be less."
Several participants in the lawmakers' meeting with the airlines said the federal assistance was likely to be close to the $2.5 billion in direct aid and $12.5 billion in loan guarantees that the House considered but failed to pass last Friday night. Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader, called the $15 billion package "a very good starting point." A senior Congressional aide said the airlines might get as much as the $5 billion in direct aid that they were requesting.
Congressional aides said that in the session with lawmakers Mr. Nickles, the senior Republican in the room, sharply questioned the industry on its figures, warning that the government would not bail it out from problems that existed before last week's terror attacks. 
Aides said Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, the House minority leader, wanted assurances that an aid package would also be used to ensure that laid-off workers receive unemployment compensation.
Participants in the meeting said legislators warned that protecting the airlines from liability claims might be complicated and that the issue might have to be put off while the remainder of the financial aid package was rushed through. Executives from United and American, the airlines whose planes were hijacked, argued strongly that they needed a signal from Congress that liability protection might be forthcoming.
The briefing papers given to lawmakers by the airlines said the industry had $9 billion in cash as of Aug. 31. By November, the industry said, it will have run through all of that money and need $1.1 billion more. By next June 30, the industry said, it would need an additional $15 billion.
Mr. Mullin of Delta said the government and the industry needed to work together to make sure that airlines did not become "a major economic casualty of the war" and, by laying off workers and disrupting commerce, a drag on the overall economy.
For three or four days last week, Mr. Mullin said, the industry had almost no revenue because of the grounding of all flights. With many people choosing not to travel by air, revenue is now running at 40 percent to 50 percent of normal, he said, a level the industry cannot sustain.
Mr. Mineta said the industry as a whole could be losing $200 million to $300 million a day.
"What we have now gotten is the kind of essential data that we need from the aviation industry to put together a package," Mr. Mineta said. "We will then go to the Hill and work with the Republicans and the Democrats and come up with a timetable in trying to get this done as quickly as possible."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DIPLOMACY; 
World Leaders List Conditions On Cooperation

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER and JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
After a week of unconditional support from abroad, the Bush administration confronted its first significant difficulties today in building a broad international coalition to support using military power and other means against a still-faceless terror network rooted in Afghanistan and elsewhere.
 A procession of world leaders was either on the way or on the phone to Washington seeking to convince the White House that only a multilateral approach based on consultation, hard evidence and United Nations support would justify the use of military power in response to the devastating attacks last week. 
 Today, President Jiang Zemin of China telephoned Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Jacques Chirac of France as each prepared for meetings with President Bush. He admonished his Western counterparts to tell Mr. Bush that "any military action against terrorism" should be based on "irrefutable evidence and should aim at clear targets so as to avoid casualties to innocent people," according to official news reports from China. 
Mr. Jiang also telephoned President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, and although the two leaders denounced "terrorism in all its forms," they spoke just of cooperating with each other and the United Nations to "develop a mechanism for fighting terrorism," the reports said.
As the Bush administration sought through White House consultations and overseas missions to strengthen the sinews of an antiterror effort whose scale and objective remain unknown, a number of countries began to calculate the potential cost of their taking part, and to try to exact a price for it from the United States.
For a number of Middle Eastern countries, the price was straightforward. The United States has to become more deeply involved in ending the violence and in reinvigorating the Israeli-Palestinian peace effort. 
But it was clear that a convulsion in Israel, the West Bank or Gaza could threaten Washington's efforts to maintain support in moderate Arab countries, a problem that Mr. Bush's father faced in the 1991 coalition that defeated Iraq in Kuwait. 
"The people that we expect to work with closely in combating terrorism," a spokesman for the State Department, Richard A. Boucher, said, are "interested in the Israel-Palestinian situation," and their attitudes toward America's war on terrorism are "linked in people's minds" to America's commitment to Arab-Israeli peace. 
Foreign Minister Saud al-Faisal of Saudi Arabia, is due to arrive on Wednesday with a large contingent of Saudi intelligence officers and their files on Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network. 
But other potential American allies raised urgent economic and political agendas that officials said Washington was beginning to address. Pakistan, in exchange for whatever bases or rights to fly in its air space that it provides, would like an agreement to end 11 years of sanctions, to restore the flow of American arms and to reduce a punishing debt load. 
Russia, if it is called on, has a clear set of grievances over NATO expansion toward its borders and criticism of its military campaign in Chechnya. Foreign Minister Igor D. Ivanov arrives on Wednesday. Administration officials said they were eager to establish Moscow's price to open the northern corridor to Afghanistan through Tajikistan, a former Soviet republic.
A number of Russian generals have questioned whether Russia could join an American-led antiterror campaign whose operational objectives remain unclear. One high-ranking military officer told a newspaper, Vremya Novestei, that "fighting terrorists is like trying to rid oneself of roaches in a block of flats."
"You do it in one flat," the officer said, "and they go to another."
Nowhere was the sense of alarm over American plans more apparent than in the warning of one of America's staunchest Middle East allies, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. In remarks broadcast on Monday night, he implored the United States not to undertake military action that might kill innocent civilians, divide Christians against Muslims and further inflame attitudes against American policy in the region.
Mr. Mubarak, like Mr. Jiang, urged that "hard evidence" be the basis for any military action and that "countries not be punished" for the actions of "individuals." He called on the United Nations to organize an international convention against terrorism that would develop a common program of action for all countries.
His remarks were echoed by other leaders in the region where Washington has yet to establish a firm diplomatic beachhead in dealing with intractable and volatile conflicts. 
While Egypt and Jordan were both crucial allies in the 1991 coalition against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, diplomats from both countries said they did not expect to be called on to provide bases or other direct military support. Both said they were providing intelligence information on terrorist groups to the Central Intelligence Agency under longstanding agreements.
Beneath the veneer of solidarity and support in Europe, misgivings can be heard about how Mr. Bush plans to proceed. Germany has repeatedly called for a multilateral approach to the problem and warned against America's going it alone. 
Speaking at the White House today, Mr. Chirac pointedly declined to accept Mr. Bush's characterization of the fight against terrorism as a war. "I don't know whether we should use the word 'war,' " the French leader said.
Diplomats noted that Mr. Bush sent a high-level State Department envoy, John R. Bolton, to Moscow on Monday to push forward on American missile defense plans, even though a decision by Mr. Bush to withdraw unilaterally from the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972 would raise questions of a return to a "go it alone" ethos in international affairs.
President Bush's father last week seemed to be the first to declare dead the sort of unilateralism that prevailed in the administration's early months. He told a Boston audience, "Just as Pearl Harbor awakened this country from the notion that we could somehow avoid the call to duty and defend freedom in Europe and Asia in World War II, so, too, should this most recent surprise attack erase the concept in some quarters that America can somehow go it alone in the fight against terrorism or in anything else for that matter." 
No one has suggested, least of all the former president, that his statement represented criticism of his son or the current administration. But it seemed an unmistakable effort by the father to assert that the son was breaking with the recent past.
If policy is changing, nobody seems quite sure where it is heading. Just what Mr. Bush, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Vice President Dick Cheney meant when they indicated that harboring terrorists would be a casus belli in the fight against terrorism remained unclear. 
In Moscow, an influential parliamentarian, Aleksei G. Arbatov, said although the consensus there was "total moral support" for the United States and the struggle against terrorism, there also existed a strong humanitarian concern "not to resort to massive strikes, to nonselective actions which are unjustified from the moral point of view, to avenge the death of thousands of innocent people with the deaths of tens of thousands of other innocent people."
Karl Kaiser, a foreign policy expert in Germany, said the "experience of the first months of the administration caused a great deal of concern in Europe about unilateralism."
"However," Mr. Kaiser said, "something rather extraordinary has happened, and the reaction of the administration thus far, contrary to some fears that existed, was so different, so cautious and stressing the need to act with others." As a result, Mr. Kaiser suggested that at least for now "the image of the cowboy shooting from the hip is gone."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-11

Both Sides Make Moves Toward Peace In Mideast
Yasir Arafat instructed his Palestinian security forces to hold their fire even in self-defense, and Israel forswore all offensive action and pulled its tanks and troops out of Palestinian-controlled territory, possibly setting the stage for the first truce talks since midsummer. Mr. Arafat also said he wanted to volunteer for the American-led anti-terror effort. A1

Denial of I.R.A. Role in Colombia
Sinn Fein, the political ally of the Irish Republican Army, turned aside fresh complaints from the Bush administration about the arrests of I.R.A. terror suspects in Colombia, saying the party "had no case to answer on this issue." A7

Bush to Meet Indonesia Leader
President Megawati Sukarnoputri, who leads the most populous Muslim nation, is to meet President Bush in Washington today. Both leaders share concern over the threat of violence by militant Islamic groups. Mrs. Megawati's visit has been criticized by Muslim extremists. A9

Mass Grave in Belgrade
Serbian investigators have found 269 bodies in the biggest of five mass graves discovered since the downfall of Slobodan Milosevic, the Belgrade District Court said. The graves are believed to contain victims of the Kosovo conflict. A5

Disarming in Macedonia
Ethnic Albanian rebels, reassured by plans for a Western security presence, have told NATO that they will turn in their remaining guns, even though Parliament has yet to strengthen civil rights. Both sides had agreed to a Sept. 28 deadline for amending the Constitution to give ethnic Albanians greater rights. A5

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MULLAHS; 
Adding Demands, Afghan Leaders Show Little Willingness to Give Up bin Laden

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 18 

 BODY:
Hard-line Islamic clerics who control Afghanistan's Taliban government today postponed for at least another 24 hours a final response to the American demand that they hand over Osama bin Laden and top lieutenants in his terrorist organization, Al Qaeda.
 At the same time, they set new conditions for future American support to Taliban rule in Afghanistan that made a peaceful end to the crisis seem increasingly unlikely. Their demands included diplomatic recognition, a cutoff of all support for the Taliban's opponents and a resumption of economic aid. 
 After a second meeting with the Taliban's elusive leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, high-ranking military officers from Pakistan flew home from two days of negotiations in Kandahar and Kabul and told associates in Islamabad that there were conflicting attitudes that made the outcome somewhat uncertain. 
On balance, though, the officers said Taliban hard-liners seemed likely to prevail in their refusal to give up Mr. bin Laden, whatever the risk. According to an account relayed by the officers after their return, they bluntly warned Mullah Omar and other high-ranking clerics about the readiness of the United States to use its military power to settle the matter, if necessary. But the Taliban leaders remained obdurate, even serene.
"You want to please America, and I want only to please God," Mullah Omar, a one-eyed veteran of the Muslim guerrilla struggle against the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan in the 1980's, said as he bade farewell to the Pakistani officers, according to this account.
By stretching out the deliberations, the Taliban leaders appeared to be hoping that events outside Afghanistan would evolve in ways that would frustrate President Bush in his repeatedly stated intention of capturing or killing Mr. bin Laden for the part American investigators believe he played in the attacks on the United States last week. 
The Taliban's hopes seemed to rest mainly with Pakistan, identified by the Bush administration as a vital base for any American military operation. Events today brought new signs that Pakistan's involvement could set off a major domestic crisis.
Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who has promised "full support" to an American military operation, faced a mounting challenge on two fronts. Along Pakistan's borders with Afghanistan, relief officials reported that fears of a military showdown had set off a "mass exodus" from Afghanistan's Taliban-controlled cities.
In another development that threatened the stability of this Muslim nation of 140 million people, a hard-line Islamic cleric in Karachi who condemned the terrorist attacks in the United States as "wrong" for killing innocent people changed tack abruptly and issued a religious decree, or fatwa, calling for a "holy war" against an American military operation from Pakistan and against General Musharraf.
"It is un-Islamic for any Muslim country or any Muslim armed forces to be part of any military expedition launched against the Islamic Emirate of Pakistan," Mufti Nizamuddin Shamzai said. Mr. Shamzai leads a powerful sect that propagates deobandism, a belief that has inspired modern revivals of Islamic fundamentalism.
But the Taliban are a complex movement that joins simple village clerics and lifelong students of the Koran like Mr. Omar with more worldly officials and military men, some of them people who served in the communist government that ruled Afghanistan under Soviet occupation in the 1980's. It is split into hard-line factions and others more inclined to compromise.
Members of Pakistan's delegation said they did not rule out a last-minute change of mind as these groups grappled with the decision before them. At least some Taliban officials, the officers said, seemed aware of the devastating price likely to be paid by Afghanistan, and by the Taliban leaders, if the crisis slides into a military showdown.
At no point in the discussions, it seems, did the Taliban suggest that they were not in a position to hand over Mr. bin Laden if they chose to do so. His whereabouts seems to be no secret to them.
The meetings with the Taliban's religious leaders began on Monday amid the high mud walls and battlements of Kandahar, in southern Afghanistan, then moved overnight to Kabul, 300 miles away by air, where the visiting officers met with the government's senior officials before resuming this afternoon with the meeting Mullah Omar in Kandahar.
In their travels, the visitors saw the Taliban's two faces.
In Kandahar, the Taliban's religious headquarters, Mullah Omar surrounds himself with scores of bushy-bearded clerics like himself, many of them wounded veterans of the Muslim guerrilla struggle against the Russians.
Kabul, fought over by foreign armies for 3,000 years, is a center of political intrigue. Top Taliban officials in Kabul, most of them Muslim clerics with a reputation for having a firmer grasp of realities outside Afghanistan than their counterparts in Kandahar, tend to be more pragmatic. Members of the Pakistan delegation, who went straight from Islamabad airport to report to General Musharraf, told associates in the Pakistan capital they had been told by the Taliban that the final decision on Mr. bin Laden remained with a shura, a council of high Muslim clerics, some from Kandahar and some from Kabul.
That meeting was to start today, but the Taliban announced that it had been set back to Wednesday and possibly later. A Wednesday meeting would leave the clerics one day to meet a 72-hour deadline for a decision that the Pakistan officers carried with them on Monday.
As outlined by the Taliban leaders, the concessions they seek would amount to the rest of the world, and especially the United States, ending all forms of isolation for the Taliban. Even then, the accounts given in Islamabad suggested, the Taliban's offer would not bring Mr. bin Laden to the United States, but to only another Islamic country, not necessarily Pakistan, that was unspecified in the Taliban demands.
Taken together, officials in Islamabad said, the conditions appeared intended less for serious negotiations than to gain time.

 BODY:
Design in Four Centuries
Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street; (212) 832-1155.
 "Traditional Japanese Design: Five Tastes," an exhibition of 140 objects including lacquered items, ceramics, baskets and textiles, will be at the society from Wednesday through Jan. 6. The exhibition will look at antiquities for the origins of design in Japan, and will examine styles that developed in the 16th century. The exhibition includes simply designed bowls, coats and kimonos; tea ceremony bowls and utensils that reflect a natural, austere aesthetic; boldly decorated furniture and swords; elegant lacquered boxes; and clothing. 
 On Oct. 1 at 6:30 p.m., there will be a lecture by Michael Dunn, the curator of the exhibition. Fee, $10; members and those 60 and older, $8; students, $5.
Open Tuesday through Friday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturday and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission is by contribution of $5; students and those 60 and older, $3.

92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; (212) 996-1100.
The art, music and dance schools will hold an open house on Sunday to introduce their education programs. Art and music instructors will be on hand from noon to 2 p.m., and sample dance classes will be offered from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Arts classes are offered for children, teenagers and adults. Gardens and Landscapes
New York Botanical Garden; (718) 817-8747.
The annual landscape design lecture series will take place starting Oct. 1 at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (50th Street). This year's series will feature four landscape designers. Marc Peter Keane will speak about Japanese gardens on Oct. 1; Joe Brown will look at urban gardens on Oct. 15; Mary Riley Smith will talk about designing gardens for urban backyards and terraces as well as country sites on Oct. 22, and Thorbjorn Andersson will discuss gardens in Sweden on Oct. 29. Reservations are required for the series. The fee is $65; members, $59; single lectures, if available, $18; $16.

Highway for a Modern World
New Jersey Historical Society, 52 Park Place (across from Military Park), Newark; (973) 596-8500.
"What Exit? New Jersey and Its Turnpike," an exhibition of photographs, maps, models, souvenirs and even a table and chairs from the Howard Johnson's restaurant chain, which operated eateries at the original 11 rest stops, will be part of an exhibition about the 148-mile toll road. It will be at the society from Wednesday through Aug. 3, 2002.
The turnpike, which has shaped economic and cultural life in New Jersey for 50 years, was one of the first limited-access roads in the United States. It featured straightened curves, flattened hills and a sleek, functional design for its toll plazas and the restaurants and gas stations at the service areas. Open Tuesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. No charge.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE ART; 
Thinking About Gadgets For a More Sober World

BYLINE:  By David Pogue; E-mail: Pogue@nytimes.com

 BODY:
IN the short term, last week's terrorist attacks had the same effect in the personal-technology business as they had in every other walk of life: they changed our priorities.
 Apple canceled its Expo 2001 in Paris next week. Business-as-usual evaporated as Oracle, Compaq, Sun and many others mourned the loss of employees who were aboard the hijacked planes or in the World Trade Center. These days, the few press releases still sent to technology reviewers typically begin: "If this is a painful time for you, please disregard this message and know that our thoughts are with you." 
 Of course, predicting the future of technology is a fool's game under the best of circumstances. But it seems safe to say that the changes in the technology landscape are likely to be long-lasting and profound. 
Suddenly, we live in a more serious world. As we shop for electronics in the coming months -- if we do so at all -- it is likely that we'll look for staples, not frills. We want utility in our gear, not flash. On a personal level, as we reconsider life's priorities, many of us may find less appeal in electronics designed to let us to keep working even when we're at home after hours.
Of course, as the most prominent victim of the last year's economic downturn, the tech industry had already sobered up quite a bit. But last week's events may have been the final chapter in the story of America's era of turbocharged innovation, the giddy, high-flying decade of technology for its own sake. Sony's $1,500 Aibo robot dog may be the last of its breed.
In the more pragmatic product lines that remain, the particulars of last week's events may reshape the technology industry in surprising ways. The role of cellphones is a prominent example. Calls made by the passengers on the hijacked planes provided the only insight we may ever have into what took place in the air. Those calls from the planes also afforded a few seconds to exchange last words with loved ones -- not much solace, but something closer to closure than they would have had otherwise. 
Cellphones played a starring role on the ground, too. In innumerable cases they were the link that allowed those who escaped the attacks to get word to family and colleagues. And while rescue workers have not located survivors under the rubble by tracing their cellphone signals, the possibility gave them hope in the first few days after the blast. 
Last week, we saw the cellphone in a new light, less a yuppie status symbol than a vital piece of personal-security equipment. For the foreseeable future, society will surely set aside some of its traditional resentment of cellphones and the people who use them in public. Don't be surprised if a national cellphone boomlet ensues, complete with a resurgence of low-cost plans designed for emergency use only. 
If you could buy shares in the Internet, its stock would surely be going up, too. In the hours after the plane crashes, it held up -- slowed but steady -- under a torrent of Web and e-mail traffic, serving as a national conduit for news, discussion and emotion. After the buildings were hit but before they collapsed, e-mail also carried the last words of several who worked inside. 
Last week's events established just how beautifully the Internet's underlying design holds up more than three decades after it was conceived. Still, the Internet is not invincible. First of all, most of us still connect to the Net over ordinary phone lines, a system that proved far more vulnerable last week, and the day when we all connect wirelessly is still years away. Second, the Internet remains exposed to software weapons like viruses and the malicious attacks known as denial of service, a wave of which crippled some e-commerce sites early last year. Last week's events should inspire renewed efforts to shore up this communications lifeline. 
As companies at the epicenter of the New York attacks struggled to restore operations, the Internet again proved crucial. Big businesses invariably transmit daily backups of their data files to secure locations in other parts of the country over the Internet. Their computer-system administrators follow such routines more from fear of small fires or sprinkler-system malfunctions than suicidal terrorists, but no matter: thanks to the backups, enterprises at the heart of the country's financial system are back in business.
Their stories may serve as a grim, worst-case reminder of the value of backups, especially the offsite variety, for individuals and smaller companies, too. Web-based companies that offer just such a service may soon see a spike in subscriptions. (Since the dot-com bubble burst, only a few free Web-based 20-megabyte personal backup "disks," like Apple's iDisk, are still operating. Most are fee-based, automatic-backup systems with much higher capacity limits, like @Backup (www.backup.com) and SystemSafe by NetMass (www.systemrestore.com). 
Americans' newfound fear of flying will have an impact on the technology world, too. Suddenly it may not always seem necessary to fly halfway across the country to close a deal or take a meeting. As more business people become infrequent flyers, videoconferencing equipment -- or even Web-based videoconferencing services like WebEx
.com, PlaceWare.com and Centra.com -- may become increasingly attractive substitutes. Such virtual meeting places are also far less expensive than flying, a point that will have growing importance if the tech industry's fortunes continue to shrivel.
Fear is likely to play a part, too, in a nationwide re-evaluation of the privacy debate. Before Sept. 11, the public outcry for privacy had become almost deafening. For many people, eavesdropping technologies like the government's Carnivore software for screening e-mail conjured images of snoopers in Washington reading our mail and tracking our movements online. Privacy advocates have also fought the E-911 program, proposed by the Federal Communications Commission, which would make it possible for emergency personnel to trace cellular 911 calls to within a few feet.
But everything is different now. Already Attorney General John Ashcroft is pressing Congress to adopt several proposals that would give law enforcement officials greater surveillance freedom. Security experts are even proposing that every American carry a secure ID card, complete with embedded computer chip. 
We may still resent the collection of personal information by companies and Web sites. But since last week, many Americans appear more willing, at least in the short term, to accept greater intrusions from government agencies in exchange for greater security. 
Even an E-911 system would not have saved many lives last week -- there were, alas, few survivors to locate, and short-lived cellphone batteries would have precluded such efforts after a few days anyway. But it's easy to see how valuable such a system might be. 
A new age began on Sept. 11, technologically and otherwise. No, the coming months and years probably won't bring us quite the same flood of over-the-top technological innovation. For some time to come, the industry won't have the money or the drive to develop the kinds of crazy devices -- underwater DVD players, combination phone-cameras, Internet-enabled microwaves -- that once spiced up our mail-order catalogs.
But that's all right. Most people figured out which technologies matter long ago. In these days of shifting priorities, what matters is the phone, the computer, the Internet. These are the machines that connect us rather than distract us, serve as tools instead of toys, and in the harrowing days since tragedy struck, have made it possible for the people in this country and others to watch, and grieve, together.

HEADLINE: Two Nations Cut Interest Rates 

 BODY:
Following the lead of the Federal Reserve, the European Central Bank, the central banks of England and Japan and others, the monetary authorities of South Korea and New Zealand lowered their benchmark short-term interest rates yesterday, joining in a worldwide effort to forestall recession and reassure financial markets after the terror attacks in the United States last week.
 The Bank of Korea, which never before reduced interest rates by more than a quarter-point in one move, reduced its overnight call rate by half a percentage point to 4 percent, the lowest in the bank's history. 
 The action came after an emergency meeting of the bank's monetary policy committee.
Chon Chol Hwan, the bank's governor, said the main motive for the reduction was to reduce the shock of last week's events on an economy already slowing drastically because of widening slumps in the two largest markets for Korean products, Japan and the United States.
In Wellington, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand also made a half-point move, reducing its benchmark overnight cash rate target to 5.25 percent, "primarily because of recent tragic events in the United States" and the threat that a global economic slowdown would worsen in their aftermath, according to the bank's governor, Don Brash.
The bank acted between regular policy meetings "as a precaution," Mr. Brash said.

HEADLINE: Japan Learns Yet Again How Tied It Is to Trade 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 19 

 BODY:
Shock waves from the terror attacks in the United States are reverberating in unexpected ways through Japan, Asia's largest economy.
 After seeing the world air transportation system thrown into disruption and confusion after hijackers turned four American jetliners into missiles, Japan is rapidly realizing just how heavily its economy depends on airplanes. 
 For electronics exporters, hopes for a good end to a bad year are foundering on gloomy predictions of a tight-walleted American Christmas. And in the political sphere, the sense of a world in crisis is pumping new life into Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's faltering program for free-market economic restructuring. 
Surrounded by the sea, Japan has for decades had an acute awareness of its dependence on shipborne commerce, especially the lifeline of oil and liquefied gas tankers that bring the country nearly all its energy from abroad. But the country woke up last week to the fact that aircraft, not ships, carried 40 percent of the country's trade last year with the United States -- 11,000 parcels and 360,000 pieces of mail daily, or $76 billion worth of goods a year.
Belying the image of Japan as a self-sufficient trading fortress, the nation now imports 30 percent of its medicines and 60 percent of its food. Much of it travels by air.
When service across the Pacific was suspended for up to five days, consumers saw immediate effects: the wholesale price of Boston tuna doubled, for example, and California strawberries vanished from supermarkets.
Japanese industry, whose early adoption of just-in-time inventory methods gave it a big edge in efficiency in the 1980's, also found itself immediately smarting from the air shutdown. With no semiconductors or car parts crossing the ocean by air, factories on both sides of the Pacific had to halt production lines. 
Japan's two leading carriers, Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways, each derive about one third of their income from trans-Pacific routes. Both companies' stocks fell sharply after the attacks, as did airline stocks around the world. All Nippon said it lost $2.5 million in the five days of disruption. 
Even going on vacation tends to put the Japanese, more than most nationalities, on international flights. For every American who visits Japan, four Japanese visit America, and the flow of traffic to Southeast Asia and other regions can be even more lopsided. Those tourists are turning skittish and staying home, if sharp falls in airline and tour bookings are any guide, and the economic pain will be felt as much in destinations like Hawaii and San Francisco as it will in Japan.
For Japanese exporters, the big question is whether Americans will react to the threat of war and terrorist reprisals by snapping shut their pocketbooks. 
"We still don't know if people will be having a happy Christmas or not," said Yoshiko Furukawa, spokesman for Sony Computer Entertainment, which is shipping PlayStation 2 units to the United States for holiday sales. Matsushita Electric Industrial, which like many consumer electronics companies derives two-thirds of its American sales between Thanksgiving and Christmas, voiced similar concerns. 
Last week, Japanese automakers suffered sporadic production slowdowns, but the real fear is that the American consumer will hunker down for the fall. "We will probably have to revise U.S. plans, but I don't know when or how at the moment," Hiroyuki Yoshino, president of Honda Motor, said at a news conference Tuesday. "There are fewer people visiting our dealers in New York and the Washington, D.C., area."
The timing of these blows to Japan's economy could hardly be worse, coming as the country had already slipped into recession. In a dreary drum roll of statistics, Japanese industrial production in July dropped to 1994 levels. Industrial electricity use was down 4.5 percent in August from August of last year, and steel production was down 5.4 percent.
"If the U.S. recovery is now delayed until the first half of next year, that means that Japan's recovery will also be delayed," Toyoo Gyoten, president of the Institute for International Affairs, a private research group, predicted today. "There is now a broadly shared sense of urgency and crisis about the medium and long-term future of the economy."
In July 2001, Japan's trade surplus was half the size it was in July 2000, and though its surplus with the United States grew in July, it was mainly because Japan's shrinking economy bought 14 percent fewer goods from America than before. Mamoru Yamazaki, an economist at Barclays Capital Securities, predicts that because of the attacks Japanese exports will fall at least 10 percent in the fourth quarter. Private economists foresee a 1 percent contraction in the Japanese economy this year.
Harder on the public psyche has been the plunge of the Nikkei 225 stock index below 10,000 for the first time in 18 years. The bombings "pushed the Japanese stock index into a scary place psychologically," said Paul Sheard, chief Asia economist at Lehman Brothers. The index closed up 2.7 percent today, to 9,939.60.
But though the crisis diverted the Bush administration's attention from Japan's immense mountain of bad loans, Japanese leaders seem finally to be focusing on the issue. 
The official estimate of the amount banks are owed by debtors who cannot pay has risen to $150 billion, and the value of the collateral underlying many of the loans -- stocks and real estate -- has been dwindling. Commercial land in Tokyo now sells for about one-sixth what it was worth at the peak in 1990, and is still falling -- down 6.6 percent in July from a year earlier. 
For years, Japan has tried to prop up the economy with public works projects, to the point that 10 percent of the labor force works in construction. But Mr. Koizumi seems to be resisting pressure to throw more money into infrastructure projects. Similarly, his resolve to avoid bailing out the banks by buying bad loans from them at book value has grown.
In a wide-ranging meeting with foreign reporters, Mr. Koizumi vowed to hold the line on public spending, to move ahead with deregulation and to try to cut the bad- loan overhang significantly during the next three years.
"Just the fact that we are restraining the public budget is reform," he said. "Unless this symptom of addiction to debt is cured, we cannot hope for revitalization of the Japanese economy."
With a sense of crisis already gripping Japan's parliament because of the sudden war footing in the United States, Mr. Koizumi's ministers have sharpened the picture, warning of more unemployment and more hardship before the economy turns around.
Mr. Koizumi hopes to use the new air of urgency to push through privatization and deregulation bills that special interest groups have blocked.
"Some people believe that the terrorist incident will have the effect of delaying structural reform in Japan," Mr. Koizumi said at the news conference. "That will never be the case. There is no change in our basic policy that there cannot be economic growth without reform."

HEADLINE: Primary Voters Reject Seattle Mayor After One Term 

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Sept. 19 

 BODY:
For the first time in 65 years, voters here have thrown out an incumbent mayor in a primary election, ousting the one-term mayor, Paul Schell, on Tuesday after a turbulent four years in which the city's image took a battering and its economy stumbled. 
 Two veteran city leaders will now face each other in the November election. 
 One is City Attorney Mark Sidran, whose family is from Brooklyn and who embraced the political style of New York's Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani even before the terrorist attacks. The other is Greg Nickels, a member of the King County Council. Both are Democrats, though the race is officially nonpartisan. 
The election could foreshadow a new kind of municipal politics nationwide, in which people focus on security and public safety concerns and are less supportive of bold urban visions.
Mr. Schell's collapse was overwhelming. Nearly four of five voters in Tuesday's primary selected someone other than Mr. Schell, who came to office when Seattle was held up as a model for new American cities and who will leave in a year when the city seems to have lost some of its self-confidence.
Mr. Schell, 63, is a former developer and architecture school dean known for his intellect and urban vision. Under his watch, the city decided to build a new City Hall, justice center and library and to invest nearly $500 million in neighborhood and community centers while building two of the costliest sports stadiums in the world. Tax revenues soared, elite architects were chosen to sketch new monuments, and the city was flush with dot-com millionaires.
But the mayor was plagued by a combination of bad luck and bad management decisions, his critics and supporters said.
The 1999 World Trade Organization meeting, which was supposed to show off the city's embrace of the global economy, turned into a melee with tear gas and violence. An annual Mardi Gras festival ended in a riot, with police timidity and the death of a man who tried to save an injured woman. And the city's home-grown corporate giant, Boeing, moved its headquarters to Chicago.
The latest blow, layoffs of up to 30,000 Boeing workers, was announced just as the polls were closing on Tuesday night. 
"Paul Schell will be viewed almost as a Shakespearean tragic figure," said Mr. Sidran, who criticized him during the campaign as a weak leader. "He is a man of great vision and heart whose tragic flaw is the lack of political skills and lack of judgment."
The mayor's race now will turn on traffic congestion and an economy that has been gut-punched by Boeing layoffs and dot-com woes. A larger issue will be whether the city's tradition of process politics, in which all sides are consulted through innumerable hearings, will be replaced by more unilateral mayoral decision-making. 
Mr. Sidran, 50, was born and raised in Seattle, and makes a point of celebrating his Jewish and New York roots. As city attorney for 12 years, he championed a series of so-called civility laws that cracked down on urination on the streets, aggressive panhandling and rowdy behavior at night clubs. For several years, he has been compared to Mr. Giuliani, sometimes scornfully. 
The city's two daily newspapers endorsed Mr. Sidran. He may also have benefited from public safety concerns after the terrorist attacks. 
Mr. Nickels, who finished slightly ahead of Mr. Sidran, has been active in Seattle politics his entire adult life, serving once as aide to Norm Rice, a popular two-term mayor before Mr. Schell.
"We have a choice between someone who listens to all sides and someone who is divisive," Mr. Nickels said.
Where Mr. Sidran has an aggressive political style, Mr. Nickels says he reflects the traditional Seattle of minimal confrontation. 
"Nickels has embraced the Seattle we all know and love," said Jim Compton, a former newsman for NBC who is now a member of the City Council. "The question is whether that Seattle is still there."
With traffic congestion, voters have been frustrated by the slow pace in constructing a light rail system. The project is years behind schedule and faces huge cost overruns, even though not a shovel of dirt has been turned. Mr. Sidran has vowed to scrap the light rail plan, risking the loss of up to $500 million in federal financing. He says he will concentrate on improved bus and monorail service. 
Mr. Nickels has stuck by the light rail plan. "We've got to build this thing and end a 30-year debate," he said. 
In a city that is heavily Democratic, Mr. Nickels has the endorsement of most party leaders. Mr. Sidran calls himself "a Lieberman Democrat," after Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut. 
"I think we're at a real turning point with this election," Mr. Compton said. "The city that was politically correct and affluent is suddenly facing an uncertain future."
Mayor Schell, in conceding the loss today, expressed no bitterness over his rough ride in office.
"We have no regrets," he said. "I wouldn't trade the past four years for anything."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mark Sidran applauding primary returns on Tuesday in Seattle. He will face Greg Nickels in the mayoral election in November. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: In the Gaza Strip, Anger at the U.S. Still Smolders 

BYLINE:  By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: GAZA, Sept. 19 

 BODY:
Two symbols of Palestinians' anger against the United States hovered over Gaza City shortly after noon on Saturday. The city went to the streets, all heads craned up. The two black dots above were American-made Apache helicopters, searching for targets.
 A boy on a bicycle, his eyes more on the sky than the road, struck a cab. Children ran out of school. Five rockets from the helicopters crashed into a military intelligence headquarters of the Palestinian Authority -- one of three official buildings struck that day in the Gaza Strip. 
 A cease-fire has now taken tenuous hold, but the mood remains dark. 
"We are against terrorism," said Abd al-Raof Abu Daka, a captain with the Palestinian police force in the southern town of Rafah, who watched as his headquarters was hit. "We don't like Americans to die. But the Israelis are hitting us with American weapons."
Anger, even hatred, of the United States as the perceived best friend of Israel is strong in the Gaza Strip. 
Few Palestinians in the strip, whose unresolved status fuels conflict in the Middle East, go so far as to say they feel the joy of other Palestinians filmed celebrating after the terror attacks last week in New York and Washington.
But they look at the misery of their lives and cannot help feeling that the United States has a hand in it. The two sides are killing each other, but nearly every day for the last year, young Palestinians have died in intensified clashes with Israeli soldiers and, increasingly, in Israeli assaults on Palestinian areas.
Here in the isolated territory of Gaza, the Israelis have sealed off the border for almost a year. 
That has made Israelis feel safer, but it has made Palestinians feel that they live in a giant prison of poverty and despair, which makes a ripe breeding ground for fanatics and suicide bombers.
Baram al-Faramawy, 17, shrieked away with giggles from Israeli soldiers who were firing back bullets at youths like him throwing stones near Rafah last weekend. Out of breath but full of bravado, he stopped amid shops eroded by bullet holes and said he would happily do worse, and to Americans if he had the chance.
"I am willing to go and explode myself," he said.
Eyad Sarraj, a psychiatrist and human rights activist in Gaza, said most Palestinians, like most people around the world, were horrified at the enormous loss of civilian life in New York and Washington. But he added that United States support of Israel, particularly during the yearlong surge in fighting, had earned America few friends here.
"Many people around the world," he added, "including this place, are expressing a kind of evil spirit of joy: that the Americans, at last, are tasting from the same cup. We are backward and ignorant, but this has been helped by the American policies in the Middle East."
As with most of the military strikes, Israeli officials said the attacks on Saturday had been retribution for Palestinian violence, in this case grenades thrown at the main crossing from Israel into Gaza, at Erez, wounding two Israeli soldiers.
Israel's prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has drawn parallels between the attack on the United States and Israel's long experience with violence. All suicide bombers are terrorists, he says, whether in Jerusalem or Manhattan. He has called Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, "our bin Laden."
There is some debate in Gaza -- home to the radical Islamic groups Hamas and Islamic Holy War -- over whether the attacks in the United States should force a change in tactics.
Ziad Abu-Amr, a prominent Palestinian politician, said most Palestinian leaders had agreed in recent days that suicide bombings inside Israel should be suspended.
"This would be helping Israel," he said of further bombings now. "And unless you are ignorant and stupid, you wouldn't do these things under the circumstances."
One who disagrees is Sheik Abdallah al-Shami, spokesman for Islamic Holy War, a group founded in the 1970's that has carried out so many suicide bombings that he said he could not count them.
"There is a big difference between what is going on inside occupied Palestine and what is going on inside the United States," he said, strongly disavowing any connection between his group and the men who carried out the attacks in the United States. "We don't have the weapons that Israel has."
Here he drew a connection to the United States and the fighter jets it sells to Israel. "They have F-16's," he said of the Israeli military. "We have F-16's that are our bodies, and that's what we use by exploding."
Public opinion polls show that since the so-called second intifada, or uprising, began last September, extremist groups like Islamic Holy War and Hamas have gained more support.
Even before the new fighting, the Gaza Strip, where some 700,000 of the Palestinian residents live as refugees, was exceptionally poor and a hotbed for extremism. But since last September, almost none of the 40,000 Gazans who worked in Israel have been able to cross the border. The United Nations estimates that the unemployment rate has shot up to about 50 percent from 25 percent. The poverty rate, defined as those living on less than $2 a day, has risen.
Hamed al-Batnijy, 74, a farmer, is letting some of his fields lie fallow because trucks cannot take his tomatoes and cucumbers to their usual markets in Israel and Jordan.
Nazir Ghabir, 43, said he had succumbed recently to the despair of not having enough money for his 12 children by pouring about five gallons of gasoline on himself and threatening to light a match. His neighbors stopped him.
Last week, Muhammad al-Madhon, 13, dyed his hair to cover up gray growing in, which his mother insists is from the stress of constantly hearing Israeli warplanes over Gaza.
"Our husbands are sitting at home," said his mother, Mariam, 52, whose husband, for years a construction worker in Israel, has not worked for a year. Like nearly every Palestinian interviewed in Gaza, she said she felt bad for the people who had died in New York. But she added that the attack was, in the end, America's own fault.
"America is the one who caused it, because of what it is doing," she said. "America is a superpower. They are the strongest. They should stand beside us. Why do we get all this pressure? This pressure is generating a volcano."
In Gaza, death has become routine. "This is normal," said Raed al-Balawi, 18, as yet another funeral for a young man shot while throwing stones passed by. Flags waved, and men fired guns in the air and hauled the body through the streets on a green army cot. "Sometimes it's even more crazy," he said.
The dead boy's father, Khalil Hasona, said his son, Ramzy, 17, had been shot while throwing stones on three occasions in the last six months, twice in the same leg and then, on Friday, through the heart.
"The first time he was shot, he promised he wouldn't go anymore," Mr. Hasona said. "But he was shot again, so I knew he was going again. I beat him up."
Still, he was proud of his son -- proud, he explained, that Ramzy was a martyr.
"But," he added, "I hope he is the last martyr."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED; 
Trade Deficit Ebbs Amid Shrinking Demand

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit shrank slightly in July, reflecting a slump in both exports and imports amid slower economic growth at home and abroad, the Commerce Department reported today.
 In a separate report, the Federal Reserve, in its regional survey known as the beige book, said that the economy remained sluggish in August and early September -- before the terrorist attacks. 
 The trade deficit narrowed to $28.8 billion in July, the last month for which official figures are available, from $29.1 billion in June. Weaker foreign demand for a broad range of goods reduced United States exports by $2.2 billion in July from June, the Commerce Department said. It was the largest month-to-month decline since at least January 1992, when the government began keeping the current series of monthly statistics. 
Imports dropped $2.4 billion in July amid shrinking domestic demand, to $112.6 billion, a fourth consecutive month of decline.
Economists said the data made it more likely that the economy would show a contraction in the third quarter. But a downward revision in the trade deficit in June could allow second-quarter figures to remain in positive territory at next week's final revision.
Jay Bryson, global economist at First Union Bank, remarked that "it's all consistent with an economy that's teetering on the brink of a recession, if not headed into one." With the shock from last week's attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, he said, it is "highly probable" that the overall economy this quarter will show a contraction.
The beige book survey, based on anecdotal reports gathered before Sept. 10, the day before the attacks, said that consumer spending was "flat to down" in the survey period. Spending was weak despite back-to-school shopping, and the Fed said there had been little help from the income tax rebates mailed in the last several weeks.
"Reports from Federal Reserve districts generally indicated that overall economic activity remained sluggish in August and early September," the report said, "with several suggesting that activity slowed further."
The downturn in exports, to $83.7 billion in July from $85.9 billion in June, was broad based, with capital goods, industrial material and supplies, and automobiles and parts showing the largest declines.
Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo, said that hopes that the contraction in world trade would stabilize later this year were undermined last week. "As result of the terrorist attacks," he said, "international trade in both directions will shrink," adding that the global economy would worsen.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REGULATORS; 
<HD L>S.E.C. Plans An Extension Of Its Waiver Of Some Rules

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 

 BODY:
Federal officials are preparing to extend an order waiving certain trading regulations to permit companies and executives to help prop up the price of their shares.
 Officials at the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the order, which was to have lapsed on Friday, would be extended at least a week to allow companies more time to take advantage of it. 
 The agency has also begun to seek records from several investment firms to see if terrorists may have tried to profit financially from the attack. Law enforcement officials described the request as the beginning of an inquiry that had so far yielded no direct evidence of such activity. 
The waiver, first issued last Friday, is the first instance of the agency's having invoked its emergency powers. It enables publicly traded companies to buy their own shares in the stock market without the normal restrictions on the volume and timing of those trades.
The officials emphasized that the extension of the waiver was not motivated by any problems that have arisen since the exchanges resumed trading on Monday.
"We have not seen any liquidity problems as of this moment," said Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the S.E.C. "The extension is not based on anything we've seen or because we've seen any problems. A number of issuers want to repurchase their shares and there's no harm in extending the order. It's useful to give the markets a sense of continuity."
Mr. Pitt said that the last three days of trading suggested that the exchanges were able to operate normally despite the extraordinary circumstances.
"The sense we've had is that the markets are responding on the fundamentals and not on emotions," he said. "That's what we hoped to achieve. I have a reasonably good feeling. Yesterday's market was uplifting. And the finish line today wasn't all that terrible. It's not our business to control the markets. I'd obviously be happier with a bull market."
In a separate development, the commission recently requested trading records from several major investment houses to determine whether any of the terrorists may have tried to profit from the attack.
Law enforcement officials said that they did not have direct evidence of short-selling or trading in put options, two common methods of profiting from a decline in a stock's price. But shortly before the attacks, there was unusually heavy trading in put options in several airline and insurance companies, including AMR, the parent of American Airlines; UAL, the parent of United Airlines; and Citigroup, the parent of Travelers insurance as well as Citibank and Salomon Smith Barney. There was also unusually heavy option trading in Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the largest tenant at 2 World Trade Center, which was destroyed.
German officials are conducting a similar review of moves related to three large reinsurance companies.
But American and European officials also emphasized that there could be innocent explanations for the trading patterns, particularly since many investors had already been betting that the world economy would weaken further.
People close to the inquiry said that the S.E.C. had asked Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers for trading records.
Law enforcement officials today emphasized that the inquiry was only in its preliminary stages and that they did not have any direct evidence that terrorists were involved in trading.
"We are vigorously pursuing all credible leads, but, at this time, we have drawn no conclusions," said Stephen M. Cutler, the acting director of enforcement at the commission. "We are working closely with other federal law enforcement authorities, as well as the self-regulatory organizations and our foreign regulatory counterparts, to provide all possible assistance."

HEADLINE: Administration Seeks to Shift Farm Policy From Subsidies 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 

 BODY:
The Bush administration called today for a major shift away from the current farm policy, arguing for more conservation and international trade over an existing approach that it said was too generous to wealthy grain and cotton farmers.
 "A new farm policy must be tailored to reflect the wide difference in farms today," said Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman as she unveiled the new program. 
 After months of debate in Congress over the shape of farm policy in the next decade, the 120-page platform unveiled today was a blow to several farm-state lawmakers who had argued for increased commodity subsidies and an unexpected boost to those from both parties who had argued for greater conservation efforts. Such efforts would include maintaining wetlands. 
The policy statement was a general idea of the direction the administration would like for legislation to take.
While Ms. Veneman stopped short of choosing between rival programs being considered in Congress, the report showed precisely how the current $20 billion annual subsidy program distorted the market, pushed land prices to artificially high levels and jeopardized current as well as future trade agreements.
The administration's policy argues that all farmers would benefit if federal farm aid shifted from its singular focus on commodity subsidies and instead helped underwrite greater access to foreign markets, more conservation programs, expanded research into pest and disease control and better infrastructure.
That will require an overhaul of today's Depression-era policy that largely rewards only farmers of cotton, wheat, corn, soybeans and rice. Eight percent of American farmers receive almost half of the federal subsidies. Those subsidies, according to the report, have helped big farmers to expand their acreage and increase production without losing any benefits because subsidies are not based on need. Indeed, their average household income was $135,000, the report said.
"We want to reorient programs to help not just big wheat or corn farmers but all farmers," said J. B. Penn, the undersecretary of agriculture. 
Administration officials said it was uncertain whether Congress would spend $171 billion for a new 10-year farm bill given the increased military and economic demands on the budget.
In what is shaping up to be a battle in the Republican Party, the administration's critique of the current farm policy undercut much of the House farm bill sponsored by Rep. Larry Combest, Republican of Texas and chairman of the Agriculture Committee.
Under Mr. Combest's measure, current subsidies would be increased and new ones added. But in a statement today, he said the administration's policy goals were consistent with his bill.
A Senate bill being drafted by Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa and Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the senior Democrat and Republican on the Agriculture Committee respectively, is much closer to the administration's plan and places greater emphasis on conservation. 
Other supporters of the administration's policy include moderate Republicans and urban lawmakers who want farm aid spread to their constituencies, as well as conservative Republicans who have always considered these subsidies misguided welfare.
Conservation and environmental groups praised the administration's new policy.
"We're all very pleasantly surprised," said Ken Cook, president of the Environmental Working Group, a nonprofit organization promoting conservation in agriculture. "This could be a watershed in agriculture policy if the administration follows through with specific proposals for the new farm bill."
Agriculture Department officials said they were not advocating an abrupt end to subsidies. They said they recognized a need for a safety net, or cash subsidies, to help farmers and ranchers during "unexpected events beyond their control."
