HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MEDIA; 
Draping Newscasts With the Flag

BYLINE:  By JIM RUTENBERG and BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
On the Fox News Channel Tuesday, the anchor Jon Scott told Wolfgang Ischinger, the German ambassador to the United States, "We look forward to working with your country in wiping out these terrorists."
 Reporting from the New York Stock Exchange on Monday, the CNN financial news anchor Lou Dobbs said, "This country is blessed with a very strong economy and the greatest democracy in the world." 
 On "Late Show With David Letterman" on Tuesday the CBS anchor Dan Rather said, "George Bush is the president, he makes the decisions, and, you know, as just one American, he wants me to line up, just tell me where."
Coverage of crisis or war has always put the American media in an ambiguous position, raising the question: Should it be an unbiased broker of information or unapologetically patriotic in style and substance? 
Empathy with victims is a staple of news coverage, but television has draped its coverage with the flag in the last week. In between presenting straightforward reports -- or even, like Mr. Rather, in interviews away from their news programs -- anchors and correspondents have not hesitated to conduct the postattack coverage primarily through the viewpoint of the United States. Use of the pronouns "our" and "us" have been commonplace.
CNN, Fox News Channel and MSNBC have incorporated screen images of American flags. And red, white and blue ribbons and flag pins have at times adorned the lapels of news anchors, like Brit Hume on the Fox News Channel -- often simulcast on the Fox broadcast network -- and Tim Russert of NBC.
Critics say that such actions undermine the anchors' position as disinterested conveyors of news and can intensify public opinion in a way that could help push America into a war footing.
The news broadcasters are clearly feeling the same pain from the attacks as the viewers are. In addition to the emotions the attacks aroused because of the sheer numbers of presumed dead, they also took place close to the offices of the news organizations in New York and Washington that are now on the front lines of the coverage, and this is influencing the situation, news executives said.
John Moody, a senior vice president at the Fox News Channel, said his network was doing the right thing in showing a waving American flag on its screen.
"I'd sure prefer that to a hammer and sickle, I'll tell you that," Mr. Moody said. "I think that there's some patriotism on camera now, and I think inasmuch as TV news often reflects America's mood at any given moment, that's what it's doing now."
Alex S. Jones, the director of the Joan Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard, said the showing of some emotion now was understandable. 
But, he said, as the government prepares for war, television news is going to have to be vigilant in maintaining a critical and analytic eye and not falling to boosterism, especially when it has to cover foreign governments that might not fall right in line with the United States.
"There may be differences of opinion," Mr. Jones said. "And part of the responsibility of the media will be to not seem to adopt the style and the language and the sort of symbols of one particular group."
Nonetheless, John R. MacArthur, the publisher of Harper's Magazine, who wrote "Second Front: Censorship and Propaganda in the Gulf War" (Hill & Wang, 1992), said the television networks already seemed to be "preparing the nation for war" without asking many tough questions of the administration. 
And, he said, the news networks that are adorning their screens with the flag are sending "signals to the viewers to some extent that the media are acting as an arm of the government, as opposed to an independent, objective purveyor of information, which is what we're supposed to be."
But news executives said their staffs are seasoned and could manage to protect their coverage from their own feelings. 
"We do feel connected to our audience, to the people of this country, to the people of New York and the people of Washington," said Sid Bedingfield, executive vice president of CNN. "But we would never let that compromise our core journalistic mission, which is to report the news without bias."
On "Late Show," Mr. Rather struck a critical note about the government's intelligence efforts.
Still, Mr. Moody of Fox News said he was going to be careful not to let Fox play a role in which it would help drive public opinion toward war. 
"I'm aware that there is a fine line," he said.
Then again, he added, it might not take the media to influence the public to support war. "I don't think the American public needs to be hopped up right now," he said, adding that it already is.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Late-Afternoon Rally Stems Steep Losses; Dow Declines 1.6%

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Stocks plunged most of yesterday, then recovered sharply in the final hour of trading as investors struggled to reconcile a raft of ugly profit reports with the hope that the economy might recover strongly next year.
 At their afternoon nadirs, the Nasdaq composite index and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index hovered just above the lows they reached in the fall of 1998, when Wall Street worried that a financial crisis that had begun in Asia and was spreading to Russia would turn into a worldwide recession. 
 By 2:45 p.m., the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen more than 400 points, or nearly 5 percent, on fears that the terrorist attacks of last week might depress consumer spending and corporate profits for many months. The possibility of further terrorist attacks on the United States, or of a widening conflict, added to the gloom. 
The economy appeared headed for recession even before last week's attacks, with corporate profits skidding and unemployment rising to 4.9 percent in August from 3.9 percent in November. Now, with travel disrupted and some consumers postponing big purchases, like homes and cars, analysts expect the economy to struggle for at least several months.
Contributing to the bearish mood were profit warnings from several big companies, including Eastman Kodak, Viacom and the Ford Motor Company, as well as Boeing's announcement on Tuesday that it would lay off up to 30,000 of its employees. American Airlines and United Airlines said yesterday that they would each lay off 20,000 workers.
The wave of layoffs could further undermine consumer confidence and spending.
Selling by individual investors appeared to account for most of the drop yesterday morning and early afternoon, according to Biryini Associates, which tracks the flow of money in and out of stocks.
Other market strategists suggested that some investors had been forced to sell to pay off loans.
After moving down in tandem, the Nasdaq and the S.& P. 500 began a strong rally about 2:45 p.m. The surge was fueled by both large and small investors, according to Biryini.
By the close of trading, the Dow was off only 144.27 points, or 1.6 percent, at 8,759.13. The Nasdaq, which fell more than 100 points during the day, ended the day down just 27.28 points, or 1.8 percent, at 1,527.80. The S.& P. 500, which was down almost 50 points at its low, closed down 16.64 points, or 1.6 percent, at 1,016.10.
Douglas R. Cliggott, the chief equity strategist at J. P. Morgan, said he thought the sharp sell-off was largely a result of margin calls on individual investors by brokerage firms. 
Some investors take out loans, called margin, from their brokers so they can buy stock. The stock provides the collateral for the loan, so if its value drops, the investor has to put up more money or the brokerage firm will sell his stock and use the proceeds to repay the loan.
Margin calls are most likely to occur in the days after a sharp decline like Monday's.
"The timing suggests that a part of the sell-off midday was margin calls, and a big part of the rebound was institutional buying," Mr. Cliggott said. "The margin calls created some opportunities that some big institutions came in and took advantage of."
Analysts said the rally provided some reason for optimism even though the short-term outlook for the economy was bleak.
"At some point, market valuations get squeezed down enough so that the U. S. stock market is more attractive than alternative places to put your money," said Chris Kaufman, the lead manager of the $1.9 billion BlackRock Large Cap Value mutual fund.
Rick Peterson, 57, of Houston, said he was "keeping some cash around because there may be a chance to start buying into quality."
He mentioned Home Depot, Intel and General Electric as possibilities. "If it had held this morning, I would've eased into some of those. Now I'll wait until Monday and see how the market reacts."
Despite this week's market losses, Richard Linowes, an assistant professor at the Kogod School of Business at American University, said he was "basically very optimistic about how we pull through."
Mr. Linowes added that the New York Stock Exchange, the Nasdaq stock market and the Wall Street firms deserved credit for the smooth resumption of trading despite the severe disruption in Lower Manhattan.
"It's almost miraculous that everything is up and running," he said.
Still, the economy will probably struggle, said Charles L. Hill, the research director at Thomson Financial/First Call. More bad economic news and the risk of more terrorist attacks may weigh on the markets for several months, he said.
Before last week's attacks, Wall Street analysts expected profits to decline 15 percent in the third quarter from the year-earlier period. Now profits will probably fall more than 20 percent in the third quarter, and 15 percent to 20 percent in the fourth quarter, Mr. Hill said. Profits will probably not recover until at least the second quarter of 2002, he said.
"We're going to continue to have a drag on the earnings front that's going to be horrendous for a month or so and going to make it difficult, even ex-political things, to have a sustained rally," he said.
Over all, the United States might be headed for the deepest recession it has faced in a generation, Mr. Hill said.
Even so, he expects that by the second half of next year, the United States will be recovering strongly, thanks to increased federal spending and the Fed's rate cuts.
Some individual investors said they did not plan to buy or sell, at least for the moment.
"Sell? No, absolutely not," said Rick Negri, who is 36 and a salesman at a finance firm. "In fact, I might start buying -- not because I'm looking for bargains but because it's the right and important thing to do."
More investors than usual called to check on their mutual funds, several fund companies said. But most of those who called did not sell their fund shares, and the number of transactions was not unusually high, they said.
"For most part, investors were standing pat," said John Woerth, a spokesman for the Vanguard Group, the huge fund company.
He said the company received about 30 percent more calls than usual on Monday and Tuesday, but only 15 percent more yesterday. 
Bill Garcia, a computer consultant from Wayne, N.J., said: "I don't intend to touch anything for a while. It's kind of sad to look at it on a day-to-day basis, so I try not to."

HEADLINE: Mayoral Candidates Discuss Plans for a Transformed City 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Struggling to adjust to what has become an entirely different agenda for New York's next mayor, the six major mayoral candidates offered a troubled view of New York's future yesterday, as they began discussing ways the city could rebuild, guard against an exodus by business, and ensure the safety of its citizens from future terrorist attacks.
 In a series of interviews with The New York Times, the four major Democrats and two Republicans discussed in some detail their proposals to respond to the crisis that they agreed had completely rewritten the demands and mission of the job they are seeking. 
 Their responses -- the first discussion the candidates have had, publicly and at length, on how they would lead New York City out of this crisis -- signaled the extent to which the attack has shifted the issues that are likely to frame the primary, originally scheduled on the day of the World Trade Center attack and now reset for Tuesday.
Talk about opening up the plaza in front of City Hall, which had been blocked by Rudolph W. Giuliani, the outgoing Republican mayor, as an antiterrorism measure, has been replaced with a strong advocacy for toughened security, from the use of surveillance cameras with digital facial recognition technology to random checkpoints for vehicles on the street and for people carrying luggage. 
What had been mild disagreements about the degree that New York might suffer in a national recession has now been replaced by a consensus that the city is heading into potentially perilous economic times, faced with a loss of jobs, tax revenue and tourism. What had been the predominant subject of discussion before last Tuesday -- how to rebuild the city's school system -- has been replaced with a discussion about how to rebuild Lower Manhattan itself.
The candidates agreed to the interviews at a time when all six have halted campaigning, in response to the crisis that began unfolding when the first of two hijacked jetliners crashed into one of the trade center towers three hours after the polls opened on the morning of Sept. 11. Since then, the candidates have not agreed to any group forums where they might be drawn into discussions or quarrels. But they have agreed to give six back-to-back nine-minute speeches on the subject to be broadcast on WNBC-TV this Sunday.
All the candidates said they would draw on the expertise of business and civic leaders as they worked through a reconstruction plan for New York. Nonetheless, all the candidates said they had been thinking increasingly about the challenges that would face them as mayor as the extent of the destruction became clear -- and each offered ideas about how to deal with it.
Among the Democrats, Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, said New York should replace the office space that was lost by dispersing construction across the city, eliminating the centralization of commerce and communications that Mr. Ferrer warned might invite another devastating attack. Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller and another Democrat, said New York should give tax forgiveness of as much as 10 years to companies whose offices were destroyed, as a way of encouraging companies not to flee New York.
Mark Green, the public advocate, called for the creation of a consortium of state, city, labor and business leaders with the authority to lay out reconstruction plans, along with how to use bonds, business tax breaks and federal subsidies to finance it. Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, said New Yorkers had to adjust to a stringent new era of tightened security. "The priorities in every case are going to be security now: it's a new war," he said. 
Among the Republicans, Michael R. Bloomberg said the city should embark on a huge housing construction project, to make it attractive to corporations that might otherwise be tempted to leave. "You can make the case that we need housing more than we need office space," he said.
His opponent, Herman Badillo, said that he would ask every member of Mayor Giuliani's cabinet to stay on in office to ensure as much continuity as possible in the change of administrations.
To varying degrees, the candidates said that the attack had forced them to reconsider the promises they made to New Yorkers before the primary. In the most obvious example, most of the candidates had proposed using revenue the city derived from the World Trade Center for housing, while Mr. Green said he would use it to help pay for a Second Avenue subway line. 
"Clearly, our first priority is to maintain safety and security, and the second is to rebuild our infrastructure," Mr. Green said. "I don't doubt that local goals I had will have to yield in time to these first two goals, to meet these first two urgent demands." 
Mr. Vallone argued that the influx of federal aid -- "This is a federal responsibility; this was an attack on the United States," he said -- would give the next mayor a chance to rebuild New York. "We have a tremendous opportunity here, to do whatever has to be done with this city," he said. 
Mr. Ferrer said that while the attack had led him to change some priorities, it was not at the expense of his theme to deal with neglected New Yorkers. "This has become an urgent priority," he said. "But while we're addressing these urgent issues, are we going to ignore the other important issues in the city? They are the issues that made me run for mayor in the first damn place."
The candidates all said the trade center should be reconstructed in some form, along with some sort of memorial. Mr. Hevesi said he would support a replacement that was larger in total size, but not height, than the destroyed complex, to demonstrate that New York City "could not be beaten."
Mr. Bloomberg said, "You have to put something up on that site for emotional and patriotic reasons," though he said large-scale public construction should be done instead near the Javits Center.
Mr. Hevesi said the city should move quickly to putting together a plan to discourage businesses from fleeing. "If we are smart and we quickly develop and create a redevelopment program for downtown, and a very serious business-friendly program -- to encourage businesses to stay here and to come here with massive tax breaks and energy breaks and subsidies, we can turn this around," he said.
Mr. Badillo said the city should build on the model of its response to the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, enlisting "businesses of all kinds, bankers, insurance companies, and labor."
Mr. Bloomberg, though, asserted that the attack had dimmed the hopes of the project's being built anytime soon. "I don't want to be the one to say it's not going to happen, but it's clearly going to be harder now than it was before," he said.
The candidates, with varying degrees of enthusiasm, said they expected -- and supported -- increased security measures in the city. Mr. Green, for example, said that he was prepared for random checks of people in public places like Grand Central Terminal.
Mr. Vallone said the most important consideration was that "people have to feel comfortable." Mr. Ferrer, though, said he was worried that there would be too much of an infringement on civil liberties. "We don't do this by tossing our values out the window," he said. "Look -- if we abandon our values, the people behind these attacks will have won." 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 21, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the New York mayoral candidates' views on rebuilding the city omitted a reference in some copies to the project that Michael R. Bloomberg said would be harder to carry out in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack. It is the proposed subway line under Second Avenue.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE BORDERS; 
New Security Clogs U.S. Borders

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. with BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: McALLEN, Tex., Sept. 19 

 BODY:
Traffic congestion at border crossings with Mexico and Canada began to ease a bit today as the United States brought in off-duty Customs agents and National Guard troops to relieve delays caused when security was tightened after terrorists attacked the World Trade Center and the Pentagon last week.
 But shoppers from Mexico and truckers from Canada could still face waits of more than an hour to cross the border, and that was enough to discourage many from trying. The effect on local economies was apparent, especially here in this booming border city in South Texas. 
 Since the attacks, the number of cars crossing into the United States at the McAllen-Hidalgo International Bridge here has dropped by one-third, to about 12,000 a day, as drivers choose not to endure delays from increased searches and other security measures. "A lot of people evidently have decided they don't want to cross and put up with the hassle," said George Ramon, the bridge director. "That seems to be the case up and down the border." 
In some places this would be a big inconvenience, though little else. But in McAllen and some other Texas border towns, it is much more because their economies depend on the business of Mexicans who travel to Texas, often with extended families, to shop.
The slowdown at border crossings has crimped the flow of shoppers not only from Reynosa across the Rio Grande, but from places in the interior like Saltillo and Monterrey, a big northern city that is prosperous in Mexican terms and is by some measures the country's industrial capital. Those customers contribute a big part of the local economy at stores and malls in Texas. This type of trade -- and the anxiety of local economic leaders who worry that it could be diminished for some time -- underlines just how much the Texas border economy is tied to Mexico.
It is hard to overstate what the spending by Mexican shoppers means to Texas retailers. In 1998, for example, almost a quarter of McAllen's retail sales -- or $901 million -- was to Mexicans who took their purchases back home, according to calculations published by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas. In Laredo, Tex., another important crossing, more than a third of retail sales were to visiting Mexican shoppers.
"We support our country, we support the president, and we understand the need to protect borders and search everyone who comes in," said Mike Allen, president of the McAllen Economic Development Corporation, "but if this continues I see a tremendous financial crisis on the border. You have to understand: the Mexican people are our customers."
Many of those customers work in factories, or maquilas, just inside Mexico. Ray Perryman, head of an economic consulting firm in Waco, Tex., calculates that every $1 earned in the maquila plants translates into $1.06 in spending in border towns on the other side of the Rio Grande.
"You shut down those border crossings and a lot of that retail spending is going to go away," he said. If the border points remain clogged, Mr. Perryman said, the region "doesn't have as much slack to absorb things as other areas."
Federal officials have tried to ease the bottlenecks, and city officials said traffic was moving faster today after Customs officials authorized overtime pay for inspectors, allowing more lanes to be opened on the McAllen-Hidalgo bridge. That, in turn, helped shorten the wait.
Along the Canadian border, shippers reported waiting times of one or two hours at most after National Guard troops were brought in on the American side to supplement Customs agents. Immediately after the terrorist attacks, some truckers said they waited as long as 15 hours to cross the Ambassador Bridge from Windsor, Ontario, to Detroit.
Gerald Fedchun, president of the Automotive Parts Manufacturers Association of Canada, whose members supply assembly plants in both countries, said the current delays are "something everybody can handle."
Texas business owners are not so sanguine. Here, retailers are awaiting the weekend's crowds as a barometer of how things will evolve. "The big test is going to be this weekend, that's when we see a lot of them come down," said Al Serrano, district manager for nine Wal-Mart stores in south Texas. The branches with the biggest impact from the border delays, Mr. Serrano said, are in Eagle Pass, Laredo and McAllen. He said he saw signs of business returning today, but the number of customers is still down.
Just 4 of 12 northbound lanes had been open on the bridge here, but Customs officials authorized overtime pay for inspectors so they could open three more lanes for periods of eight hours a day.
Mr. Ramon, the bridge director, said that was likely to reduce delays. But he called paying overtime a "Band-aid solution" to a problem that could be resolved only by the allocation of more federal money to hire inspectors. "Our economies are so interdependent," he said, "and this bridge is the link."
As in other Texas border cities, McAllen's job growth and population have soared -- more than 106,000 within city limits, according to the 2000 census. But unemployment runs roughly twice the national level and incomes are less than half that -- a continuing source of frustration for local leaders trying to attract jobs that pay better-than-typical retail wages. The loss now of significant retail traffic could really hurt, they say, as the region tries to deal with an economy that was softening even before last week. 
Mike Perez, McAllen's city manager, said that the impact from Mexicans' not being able to buy goods and products here would be substantial and that the tightening of borders had made the situation harder.
But a Customs spokesman said that delays were inevitable now, and he added, "We're doing everything we possibly can to move traffic and move commerce."
The border-crossing slowdown disrupted the flow of cargo including shipments of raw materials to the maquila plants in Mexico and shipments back as finished products.
Auto parts makers and other manufacturers face similar problems along the Canadian frontier. Some companies there have switched from road to rail movement in the last 10 days to try to minimize delays. "We expect shippers will consider rail where it is feasible," said Dawneen MacKenzie, director of communications at Livingston International, a big Customs broker based in Toronto.
Shippers and government officials alike say that, for now, security will be as high a priority as efficiency at border posts. "We're on a high state of alert," said Michel Proulx, a spokesman for the Canada Customs and Revenue Agency. "We expect things are going to change, but which direction they're going to go in is too early to predict."
That is something of a turnabout from the state of things earlier this month. Before the attacks on Sept. 11, the highest priority of business people and bureaucrats involved in United States-Canada trade had been to speed up and simplify procedures at the 3,000-mile border, not necessarily to make movement more secure. "We never thought the border was a security problem," said Mr. Fedchun of the auto parts makers association.
Customs officials are now verifying the identity of every person who crosses the border between the United States and Canada, the world's biggest trading partners, and inspecting most of the cargo. Systems put in place over the last few years to speed low-risk travelers through border formalities have been set aside, and the future of proposed Canadian legislation to streamline Customs procedures is uncertain.
There are hundreds of points of contact between the two economies: 147 land border crossings, 187 airports of various sizes with cross-border flights, 76 ports and 15 rail crossings through which people and cargo move, according to Canada Customs' tally.
In the long term, Mr. Fedchun said, border authorities will need "more sophisticated and complicated solutions" than just adding people -- perhaps using huge X-ray machines that can examine an entire truck and its contents at once, or sealing trucks before they leave their points of origin.
But extra security and longer delays at the border are sure to push up costs, and shippers, carriers and brokers are increasingly asking: Who will pay?

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Bond Investors Show Signs of Optimism

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Bond investors are known as the financial market's worriers, but yesterday they became the optimists on the economy. 
 Usually, stock investors are the true believers, upbeat about their companies' future earnings and operations. Bond investors, by contrast, think every cloud on the horizon is a Force 5 gale headed their way. 
 They switched colors yesterday. Investors jettisoned stocks as too risky in a world where terrorism may become commonplace, even though stocks came back at the end of the day. Bond investors, meanwhile, apparently grew more confident that lower interest rates and renewed spending by the United States government would reinvigorate the economy in the not-too-distant future. 
"I'm not saying the market's omniscient," said Stan Jonas, managing director at Fimat USA, a broker dealer in New York. "But people are making plans and convincing themselves that sometime in the next four months, this economic weakness is going to pass, and we're going to be on a healthy road." 
Based on the action in the futures markets, bond investors expect the Federal Reserve policy makers to cut rates one-half point more when they meet on Oct. 2. Looking further out, these investors see short-term rates falling to 2 percent by the end of the year. On Monday, the Fed cut the target rate on overnight loans among banks to 3 percent from 3.5 percent, the eighth time it has reduced rates this year.
Yields on short-term Treasuries have plummeted in recent days and fell to new lows yesterday. Yields fall when investors bid up prices, usually in search of the safety of securities backed by the United States government. The two-year Treasury yielded 2.82 percent, down from 3.5 percent before the terrorist attacks. And the five-year Treasury note yielded 3.8 percent, down from 4.3 percent before the disasters.
The yields on 30-year bonds, meanwhile, have risen to 5.55 percent, from 5.44 percent before the attacks. 
These yields are telling, bond strategists say. Short-term rates reflect economic prospects in the near term, while long-term rates give the longer view. The widening spread between them shows that investors' views are diverging. If investors felt the economy was going to be weak indefinitely, securities with longer maturities would do better than those that mature in the near future. 
Along with the brightening long-term pictures, bond market participants were heartened to see that transactions agreed to in recent days actually settled yesterday for the first time. Fears of problems eased as few glitches were reported. Trading remained light, and most of the transactions came from managers who felt they had to exit positions, traders said.
"People are still concerned about the immediate outlook, so there's a heightened desire to stay safe and liquid and short," said Robert DiClemente, chief United States economist at Citigroup. "People are willing to pay a high price for safety, and that's what is really driving these short-end yields into the ground."
Another reason that the prices of long-term bonds slipped yesterday was a growing awareness that the government's plan to buy back Treasuries is ending. In the days of budget surpluses, attention had turned to a day when there would be little government debt outstanding. Treasury bonds had become a hot commodity among insurance companies and other investors looking to lock in income over long periods. Now, the government will probably issue additional bonds. And people who had been willing to pay more for something scarce are anticipating days of plenty. 
The Japanese were said to be big sellers of long-term Treasuries yesterday. Some traders also speculated that insurance companies, as a group the largest holders of long-term government issues, were selling to raise money needed to cover losses created by the World Trade Center implosion.
Some traders said they were perplexed that consumers had not rushed to refinance their mortgages at new, low rates. Refinancings, which allow people to take cash out against their home equity or to make smaller monthly payments, are considered crucial to keeping the consumer confident and spending. The rates on 30-year mortages have fallen to 6.63 percent.
"Once people sit down and reflect, there's bound to be a surge," Mr. DiClemente said. "That is going to stabilize the economy."
If short-term rates fall to 2 percent, as investors are betting, and the economy does not restart, what then? Such is the problem facing Japanese policy makers. But few see much likelihood of that here. 
"The market seems to be saying they believe three to five months down the road, things won't be as bad," Mr. Jonas said. "Let's hope they're right."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Gross domestic product vs. gross domestic well-being.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.com.

 BODY:
SHORTLY after the planes slammed into the World Trade Center and the Pentagon last week, a reporter called to ask, "What effect will the terrorist attacks have on the economy?"
 "That's the least of it," I replied. How can one even begin to consider the economic costs before the human toll is known? The reporter sheepishly confessed that his assignment was to cover "the least of it." Indeed, he himself was supposed to have been covering a conference in the World Trade Center that fateful morning and was lucky to have overslept and missed it. In the aftermath of the tragedies of Sept. 11, I find myself compelled to address "the least of it" as well. 
 Economists try to answer questions like this by looking at past experiences and relying on theoretical reasoning. Though there is nothing like these monstrous attacks to draw on, experiences with natural disasters might provide clues.
Most research finds that natural disasters like earthquakes and hurricanes have a relatively small impact on the economy. George Horwitch, a Purdue economist, provides a striking example in a recent study of the earthquake that struck Kobe, Japan, in January 1995, the most destructive ever in a modern city. Some 100,000 buildings were destroyed, and 250,000 damaged. More than 300,000 people became homeless, and 6,500 lost their lives.
Yet within 15 months manufacturing output returned to 98 percent of its pre-earthquake trend level. By July 1996, all department stores and 79 percent of small shops had reopened. Investment boomed. Similar stories can be told about Hurricanes Andrew and Hugo and other natural disasters.
Even the severe bombing of German cities in World War II did not deter growth after the bombing stopped. German output grew 148 percent from 1947 to 1955, and well surpassed its prewar level.
Some disasters, however, have caused lasting economic damage. For example, Newark never fully recovered from the riots of the 1960's. The rioting and the looting are believed to have undermined faith in the government and market there; by contrast, the terrorist attacks seem to have strengthened Americans' resolve to work together and trust their system and public servants.
The conventional wisdom is that disasters, natural and otherwise, typically have only a modest effect on economic activity because human capital -- the knowledge and skills embodied in the citizenry -- survives intact. In modern economies, human capital accounts for as much as 70 percent of national income.
Buildings and machines can be rebuilt, debris can be swept up; the key to production is people and human knowledge and skill, and a system that allows resources to be put to maximal use.
The economic costs are also dampened because output, including services, can be produced using different combinations of resources. Financial firms, for example, are cleverly finding new sources of office space, including hotels.
Some economists have predicted that the tragic events in New York and Washington could possibly do some economic good by stimulating investment and unlocking the Social Security lockbox. But there is something profoundly wrong with the way we measure economic well-being if this tragedy leads to the conclusion that some economic good was achieved. Pain and suffering do not enter into national income statistics; destroyed buildings do not subtract from the gross domestic product; and the option of tapping the budget surplus was always available.
If the conventional wisdom is correct, the terrorist attacks -- horrific as they were -- are unlikely to knock economic production far off track a year from now.
The conventional wisdom might not be the end of the story, however. James R. Hines Jr. and Christian Jaramillo of the University of Michigan are studying the effects on economic growth of 728 earthquakes in 97 countries in the postwar period. Their results suggest that although severe natural disasters do not affect short-term growth, they do reduce G.D.P. around 2 percent three years later.
The reason is that after the investment boom subsides, the capital stock is still less than it otherwise would have been. In addition, disorganization and government missteps in reaction to disasters can curb longer-term growth.
Of course, the economy was already teetering on the brink of recession before the attacks. G.D.P. grew at a 0.2 percent annual rate in the second quarter of 2001, down from 5.7 percent a year earlier.
But focusing on whether the economy crosses a line into a recession -- which is just an arbitrary threshold -- misses the point that the reaction to the tragedy could affect the longer-term level of economic activity more than the direct effect of the destruction wrought by the attacks, and ignores the fact that economic well-being depends on much more than the G.D.P.
There is a limit to how much one can extrapolate from past disasters to the current situation. The impact of this tragedy would seem to depend on repercussions from at least three factors that cannot be predicted with any confidence.
The first is consumer behavior. Frankly, economists were already puzzled why consumer spending was so strong in recent months despite the stock market decline. Consumer confidence could plummet, dragging consumer spending down with it. Because consumer spending represents two-thirds of G.D.P., just a 3 percent drop in consumption this quarter would cause growth to contract at an 8 percent annual rate.
Second, the government's response is unknown, and the response to the government's response is also unknown. A war, if it occurs, could raise the price of oil and weaken the economy, as it did during the Persian Gulf war. Even without a war, a large call-up of reserves could disrupt civilian production.
It is also possible that the United States would turn inward and restrict trade and immigration.
Third, failures in leading industries, like finance and transportation, could impair the economy. These industries are critical because they facilitate trade and investment in other sectors. Although the financial markets are functioning and most financial firms are back on their feet, many airlines face the risk of insolvency.
The concrete forecasts of economic recovery or decline proffered by pundits stand in sharp contrast to the cautious and deliberate approach exercised by public officials in determining the casualties and perpetrators of this heinous crime. For now, the economic watchword should be uncertainty. And uncertainty itself is usually not good for the economy.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: GERMAN SECURITY; 
The Frankfurt Airport Steps Up Its Scrutiny

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Sept. 19 

 BODY:
Among the 63,500 employees at Frankfurt's giant airport there are almost as many nationalities as there are among the millions of passengers who pass through the airport each year.
 Nobody can say exactly how many of the employees are not German. But roughly 13,000 people are employed by Fraport A.G., the big company that runs Europe's second-largest airport, after Heathrow Airport in London. 
 Klaus J. Busch, Fraport's senior vice president for communications, estimates that roughly one-third to one-half -- or more than 4,000 people -- are not German. They come from about 40 countries, he said. 
But before anyone is hired for a permanent job, or a plumber is sent in to repair a broken sink, the names are run through computers of the state police in Hesse (Frankfurt is its biggest city) and at Germany's domestic intelligence service. The background of every employee is checked.
Thomas Uber, the spokesman for the Economic and Transport Ministry in Hesse State, which is responsible for the checks, said about 1,200 such checks are done every month. About 10 percent to 20 percent of applicants are turned down, he said.
"Except for minor things, like theft, we have never had a security problem involving an employee," Mr. Uber said. 
Still, air-travel security in Germany, already rated among the best in the world after Israel, is about to be tightened. In the wake of the terrorist attacks in the United States, the German government today approved a $1.4 billion package of measures to tighten security, including at airports.
Kurt Bodewig, the federal minister of transport, said the measures would include wider security checks for prospective airport employees, whose names will now additionally be run through computers at Germany's military intelligence service; at the B.N.D., the German equivalent of the C.I.A., and the files of the former East German intelligence service, the Stasi.
"The extent of the checks and the criteria we apply will be broadened," Mr. Bodewig told a news conference in Berlin called to announce the measures. But security checks, though crucial to safety at Frankfurt, do not exhaust its arsenal for assuring safety for the more than 50 million visitors who pass through the airport each year.
Passengers boarding the roughly 600 flights that leave Frankfurt daily, domestic and international, pass through metal detectors and undergo personal searches. Their luggage, including carry-on bags, is examined. 
This week, security officials began subjecting passengers boarding flights to North America to a second search and to security questioning, Mr. Busch, the Fraport employee, said, to comply with a request from the F.A.A. in the United States.
Security measures prevent Mr. Busch from receiving visitors in his office, so he meets them in a nearby hotel, where he explained that one reason for the widespread use of non-Germans is that immigrants often take manual labor like baggage handling and packing cargo on pallets. At American airports, such jobs are contracted out to specialized companies. Here, they are done by Fraport. 
The roughly 500 companies in addition to Fraport that employ people at the airport, from airlines to travel agencies to duty-free shop operators, must submit the names of any new permanent employees for security checks. Construction and maintenance companies that intend to employ workers temporarily at the airport must do likewise and the employees are then issued temporary clearances, Mr. Uber said.
Mr. Busch said the German drive for greater airport security got its first major push in the late 1970's in reaction to the wave of urban terrorism that swept West Germany. German sensitivity to issues of flight safety was also a product of the cold war, he added, in which West Germany was a front-line state. 
In 1977, for instance, German and Palestinian hijackers, who often enjoyed the backing of East Germany, seized a Lufthansa jet that left Frankfurt for Majorca. After crisscrossing the Mediterranean, the plane landed in Somalia where it was stormed by German antiterrorist troopers. Three hijackers and the pilot were killed.
But tight security introduced after the 1977 hijacking has not spared Frankfurt violence. In 1985, a bomb exploded in one terminal, killing several members of a family from Australia. No one claimed responsibility, and the case remains unsolved. 
In 1988, it was baggage checked through Frankfurt to London and onward to the United States that concealed a tape-recorder bomb that destroyed Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.
In 1993, a jetliner taking off from Frankfurt was hijacked by a German passenger who smuggled a gun through security controls. But the plane landed in Hanover with no loss of life. The hijacker, who was taken into custody unharmed, was found to be mentally unbalanced.

SECTION: Section B; Column 1; National Desk; Pg. 3

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE TRAVEL INDUSTRY; 
America's Fear of Flying Has Devastating Effect On Tourist Businesses

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK and LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
With millions of people around the country putting off vacations, canceling convention plans and halting all but the most essential business trips, the nation's normally busy travel rhythms have abruptly ground down to virtual slow motion.
 The downturn in travel has most severely affected the $100-billion-a-year airline industry, but the innumerable individual decisions by Americans not to fly have had a devastating ripple effect on other businesses, including hotels, resorts and independent taxi drivers, whose livelihoods depend on airport travelers. 
 Many travel agents report that bookings have fallen off by half or more. While New York and Washington, the sites of the terrorist attacks, have had especially precipitous drops in bookings, the effects of the falloff in travel are being felt across the country and beyond. 
In Las Vegas, cancellations are pouring in. The International Vision Expo, a trade show for the optical equipment industry that was to have 18,000 participants this weekend, has been called off; so have more than 240 other conventions, trade shows and meetings scheduled in the city in coming weeks. 
Miriam Morris, a talent manager from Los Angeles, who was to attend a wedding this weekend at the Monte Carlo hotel and casino, will not be in Las Vegas either. "I think everyone has canceled besides the bride and groom," Ms. Morris said. "It was just not the right time to be going to Vegas to celebrate." 
People are also staying away from other convention cities, like Orlando, Fla., and San Francisco. On the streets of New Orleans, it is easy to find parking space, easy to find a restaurant table, easy to walk down streets that are usually humming with tourists.
Beaches, hotels and restaurants in Hawaii are eerily quiet. "It hasn't been this bad since the gulf war, when we just sat here all day," said Tom Cameron, a beach boy in flowered board shorts who had no customers for his surf lessons. Dennis Sambrano, another beach boy, said: "I've never seen the beach this empty except when there's a big storm."
No one knows how long the rate of cancellations and delayed trips will last, though some in the industry are expressing optimism that some normalcy will return as people discover that such trips are not as much of a logistical inconvenience as first feared -- or as they are lured back by the bargains that airlines and hotels will offer to get back business. 
Nicki E. Grossman, president of the Greater Fort Lauderdale Convention and Visitors Bureau, said that hotel cancellations and other lost business had been staggering, but that she hoped they would be short term. 
"We're not seeing any cancellations after Oct. 1, and that may be a good sign," Ms. Grossman said. "This is America. This can't last. We've got hotels willing to come up with package deals to keep business going. In the long term, we're going to pull out of this and be fine. It's not going to be business as usual, but we're hoping it will be business."
There is no one reason people are not traveling. Some express a new fear of flying in general or hijacking in particular; many more say they fear the logistical problems. Others say their own economic situation seems much more precarious, leading them to cancel plans for vacations. 
And many simply say this: They do not feel like taking a trip anymore. 
At Sol Duc, a resort on Washington State's Olympic Peninsula, about as far as it is possible to be in the continental United States from the sites of the attacks last week, two-thirds of the guest rooms are empty. 
"People are calling in and saying they just don't want to come, they don't want to leave their homes, they don't want to leave their families," said Keli O'Hara, a reservations clerk at the hot springs resort. 
At least for the short term, the impact of the drop in travel is swift and widespread, leading to hundreds of millions of dollars of lost revenue and tens of thousands of layoffs. The industry was already being pinched by the effects of a recession; but this, officials says, is like being hit by a sledgehammer. 
"Airlines are the vehicle, for the most part, for delivering guests and business travelers to our doors and if people are not flying, they are not staying in our hotels," said Jonathan Tisch, chairman and chief executive officer of Loew's Hotels and chairman of the Travel Business Roundtable, an organization of executives from 60 of the largest travel companies in the United States.
"If they are not in hotels," he added, "then they are not eating in our restaurants or shopping in retail." 
In Central Florida, where at least one in every five jobs is directly dependent on tourism, many hotels are at less than 25 percent capacity, much less than half the usual rate, said Richard Maladecki, president of the Central Florida Hotel and Lodging Association. 
"This will be the worst month in the history of Central Florida," Mr. Maladecki said. Some hotels look like ghost towns. 
"We are not getting any calls for reservations," he added. "It's quite the opposite. We're the ones calling them. Our hotels are calling those who have reservations, to see if they are still coming." 
Some businesses that operate on tight margins to begin with are especially worried about surviving, and say that no one in Congress seems to be talking about a bailout package for them. Independent taxi drivers who rely on airport pickups seem particularly vulnerable. 
"Basically, the airport is our business," said Patricia Stephens, president of Stita, the Seattle owner-operated cab company that has an exclusive contract to pick up passengers at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, to which the company pays $2 per trip. "We have a lot of cabs that are sitting around a long time." 
Although the short-term damage is severe, the travel industry hopes for at least some relief from the road warriors of American business. While some companies are telling employees to stay put for cost or security reasons, plenty of others emphasized in interviews yesterday that they were continuing to visit and support clients in person. 
"Flying isn't an option for us -- we have to take care of our customers," said Gary Nelson, president of Advanced Financial Solutions, an Oklahoma City developer of check-processing software, sounding the mantra of many service-based company. 
Leisure travel could be more resilient than business travel, said Rolfe Shellenberger, the senior travel consultant for Runzheimer International, a management consulting concern in Rochester, Wis. Once the fear factor fades, Mr. Shellenberger said, leisure travelers, who make up 60 percent to 70 percent of airline passengers, will come back when there are lots of bargain fares to tempt them. 
In Hawaii, where many hotels that normally have 80 percent to 85 percent occupancy rates were at 40 percent or lower.
Some of the canceled trips, of course, represent revenue that is lost forever to airlines, hotels, restaurants and other service companies. Others could be rescheduled.
Anna Costantino, a marketing professional in Houston, said she postponed a business trip to Moscow that was scheduled to begin last weekend. 
"It was more my personal comfort level," Ms. Costantino said yesterday. But, she added, she had tentatively rescheduled the trip for October. 
"Somehow life will be normal again," she said, but second-guessed herself, as if anything would ever feel normal for Americans again, then concluded: "Eventually everybody will get back to business. You just have to do it."

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Software: Adobe Warns On Outlook 

BYLINE:  By Chris Gaither (NYT) (Compiled by Alan Krauss) 

 BODY:
 Shares of Adobe Systems Inc. slid 13.3 percent after the graphic design software maker warned that it would miss its earnings and sales forecasts this quarter. Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., reported third-quarter earnings, excluding special items, of 28 cents a share, matching Wall Street's expectations despite a revenue shortfall. 
But the company lowered its fourth-quarter prediction to 27 or 28 cents a share, from 31 cents, because of rapidly declining sales in Japan and weak demand among American "creative professionals." Bruce Chizen, chief executive of Adobe, said the forecast did not take into account the potential impact of last week's terror attacks, which he said would hurt Adobe's business if they pushed the economy deeper into its malaise. In light of that risk, Mr. Chizen said, "anything I say today would be nothing more than a guess." Adobe's shares fell $4, to $26.10. Chris Gaither (NYT)

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
BERRY, JOSEPH JOHN

 BODY:
 BERRY-Joseph John. Of Saddle River, N.J. Joe was a victim of the World Trade Center tragedy. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Cherished father of Joseph Scott, Todd Patrick and Kimberly Ann. 
Our family and community have lost a person of great integrity, generosity and unbridled love for his fellow man. His children have lost their mentor, best friend and guiding light in all things. His wife has lost her partner, her best friend, her love. Joe was a man that always had a smile on his face and his family was his first priority. We are grateful to have had such a man in our lives and his spirit and philosophies will live through us and guide us always. Joe grew up in Woodhaven, Queens, attended Molloy High School, received his BA in Economics and Math from Queens College and his MBA from St. John's University. He was Chairman and Co-CEO of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, Inc., an investment banking firm headquartered in the World Trade Center. For the last two years, Joe was honored as one of the top fifty Irishmen on Wall Street by Irish America Magazine. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated at 12:30pm on Saturday, September 22 at St. Gabriel's Church, 88 East Saddle River Road, Saddle River, NJ. No flowers please. Donations are requested to the Joseph J. Berry Scholarship Fund, Archbishop Molloy High School, 83-53 Maton Street, Briarwood, NY, 11435, attention Brother Richard. 718-441-2100

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
U.S. Has Failed to Trace Bin Laden's Money Trail
A six-year struggle to uncover Osama bin Laden's financial network failed because American officials did not skillfully use the legal tools they had, did not realize they needed stronger weapons, and faced resistance at home and abroad, officials say.
 Officials say they have not persuaded foreign banks to open their books to investigators and that a law that would have allowed the United States to penalize foreign banks that did not cooperate was blocked. Page A1. 

Business Goes On, With Grief
When Didier Varlet, the chief executive of the global trading firm Carr Futures, ran through disaster drills, they always involved computer back-ups, new phone lines and ways to get his employees up and running. But nothing prepared the firm for the World Trade Center disaster. "We never had a contingency review for when the people are missing," he said. Nearly half of Carr's New York workers, who had been on the 92nd floor of 1 World Trade Center, are missing. Business is continuing, but with obvious strains. C4.

Stimulus Plans Under Consideration
President Bush and the leaders of both parties in Congress began considering plans to bolster the faltering economy. B1.

S.E.C. Requests Trading Records
Federal officials are preparing to extend the order waiving certain trading rules, and the Securities and Exchange Commission has requested trading records from investment houses to determine whether terrorists may have tried to profit from the attack. C6.

Insurers Speed the Claims Process
With emotions high and the reputations of insurers on the line, many companies say they have decided to pay claims swiftly without insisting on the usual documentation. C4.

Automakers Urged to Aid Economy
Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans and Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao visited Detroit to urge the auto industry to do what it can to help stimulate the economy. C4.

Patriotism Surges on TV News
Empathy with victims is a staple of news coverage, but television news has become unmistakably patriotic in the last week. C8.

Economic Effect Far From Certain
The conventional wisdom is that disasters have only a modest effect on the economy because human capital -- the knowledge and skills of the citizenry -- survives. But conventional wisdom might not be the end of the story, and the watchword should be uncertainty. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

Trade Deficit Narrowed in July
The United States trade deficit shrank to $28.8 billion in July from $29.1 billion in June, reflecting a slump in exports and imports amid slower economic growth at home and abroad. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve's regional survey, known as the beige book, said the economy remained sluggish in August and early September. C8.

Microsoft to Open Web ID System
Microsoft will announce today that it plans to open up its online identification system, which stores personal information like account names and passwords, so that it can share information with rival products that are being developed by other companies. C10.

Typhoon Hampers Cargo Shipments
Just as the world's air cargo traffic was beginning to flow again, a deadly typhoon has disrupted production in Taiwan, one of the most important suppliers of computers, semiconductors and other electronics to the United States. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: La Rumorosa Journal; 
To Risk Death in the Desert: An Inalienable Right?

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: LA RUMOROSA, Mexico 

 BODY:
In recent years, more than 650 immigrants have died trying to cross the barren territory that stretches from here into southern California. Crossing it on foot, say Mexican immigration agents who patrol the area, is only slightly easier than scaling Mount Everest, requiring training and special gear.
 Still, the mountainous area between Tecate and Mexicali -- called La Rumorosa for the whispering sounds made when the winds blow through the canyons -- has become a favorite crossing area for illegal immigrants from around the world. Its jagged landscape provides ample cover from law enforcement agents on both sides of the border, but also makes it easy for disoriented travelers to get lost. 
 A few months ago, immigration agents found a group of more than a dozen men and women from the Mexican state of Oaxaca huddled under a few umbrellas. Last month, a 25-year-old woman from Guanajuato, traveling across the border with her two brothers, broke her leg climbing the canyons. She was rescued only after her brothers escaped the desert to seek help.
Nature forged this desert along the United States-Mexico border into a no man's land. Extreme temperatures turn the jagged canyons into summer ovens and winter freezers. The sand on the desert floor is rippled by footsteps and littered with haunting signs of life and death. There are Styrofoam coolers and tattered shoestrings; soda bottles and sandwich bags; driver's licenses and pocket knives. On their worst days, immigration agents find human remains. 
Now, in an effort being watched from Tijuana to Laredo, Mexican officials have decided to try to close this death trap. Starting next month, the government of the state of Baja California intends to station agents along the highway at the edge of the desert that stretches to the east and west of the city of Mexicali. The agents will prohibit trucks and buses from dropping off immigrants in isolated areas, and intercept others immigrants making their way across the sandy dunes.
Alfredo Escobedo, the director of the state civil protection agency and the author of the plan, said that the 45-mile stretch of desert had been declared a "high-risk area," much like the ridges around the Mexican volcano Popocatepetl.
Political analysts say the plan is part of Mexico's efforts to prove its willingness to be more aggressive against the tide of immigrants at a time when President Vicente Fox has pressed for new immigration agreements with the United States, including expanded guest worker programs and the legalization of some three million Mexican workers.
Critics of the plan, including human rights advocates and political opponents, charge that it violates the Mexican Constitution, which prohibits the government from impeding the free movement of its citizens. 
Mr. Escobedo confessed that he was unsure about the legalities of the effort, which is sure to be challenged in court. His job, he said, is to save lives.
"For a long time there have been protests because immigrants are dying and the government was not doing enough," he said. "We have decided we have to try to do something, and there are still protests.
"Maybe it won't work," he said of his plan. "But we have to try something."
Patrols made up of state law enforcement officers, civil protection officials and federal immigration agents will not be empowered to detain immigrants headed across the desert. However, Mr. Escobedo said, the agents will warn immigrants about the risks of crossing the border in an attempt to persuade them to turn back.
New radio towers will be installed across the desert so stranded immigrants can call for help, and officials intend to conduct regular patrols of the area by helicopter. The towers will also help agents monitor the movements of immigrants.
Critics worry that if Baja California is allowed to establish no-go zones, state governments across the 2,000-mile border will follow suit. Any plan that gives Mexican law enforcement and immigration officers more control over the movements of immigrants only puts the immigrants at greater risk of extortion, the critics charge.
Moreover, they say, such plans could shift the focus of Mexico's immigration efforts toward law enforcement, and away from complicated economic initiatives to address the poverty that propels the steady Mexican exodus.
"The government's claims in support of this plan are shallow," said Raul Ramirez Bahena, the state attorney for human rights in Baja California. "The only thing that is going to happen is that migrants will find new areas to cross. They will keep crossing and keep dying everywhere else along the border."
Photographs of some of the desert's most recent victims are kept in a scrapbook at the office of Felipe Flores, an immigration agent in Tecate. 
One photograph shows the bodies of two Dominican men who were found lying almost naked in the desert at the end of August. The two are stretched out on the desert floor as if napping in a hammock. One had propped a hand behind his head.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The desert at La Rumorosa, a fearsome route to the United States, is named for the whispering of the wind as it blows through the canyons. (Arturo Fuentes for The New York Times) Map of Mexico highlighting La Rumorosa: Hundreds of immigrants have died in the desert at La Rumorosa.

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-11

Mideast Cease-Fire Holds In Push to Restart Talks
Israelis and Palestinians largely held their fire. Though both sides reported some violence, neither rushed to abandon the attempt to halt the clashes for 48 hours, the condition that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon had set for allowing a meeting between Shimon Peres, the Israeli foreign minister, and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. That meeting could take place as early as today, officials said. A4

I.R.A. Reopens Contact
The Irish Republican Army offered to renew contact with the international panel charged with supervising the disarming of Northern Ireland's paramilitary groups. But it made no mention of any disarmament move of its own, a step considered essential to keep the peace accord from ending this weekend. A9

Tightening Britain's Borders
Britain said it would tighten border controls to reduce the number of people seeking asylum and to deter terrorists after the attacks in New York and near Washington. New controls would include scanners to be installed on both sides of the English Channel that could detect people hidden in vehicles. A10

Europe Considers Terror Laws
The European Commission proposed drastic changes to law enforcement because of last week's terror attacks on the United States. The proposed measures include a common definition of "terror crimes," as well as arrest and search warrants that could be enforced across the Continent and the streamlining of extradition procedures. A11

New American at the U.N.
John D. Negroponte, the new United States ambassador to the United Nations, presented his credentials to Secretary General Kofi Annan, ending a hiatus of eight months without a senior American representative. Mr. Negroponte, President Ronald Reagan's ambassador to Honduras from 1981 to 1985, was confirmed with unexpected ease after a Senate confirmation hearing held on the day after the terror attacks. The rejected language said court employees have no right to privacy when they send e-mail messages or surf the Web. A15

Ambivalence About War
While much of the country clamors for martial retribution, with polls showing nearly 90 percent supporting a military response, many New Yorkers said in interviews that they remain ambivalent about President Bush's promised war against terrorism. Many expressed fear that any strike would spark another wave of mayhem in New York. A20

Delay for New Stadiums

BUSINESS DAY C1-16

Cash Aid for Airlines
The Bush administration sent a proposal to Congress for a quick $5 billion in cash for the airlines, House aides said. C1

Border Congestion Eases
Traffic congestion at border crossings with Mexico and Canada began to ease a bit as the United States brought in off-duty customs agents and National Guard troops to relieve delays caused when security was tightened last week. C1

A Plea to Automakers
Donald L. Evans, the commerce secretary, and Elaine L. Chao, the secretary of labor, made an unscheduled visit to Detroit to urge the auto industry to help stimulate the economy. C4

A Topsy-Turvy Market
Stocks plunged, then recovered sharply in the final hour of trading. The Dow closed down 144.27 points, or 1.6 percent, at 8.759.13. The Nasdaq fell 27.28 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,527.80. The S.& P. 500 was off 16.64 points, or 1.6 percent, at 1,016.10. C1

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AIRLINES; 
White House to Seek $5 Billion As Part of Airline Rescue Plan

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ with LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 

 BODY:
The White House, working quickly to try to bolster the nation's ailing airlines, is proposing to give airline companies $5 billion in cash immediately and to help protect them from liability in last week's attacks, according to White House advisers and lawmakers.
 The plan, which was sent to Congress tonight, would not grant the airlines the $12.5 billion in loan guarantees they had requested, at least not now, despite the pleas of airline executives who said the money was needed to stay afloat. 
 President Bush will immediately direct $3 billion of the $40 billion he received from Congress last week to pay for airplane and airport security, aides said. The money and liability protections are needed for the "immediate safety and stability of the airlines," an administration official said. 
Just today, American Airlines and United Airlines announced that they would each lay off at least 20,000 workers, bringing the total of industry layoffs to 100,000.
But lawmakers and Capitol Hill aides cautioned tonight that the deal was far from done and that Congress might decide to extend the loan guarantees and ignore the liability provisions for now. Or it may wind up doing both, including offering $5 billion in cash. Some lawmakers want to ensure that laid-off workers also receive help and benefits. The House, which is working feverishly on a bill, is hoping to move legislation as early as Friday.
"Not one chip of that is set in stone," Representative Roy Blunt, the Missouri Republican who is heading the legislative effort in the House, said of the White House proposal.
Under the White House proposal, airlines would be partly shielded from lawsuits related to damages on the ground caused by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Mr. Bush would bar punitive damages. He would also funnel all lawsuits to the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. Compensation costs that exceeded those covered by insurance would be borne by the federal government, the official said.
The government would also extend to the airlines temporary war-risk insurance that would cover domestic flights for 180 days. Such insurance is typically available only on international flights.
Earlier in the day, airline executives told a House committee that their companies needed $5 billion in cash and $12.5 billion in loan guarantees, plus protection from liability for damages and deaths that occurred on the ground, to avert bankruptcy. Airlines executives said they would continue to assume responsibility for passenger deaths.
Painting a bleak forecast for the industry, the executives said at least three companies, including America West, would be forced to declare bankruptcy if a financial relief package was not approved. The announced layoffs today only added to the economic fallout from the terror attack. US Airways, Continental Airlines and the aircraft manufacturer Boeing have also announced big layoffs, and Delta Air Lines is expected to join them.
"This is, without a doubt, the most difficult thing I have had to do in my two decades at American," Donald J. Carty, chairman of AMR, the parent of American Airlines, said in a letter to employees.
Airlines executives testified at a hearing of the House Transportation Committee that with fewer passengers flying on airplanes and the cost of security and insurance rising, their companies could lose $18 billion to $33 billion by next summer.
Legislators of both parties, led by the House Speaker, J. Dennis Hastert, expressed strong support for the industry, and members of the House committee appeared satisfied that the airlines needed the money to keep operating. Still, members peppered the executives with questions about who would pay for airline security, how laid-off employees would be treated and whether the executives were willing to take pay cuts. Some also questioned the need for the loan guarantees.
Committee members, for the most part, did not try to exact commitments for improved service from the airlines. Instead, they emphasized the need to lift consumer confidence by making sure that people feel safe in the air. And they made clear that they wanted the government to closely oversee how any federal money was spent.
"We have to get this done as soon as possible or we will not have an air transportation system," said Representative Don Young, the Alaska Republican who heads the panel and is helping write the legislation.
Wall Street delivered another blow to the airline companies today. Moody's Investors Service, the bond rating agency, said it had downgraded the corporate debt of several airlines, including American; United, a unit of UAL; and Delta, to speculative, or junk bond, status.
Doug Parker, the chairman of America West, said his company would face bankruptcy if Congress did not approve the federal aid package, and executives warned that two other major airlines would face the same situation.
Analysts and industry executives have said that US Airways and Continental are also leading candidates for bankruptcy, without government assistance.
Hoping to begin resuscitating consumer confidence in air travel, Southwest Airlines today became the first major carrier to resume advertising since the attacks last week in Manhattan and Washington. Southwest is running television commercials resonating with patriotic music and featuring the faces of Southwest employees; print advertisements will follow on Thursday.
In their testimony to Congress today, airline executives said their companies needed not just immediate financial aid but also relief from liability concerns. American and United, whose hijacked planes were used in the suicide terror attacks, do not want to be held liable for property damage on the ground or the deaths of people who were not on their airplanes.
The airlines now have two different kinds of war-risk insurance, a policy for the plane itself and a policy covering overall liability. In both cases, the insurers can either cancel the policy or renegotiate terms in as little as a week.
Some major airlines have already received such notice. In particular, insurers have told airline executives that overall liability coverage for passengers could cost an additional $1.25 a person, or an additional $1 billion industrywide. Insurers, too, are considering severely limiting the money paid out for damages on the ground, including ruined buildings.
"Capital markets fear an avalanche of lawsuits," said Thomas W. Horton, chief financial officer of American Airlines.
Leo F. Mullin, chairman of Delta, told the House panel that the industry wanted Congress to expand an existing government insurance program that insures international flights against wartime risks to include domestic flights. The federal government's position is to provide wartime insurance coverage for international flights if appropriate, but not domestic flights, one insurance specialist said.
John F. Kelly, chief executive of Alaska Airlines, told lawmakers that his carrier had received a notice of cancellation from its insurance company and would have to renegotiate its coverage, at presumably a much higher cost.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Airline executives testified yesterday before the House Transportation Committee, including, from left, Frederick Smith, FedEx; Richard Anderson, Northwest Airlines; Leo F. Mullins, Delta Air Lines; John F. Kelly, Alaska Airlines; Douglas Parker, America West; and Thomas W. Horton of American Airlines. (Susana Raab for The New York Times)
