HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SUSPECT; 
Mysterious Life Of a Suspect From France

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: NARBONNE, France, Sept. 20 

 BODY:
It has been almost a week since Zacarias Moussaoui's mother, a Moroccan-born retired employee of France's telephone company, first saw her son's face on the evening news. 
 She had not heard from him for more than a year. In the past there had been other long stretches of silence, when, in his growing Islamic fervor, Mr. Moussaoui wanted nothing to do with a mother who refused to wear the veil or say daily prayers. 
 But as she watched the news at home in this southern French town, she saw things she could hardly believe. Mr. Moussaoui had been caught in America using false papers. He had been trying to learn how to fly and investigators were wondering now whether he might be connected to the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.
Some investigators wonder whether he might be the missing 20th hijacker. Three planes were taken over by five men, and one by just four. Investigators also wonder whether Mr. Moussaoui was part of the plot but prevented from playing his role when he was detained by immigration on Aug. 17.
The idea of it, his mother says, is too horrible to contemplate. Could this be her son, a solid student, with several technical degrees? 
"How could he be involved in such a thing?" she said. "I cannot eat. I cannot sleep. I keep saying to myself, could this be? All my children, they each had their own rooms. They had pocket money. They went on vacations. I could understand if he had grown up unhappy or poor. But they had everything." 
Mr. Moussaoui, 33, has become the focus of intense interest. The French secret service now has a whole team working on him, retracing his life and contacts in France. How much time he spent here in the last decade is unclear. Even before his arrest in the United States, a French antiterrorist task force already had an open police file on Mr. Moussaoui. The police say he had traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan several times, and may also have been to Kosovo and Chechnyna.
Though he moved to London in the early 1990's, he was back in France enough to catch the eye of the police in the mid-90's because he was sounding fanatic, exhorting other French Muslim friends to "come and work for jihad," a French official said. France put Mr. Moussaoui under surveillance, but they never formally charged him.
His mother said she was totally unaware of his travels. She believed he lived in London. But he was vague and evasive when she asked for specifics. 
Last Saturday, the police raided an apartment at 23 Lambert Road in Brixton, a working-class neighborhood in London, the address Mr. Moussaoui gave when he renewed his passport at the French Embassy in London last September. 
But they may have been late by some nine months. A young woman who answered the door to the apartment there said she had been living there for the past nine months. 
Mr. Moussaoui's troubles in the United States began when he was arrested in Minnesota on a passport violation. He had aroused suspicions at the Pan Am International Flight Academy where he wanted to get training on a flight simulator for large jetliners. Local officials were making plans to send him back to France when the World Trade Center and the Pentagon were hit.
Almost immediately local officials made the connection. Investigators said that Mr. Moussaoui had already trained at the Airman Flight School in Norman, Okla., though he left without finishing his course of study.
The e-mails he sent -- obtained as part of a joint project between The New York Times and the PBS program Frontline -- trying to enroll in the Airman School started in October last year and have a friendly, cheery quality, though the English is sometimes choppy. "Finally I am coming to fly hopefully with you," one says. "Hello, Ms. Brenda, sorry it is me again today."
Mr. Moussaoui has refused to cooperate with authorities. 
The F.B.I. is also investigating a former University of Oklahoma student, Hussein al-Attas, who may have driven Mr. Moussaoui to Minnesota this summer. The Associated Press has reported that Mr. al-Attas also may have let Mr. Moussaoui live with him at one point. Mr. al-Attas also has been transferred to New York for questioning. 
Mr. Moussaoui was born in the Atlantic coast town of St.-Jean-de-Luz, the youngest of four children. His mother was 14 when she married a man in Morocco she said she did not love. A year and a half later he wanted to move to France and she agreed reluctantly. But the marriage went bad quickly. By 24, she was divorced and had moved to the other side of the country near the Swiss border town of Mulhouse. There, for a time, she made her living by sewing. Then a friend offered her a job as a cleaning woman for the telephone company. After taking night classes she passed a civil service test and was promoted. 
When Mr. Moussaoui was an adolescent the family moved to Narbonne where his mother bought a villa in the hills outside the city. "I wanted them to be away from the city and the drugs and all the trouble there," she said. "I just asked that they get a profession." 
Mr. Moussaoui's high school records note that he was a "likeable boy, tenacious, a slow worker but full of good will." He eventually earned various technical degrees.
But then, his mother said, a cousin came to visit. In the Moussaoui household, all the children were required to make their beds, vacuum and help with the dishes. But the cousin told Mr. Moussaoui and his older brother that they were not supposed to do such work. "She told them that they were not acting like men," his mother recalled. "She told them that Muslim men should have four wives. She started criticizing me because I did not wear a veil. The boys liked what they heard."
In 1990, she says, Mr. Moussaoui left for London. When Mr. Moussaoui returned home in 1997, he had pictures of himself in a cap and gown. He told his mother he had an economics degree, though she does not know from what institution. Mr. Moussaoui's activities in Britain remain a mystery. The French Embassy in London believes he first arrived in the early 1990's but a search of phone and utility records turned up no trace of him. On his passport renewal application last September, he said simply that he was unemployed.

HEADLINE: The Case for War, and the Case for Restraint; 
An Airline Proposal

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 By committing billions of dollars to sustaining the commercial airline industry (front page, Sept. 19), the United States government is recognizing commuter air travel to be vital to the national economy, as well it should. 
 However, with so much of the infrastructure (airports, air traffic control and so on) already paid for in large part by public money, and with new appreciation for the low profit margins and unstable financial foundations of most carriers, why not consider an obvious alternative: nationalizing the airline industry? 
A national airline system could synthesize and streamline the response to economic and security concerns, and finally acknowledge that the public interest is as linked with air travel as with the Interstate highway network.

WARWICK SABIN
Washington, Sept. 19, 2001

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-12

Israel Postpones Meeting After Woman Is Killed
Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, under intense pressure from the Bush administration, decided to delay but not cancel a planned meeting between the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres after the killing of an Israeli woman shook the fragile cease-fire. A10

Attack on Iraqi Air Defenses
American and British warplanes attacked Iraqi air defense forces in southern Iraq for the second time in three days, the latest intensification of a tit-for-tat skirmishing that has dragged on for nearly three years, Pentagon officials said. A4

Pope to Visit Kazakhstan
Pope John Paul II asserted that he would leave tomorrow for a trip to Kazakhstan, where a poster announced his visit to Astana. Officials are planning unprecedented security measures during his four-day visit. The region is on edge waiting for American retaliation for last week's terror attacks, though ethnic and religious tensions in Kazakhstan itself remain relatively low. A10

Poland Ex-Communists Favored
A sour mood of frustration and anxiety appears likely to propel Poland's ex-Communists to a sweeping victory in national elections tomorrow. After years of exceptional economic growth, both unemployment and the government's deficit have grown this year. A3

Militants Rattle Southeast Asia
After last week's terror attacks in the United States, fears have heightened throughout Southeast Asia that militant Islamic groups there may be cooperating and receiving increased support from militants in the Middle East. A7

Parents Fear for 2 Aid Workers
In Islamabad, the Pakistan capital, the parents of two Americans on trial in Afghanistan for preaching Christianity to Muslims are waiting anxiously for their daughters after being forced to leave Afghanistan. A10

World Briefing A12

NATIONAL A14-16

Airport Agency Patronage Comes Under Scrutiny
The terror attacks on New York and Washington, which involved two hijacked planes that took off from Logan International Airport in Boston, have put Massachusetts officials on the defensive about political hiring at the agency that runs the airport. Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift, who herself was given a top position at the agency, Massport, after she lost a Congressional race in 1996, has created a commission to recommend "structural and cultural changes" there. A14

Use of Profiling May Widen
Legal experts said racial profiling by law enforcement agencies might now be authorized by judges more definitively than ever because of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. A16

Move to Reregulate Energy
The California Public Utilities Commission voted, 3 to 2, to revoke a consumer's right to choose a power provider, tossing out the centerpiece of the state's failed effort to deregulate its electricity industry. The move makes it easier for the state to use revenue from retail power sales to finance a $12.5 billion bond issue. A16

SPORTS C16-20

Somber Air for Football
Network executives and announcers said that when college and pro football return to television this weekend, the presentations would be tailored to reflect the subdued and patriotic mood of the country. Producers are discussing an approach to language that will try to avoid war metaphors and to production that will mute percussive graphics. A1

SCIENCE/HEALTH

Pesticide Labeling Case
The E.P.A. accused Micro Flo, a pesticide manufacturer based in Memphis, of illegally marketing millions of pounds of insecticides containing falsely labeled imported ingredients. The agency is seeking $3.7 million in penalties for violations of federal pesticide laws. A14

NEW YORK/REGION A20-28

Talk of Vote Delay Looms Over Mayoral Candidates
The campaign for mayor commenced again amid concern about whether the Board of Election could effectively administer the vote on Tuesday. Aides said that Governor Pataki asked Democratic mayoral candidates whether he should postpone the election again. A20

Night Life Slowly Returns
Night life in New York City gingerly began regaining its footing as entertainment spots reopened and New Yorkers sometimes trickled and at times even flocked back to allow themselves some fun. On Thursday night, Carolines on Broadway staged its first comedy shows since the attacks, and tonight, the Mets are scheduled to play their first home game at Shea Stadium. A20

WEEKEND E1-26; E27-36

Dark Days for Broadway
This was one of the worst weeks in Broadway history. Five shows are closing this weekend because of the terrorist attacks, and a half-dozen others, all long-running shows with large casts, are wobbling dangerously near the edge. Nearly 100 actors suddenly lost jobs, as did dozens of crew members and backstage workers. Layoffs were being whispered about in other sectors, too. E1

Art Shows Canceled
The third annual International Art and Design Fair, 1900-2001, scheduled to open at the the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan on Sept. 29, was canceled this week. The fates of dozens of other fairs are now in question, too, including the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show and others like it, which have been part of the New York social calendar for decades. E27

OBITUARIES C14-15

Lewis Rudin
The head of one of New York's oldest real estate dynasties and a behind-the-scenes power during the fiscal crises in the 1970's and early 1990's, he was 74. C14

BUSINESS DAY C1-13

Greenspan Urges Prudence
Saying it is "far more important to be right than quick," Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, urged Congress to wait a week or two before deciding whether to bolster the economy through tax cuts and government spending. C1

Pall Over Markets
Gloom fell over America's stock markets as investors grew fearful that the economy was falling into a deeper recession. After seeming to stabilize on Tuesday and Wednesday, stocks plunged. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 382.92 points, or 4.4 percent, and other major market gauges dropped more than 3 percent. Major indexes are now only a few points above the lows they reached during the fall of 1998, when Wall Street last worried that a worldwide recession might have begun. C7

Measure of Distress
The stock market has fallen so far that some members of the Bass family of Texas have been forced to sell a big stake in Disney to raise cash. C1

Financial Community Dispersed
The destruction of the World Trade Center will leave the financial-services industry more scattered than ever and with far fewer employees in Manhattan. The corporate headquarters of displaced financial giants like American Express and Merrill Lynch are unlikely to relocate, but entire units of those companies may never return. C1

Airline Bailout Questioned
Congress is poised to bail out the airlines with cash and federally backed loan guarantees. While even some of the industry's biggest critics agree that a bailout is needed, some question whether enough care is being taken to make sure that taxpayer money is not wasted. C7

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Hardware: Palm Loss Is Narrower Than Expected 

BYLINE:  By Chris Gaither (NYT) (Compiled by Alan Krauss) 

 BODY:
 Palm Inc., the hand-held computer maker, reported a fiscal first-quarter loss of $38.7 million, or 7 cents a share, bettering analysts' per-share forecast by 2 cents. Revenue was $214.3 million, down by half from a year earlier. 
Palm, based in Santa Clara, Calif., predicted flat or slightly improved sales for the current quarter and said it did not expect to turn a profit despite the typically strong holiday season. Separately, Palm began shipping its newest product, the m125, a hand-held with an expansion slot and a $249 price tag, aimed at the midlevel market. Carl Yankowski, above, Palm's chief executive, said the company had postponed its October software developers' conference because of the terror attacks, and had delayed the scheduled preholiday release of an always-connected wireless device amid concerns about slumping consumer confidence. The stock fell 36 cents, or 14 percent, to $2.15. Chris Gaither (NYT)

HEADLINE: National Briefing South: Florida: Addressing Budget Deficit 

BYLINE:  By Gary Fineout (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Gov. Jeb Bush said he would call state lawmakers into a special session this fall to deal with a growing budget deficit. 
Tax revenue has been slowing in recent months and a $673 million budget deficit had been projected even before last week's terrorist attacks. Mr. Bush said the attacks would only weaken the state's $50-billion-a-year tourist industry and worsen the state's financial health. The governor said he wanted lawmakers to not only consider budget cuts but also ways to boost the economy, like using the state-collected aviation fuel tax on incentives to help the airline industry. Gary Fineout (NYT)

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Aid For Trade Center Janitors 

BYLINE:  By Steven Greenhouse (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 New York's largest janitors' union and the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations reached an agreement yesterday to help the 2,000 janitors, elevator operators and security guards who lost jobs because of the World Trade Center attacks. The realty board and the union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, agreed to provide the workers with health insurance and supplemental unemployment insurance equal to 80 percent of their gross pay for six months. Several dozen cleaning contractors also agreed to give preference to those janitors in future hiring.
 Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
SIMON, MICHAEL JOHN

 BODY:
 SIMON-Michael John. Born July 27, 1961 to the late Charles and Peggyann Simon of Rye, NY has tragically passed to his eternal rest on September 11, 2001. His wife, Eileen (nee Isacsen), their children, Brittany Radcliffe, Michael John, Jr., and Tyler Ingram have been robbed of a devoted husband and loving father. Family and friends will grievously mourn this supportive, moral man of great character. Growing up in Rye, NY, Michael graduated in 1979 from Rye County Day School. He then attained a degree from Hobart College in Economics and Religion. He was an outstanding athlete in ice hockey, lacrosse, tennis and golf. Michael also completed a cross-country bicycling trip from Seattle, WA to Geneva, NY. Michael continued his love of athletics through coaching his children's teams in soccer, softball and baseball in Harrington Park. He never missed a game or a school function. Michael also leaves behind a brother, Scott (Margaret) Simon, sisters Christine Coats, Kathleen and Patricia Simon and brother-in-law E. Craig Coats. His in-laws Barbara and James Romaine, Cathleen and Robert Isacsen, as well as Kristen and Christopher Klass, Elise and Spiros Polikateros, Bridget and Robert DiMartini, Kathryn Isacsen, James and Fiona Romaine and Lenore and Mark Goley also survive him. His parents as well as his brother-in-law Scott Romaine have predeceased him. Michael leaves behind twenty-two adoring and devastated nieces, nephews and grieving aunts and uncles, Mary Ellen and Martin White and Madeleine and Bill Becker. 
The whole community of Harrington Park, his Wall Street business associates and clients will surely miss Michael. The premature loss of such a wonderful individual so loved and respected by all that knew him is society's loss. A memorial service will be held at Saint Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Closter, NJ at 1:30PM Saturday September 22nd. In lieu of flowers a special fund in remembrance of Michael has been established for his three children. Please send donations to: College Bound Fund, C/O Scott Simon, 95 Ferris Hill Road, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

HEADLINE: EUROPE; 
Turmoil Hits Large Players And Shakes Second Tier

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 20 

 BODY:
Joining the forlorn procession of United States and European airlines facing grim prospects after the terror attacks in New York and Washington, British Airways, Europe's biggest airline, said today that it would lay off one-eighth of its workers, drop 10 percent of its flights and mothball 20 planes.
 Arguably, though, the real news is in the small print of the stock tables: British Airways' announcement drove its share price down an additional 7 percent, for a total decline of 42 percent since the Sept. 11 terror attacks. It also left its total market value at $2.64 billion -- which is, for the first time, less than that of Ryanair, the upstart low-cost carrier. 
 The development may signify a broad reshaping of European aviation. It threatens to push the struggling second-tier flag carriers, like Sabena, over the edge and leave the big three -- British Airways, Lufthansa and Air France -- to struggle with falling income, excess capacity and high costs, while nimbler entrants like Ryanair gain market share. 
And that, in turn, could mean a reintroduction of large-scale government aid, mirroring the United States government's readiness to prop up its airlines. 
The drumbeat of gloom has been steady this week:
*KLM of the Netherlands said it would not meet profit targets.
*Virgin Atlantic Airways, British Airways' biggest domestic rival, cut 1,200 jobs.
*Lufthansa said Wednesday that it would need an "immense effort" to avert a loss this year and that it would postpone orders for 15 Airbus A380's and 4 Boeing 747-400's.
*Aer Lingus of Ireland said it would cut back operations by one-quarter, retire 7 of its 40 planes, abandon some trans-Atlantic routes and lay off 1,700 people. 
*Alitalia said today that it would cut its work force by about one-sixth.
British Airways had already been downsizing, with 3,000 layoffs in 2000 and 1,800 announced this year before the terror attacks. Today's move adds 5,200 more.
"We face exceptional conditions, which have forced us to take very tough decisions," said Rod Eddington, the chief executive, in a statement. "The tragic events in the U.S.A. will undoubtedly have a significant impact on the demand for air travel in the months ahead." 
But the impact will probably not fall evenly on everyone. Among major European carriers, British Airways is the most exposed to the trans-Atlantic market, said Anthony Bor, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, "and that is the market we expect to decline most."
British Airways' strategy of concentrating on premium-fare business and first-class passengers adds to its vulnerability in an economic downturn, analysts said. 
One rung down from the majors, the global economic slowdown had already cast doubt on the futures of some ailing carriers, notably Sabena of Belgium and Swissair, which is reeling from a failed plan to expand through stakes in smaller carriers like Sabena. The fallout from the attacks will make resuscitating them much harder. Over all, European airlines may lose $2.5 billion to $3 billion this year, according to the Association of European Airlines.
Analysts like Jonathan Wober at Deutsche Bank say the fates of the second-tier carriers may depend on whether the European Union is moved by the pleas of airline executives, who are besieging officials in Brussels this week, and relaxes its stance against aid for the airlines. 
So far the European Commission has not given much ground. It said today that there was no prospect of direct government aid for airlines, though it might consider helping to defray insurance costs or relaxing landing-slot rules at some airports.
British Airways is among those pushing for an aid package akin to the one the Bush administration is considering for American carriers. "We want to compete on a level playing field," Mr. Eddington said.
The idea of state support irks others, like Robert Ayling, a former British Airways chief executive, who said past aid had hampered consolidation. Ryanair's chief executive, Michael O'Leary, also objects, saying, "State aid to selected state airlines that were loss-making before last week's events cannot be justified by the impact of last week's events."
Because Ryanair and the other low-cost European airlines fly only in Europe, not across the Atlantic, they may suffer much less than the flag carriers, and they stand to gain if passengers look to save money. After a brief spate of cancellations at Ryanair, "bookings have returned to normal levels," Mr. O'Leary said. He added, "The immediate consequences of last week's events on Ryanair will not be material."
Still, the terror attacks "impinge directly on people's willingness to fly," said Brian Tora of Gerrard Asset Management, and more may stay home or take the train.

GRAPHIC: Photo: British Airways, Europe's biggest airline, announced yesterday that it would lay off one-eighth of its workers and scrap 10 percent of its flights. (Associated Press)
